This paper proposes an orthogonal semi-nonnegative matrix factorization (OSemiNMF) method, extending NMF to directly handle mixed-sign dFC data. Furthermore, an orthogonality constraint on the bases (i.e., dFC states) is incorporated to enhance the uniqueness of dFC states. For 10 simulated datasets with varying properties, our method outperforms comparison methods, supporting its superior ability to capture dFC states and state transitions. Using four resting-state fMRI datasets consisting of 708 healthy controls (HCs) and 537 schizophrenia patients (SZs), our method identifies reproducible dFC states and state transitions across datasets. Further, our findings reveal that SZs spend less time in high-connectivity states compared to HCs. Our study identifies meaningful and reproducible biomarkers of schizophrenia, mainly involving the connectivity associated with the sub-cortical domain. In summary, the OSemiNMF method facilitates the dFC analysis for understanding brain dynamics.

title: CMIS: A Class-aware Multi-structure Instance Segmentation Model for Fetal Brain Ultrasound Images with Fuzzy Region-based Constraints
authors: Hang Wang, Mingxing Duan, Yuhuan Lu, Bin Pu, Yue Qin, Shuihua Wang, Kenli Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Fetal anatomical structure segmentation in ultrasound images is essential for biometric measurement and disease diagnosis. However, current methods focus on a specific plane or a few structures, whereas obstetricians diagnose by considering multiple structures from different planes. In addition, existing methods struggle with segmenting fuzzy regions, which leads to performance degradation. We propose a real-time segmentation method called Class-aware Multi-structure Instance Segmentation (CMIS), designed to segment 19 key structures in 3 fetal brain planes to support brain-disease diagnosis. We extract instance information and generate class-aware attention for each class instead of dense instances to save computing resources and provide more informative details. Then we implement cross-layer and multi-scale fusion to obtain detailed prototypes. Finally, we fuse global attention with local prototypes cropped by boxes to generate masks and randomly perturb the boxes during training to enhance robustness. Moreover, we propose a new fuzzy region-based constraint loss to address the challenge of structures with varying scales and fuzzy boundaries. Extensive experiments on a fetal brain dataset demonstrate that CMIS outperforms 13 competing baselines, with an mDice of 83.41<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>0.03% at 37 FPS. CMIS also excels in external experiments on a fetal heart ultrasound dataset, achieving a mDice of 85.73<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm$</tex-math></inline-formula>0.02%. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of CMIS in segmenting complex anatomical structures in ultrasound and its potential for real-time clinical applications. CMIS is limited to 2D normal standard planes (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\geq$</tex-math></inline-formula>19 weeks). Thus, its generalization to abnormal cases and broader datasets remains to be investigated.

title: AMFFNet: An Attention-Enhanced Multi-Scale Feature Fusion Network for Built-Up Area Classification in Ku-Band AIRSAT-01 Imagery
authors: Nan Chen, Fan Wu, Chaowei Jiang, Shaoyang Guan, Peichen Yu, Jing Ning, Lichuan Zou, Chao Wang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Accurate spatial distribution and categorical information of built-up areas are crucial for urban planning and cultivated land protection. However, diverse building morphologies and similar backscattering characteristics in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery pose significant challenges for multi-category built-up area classification. To address this, we established the Built-up Area Classification Dataset (BACD) using Ku-band AIRSAT-01 satellite data, which includes three categories: low-rise, high-rise, and metal-roofed structure areas. Based on BACD, we propose an Attention-enhanced Multi-scale Feature Fusion Network (AMFFNet) for classification. The model incorporates a Dual Attention Inverted Residual Block to enhance building feature extraction. In the decoder, an Atrous Spatial Pyramid and Pyramid Pooling Module is combined with attention mechanisms to enhance multi-scale feature extraction and discrimination. Experimental results demonstrate that AMFFNet achieves 73.53% mean Intersection over Union on BACD, significantly outperforming mainstream segmentation models including U-Net, Fast-SCNN, OCRNet, PSPNet, and SegFormer, and exceeding the second-best model by 6.3 percentage points. Generalization experiments on geographically distinct regions further confirm the robustness of AMFFNet across diverse urban environments. This study validates the feasibility of SAR imagery for multi-category built-up area classification and provides both a valuable dataset and a high-accuracy model for urban monitoring and land management applications.

title: A Bidirectional Non-Isolated Electric Vehicle On-board Charger Aiming for Leakage Current Suppression
authors: Alireza Moavi, Sadegh Nadi, Arash Khoshooei, Mehdi Saradarzadeh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: Non-isolated chargers are attractive solutions for electric vehicle (EV) applications due to their simple structure, high efficiency, compact design, and lower cost. However, compared with isolated chargers, they inherently suffer from higher leakage currents, raising safety concerns. To address these challenges, this paper presents a two-stage non-isolated bidirectional on-board charger in which both stages collaboratively suppress leakage current. The proposed architecture employs a Bidirectional Clamping Highly Efficient and Reliable Inverter Concept (BDC-HERIC) topology as the AC/DC stage and a symmetrical buck converter as the DC/DC stage, achieving substantial leakage current reduction. The control strategy ensures unity power factor and enables Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) operation. By maintaining a constant common-mode voltage, the proposed system achieves approximately a tenfold reduction in leakage current. The effectiveness and performance of the proposed topology are verified through both MATLAB/Simulink simulations and hardware experiments, confirming its superior efficiency and compliance with safety standards.

title: Low-Voltage Topology Description Method Based on Graph-relation Model for Distribution Grid with Large-Scale and High-Frequency Measurement
authors: Junfeng Qiao, Lin Peng, Aihua Zhou, Meizhao Liu, Pei Yang, Min Xu, Sen Pan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The intricate structure and frequent online reconfiguration of low-voltage distribution lines result in massive, multi-version dynamic topologies that are challenging to acquire and analyze for operational applications. To address these issues, this paper proposes a dynamic topology characterization method for distribution grid based on a graph-relationship hybrid model. A mapping strategy between line topology and graph models is designed to construct a static topology graph of the distribution grid. The calculation logic for node connection weights is defined by considering the distribution characteristics of switches between devices, thereby generating a graph node similarity matrix. Spectral clustering algorithms are employed to segment the topology graph to reduce the complexity of dynamic topology graph updates. The adaptive generation of connecting edges between dynamic topology nodes is achieved by decomposing the measurement state sequence features of switch-type devices. The graph-relation model incorporates a trade-off between the computational performance across topological versions and the storage efficiency of massive measurement data, thereby resolving the challenge of representing dynamic topologies under highfrequency, large-scale data influx. The efficiency of the proposed method in topology analysis scenarios is validated using low-voltage topology data from a regional distribution grid, with analysis cases including topology version backtracking, power supply range analysis, and real-time connectivity. For these scenarios, the topology computation time has been compressed to below the low-voltage equipment’s measurement interval, which enables real-time updates and rapid calculations of dynamic topologies.

title: Hierarchical UAV Trajectory Generation and Optimization in MEC Systems with Physical Constraints and Uncertain Obstacle Avoidance
authors: Xiao Liang, Wei Shangguan, Junjie Chen, Linguo Chai, Yue Cao, Tong Zhao, Yuanyuan Zha
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-assisted multi-access edge computing (MEC) networks significantly improve Internet of Things (IoT) communication in infrastructure-limited environments. However, in large-scale, complex, and dynamic 3D environments, uncertain sensor information and unexpected obstacles pose serious challenges to UAV flight safety, thereby necessitating robust and fast-responding trajectory optimization methods. This study presents a hierarchical trajectory generation and optimization scheme for UAV-assisted MEC in complex environments. Different from existing works, our scheme incorporates constraints from the UAV’s realistic dynamics model and a communication-computation energy consumption model. A global trajectory is first generated using an improved cost-function-based rapidly-exploring random tree star (RRT*) algorithm, followed by refinement via nonlinear model predictive control for high-precision smoothing. In addition, an attention-enhanced double deep Q-network (DDQN) module is employed as the high-level controller within the hierarchical trajectory optimization framework, providing optimized obstacle avoidance strategies in the presence of uncertain obstacles. Simulation results show that: 1) Compared with traditional approaches, the proposed scheme generates trajectories that demonstrate improved smoothness while rigorously satisfying physical and safety constraints, thereby enhancing the overall reliability of flight operations; and 2) in scenarios involving uncertain obstacles, the proposed framework effectively balances multiple objectives, including flight efficiency, obstacle avoidance safety, and energy consumption, leading to more robust and cost-effective aerial operation performance.

title: Front Cover
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics

title: Unveiling Dynamic Finger–Key Interactions in Piano Performance through 3D Force Measurements
authors: Miyu Ishiguro, Yutaka Sakaguchi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Haptics
abstract: Understanding haptic interactions between fingers and piano keys is essential for uncovering the sensorimotor mechanisms underlying piano performance. In the present study, we developed a sensor-integrated piano keyboard capable of monitoring three-dimensional (3D) forces applied to the keys, achieved by embedding MEMS sensor devices in both white and black keys spanning an entire octave (C4 to C5). The system captures both vertical (depressing) and horizontal (frictional) forces, offering novel insights into how pianists utilize friction to execute complex finger movements in playing note sequences and chords. We describe the system's design and functionality, and present representative results demonstrating its capabilities. Our findings reveal that the temporal profiles of both vertical and horizontal forces contain rich information about physical mechanisms underlying pianistic skills. Moreover, we report novel observations of the dynamic force interaction between the fingers and key surfaces. This system offers a valuable tool for analyzing the sensorimotor foundations of pianistic skills and for providing objective data to support piano pedagogy.

title: Fast Electromagnetic Design of the MRI Superconducting Magnet via Deep Residual Neural Networks
authors: Jing Li, Xinyu Wu, Jiajun Zhong, Songlin Li, Ruichen Wang, Jingwei Chai, Pengbo Zhou, Yalin Zhao, Guangtong Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: This study focuses on the development of a high-efficiency computational model for predicting the magnetic field of high-temperature superconducting (HTS) magnets, which is crucial for the design and optimization of HTS-based devices. A fast-computational model for magnetic field was proposed, leveraging the feature extraction capabilities of the deep residual neural network (ResNet). To validate the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed model, a prototyped HTS magnet system was employed for experimental verification. The comparison between the calculation results and the experimental data demonstrated a high degree of consistency, confirming the practical applicability of the model. Subsequently, an enhanced linear adaptive genetic algorithm was introduced for the optimization design of a 3 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) magnet utilizing REBCO superconducting tapes. The optimized magnet is composed of 60 double-pancake coils, operating at a cryogenic temperature of 30 K and featuring a coil inner diameter of 600 mm. An active shielding technique was adopted, which involves the strategic arrangement of additional coils to counteract the stray magnetic fields. Through this approach, the fringing field was effectively suppressed. In terms of field homogeneity, the magnet achieved 74 ppm within a 250 mm diameter spherical volume (DSV).

title: Aging Effects in REBCO Tapes Solder Joint Made with Indium-Tin
authors: Ga¨el Berthet, Hyunsoo Park, Insung Park, Wonseok Jang, Wonju Jung, Jeonghwan Park, Minkyu Sun, Haigun Lee, Seungyong Hahn, Sangjin Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: With the promises of nuclear fusion, an increasing number of fusion magnet projects are employing (RE)Ba<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> Cu<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>O<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7−δ</sub> (REBCO) tapes. These magnets often include multiple demountable joints, which typically incorporate low temperature solder either in the joint itself or in the cable. Such solders usually contain elements that diffuse readily in copper, raising concerns about the aging effects. This study investigates the impact of the InterMetallic-Compound (IMC) growth on the joints properties through room-temperature aging and annealing. Eutectic indium-tin solder joints stored for nine months in a desiccator did not exhibit any significant change in their properties. Given the strong temperature dependence of the IMC growth, annealing at 100°C was performed to simulate long-term effects. After 6 to 8 days of annealing, critical current degradation was measured in all samples containing solder, indicating that the IMC had grown to the REBCO layer deteriorating it. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) analyses revealed that even after 20 days, solder elements reached the REBCO layer only in regions where the solder was abundant.

title: FlowTwin: A Digital Twin for Traffic Flow Monitoring
authors: Manfredi Napolitano, Alessandra Somma, Alessandra De Benedictis, Nicola Mazzocca
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Urban mobility systems are growing increasingly complex due to rapid urbanization, evolving transportation demands, and rising congestion levels, which lead to travel delays and increased environmental impact. These challenges underscore the importance of developing advanced modeling, monitoring, and management approaches that can capture the dynamics of urban mobility systems and support more efficient, sustainable and adaptive transportation solutions. Mobility Digital Twin (MoDT) has emerged as a promising paradigm for monitoring, managing, and predicting urban mobility by maintaining a synchronized digital replica of the transportation system and enabling feedback to the physical infrastructure. However, most existing MoDT implementations remain fragmented, and tightly bound to specific use cases, limiting scalability, reusability, and broader applicability. This paper presents FlowTwin, a comprehensive methodology and software framework for developing a MoDT for traffic flow monitoring. The proposed approach introduces a dual-phase methodology: an offline phase for modeling and calibration using macroscopic and microscopic traffic flow models to capture both aggregate and fine-grained driver dynamics; and an online phase that enables simulation, monitoring, and feedback generation. The presented architecture is aligned with the capabilities proposed by Digital Twin Consortium, ensuring structured design and extensibility. The feasibility and effectiveness of FlowTwin are validated through its instantiation in the Italian city of Bologna, resulting in BoMoDT. BoMoDT operates on traffic flow streams generated by a city-scale emulator built from real-world mobility data, enabling continuous monitoring, simulation, and feedback within a realistic but controlled environment. Quantitative evaluations confirm BoMoDT’s capability to support accurate traffic simulation and responsive monitoring under diverse traffic scenarios.

title: Quantitative Frequency-Based Framework for Interpreting Adversarial Examples
authors: Sicong Han, Chenhao Lin, Chao Shen, Zhengyu Zhao, Qian Li, Qian Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Deep neural networks are known to be susceptible to imperceptible adversarial perturbations. Many studies aim to interpret adversarial examples in the frequency domain. However, existing research often relies on a limited number of datasets, models, and adversarial attacks, leading to incomplete conclusions. Moreover, a quantitative interpretation of adversarial examples remains lacking. This paper proposes a quantitative frequency-based framework to comprehensively investigate adversarial examples, where six kinds of attacks against naturally and adversarially trained models across three datasets are adopted. Initially, our framework visualizes the distributions of successful adversarial perturbations in the frequency domain to locate their target regions. Subsequently, we characterize the importance of perturbations contained in different frequency bands and define adversarially effective frequency bands (AEFBs). Furthermore, we leverage the identified AEFBs to enhance two query-based black-box adversarial attacks. Our experimental results uncover the varying characteristics of adversarial perturbations, which are analyzed from dataset-level, model-level, and attack-level perspectives. After reordering frequency bands and identifying AEFBs, we further demonstrate that adversarial attacks guided by AEFBs can achieve superior performance, verifying their effectiveness and generalization. These significant findings contribute to a deeper understanding of adversarial examples and provide valuable insights for future research.

title: Effects of Electrolyte Volume on Electrochemical Migration of Tin in Water Drop Test
authors: Ee Lynn Lee, Yi Sing Goh, A. S. M. A. Haseeb, Yew Hoong Wong, Mohd Faizul Mohd Sabri, Boon Yew Low
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: Miniaturization of electronic devices and the consequent reduction in pitch can increase the risks of short circuit failures due to electrochemical migration (ECM). Water drop test (WDT) is one of the most widely used methods for ECM studies. However, the volume of the electrolyte used in WDT has not been standardized yet. This work investigates the effects of varying electrolyte volume on the ECM of tin (Sn) in WDT, using a two-probe semiconductor characterization system (SCS). The volume of the electrolyte was varied from 5 μL to 100 μL. The electrolytes used for this study are NaCl solutions (0.1, 1, and 10 mM), which are commonly used electrolytes for ECM studies. Results show that the electrolyte volume does not affect the time to failures (TTF) of Sn at low and medium Cl-. concentrations (0.1 mM and 1 mM). However, at a high Cl-. concentration (10 mM), the TTF increases as the electrolyte volume increases. Results further show that the electrolyte volume and Cl. concentration influence the hydrodynamic conditions of the electrolyte during WDT. The synergistic effects of the electrolyte volume, Cl-. concentration, and hydrodynamic conditions in the electrolyte on the ECM behavior of Sn are elucidated.

title: Lifetime-guaranteed Cost-minimized Heterogeneous Visual Sensor Networks with Feature Collection for Effective Target Coverage in 3D Space
authors: Xiaojian Zhu, MengChu Zhou
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In Visual Sensor Networks (VSNs), the generation and transmission of a large quantity of image data lead to huge network traffic. As a result, their lifetime is short and their delay is long. Therefore, reducing their traffic is critical to prolonging their lifetime and shortening their latency. Since the feature data of an image is much smaller than raw data, deploying processing nodes near camera nodes to extract the features of their images for transmission can greatly reduce network traffic. Moreover, installing camera nodes of multiple types can also help, since their use can decrease the total size of images. This work comprehensively utilizes these two measures and investigates how to deploy a heterogeneous VSN to satisfy sampling frequency requirements of targets and gather features of their images while minimizing the network deployment cost and meeting the network lifetime requirement. We formulate this important and new problem as a mixed integer nonlinear program and propose a separate node deployment algorithm and a joint one to solve it. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that both success rate and solution quality of the latter are higher than those of the former at the expense of computational time.

title: A New Target Domain One-Class Learning Bearing Fault Detection Framework
authors: Chang Liu, Ziqian He, Qian Xiang, Chen Li, Xiben Jiao, Wei He, Le Jin, Yuanchao Yu, Ye Liu, Jiahao Liu, Jun Zhou
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Bearing fault detection is essential for machinery health management. An issue of existing work is that the network trained with a publicly available dataset (source domain) often has a large accuracy drop when applied to a target machine (target domain), since the source domain and target domain originate from different machines, and thus exhibit significant differences in data distribution. Besides, in real industrial processes, collecting large amounts of fault data from the target machine is unrealistic. To address the above issues, a target domain one-class learning bearing fault detection framework (TDOCL-BFDF) is proposed in this article inspired by the distribution discrepancy between the normal and the fault data. Firstly, a new three-stage training-initializing scheme, which fully utilizes data from source and target domains, is designed for the TDOCL-BFDF to extract features from the target normal data and increase the distribution discrepancy between the normal and the fault data. Secondly, a Gaussian fault detector (GFD)—serving as a critical performance-enhancing module of the TDOCL-BFDF model is proposed to mitigate the scale imbalance across the dimensions of latent features. The proposed framework is evaluated using four bearing datasets (three public and one in-house dataset) and achieves an accuracy of 0.990-1.0 in all the fault detection tasks. The results show that the TDOCL-BFDF outperforms other state-of-the-art methods and manifests the great potential of the proposed TDOCL-BFDF for real industrial application scenarios.

title: Simulation of the Anode Erosion Process in Highcurrent Vacuum Arcs under Various Frequencies
authors: Xinquan Li, Yirui Zhang, Yueheng Yang, Hui Ma, Zhiyuan Liu, Peng Li, Baoling Zhang, Kai Liu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Anode activity plays a critical role in determining the success of current interruption process of a vacuum interrupter. Various frequency transmission technology has a broad application prospect in the different power systems. The objective of this paper is to investigate the anode erosion, deformation and temperature distribution in high-current vacuum arcs under various frequencies. The model incorporated heat transfer from arc plasma to anode surface and phase change of anode materials. The simulation results indicate that lower frequency results in delayed crater initiation, slower early-stage development, ultimately leading to larger final crater dimensions. During the arcing process, the maximum temperature on the anode surface reaches 1920 K at $50 \mathrm{~Hz}, 2860 \mathrm{~K}$ at 20 Hz, and 2880 K at 15 Hz. Under lowfrequency arc erosion, craters exhibit a saturation trend in dimensions over time during later stages of development, with lower frequency leading to a more pronounced saturation trend and longer duration.

title: ADIS: Detecting and Identifying Manipulated PLC Program Variables Using State-Aware Dependency Graph
authors: Zeyu Yang, Liang He, Yujiao Hu, Peng Cheng, Jiming Chen, Jianying Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: The increasing network integration of industrial control systems amplifies the risk of cyberattacks on Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs). In particular, the weak authentication of industrial communication protocols makes PLC program variables vulnerable to manipulation. Current defensive methods cannot reliably identify manipulated variables, even after PLC program manipulations have been detected. To bridge this gap, we present <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ADIS</monospace>, a cross-domain Attack Detection and Identification System designed to detect and identify manipulated PLC program variables. Building on a novel state-aware graph representation of the PLC program, <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ADIS</monospace> detects variable manipulations by comparing SCADA monitoring data with the control logic defined by the PLC program. <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ADIS</monospace> further identifies suspiciously manipulated program variables by excluding cascading failures from the detected anomalies and tracking suspicious variables based on the edges of the state-aware dependency graph. We have implemented and evaluated <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ADIS</monospace> on two platforms. The results demonstrate that <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ADIS</monospace> detects attacks with a true positive rate exceeding 99% and a false positive rate of less than <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.04{\unicode {0x2030}}$ </tex-math></inline-formula>. Furthermore, it successfully identifies manipulated program variables with up to a 71.3% reduction in suspicious variables compared to a baseline method.

title: Electrical Arcs with Low Melting Cathode Materials
authors: Isak I. Beilis
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Cathode region of an electrical arc was studied using kinetic model of vaporization and plasma generation for low melting material cathodes. The calculated results are in agreements with experiments. As such, this model indicates some specifics of cathode spot characteristics. Namely, low cathode potential drop, low vapor ionization, plasma electron temperature in comparison to previous analysis of that data for widely studied copper and similar cathode materials. The calculations show that the cathode plasma flow is impeded. Therefore, the plasma velocity at the external boundary of nonequilibrium layer significantly lower than sound speed of mass flow at the target vaporization due to laser irradiation.

title: Validation of an iterative method for vacuum circuit breaker temperature rise simulation and its application
authors: Lu Zhu, Junxiang Liu, Yong Wang, Jun Xiao, Jie Zhang, Jun Xiong
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Most of the faults in the operation of high-voltage vacuum circuit breakers (CBs) occur in the operating mechanism, and the accidents caused by mechanical failures account for the highest proportion. Therefore, it is of great practical engineering value to carry out the research on mechanical condition evaluation and fault diagnosis of vacuum CBs. In this paper, according to the relevant research on mechanical condition evaluation and fault diagnosis of high-voltage CB at home and abroad in recent years, firstly, the fault mechanism is analyzed from the typical faults of the CB; furthermore, the advantages and disadvantages of the current commonly used methods of mechanical condition evaluation and fault diagnosis of the CB are compared, and it is pointed out that accurate extraction of feature signals is the key to drive the evaluation of the CB’s mechanical condition, and that the multisource data joint fault diagnosis method based on the artificial intelligence algorithm is the key to the future research. fault diagnosis method is the hotspot and difficult point for future research. Finally, the development trend of mechanical condition evaluation of high-voltage vacuum CBs is further outlooked to lay a foundation for subsequent in-depth research.

title: Analysis of the JSON Web Certificate Proposal
authors: Giacomo Leopizzi, Andrejs Romanovs
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: JSON Web Certificate (JWC) provides a URL-safe mechanism for binding a public key to an entity (such as an individual, organization, or device) through issuance by a trusted party. The certificate can contain claims similar to a JSON Web Token (JWT). The public key is encoded using the JSON Web Key (JWK) format. JWC leverages concepts from JSON Web Signature (JWS), ensuring the integrity and authenticity of the contained information. The paper explores JWC’s structure, use cases and its revocation mechanism.

title: Design and Implementation of STM32 Embedded System
authors: Yao Ying, Minchuan Huang, Shubin Chen
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: This STM32 model combines a machine learning algorithm with Things sensing technology, significantly improving prediction accuracy. The PyCharm integrated development environment and MySQL relational database were used to realize the model architecture and build a multidimensional feature data set. Experimental results show that the model has good generalization performance in sample testing. An automatic questionnaire crawler system based on Python was developed to improve the efficiency of questionnaire data collection, and a structural equation model for cognitive feature analysis was constructed to enhance the cognition of STM32. Based on the STM32 microcontroller architecture, a multi-node intelligent environment monitoring system model is implemented and designed. The temperature and humidity sensor is integrated with the wireless communication module to improve the time accuracy of monitoring data.

title: Study on the Conditioning Characteristics of Different Metal Materials under Different Breakdown Energies
authors: Yuanzhao Li, Zeming Song, Shichen Deng, Shuchen Liu, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Conditioning is an effective method to enhance the insulation strength of vacuum gaps between the metal electrodes, and the breakdown energy plays a crucial role in determining the effectiveness of the conditioning. The objective of this paper is to investigate the differences in conditioning characteristics of different metal materials under various breakdown energies. In the experiments, a lightning impulse voltage was used for conditioning of the vacuum interrupters. By introducing current-limiting resistors and parallel capacitors, the breakdown energy was controlled. Cr, Ti, and Cu were selected as the electrode materials, and their conditioning characteristics under different breakdown energies were analyzed. The results indicate that breakdown energy significantly influences the conditioning effect, with an optimal energy range existing for achieving the best conditioning performance. Furthermore, the optimal breakdown energy for the three metals is approximately similar. In addition, Cr and Ti electrodes tend to develop better surface states during the conditioning process, and their breakdown voltage improvements from energy control are less pronounced compared to Cu electrodes.

title: AnoDiffIR: Diffusion Models for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Brain Imaging
authors: Lin Zhang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: The complexity of brain anatomy and the scarcity of annotated data pose significant challenges to detecting pathologies in the brain scans using supervised deep learning approaches. In contrast, unsupervised anomaly detection is not constrained by annotated requirements by leveraging generative models to construct healthy references for pathological images and identifies anomalies through pixel-wise comparisons. Nevertheless, existing generative models still suffer from insufficient accuracy in reconstructing the fine-grained anatomical details of the brain. Inspired by the image restoration model DIffIR, in this study we propose AnoDiffIR, a novel hybrid unsupervised anomaly detection architecture, which synergizes diffusion priors with generative reconstruction. Specifically, AnoDiffIR consists of Dual-Domain Masking CutMix (DDMC), Hierarchical Feature Extraction Network (HFENet), Dynamic IR Transformer (DIRformer), and a denoising network. Our method employs a two-stage progressive training strategy. In the first pre-training stage, pseudo-lesion data generated by DDMC prompts HFENet to extract and decouple healthy prior features, which can constrain the reconstruction process of DIRformer. In the second stage, the diffusion model inversely derives healthy priors from pathological inputs, which are jointly optimized with DIRformer outputs to refine anomaly maps. We evaluated our method on brain tumor and multiple sclerosis datasets, and the result demonstrates the superiority of our method compared to existing baseline approaches.

title: Knowledge graph visualization of Artificial intelligence for lung disease diagnosis
authors: Wenzheng Wu, Cuirong Zhao, Jinyu Song, Enrui Hu, Lisha Zhong, Zhiwei Huang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: This work executes a systematic and rigorous bibliometric and visual investigation on the uses of artificial intelligence (AI) to medical imaging of lung disease applying knowledge graph approaches. From 4,420 English sources from the Web of Science Core Collection (2009-2023), applying CiteSpace, we systematically analyzed research collaboration, citation, and knowledge structures by country, institution, authors, and journals. The results reveal continued growth in publication output, particularly from 2016 to 2021, and China as the top country and England with the highest collaboration influence. Harvard seems to be the leading institution, whereas Qian Wei and Seo Joon Beom are the leading authors. The journal analysis reveals Radiology to be the most cited publication and New England Journal of Medicine to possess the highest influence. Deep learning seems to be the top and long-enduring research theme on this subject. By visualizing the research landscape and evolution, this work provides rich information to facilitate an understanding of current developments and future directions on AI-based pulmonary imaging diagnoses.

title: Adaptive Artistic Technologies
authors: Rodolfo Cossovich
publish: ACM SIGACCESS Accessibility and Computing
abstract: Given that art-making can support self-expression and social integration, there is a growing interest in the research community in developing more accessible artistic computer inputs. However, the conditions needed to achieve mastery of creative processes, particularly for artists with motor impairments, remain to be explored. We look at implementing new adaptive technologies that leverage more natural interactions on the drawing tools, balancing the challenges and skills artists need to navigate their creative stages. We describe the findings of a qualitative first study involving interviews with 15 digital artists with upper limb motor impairments. We analyze the challenges related to artistic workflows, internal and external perceptions, and what disrupts their creative processes. We share a second study where six digital artists with upper limb motor impairments tested an adaptive stylus which captured their pen-based interactions, triggering accessibility features participants thought could improve their artistic workflows. Future work will address the cognitive load introduced by pen gestures, explore strategies to improve detection accuracy to build trust in the technology, and continue emphasizing the value of training personalized models over traditional accessibility features. Our research aims to contribute to designing inclusive technologies by prioritizing the creative aspects of artistic production.

title: Translation Studies in the Age of Artificial Intelligence: Sanjun Sun, Kanglong Liu, and Riccardo Moratto, Eds.: [Book Review]
authors: Li Xin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Professional Communication

title: Aggregate Model of DC Microgrid for Power System Dynamic Studies
authors: Ankit Mishra, Abdul Saleem Mir, Narayana Prasad Padhy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This paper presents a methodology for the aggregation of DC microgrid (DCMG) components for power system dynamic studies. The proposed methodology of the DCMG components preserves dynamics, dimension, and structure as that of the individual components of the DCMG. The aggregated model would be helpful to analyze the dynamics of the DCMG clusters connected to the grid through bidirectional power electronic interface and its effects during disturbances. With more penetration from solar photovoltaics, batteries, and loads, the aggregate model is computationally less intensive than the detailed model. The paper proposed different scaling parameters for the DCMG components and shows that the detailed and aggregate models have identical structures and dynamics, which have been mathematically proved via necessary and sufficient theorems. Further, extensive simulation studies have been carried out in MATLAB/Simulink to validate and compare the effectiveness in terms of computational time and applicability of the aggregate model with respect to the detailed model. The results have also been verified in real-time using an EMT-based Real-Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) on a standard IEEE 13-bus and IEEE 34-bus network with multiple DCMG clusters.

title: Pixel2Voxel: 3D Reconstruction and Visualization From Limited Number of X-Rays With 3D-Aware Diffusion Models and Iterative Refinement_supp2-3635000.mp4
authors: Gaofeng Deng
publish: N/A
abstract: 2D X-ray radiography is a widely used medical imaging technique due to its low cost, rapid acquisition, and low radiation exposure. However, X-ray images are limited to the 2D plane, making it difficult for physicians to visualize and assess the 3D anatomical information. We present Pixel2Voxel, a method to reconstruct 3D volume from a limited number (1 or 2) of 2D X-ray images for the visualization of 3D anatomical structures. Our approach backprojects the local image features onto their corresponding voxels and aggregates the 2D features from the images to get the 3D geometry-aware volume features. To address the inherent ambiguity stemming from sparse input data, we introduce a novel conditional diffusion model that seamlessly integrates with the 3D volume features. This integration significantly enhances our model's ability to generate high-fidelity and geometrically consistent 3D volumes. Furthermore, we propose an iterative refinement method that substantially improves the reconstruction quality. We evaluate our method through extensive experiments on real patient datasets, demonstrating its superior performance in 3D reconstruction compared to recent methods. Besides, we evaluate our method's capabilities in 3D organ shape reconstruction and volume measurement. Our promising results showcase its great potential across various medical applications, augmenting 2D X-rays by enabling assessment and visualization of 3D anatomical information, such as organ shape, size, and location, with lower cost and lower radiation exposure of X-rays.

title: Improved Cauer Thermal Network Model Considering Lateral Boundary Heat Flux
authors: Ziting Xiang, Xin Yang, Peixin Wu, Zhihe Zhang, Ming Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Health monitoring and thermal management of power modules become critical for their reliable application. Cauer Models show great superiority in monitoring device junction temperature. But the existing models ignored lateral heat flux under low heat dissipation conditions of power devices and require precise monitoring of case temperature. This article proposes a new RC network model for IGBT modules with lateral thermal capacitance. The proposed model integrates the existing thermal network model and reconstructs lateral heat flow using steady-state thermal simulations with the finite element method (FEM). Based on lateral heat flux and transient thermal simulations, a parameter extraction method for solving circuit partial differential equations has been proposed, which leads to determination of lateral thermal capacitance. It has been validated that lateral thermal capacitance is independent of loss and environmental temperature but is related to the convective heat transfer coefficient htc. Both FEM and experimental results corroborate the efficacy and accuracy of the proposed RC network model. The error of the proposed model is within 5%, which is significantly lower than that of the conventional model.

title: Research on Electric Field Optimization of 126kV Vacuum Interrupter
authors: Jianwei Wei, Ziyuan Chai, Wenjun Xiang, Xubin Li, Minfu Liao, Xiongying Duan
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: As vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs) are developed toward higher voltage levels, the concentration of local electric field strength has become a key technical bottleneck restricting their performance enhancement. To address this challenge, research on the electric field distribution characteristics in a 126kV vacuum interrupter (VI) was conducted based on the finite element simulation platform. By establishing an accurate two-dimensional axisymmetric model of the VI, the influences of the main shield length, intermediate shield length, and corrugated tube shield length on the floating shield electric field strength, porcelain surface electric field strength, and maximum electric field strength in the VI were systematically analyzed. It was demonstrated that the maximum electric field strength is concentrated in the contact area, with the vicinity of the contacts being the weak point of insulation. Furthermore, the optimal shield dimensions for the 126kV VI were determined: the main shield length is 298 mm, the intermediate shield length is 80 mm, and the corrugated tube shield length is 85 mm.

title: Thermal Stability Enhancement Strategy for Low Voltage Large Current Axial Magnetic Field Vacuum Switch
authors: Jiayuan Zheng, Xiaoming Liu, Hai Chen, Jingjie Yang, Yinan You, Kunming Peng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Thermal stability of vacuum interrupter (VI) is important for long-term stable operation of vacuum switch. Aiming at the temperature rise and electrical contact of low voltage large current axial magnetic field (AMF) vacuum switch, the equivalent calculation model of contact resistance of the VI was proposed, and the parametric model of VI with AMF was constructed to analyze the effect of the key structural parameters on the temperature rise. Then the surrogate model of the relationship between the structure parameters and thermal stability of the VI based on back propagation neural network was built, and the key structural parameters were optimized by genetic algorithm. Finally, a thermal stability enhancement strategy based on the optimization of the VI structure was put forward, which is conducive to improving the electrical contact performance and temperature rise characteristic of the vacuum switch.

title: Simulation Study on Vacuum Arc Ion Sources under Different Discharge Modes
authors: Zhefeng Zhang, Ze Yang, Jieli Chen, Haonan Yang, Zhongdong Wang, Lijun Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In experiments on vacuum arc ion sources, distinct plasma diffusion processes under different discharge modes have been observed. To investigate the physical mechanism differences of plasma diffusion and plasma physical property distribution in rod-ring structured vacuum arc ion sources, this paper establishes a 3D magnetohydrodynamic model, treating particles of different elements as separate fluids and calculating their physical parameters individually while considering ionization and recombination processes of multicharge state particles. Simulations using a Mo cathode-Al anode vacuum ion source show that in cathode arc discharge mode, cathode-generated plasma forms discharge circuits to the anode and emits through the anode aperture as products. Off-center cathode discharge induces discharge path shift and arc parameter changes. In cathode-anode collaborative discharge mode with active anode vapor generation, anode-generated particles participate in discharge and contribute to multielement ion source products.

title: Developing a Machinery Fault Prediction Solution in Resource-Constrained Environments
authors: Robertas Ūselis, Raimondas Pomarnacki, Artūras Serackis
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Predictive maintenance (PdM) has emerged as a transformative approach aimed at proactively reducing downtime and associated maintenance costs across various industrial sectors. This research investigates the feasibility of implementing a predictive maintenance solution on ultra-low-cost hardware in resource-constrained environments. By integrating the Raspberry Pi RP2040 microcontroller with passive current sensors, a low-power inertial measurement unit, and the SIM7020E NB-IoT module, the system was able to acquire sensor data, extract key time-domain features, and perform periodic wireless transmissions within a strict power envelope defined by a single 14500 Li-ion battery over 30 days. Experimental deployment in a real-world multi-storey building environment confirmed the system robustness in the presence of electrical and mechanical noise, validating its suitability for practical condition monitoring applications. Furthermore, simulation-based fault injection using synthetic signals confirmed that the system’s lightweight rule-based logic could successfully identify abnormal signal patterns associated with common mechanical and electrical faults. These findings support the claim that fault prediction workflows typically confined to high-resource settings can be adapted and validated on minimalist embedded platforms.

title: Simulation study on modeling of vacuum arc characteristics and anode temperature rise in low-frequency vacuum interruption
authors: Jinlei Zhu, Lu Zhu, Junxiang Liu, Haibo Su, Qingdan Huang, Bo Zhu, Xiaolong Huang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Low-frequency transmission technology has been widely used in medium and long-distance electricity transmission scenarios such as offshore wind power transmission due to its advantages of low cost and strong ability to pool renew-able energy. The vacuum circuit breaker is of great significance to ensure the safe and stable operation of low frequency transmission system, but the arc burning time of the vacuum circuit breaker is longer under low frequency conditions, and its vacuum arc characteristics have not been clarified. Therefore, in this paper, for the characteristics of the arc in the low-frequency vacuum breaking process, as well as the anode temperature rise process, a two-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic model and anode temperature rise model were established, and the plasma-related characteristics, current density distribution, energy flow density, and the anode temperature distribution and melting situation were studied. The results of the study can provide theoretical basis and technical support for the development of vacuum circuit breakers applicable to low frequency.

title: LOUD – Labeled nOise aUdio Dataset
authors: Justina Ramonaitė, Faustas Žiliajevas, Gražina Korvel, Gintautas Tamulevičius
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: The paper presents a new dataset on ambient noise. The dataset consists of 21 sound recordings reflecting indoor and outdoor noise. All recordings were made under consistent, controlled conditions to ensure high-quality and balanced data. A unique feature of the dataset is that it consists of long-duration recordings (up to 30 minutes). This makes it suitable for both continuous audio analysis and event classification tasks (by segmenting recordings into shorter recordings). We present an analysis of the acoustic parameters and a classification performance using spectrograms and a convolutional neural network (CNN), achieving an overall accuracy of 94.69%.

title: Multi-Scale Service Resilience Optimization for Space Information Network based on Distributed Proxy Self-Healing
authors: Junxiang Qin, Zhixi Yang, Sili Liu, Rong Lv, Yufeng Zhang, Junnan Li, Can Cui
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Due to unique geographical location and significant economic, social, and military value, space information network (SIN) is vulnerable to interference and potential attacks. As satellites operate in space orbits, traditional methods of manually repairing nodes in ground-based systems are impractical in the high-dynamics space environments, posing challenges for maintaining the service performance of SIN. To address this issue, this paper proposes a multi-scale service resilience optimization (MSSRO) method for SIN based on distributed agent self-healing. Our method solves the problem of relying on ground network control to achieve failed nodes and service recovery, and innovatively achieves autonomous service recovery capability through the remaining performance of satellite systems. Compared with traditional manual recovery methods for satellite system services, this method can improve the system service recovery effect by 31% after node failure, and shorten the service recovery time by 30.7% compared to random recovery methods. MSSRO significantly enhances the service resilience and adaptability of SIN in scenarios involving random interference or malicious attacks.

title: Listening to Temperature: A Novel Temperature Measurement for Flowing Water Using Audio Recognition Techniques
authors: Van-Thuan Tran, Po-Hsuan Shang, Yi-Li Chen, Wei-Ho Tsai
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This study proposes an innovative temperature measurement technique for flowing water, which uses the sound of pouring water to determine its temperature, thereby providing a non-contact temperature sensing technology. It is found that when water is poured from one container into another, different water temperatures cause subtle differences in the pouring sound. Therefore, we can use a microphone to record the sound generated during the pouring process and then determine the temperature of the water as it falls based on the recorded sound. Compared to most contact-based temperature sensors currently used to measure liquid temperature, this technique has the advantage of not causing contact contamination or affecting the water temperature. It can also be designed as an App on a handheld mobile device, where the built-in microphone records the sound to recognize the water temperature, thus eliminating the need for additional hardware costs. To achieve this, we constructed a dataset of pouring sounds across three temperature classes (cold, warm, and hot) and extracted acoustic features such as MFCCs (Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients) and Mel-spectrograms. A deep learning model, ATRNet (Audio-based Temperature Recognition Network), was proposed and benchmarked against CRNN (Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network), VGGish architecture, and SVM (Support Vector Machines) using different input durations and noise conditions. Experimental results show that ATRNet with combined MFCCs and Mel-spectrogram features achieves state-of-the-art performance, up to 100% accuracy on clean post-full segments and strong robustness under noise. Even with short audio segments (3s and 5s), the system maintains competitive accuracy, demonstrating its potential for real-time and embedded applications. These results confirm the feasibility of using impact sound during water pouring for practical, non-contact temperature recognition.

title: BoneSE: Bone Conduction-Assisted Speech Enhancement Based on COTS Earphone
authors: Qing Guo, Long Fan, Lei Xie, Jingyi Ning, Baoliu Ye, Sanglu Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Speech enhancement is crucial for reliable communication in noisy environments. However, the lack of a priori knowledge about target speech characteristics in conventional systems often leads to erroneous extraction of interfering speech as desired signals during noise suppression, significantly compromising system performance. Recently, researchers have proposed to use the side-channel signal as an assist to denoise noisy speech. This paper proposes BoneSE, a multimodal speech enhancement approach using bone conduction. The basic idea of BoneSE is to perceive the bone-conducted sound with an IMU sensor embedded in the Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) earphone and then leverage the correlations between the bone conduction signal and audio signal for speech enhancement. However, the lack of high-frequency components in the IMU modality brings data imbalance and hinders data fusion. To address this challenge, we explore and model the relationship between multimodal signals and design a fusion module according to the time and frequency correlation. Moreover, to balance fast processing and denoising performance, we propose bone conduction-based noise level metrics to measure the noise level. To accommodate different noise levels, we propose an adaptive model selection approach based on reinforcement learning to select the proper denoising model, thereby optimizing the latency. Experiments on two datasets show that the proposed method performs favorably against state-of-the-art methods and can enhance speech in low SNR scenarios.

title: An Adaptive Coordination Exploration Approach for Multi-UAV Based on Entropy-guided Local Planning
authors: Yonghao Zhao, Jianjun Ni, Jie Liu, Yang Gu, Simon X. Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Autonomous exploration in unknown environments is a critical capability for multi-UAV systems. However, existing methods often suffer from unbalanced task allocation, low exploration efficiency, and unstable paths, especially in large-scale and complex scenarios. To address these challenges, this paper presents an adaptive coordination exploration approach for multi-UAV systems. In the proposed approach, dynamic region allocation, entropy-guided local planning, and direction-consistent frontier selection are integrated to achieve efficient and collaborative exploration. The system first partitions the environment adaptively based on workload and regional complexity. It then prioritizes high-information-value areas for exploration. Directional constraints are further applied to improve path continuity and reduce turning redundancy. Extensive experiments in indoor maze and pillar environments, and outdoor forest and urban environments demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art baselines. Furthermore, ablation studies validate the necessity and complementarity of each module. This work provides a practical and efficient solution for multi-UAV exploration in structured and unstructured environments.

title: Retraction Notice: A Way to Integrate ML Algorithm with the NN for the Purpose of Crop Production Through Continuous Monitoring
authors: Neeraj Varshney, A. Mounika Rajeswari, Atreyi Pramanik, Haider Alabdeli, Pranav Kumar, K Prashanth Kumar
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This check examines the evolution of machine studying (ML) strategies in forecasting hydrological droughts, focusing at the Standardized Runoff Index (SRI) in the Han River basin, South Korea. Given the dramatic climatic shifts witnessed throughout this era, our research evaluates the general performance of six ML models—Decision Trees (DT), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Deep Learning Neural Networks (DLNN), Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference Systems (ANFIS), Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), and Fuzzy Rule-Based Systems (FRBS)—in predicting drought severity and frequency. Emphasis is placed on the model and refinement of these fashions to account for converting climatic styles and their impact on drought characteristics. The DT version, renowned for its predictive accuracy and computational performance, is identified as specifically promising. This has a look at targets to manual water resource manage and disaster preparedness via advanced drought forecasting methodologies.

title: Retraction Notice: An Intensive Review on Propagative Antagonistic N/W which is used in Health Care System
authors: Arti Badhoutiya, Borra Sivaiah, Muntather Almusawi, Rajan Verma, Rajesh Singh, Sanjeevkumar Angadi
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This article introduces a Generative Adversarial Network tailored for medical imaging, in particular designed to synthesize retinal images alongside side their segmented mask. This innovation addresses the challenge of obtaining big datasets for deep getting to know, in particular in scientific fields wherein expert annotations are high priced and time-ingesting. It not satisfactory generates fantastic synthetic scientific pics for supervised analysis but moreover achieves cutting-edge day overall performance with dice coefficients of 0.837 on the STARE dataset and 0.832 on the dataset, surpassing present techniques. This development highlights the capability of GANs in scientific imaging, deep gaining knowledge of, and style transfer applications.

title: A Model-Free Method for Irregular Bias Field Correction in Infrared Images
authors: Jun Xie, Hua Huang, Lingfei Song
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Due to the thermal imaging mechanism, infrared images are inevitably contaminated by thermal radiation bias fields. Correcting this low-frequency non-uniformity is challenging because the bias field is difficult to separate from the low-frequency scene content. Existing methods fit parametric surface models to estimate bias fields. However, variations in camera operating states and environment often lead to irregular bias field that such surface models cannot accurately capture. This paper proposes a novel model-free method for irregular bias field correction. The proposed method utilizes the normalized deconvolution module to restore the clean image in the probability density function (PDF) domain, in which the PDF of the bias field can be approximated by a series of specific Gaussian kernel functions. Accordingly, the complete bias field could be obtained gradually in the PDF domain by incremental updating. To transform the image PDF back to the intensity domain, the corresponding conditional expectation is computed in this paper. Note that the proposed method does not require any explicit parametric modeling of the bias field. Therefore, the proposed method is able to correct irregular bias fields effectively. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed model-free method outperforms existing methods in synthesized and real infrared images.

title: Groundwork for Digital Transformation: Building Digital Infrastructure in Resource-Constraint Small and Medium-sized Manufacturing Enterprises
