title: Cyclic Contrastive Representation Learning for Incomplete Multi-modal Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Shihuan He, Zongbao Yang, Jianbo Zhao, Hao Zhang, Ruxin Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate segmentation of multimodal medical images with missing modalities remains a critical challenge due to incomplete data often encountered in clinical practice. Lack of modality-specific information often leads to significant performance degradation in scenarios with severely missing modalities. To address this problem, we focus on modeling the relationships between modality-specific features. We propose a joint representation learning framework, named as Cyclic Contrastive Latent Representation Segmentation (CLRS), which incorporates cyclic modality-specific representation generation and contrastive feature alignment for robust 3D medical image segmentation under missing modality conditions. CLRS first extracts feature from available modalities using a unified encoder, then generates missing latent representations conditioned on the encoded features via an elaborately designed synthesis strategy. Meanwhile, a channel-wise attention mechanism is introduced to enhance the specific features of the modality. In addition, modality-specific contrastive learning enforces cross-modal discrimination between the generated and encoded representations, which effectively disentangles modality-specific information from shared patterns and enhances the segmentation robustness in missing modality scenarios. Extensive experiments on three 3D multimodal datasets demonstrate the superior performance of CLRS, particularly in scenarios with severe modality absence. For instance, with only a single modality available on ProstateZS dataset, CLRS improves the state-of-the-art (SOTA) by over 4.06% for peripheral zone, 2.20% for central gland. The code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/comphsh/CLRS</uri>.

title: Back-to-Back Two-Terminal Tandem Solar Cells for Enhanced Bidirectional Light Harvesting
authors: Mohammad Ajmain Fatin, Arpan Saha, Md Shahriar, Md Jayed Hossain, Tasmiat Rahman, Jaker Hossain, Mainul Hossain
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: Bifacial tandem solar cells offer enhanced energy yield by utilizing both direct sunlight and rear-side albedo light. Here, we propose a novel bifacial architecture featuring monolithically integrated 2-terminal (2T) tandem photovoltaic structures on both the front and rear surfaces. Unlike conventional designs with a single illuminated tandem stack, our back-to-back configuration employs complete tandem subcells on each side, enabling independent spectral optimization for incident and reflected light. The rear-facing 2T tandem comprises an all-perovskite stack with narrow (1.20 eV) and wide (1.60 eV) bandgap absorbers optimized for albedo harvesting. The front-facing 2T tandem integrates the same wide-bandgap perovskite with a silicon heterojunction (1.12 eV) bottom cell. Current matching in each stack is achieved by tailoring the absorber thicknesses. Device performance is numerically evaluated using SCAPS-1D simulations across four surface types: soil, sand, concrete, and snow. On highly reflective surfaces like snow, the design yields a power conversion efficiency of up to 47% and a bifacial efficiency gain (BEG) of 73%. This architecture also provides enhanced design flexibility through asymmetric bandgap tuning, optical filtering, and angular light management. Our results highlight a new design paradigm for next-generation bifacial solar cells with significantly improved performance and versatility.

title: NetCarbTrace: a Probing Tool to Measure and Explore the Carbon Footprint of Computer Networks
authors: Roberto Vergallo, Antonio Campa, Simone Casciaro, Giovanni Ciccarese, Antonio Mongelli, Luca Mainetti
publish: IEEE Software
abstract: Current methods for calculating sustainability metrics of network links are based on fixed-rate estimations. We present a context-aware model of energy consumption, also providing an open-source tool that enables developers to use the Internet more efficiently. In a proof of concept, we collected and analyzed a two-month dataset covering 43 AWS and Microsoft endpoints.

title: TS-SCLF: Threshold Learning Based SCLF Polar Decoder With Segmented CRC
authors: Yutai Sun, Jingyi Chen, Jian Zheng, Houren Ji, You You, Yongming Huang, Chuan Zhang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Successive cancellation list flip (SCLF) polar decoding has garnered extensive research attention thanks to its outstanding error correction performance. However, it suffers from high complexity and long worst-case decoding latency, particularly at low signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). To address these issues, this letter proposes TS-SCLF, an SCLF decoder that employs a dual-threshold strategy and segmented CRC to reduce latency. The proposed dual-threshold strategy dynamically skips redundant flipping attempts through historical failure pattern analysis, while employing Gaussian distribution-inspired path metric thresholds to enable early successive cancellation list (SCL) termination. Furthermore, a deep Q-network (DQN) framework is applied to optimize the threshold parameters, achieving a good balance between complexity and error performance. Experimental results show that for a (1024,512) polar code, TS-SCLF reduces the average number of decoding attempts by up to 55.3% at low SNRs compared with state-of-the-art counterparts, while preserving error correction performance.

title: Discharge Initiation in the Multipactor-Free Zone Induced by Dielectric Charging
authors: Qianqian Hu, Xue Zhang, Tao Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive analysis of discharge initiation within the multipactor-free zones of susceptibility chart owing to dielectric charging. Simulations of the multipactor effect in both one-sided and two-sided dielectric-loaded parallel-plate waveguides reveal that positive dielectric charging affects the transit time of electrons, causing them to transition into the third-order double-surface multipactor (DSMP) mode and facilitating resonant conditions. Consequently, the prolonged bidirectional transit time in two-sided dielectric-loaded waveguides enables the initiation and saturation of multipactor discharge throughout the multipactor-inactive region. In contrast, in one-sided dielectric-loaded waveguides, the asymmetric electrostatic field limits secondary electron generation to specific parameter domains, thereby restricting the spatial expansion of the discharge. In this case, secondary electron avalanche is confined to localized areas within multipactor-inactive regions near the third-order DSMP regions in the one-sided dielectric-loaded rectangular waveguide, while it extends across the entire multipactor-inactive regions in the two-sided dielectric-loaded rectangular waveguide. The numerical findings have been validated by EM-PIC simulations.

title: Analysis of Photosynthetic Photon Flux Distribution under LED Lighting using Genetic Algorithm for Efficient Okra Cultivation
authors: Yao Hervé Yao, Pascal Dupuis, Laurent Canale, Banah Florent Degni, Théodore Cissé Haba, Georges Zi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: Okra (Abelmoschus esculentus) is a major vegetable crop whose year-round production can be enhanced under controlled environments with artificial lighting. Achieving a uniform photosynthetic photon flux density (PPFD) is critical to optimize plant growth and reduce variability in morphological and physiological responses. Although many studies have focused on optimizing LED fixture designs prior to fabrication, few have validated simulation methods using existing commercial LED modules. This study evaluates and optimizes PPFD distribution using commercial LED modules. A multi-objective genetic algorithm coupled with an analytical model was developed to determine the optimal module spacing (D) and mounting height (h) needed to reach a target average PPFD of 200 μmolm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-2.</sup>S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-1</sup> with at least 60% uniformity for two LED fixtures emitting at 660 nm (red) and 445 nm (blue). Simulated and measured PPFD distributions showed strong agreement, with relative errors ranging from 2.0% to 4.1%, well within acceptable limits for photometric modeling. These results demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of the proposed framework for predicting and optimizing PPFD distribution in horticultural lighting, providing a reliable tool to improve indoor cultivation of okra and other crops.

title: Interactive Composition Operators An Alternative Approach for Selecting Linear Embedding Parameters
authors: Dirk J. Lehmann, Kai M. Blum, Manuel Rubio-Sánchez, Konrad Simon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Linear embeddings support interactive visual exploration by mapping high-dimensional (nD) data into a two-dimensional space. Despite their popularity, selecting meaningful projection parameters remains a key challenge due to the infinite 2n-dimensional parameter space. Once an informative projection is found, users often seek similar ones that emphasize specific items differently while preserving global structure. For instance: Do clusters become outliers under slight changes? Can grouped items separate-or merge-through parameter adjustments? Which changes to the embedding parameters lead to such projections - and do they exist at all? Answering these questions efficiently is critical for effective visual search. Yet, current methods-such as projection tours or manual parameter tuning-are time-consuming and risk overlooking important views, including those of specific interest. We propose Composition Operators, a mathematical foundation for a novel set-of-point manipulation concept for linear embeddings-such as Star Coordinates-as an alternative approach to selecting informative embedding parameters in a more controllable manner with respect to the desired outcome. Users specify item-based constraints on the projection result; the corresponding 2n parameters are then derived automatically, eliminating the need to exhaustively search the entire parameter space to get a similar outcome. Neither the embedding space nor the set of parameters is altered - only the mechanism for navigating and selecting parameters is redefined. We provide closed-form solutions for this and demonstrate our interactive prototype on nD datasets from the UCI repository.

title: Retraction Notice: Escalate the Returns With ML-Based Technical Analysis: Next Day Closing Price Prediction Using RNN and LSTM Models
authors: Sarthak Mahajan, Sukoon Anand, Pradeepta Kumar Sarangi, Ashok Kumar Sahoo
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: One of the subjects that has been studied the most is stock price forecasting, which is attracting interest from both academia and business. This is also an active area of research and learning. Since the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), many algorithms have been developed to predict the stock market’s movement. Accurate stock price prediction can help with better decision making and in economy. Next day price prediction is much more useful for investors. However, this requires experience, knowledge, and proper education. This article implements two advanced machine learning models such as RNN and LSTM to predict the next day stock prices. The data used in this work is the daily traded data for the stocks of HDFC bank and Infosys Ltd. It also investigates the future directions of research in this area.

title: Retraction Notice: An Experimental Analysis Into Blockchain Cyber Security Attacks
authors: Sumeet Gupta, Apoorva Bhowmick, Umamageswari K, Kapil Joshi, Heena Bhalla, Deepak Kaushal
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: WSNs are utilized in various fields, including smart urban communities, medical services, smart structures, and transportation. These networks distribute private information among numerous transceivers, smart devices, and sensor nodes. The environment of WSNs contains sensitive data that is vulnerable to numerous cyber threats and attacks. To deal with threats, attacks, and security hardships in WSNs, a viable security system is required. To decide the best countermeasures to distinguish the pernicious and security gambles using Blockchain innovation, this article fostered another methodology utilizing heuristic, signature, and voting detection techniques. In our system, the three detection methods together with Blockchain are used by the cluster head node (CN) to identify rogue sensor nodes. Also, CN utilizes vital factors like voting degree for malicious nodes, sensor node hash value, and node signature to identify malicious nodes in WSNs. The general discoveries measurement uncovered that during the reenactment of our technique, 94.9% of malicious messages were really perceived and distinguished.

title: Impact of Inverter Controls in Small-Signal Stability of Power Systems Dominated by Inverter-Based Resources
authors: Xian Gao, Muhammad S. Javaid, Balarko Chaudhuri, Houssem Bouchekara, Dao Zhou, Amjad Anvari-Moghaddam, Frede Blaabjerg, Lilia El Amraoui, Kais Ouni
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Initiatives to decarbonize contemporary power systems will lead to power systems dominated by inverter-based resources (IBR). These IBRs are broadly classified into grid-following (GFL) and grid-forming (GFM) inverter control regimes. In this paper, a small-signal state-space model is formulated for a 100% IBR-dominated power system. This formulation is then used to perform stability analysis on the IEEE 9-bus system. The analysis thoroughly investigates the impacts of varying GFM inverter penetration on system stability. The paper also discusses the system behavior in the wake of varying shares of different GFL inverter control schemes. The cause of instability is ascertained by investigating the participation factor of each component. Moreover, the paper examines the effects of phase-locked loop (PLL) and power synchronization loop (PSL) parameters on determining the minimum GFM penetration necessary for ensuring stable system operation. It has been found that the inverter type with the highest capacity is not always the biggest contributor to instability. Also, increasing the proportional coefficient and decreasing the integral coefficient of the PLL of GFL inverters allow the system to be operated under lower GFM penetration. Similarly, increasing the moment of inertia or damping coefficient of the GFM inverter’s power synchronization loop has a similar effect. The conclusions and the underlying theoretical analysis are verified by time-domain simulations of electromagnetic transient (EMT) models in Matlab/Simulink.

title: Table of Contents
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers

title: Robust Image Retrieval via Semantic Object Relationship Integration and Hierarchical Index Partitioning
authors: Sen Du, Kang Ma, Junjie Yu, Xiaochuan Guo
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Robust image retrieval remains a core yet challenging task in computer vision, particularly under complex geometric transformations (e.g., rotation, scaling) and semantic variations (e.g., object pose, context changes). Existing methods, often reliant on monolithic feature representations or simplistic similarity metrics, struggle with spatial deformations, fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships, and suffer from efficiency degradation at scale. To address these issues, we propose HALO, a Hierarchical Adaptive Latent Optimization framework. HALO introduces: (1) a multi-component similarity metric that integrates semantic object alignment, spatial relationship modeling, and attribute-level descriptors for comprehensive comparison; and (2) an adaptive index partitioning strategy employing manifold-aware decomposition and residual quantization to accelerate retrieval. Extensive experiments on COCO and ImageNet demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly improving mean Average Precision (mAP) while maintaining substantially faster query speeds on large-scale databases.

title: cuFastTuckerPlusTC: a Stochastic Parallel Sparse FastTucker Decomposition Using GPU Tensor Cores_supp1-3636547.pdf
authors: Kenli Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Sparse tensors are prevalent in real-world applications, often characterized by their large-scale, high-order, and high dimensional nature. Directly handling raw tensors is impractical due to the significant memory and computational overhead involved. The current mainstream approach involves compressing or decomposing the original tensor. One popular tensor decomposition algorithm is the Tucker decomposition. However, existing state-of-the-art algorithms for large-scale Tucker decomposition typically relax the original optimization problem into multiple convex optimization problems to ensure polynomial convergence. Unfortunately, these algorithms tend to converge slowly. In contrast, tensor decomposition exhibits a simple optimization landscape, making local search algorithms capable of converging to a global (approximate) optimum much faster. In this paper, we propose the FastTuckerPlus algorithm, which decomposes the original optimization problem into two non-convex optimization problems and solves them alternately using the Stochastic Gradient Descent method. Furthermore, we introduce cuFastTuckerPlusTC, a fine-grained parallel algorithm designed for GPU platforms, leveraging the performance of tensor cores. This algorithm minimizes memory access overhead and computational costs, surpassing the state-of-the-art algorithms. Our experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a 2× to 8× improvement in convergence speed and a 3× to 5× improvement in per-iteration execution speed compared with state-of-the-art algorithms.

title: Managing Classroom Behavior in School-aged Children with ADHD using AI-Empowered Vest
authors: Minyu Qiu, Hong Fu, Yitong Wang, Zijian Luo, Xiuhong Tong, Walei Zhang, Bin Li, Daniel Hung-Kay Chow, Philip Leung Ho Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is one of the prevalent neurodevelopmental disorders that affects school-age children. Although various treatments are currently available for ADHD, immediate and automated strategies for managing classroom behavior in children with ADHD are still limited. This study introduces an artificial intelligence (AI) empowered vest to monitor classroom activity and provide real-time vibration interventions to help manage hyperactive behavior. The vest integrates two inertial measurement units to collect behavioral data, and a neural network classifies it as typical or hyperactive. The vibration motor will be activated to remind the children to adjust their posture after detecting hyperactive behavior. A controlled experiment was conducted with 40 children aged 7-12 years to evaluate the accuracy of the vest behavior classification and the effectiveness of its vibration-based intervention. Each child attended the same lesson with three sections in the pre-test and the post-test. Vibration interventions were introduced during the post-test in the second and third sections. The teacher used a five-point scale to rate the children’s performance in each section. The classification and intervention accuracy on the test set was 0.84. A significant reduction in activity level was observed after the vibration intervention, and teacher performance ratings improved significantly in sections with the intervention (p < 0.05, Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test). These findings suggest that the proposed system provides a promising real-time solution for behavioral intervention in classroom settings.

title: Joint Multivariate Time Series Forecasting Using Empirical Symbol Mode Decomposition Modeling
authors: Yue Yu, Pavel Loskot, Wenbin Zhang, Qi Zhang, Yu Gao
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: Forecasting multivariate time series has many real-world applications involving controlling the systems as well as dimensioning and planning their growth. The key difference from univariate time series is that the channel cross-correlations can be exploited to achieve forecasting with higher accuracy at the cost of possibly much larger complexity. On the other hand, simple techniques such as DLinear achieve very good performance, and they can be used also for multivariate time series by simply ignoring the spatial channe dependencies. Furthermore and importantly, the data pre-processing has a significant impact upon the forecasting accuracy. In this paper, a novel pre-processing strategy for multivariate time series is considered to extract the relevant spatio-temporal features for subsequent downstream processing including sample forecasting. Specifically, the time series are first spatially re-ordered into a longitudinal data matrix. The data matrix is then uniformly sliced into equal-size sub-matrices, which are referred to here as data symbols. The data symbols are further decomposed into the 2D regression trends and symbols of residual noises akin to empirical mode decomposition. The symbol size is chosen, so that the residual noise is approximately stationary. The concatenated features represent a transformed time series, which can be forecasted using channel-independent methods such as DLinear. Assuming EEG data and four forecasting accuracy metrics, our numerical results demonstrate that the proposed pre-procesing outperforms other channel-independent forecasting methods for multivariate time series across different forecasting horizons. In addition, the numerical results indicate that the forecasting accuracy is dependent on the frequency sub-band of EEG data considered.

title: Spoofed Speech Detection for Physical and Logical Access Applications using Deep Neural Networks
authors: Cristian-Teodor Neamtu, Serban Mihalache, Dragos Burileanu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Speaker recognition-based biometric systems are used frequently worldwide because of their qualities and simplicity regarding the hardware setup. The increased usage of such systems has also driven the rise of different speech spoofing methods which can introduce errors for the liveness detection subsystem. This paper focuses on the detection of replay attacks (RA) and of identity spoofing methods using text-to-speech (TTS) or voice conversion (VC). We propose a hybrid MLPCNN neural network-based classification system for discerning between legitimate users’ spontaneous speech and spoofed speech, according to the three types of attacks mentioned. Two datasets were leveraged for developing the system: ASVspoof 2019 (used for training, validation, and evaluation) and ASVspoof 2021 (only for additional evaluation). Several detection scenarios are considered, involving 6 different classification subtasks. Measuring performance using the equal error rate (EER), depending on the subtask, the best proposed model reaches superior or comparable results to other state-of-the-art systems.

title: Requirements for Vacuum Interrupters in DC Circuit Breakers
authors: Verena West, Philipp Wienkamp, Simon Kimpeler, Willem Leterme
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Direct current circuit breaker topologies for medium and high voltage applications-like active current injection direct current circuit breakers and hybrid direct current circuit breakers-feature one or more mechanical breaker units, together with auxiliary circuits for interrupting direct current. The mechanical breaker provides the main current path during normal operation. During the interruption process the requirements on the mechanical breaker in direct current circuit breakers depend on the circuit breaker topology. The application of vacuum interrupters in direct current circuit breakers presents new challenges for their design, as the requirements are different from those of traditional applications such as alternating current interruption. By analyzing the operating conditions for vacuum interrupters in direct current circuit breaker topologies, requirements for the application of vacuum interrupters are given. Additionally, considerations regarding the adaption of vacuum interrupters to improve direct current circuit breaker topologies are given.

title: Statistical correlation between the parameters of surface treatment and the vacuum level and voltage conditioning performance of vacuum interrupter.
authors: Santanu Banerjee, Michael Bausmayer, Damien Canat, Sandeep Kulkarni, Amit Chakraborty
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Surface treatment plays an extremely important role in the short term and long-term performance of vacuum interrupters. The efficacy of surface treatment of the components decides the robustness of brazing. Also, the cleanliness of components achieved during surface treatment governs the presence of gases and impurities in the VI after sealoff. This is gauged by the measurement of vacuum level. The presence of gases and impurities also affects the voltage conditioning performance of the vacuum interrupter. This paper explores the correlation between the parameters of surface treatment and the test parameters like vacuum level and the discharge current during voltage conditioning. This correlation once confirmed will help in fine tuning of parameters of surface treatment to achieve an optimal performance of the VI in short and long term.

title: Investigation on Temperature Rise by the Thermal Circuit Model for High-Voltage Vacuum Circuit Breakers
authors: Wendi Xu, Lei Huang, Tianchi Tang, Hui Ma, Zhiyuan Liu, Shuaibing Wang, Jiangang Ding, Zaixing Peng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to propose a thermal circuit model to investigate the rated current temperature rise of the high-voltage vacuum circuit breaker (HVVCB). Compared to the traditional Computational Fluid Dynamics model, the thermal circuit model could reveal the temperature rise of the high-voltage vacuum circuit breakers quickly, which is helpful for the designment of the HVVCB. The thermal circuit model consisting of heat flux and thermal resistance is constructed for the thermal structure of the vacuum interrupter contacts. The thermal circuit models for AMF contacts were established, and the components in the thermal circuit were parameterized based on the physical parameters of the contact structure. The temperature rise of the key nodes of the VCBs was obtained through simulation. The highest temperature rise occurs at the contact surface of the moving and fixed contacts at $181.1^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. This is consistent with the electromagnetic coupling simulation results, and the error is within a reasonable range. Verified the accuracy and efficiency of the thermal circuit model.

title: LSTM model-driven data prediction and analysis system for digital economy
authors: Wenjing Dang, Yizhao Xing, Yuxin Liu, Feier Lei, Haoze Zhang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The digital economy is developing rapidly, and its complex and changing development trends urgently need accurate prediction tools. In this study, we design and implement a digital economy prediction and analysis system based on LSTM deep learning model, introduce the attention mechanism to enhance the ability of capturing long sequence dependencies, and construct a multi-source heterogeneous data fusion architecture. The system adopts a microservice structure to achieve high scalability, and improves the accuracy of core digital economic indicators by more than 25% compared with traditional methods. Experimental validation shows that the system has significant advantages in dealing with nonlinear time-series relationships and seasonal fluctuations, providing reliable technical support for digital economy monitoring and decision-making.

title: Impact of Tariff Policy on China's Copper Resources Import Trade and Response Strategies
authors: Wenhua Li, Cong Liu, Yuan Wu, Lianrui Ma, Shoulin Liu, Liuxin Zhang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Amid escalating China-US trade tensions, this paper employs a computable general equilibrium (CGE) model, setting four graded tariff rates—100%, 200%, 300%, and 500%—as policy scenarios to analyze the effects of tariff policy adjustment on macroeconomic performance and the copper mining industry chain. The results show that: 1) At the macroeconomic level, increasing the import tariff on copper resources positively influences GDP through industrial linkage mechanisms, but this is accompanied by adverse environmental consequences, such as increased carbon emissions. 2) At the industrial level, the tariff policy has differentiated supply-and-demand effects on the copper mining industry: on the supply side, there is a substitution effect whereby import constraints stimulate domestic capacity expansion; on the demand side, demand remains relatively stable due to the rigid demand in industrial production. 3) Policy simulations indicate that while significantly higher copper import tariffs can effectively reduce import dependence, they do so at the risk of depleting domestic reserves, thereby jeopardizing medium- to long-term resource security. To ensure copper resource security, China should build a diversified system by boosting recycled copper utilization and increasing domestic exploration to enhance reserves.

title: Dataset-Adaptive Dimensionality Reduction
authors: Hyeon Jeon, Jeongin Park, Soohyun Lee, Dae Hyun Kim, Sungbok Shin, Jinwook Seo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Selecting the appropriate dimensionality reduction (DR) technique and determining its optimal hyperparameter settings that maximize the accuracy of the output projections typically involves extensive trial and error, often resulting in unnecessary computational overhead. To address this challenge, we propose a dataset-adaptive approach to DR optimization guided by structural complexity metrics. These metrics quantify the intrinsic complexity of a dataset, predicting whether higher-dimensional spaces are necessary to represent it accurately. Since complex datasets are often inaccurately represented in two-dimensional projections, leveraging these metrics enables us to predict the maximum achievable accuracy of DR techniques for a given dataset, eliminating redundant trials in optimizing DR. We introduce the design and theoretical foundations of these structural complexity metrics. We quantitatively verify that our metrics effectively approximate the ground truth complexity of datasets and confirm their suitability for guiding dataset-adaptive DRworkflow. Finally, we empirically show that our dataset-adaptive workflow significantly enhances the efficiency of DR optimization without compromising accuracy.

title: Exploiting Large Language Models for Single-channel Blind Source Separation in Anti-jamming Wireless Communications
authors: Boya Li, Luliang Jia, Lin Zhang, Nan Qi, Wanbin Tang, Fumiyuki Adachi
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: In anti-jamming wireless communications, single-channel blind source separation (SCBSS) is an effective way to combat full-band jamming. Conventional SCBSS methods typically depend on prior knowledge of jamming, and existing deep learning-based SCBSS methods require extensive training samples, limiting their applications in practical scenarios. Alternatively, we exploit large language models (LLMs) to design a novel SCBSS method, including a new LLM-based deep neural network (DNN), and a new fine-tuning algorithm. By harnessing the extremely powerful feature extraction and cross-domain knowledge transfer capabilities of LLMs, our method can effectively separate target signals from full-band jamming after fine-tuning with a small number of labeled data samples. Experimental results demonstrate superior bit error ratio (BER) and generalization performance over traditional and existing deep learning-based anti-jamming methods with significantly reduced training samples.

title: Trans2Graph: Mining Ethereum Phishers with Graph on Heterogeneous Temporal Transaction Data
authors: Jieli Liu, Jiajing Wu, Jinze Chen, Yiyue Cao, Zibin Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: In recent years, phishing scams have caused huge economic losses in Ethereum, the largest blockchain platform enabling smart contracts. Many new sorts of phishing attacks based on smart contracts, specifically targeting Ethereum assets such as Ether and tokens, are emerging. Existing Ethereum phishing detection methods usually mine the transaction relationships among accounts from block data, while neglecting to mine the temporal transaction patterns inherent in the accounts themselves in different transaction types introduced by smart contracts. Such information provides a new perspective for analyzing account transaction preferences. However, since this information is hidden in heterogeneous data such as trace data and event logs, it is difficult to analyze and mine the information. In this paper, we contribute Trans2Graph, a novel graph-based framework for Ethereum data modeling and phishing detection, to fully exploit the massively heterogeneous temporal transaction data. We propose a new paradigm for the fusion of heterogeneous Ethereum data and model the implicit transition relationships among multiple heterogeneous transactions of each Ethereum account into a heterogeneous, temporal, directed multigraph called transaction state transition graph. Empirical analysis shows that phishing accounts have unique patterns in both the heterogeneity and time dynamics of transaction state transition graphs. Based on the analysis, we develop a novel attention-based graph neural network for the learning of heterogeneous temporal state transition graphs and phishing detection. Experiments on a large-scale real-world dataset demonstrate that Trans2Graph achieves a minimum 52.57% improvement in the average precision metric on state-of-the-art account interaction graph-based methods and a minimum 11.52% improvement in average precision on transaction sequence-based methods.

title: Retraction Notice: Customer Behavior Analysis Using Unsupervised Clustering and Profiling: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Akshay C Gopal, Lija Jacob
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Now-a-days, client conduct models are reliably established on information mining of client information, and each model is supposed to answer one solicitation at one point on schedule. Anticipating client conduct is a problematic and irksome task. Thus, making client conduct models requires the right strategy and approach. Right when an estimate model has been fabricated, it is challenging to restrict it for the motivations driving the advertiser, to pick the very thing displaying moves to make for every client or for the party of clients. Notwithstanding the multifaceted nature of this arrangement, most client models are completely fundamental. As the need might arise, most client conduct investigation models ignore such endless proper factors that the gauges they make are overall not altogether strong. This paper plans to encourage a connection rule mining model to expect client conduct using a typical electronic retail store for data combination and concentrate critical examples from the client conduct data. In this undertaking, a solo grouping of information on the customer's records from a regular food item company's data set will be played out. Customer segmentation is the act of clustering customers into bunches that reflect likenesses among customers in each group. Customers are separated into sections to advance the meaning of every customer to the business. To change items as indicated by unmistakable requirements and practices of the customers. It additionally assists the business with obliging the worries of various kinds of customers. Customers were clustered using a technique known as agglomerative clustering, which is a type of hierarchical clustering. Agglomerative clustering is a method for clustering data in a hierarchical order. It entails merging cases until you reach the appropriate n

title: Retraction Notice: Use of Block-chain and Internet of Things (IoT) for Ensuring Privacy and Reliability of Well Being Records in Medical Services
authors: Sunny Verma, Arvind Kumar Pandey, Deepak Kumar Sinha, Chitra Krishnan, Mudasir M Kirmani, Babita Singla
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The medical services framework has key reliability and protection necessities when looked at like as a venture, for example, shielding patients' clinical accounts from undesirable access, safeguarded medication following, protected association with conveyance like ambulances, as well as secure and savvy e-wellbeing observation. Through reasonable safety efforts, distributed ledger technology provides novel ideas reliability and wellbeing of clinical details, and this might accommodate the error among distribution of details and classification. We consolidate qualities of both distributed ledger technology as well as distributed computation in this exploration to give a classification strategy to obstruct chain as well as IoT. This methodology consolidates IoT and conveys IoT administrations to hinder chain hubs; meanwhile, it assembles, analyses, works, and jam in the personality approval for wellbeing material. Cooperation and addresses the deficient registering abilities of some block tie hubs to affirm details legitimacy and possibility.The proposed approach is productive, as exhibited by the reproduction try. It can safeguard and check the honesty of clinical details while additionally resolving issues, for example, high PC intricacy, details trade, and reliability insurance.

title: Robust Viral RNA Sensing Using Non-Negative Matrix Factorization of Optical and Electrochemical Signals._supp1-3636978.docx
authors: Kapil Manoharan
publish: N/A
abstract: Conventional nucleic acid methods often face challenges in achieving both high sensitivity and specificity for reliable detection of viral RNA. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) provides excellent sensitivity but fluorescence readouts often face ambiguity of detection at low template concentrations. Reverse transcription loop mediated isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) integrated with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) enables easy, cost effective, label-free detection and supports portable assays, however, non-specific impedance responses often reduce assay specificity. To overcome these limitations, we apply non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) as a post-processing strategy for heterogeneous biosensing signals. NMF decomposes data into physically interpretable latent components by enforcing non-negativity, making it well suited for effective amplification and detection analysis. Two datasets are analyzed: cycle-dependent fluorescence intensity from RT-PCR and frequency-dependent impedance magnitude from RT-LAMP EIS. NMF successfully discriminates amplification-specific contributions from residual noise, improving sensitivity in fluorescence data and specificity in electrochemical measurements. The resulting component scores enable robust classification of positive and negative samples achieving an overall sensitivity and specificity of 100% and 86.7%, outperforming conventional both optical and electrochemical schemes. Using hepatitis C virus RNA as a representative case, we demonstrate that non-negative decomposition framework offers a generalizable strategy for improving the accuracy of molecular diagnostics across diverse biosensing platforms.

title: Toward Secure and Standardized AI Frameworks in Metaverse-Enabled Cognitive Digital Twins for Healthcare
authors: Jing Yang, Abdullah Ayub Khan, Xiaoteng Yang, Xu Xu, Mahmoud Abdel-Salam, Dayu Hu, Chuan-Zhi Thomas Xie, Por Lip Yee
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: A new generation of consumer electronics known as the “metaverse” leverages the ideas, scope, and protocols of the internet to provide a stable, decentralized virtual environment that is particularly helpful in the medical area. This technical advancement includes the fusion of cutting-edge digital technologies such as blockchain, 3D modeling, augmented and virtual reality-enabled wearable sensors, the consumer Internet of Things, and Autonomous Artificial Intelligence (AAI). The metaverse has given rise to a variety of study paradigms in several domains. Its advancement increases the flexibility of virtual therapy, immersive health education and training, cognitive trials, and other session-related activities in the healthcare industry. This paper explores the effects of digital gaming therapy on the current state of health diagnosis and treatment within this investigation. After identifying these aspects, this paper proposes an innovative and secure architecture, called Meta-EGamofy, to overcome significant issues in cognitive healthcare. We offer a design solution for diagnosing phobias, conducting therapy, and providing treatment through the Sandbox platform by using an immersive game-based therapy method. Extending the definition of the digital twin in meta-EGamofy allows for system management, real-time monitoring, and cognitive health assessments, all while supporting the preservation of the consultant-patient relationship. We prioritize consortium-distributed network-enabled wearable sensor resource optimization in the development of this immersive healthcare solution. Therefore, autonomous artificial intelligence is crucial, especially when it comes to the use of artificial neural networks. In addition, meta-EGamofy may examine customized risk factors, such as vital signs, behaviors, and firsthand observations, supporting consultants in carrying out more thorough evaluations.

title: SA-DEM: Dexterous Extrinsic Robotic Manipulation of Non-Graspable Objects via Stiffness-Aware Dual-Stage Reinforcement Learning_supp1-3634725.mp4
authors: Huixu Dong
publish: N/A
abstract: We propose a novel framework, SA-DEM, for extrinsic non-grasping manipulation of ungraspable objects in robotics. This approach is grounded in dual-stage reinforcement learning and decouples the overall task into two sequential phases: interactive mode decision-making and manipulation action planning. Notably, this framework innovatively incorporates the stiffness information of manipulated objects into the decision-making process, enabling the robot to autonomously perceive, decide, and plan manipulation strategies for objects with diverse physical attributes. The first phase of SA-DEM involves a high-level agent responsible for planning the grasping pose of objects and their interaction locations with the environment, based on the initial state of the objects, observations from environmental point clouds, stiffness representations, and prior knowledge of grasping regions. The second phase is executed by a low-level agent, which focuses on planning specific manipulation actions such as poking and flipping. These actions are derived from autonomous exploration during the training process, negating the need for manual customization. Both agents employ a hybrid discrete-continuous action space along with time-abstracted and spatially grounded representations centered around the point cloud, culminating in a unified actor-critic reinforcement learning framework.

title: Exploiting Self-Adjusted Logical Individual Feature Subspace For Hyperspectral Analysis
authors: Xianjun Fu, Xiaohua Chen, Chunzhi Li
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: It is critical to decompose mixed pixels in a hyperspectral image (HSI) into pure spectral signatures and fractions, known as endmembers and abundances. However, current methods usually combine all endmembers and abundances into a single matrix. However, this approach overlooks the distinct capacity differences of each substance subspace. Furthermore, traditional approaches typically reconstruct without accounting for corresponding errors, resulting in suboptimal outcomes. In this work, we introduce a novel framework that uses self-adjusted individual logical feature (LIF) subspaces for each substance. This enables the accurate modeling of each substance’s unique properties. Our method calculates the capacity of each subspace by unifying the features of each substance, thereby ensuring a more accurate representation. Importantly, our approach balances reconstruction fidelity and error, preventing blind approximation of the observed HSI and addressing overfitting. Additionally, our approach exploits correlations between reconstructed subspaces to minimize redundancy. Extensive experimental results on several datasets demonstrate the superior performance and validity of the proposed method.

title: Proposal and implementation of a medical device monitoring tool usingsmartmeter lines for home healthcare
authors: Ryosuke Nakano, Shunya Hibino, Konosuke Yoshizato, Kosuke Shima, Takanobu Otsuka
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: None

title: Proposal and implementation of an anomaly detection algorithm for predictive maintenance of industrial machinery
authors: Tsubasa Kanda, Syunya Hibino, Takanobu Otsuka
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: None

title: Nonlinear Dynamics of the Colpitts Chaotic Oscillator Under Bias Voltage Tuning
authors: Darja Cirjulina, Sergejs Tjukovs, Ruslans Babajans, Nikolajs Bogdanovs, Dmitrijs Pikulins
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This article investigates the nonlinear dynamics of the Colpitts chaotic oscillator influenced by a DC bias source, proposing a novel method for controlling and stabilizing chaos. Chaotic oscillators are widely utilized in secure communication and random number generation applications, where maintaining robust chaotic behavior is crucial. Traditionally, adjusting the dynamics of analog chaotic oscillators requires modifying hardware components, making transitions between different operating modes complex and impractical. Furthermore, long-term component degradation and variations in nominal values can lead to an unintended transition from chaos to periodicity, compromising system security and performance. In this study, we demonstrate that bias voltage tuning provides a flexible and effective means to control and stabilize the chaotic dynamics of the Colpitts oscillator. The findings establish bias voltage control as a practical and reliable solution for sustaining chaos, ensuring long-term stability and adaptability of chaotic behavior. This method enhances chaotic oscillators’ reliability and practical applicability in security and signal processing applications, reducing dependency on hardware modifications.

title: Study on Time-Delay Characteristics of Field-Breakdown Triggered Vacuum Switch with Different Structures of Trigger Electrode
authors: Liang Bu, Xubin Li, Longfei Yu, Ming Zhang, Gang Lu, Minfu Liao, Xiongying Duan
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Optimizing the delay characteristics of the fieldbreakdown triggered vacuum switch (FTVS) is of great significance for improving the working performance of FTVS. The initial plasma is generated in the trigger gap of FTVS and is greatly influenced by the structure of the trigger electrode. In this paper, the conduction delay characteristics of FTVS under different types of trigger electrode, embedding depths, and lengths of the trigger gap were studied by using detachable vacuum chambers. The experimental results show that among the three types of trigger electrode, the FTVS with the flat-type trigger electrode has the best conduction delay characteristics. When the embedding depth of the trigger gap is within 1 mm, it shows relatively excellent conduction delay characteristics. Under the same working conditions, the conduction delay of FTVS with a trigger gap distance of 0.75 mm is approximately similar to that of FTVS with a trigger gap distance of 0.5 mm. It should be noted that when changing the structure of the trigger electrode, the performance requirements of the FTVS trigger circuit and the changes in the trigger threshold after multiple operations should be taken into account.

title: A Survey on Controller Placement Algorithms for IoT Networks in Smart City Environments
authors: Sheeraz Ali Memon, Darius Andriukaitis, Vytautas Markevicius, Dangirutis Navikas, Algimantas Valinevicius, Mindaugas Zilys, Ramunas Ramanauskas, Roman Sotner, Jan Jerabek, Dardan Klimenta
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) is transforming cities into smart cities by improving efficiency, safety, and sustainability through real-time data collection, analysis and decision making. A main challenge in IoT network is the Controller Placement Problem (CPP), which is essential for minimize latency, balance load, ensure reliability, and optimize energy consumption. This paper reviews 10 algorithms and approaches that have been proposed to solve CPP. To solve the CPP, algorithms minimize latency, improve fault tolerance, balance load, enhance energy efficiency, and ensure scalability. Various algorithms have been proposed to tackle these challenges, each algorithm has unique advantages. Among these algorithms the Hybrid Differential Evolution and Whale Optimization (DEWO) algorithm minimizes latency, improves fault tolerance and balance load. It achieved up to 20.25% performance improvement as compared to PSO in Deutsche topology. For energy efficiency, the Fitness Averaged-Rider Optimization Algorithm (FA-ROA) improves cluster head selection in WSN-IoT networks. It achieved up to 50% better energy efficiency as compared to other algorithms. Other approaches such as GWOAP, Louvain Algorithm with Betweenness-Centrality, CPCSA and Tabu Search Algorithm have also been analyzed for CPP. This review paper provides a detailed analysis of these approaches and algorithms in addressing the complexities of controller placement in IoT networks. By exploring these algorithms this review paper aim to contribute to the development of more efficient, reliable, and scalable smart city infrastructure.

title: Acceleration of Intrusion Prevention System through Integration with Software-Defined Network
authors: Yugo Morimo, Akihiro Takai, Yutaro Furuichi, Nariyoshi Yamai, Rei Nakagawa
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: As a method for configuring firewalls, systems that combine Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) with Software-Defined Networking (SDN) have attracted attention. However, in such systems, since the IDS is responsible only for attack detection and the blocking function is separated and handled by the SDN switch, there is a delay before malicious traffic is actually blocked. This delay consists of the time required for the IDS to detect the attack and to notify the SDN switch, allowing attacks to pass through during this period. This problem can be addressed by replacing the IDS with an Intrusion Prevention System (IPS), which integrates both attack detection and blocking. However, this change leads to a degradation in system performance due to the waiting time for traffic inspection by the IPS. In this research, we introduce two acceleration methods into the system to mitigate the performance degradation caused by replacing IDS with IPS: Benign Flow Bypass and DoS Blocking Offload. As a result of the evaluation, we confirmed the effectiveness of each proposed method. Furthermore, by combining the benign flow bypass and the DoS blocking offload, the system achieved 1.81 times higher performance under DoS attacks compared to the case without any acceleration methods.

title: Experimental study on cathode-initiated and anode-initiated surface flashover with streak camera
authors: Jialin Yang, Ao Xu, Xu Wen Liang, Yuanjie Shi, Yayu Hao
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Surface flashover is a critical factor affecting the reliability and longevity of electrical equipment. Surface flashover includes anode-initiated and cathode-initiated surface flashover. In this article, the time scanning images of the surface flashover under different electrode structures and different current amplitudes under atmospheric conditions are obtained using time-resolved streak photography, and the probabilities of the cathode-initiated and anode-initiated surface flashover under different conditions are calculated. Experimental results indicate that the probability of anode-initiated surface flashover may be related to the electric field intensity and surface charge accumulation near the anode and cathode. This provides experimental support for further study of surface flashover mechanism, and has reference significance for improving the performance of electronic devices.

title: The surface modification method for alumina particles employing pulsed hollow cathode discharge
authors: Zhengjie An, Junping Zhao, Bin Lv, Zhangxiang Lian, Fanyu Kong, Ye Li
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: By depositing diamond-like carbon (DLC) on the surface of alumina particles to modify the filler particle surfaces, a synergistic enhancement in the overall performance of epoxy composites is expected. To address the challenges of particle charging and agglomeration during surface modification, this paper proposes a method for modifying the surfaces of alumina particles using pulsed hollow cathode discharge. A reciprocating particle vibration circulation device was designed, where external vibration was applied to disperse the particles and prevent agglomeration. By enabling the alumina particles to fall uniformly and repeatedly traverse the plasma zone, uniform surface modification of the particles was achieved. This method enables efficient surface modification of alumina particles, with a DLC growth rate exceeding $34 \mathrm{~nm} / \mathrm{h}$. By selecting an appropriate pulse voltage amplitude, DLC coatings with $\mathbf{s p}^{\mathbf{3}}$ carbon atoms content exceeding $60 \%$ can be deposited. This lays the foundation for the development of fillers for high-thermal-conductivity epoxy composites.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Enhanced Risk Prediction for Enterprises: An Adaptive AI Approach
authors: Xuan Guo, Qingze Yu

title: Research on Virtual Try-on Immersive Recommendation Based on Multimodal Large Model
authors: Xue Fan, Jiahao Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Traditional e-commerce recommendation systems often struggle with processing multimodal data, addressing cold start challenges, and delivering immersive user experiences. To overcome these limitations, this study introduces a novel framework—M2VTT-Rec (Multimodal Model-driven Virtual Try-on Recommendation)—which aims to transform personalized recommendations in online retail. The M2VTT-Rec framework deeply incorporates users' multimodal interactions during virtual try-on sessions—including real-time imagery, biometric signals, facial expressions, and voice cues—alongside multimodal product knowledge, such as 3D product models and design semantics.The system features a cutting-edge module for sensing and encoding try-on data across modalities, coupled with a fine-grained preference alignment network and a bidirectional reinforcement learning mechanism that captures user visual inclinations and evolving interests. Furthermore, a context-sensitive recommendation generator is designed to produce rich multimodal outfit suggestions and interpretable narrative explanations.Empirical evaluation using a purpose-built multimodal virtual try-on dataset shows that M2VTT-Rec achieves superior performance over the baseline ALS model on key metrics like Recall@10 and NDCG@10, with especially strong results in various cold start scenarios. Additionally, it markedly improves the average session duration and boosts user engagement and satisfaction across user segments with different purchasing habits. Ablation studies further validate the essential roles of multimodal implicit feedback representation and reinforcement learning in achieving these outcomes. Overall, this research presents a forward-looking approach for applying multimodal large models in vertical domains such as e-commerce, paving the way for more intelligent, interactive recommendation systems.

title: Forecasting Excess Returns: Extension to Fama-French Using Volatility, Overnight Trading, and Machine Learning
authors: Allison Hu, Jiabao Zhang, Junyan Liu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: We examine whether incorporating volatility measures (VIXCLS and VXAPL), overnight returns, and their interaction terms enhances the predictability of monthly excess returns beyond the traditional Fama-French Five-Factor (FF5) model. Using both market-level (S&P 500) and firm-level (Apple Inc.) data from 2016 to 2024, we assess forecasting performance under extended linear models and compare outcomes across different volatility sources. Our results show that including volatility and overnight trading effects significantly improves model prediction, especially when firm-specific volatility is used. Interaction terms between volatility and overnight returns occasionally achieve significance, suggesting nonlinear dynamics in return generation. While the linear models capture substantial predictive patterns at the monthly level, the use of machine learning methods does not consistently outperform them, likely due to limited sample size.

title: Model Predictive Sensorless Control for Low-Speed Considering Low Carrier Frequency Drive
authors: Takashi Mitsunaga, Sari Maekawa, Ryosuke Saito, Yuki Kumakiri, Akira Nakazawa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: In recent years, Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (IPMSMs) have been widely adopted in household appliances, railway systems, and automobiles. In high power applications of PMSMs, the carrier frequency of the inverter is often intentionally lowered to minimize switching losses. However, lowering the carrier frequency increases the control cycle period, which degrades the responsiveness and stability of current control, sensorless control, etc. The high-frequency square-wave-type voltage injection method is a sensorless control that estimates the rotor position by utilizing the magnetic saliency of IPMSMs, and it is effective in standstill and low-speed operation. This method allows the injection voltage frequency to reach up to the carrier frequency, enabling efficient extraction of high-frequency components even under low carrier frequency operation. Model Predictive Control (MPC) has attracted attention for its high responsiveness, and prior research has explored its application in current control, speed control, and back-EMF based sensorless control for PMSMs. In this paper, we propose a sensorless control method for standstill and low-speed operation under intentionally low carrier frequency, by applying MPC to the high-frequency square-wave-type voltage injection method. The proposed method is evaluated in comparison with conventional PI-based control. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves higher responsiveness than conventional PI control both at standstill and low-speed and under low carrier frequency conditions.

title: Triangles and Tribulations: Translations, Betrayals, and the Making of Cultural-Historical Activity Theory: Clay Spinuzzi: [Book Review]
authors: Mason Pellegrini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Professional Communication

title: Retraction Notice: Review on the methods involved in Blockchain Technology
authors: Priyanka Bhardwaj, Appoorva Bansal
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Blockchain is hailed as a technological breakthrough that has the potential to change social transactions and interaction methods. This is largely because it allows mutually distrustful organizations to exchange information without relying on the financial value of trusted third parties and interacting parties. In addition, the blockchain provides integrity-protected system storage and data distribution. We examine if blockchain is a good idea and the finest possible solution for a certain application situation in this study. We offer a structured technique for determining the optimal technological option for a particular application scenario. Applying our framework, we explore three usage cases in depth: Supply Chain Management, Interbank and International Payments, and Decentralized Autonomous Organizations, and conclude the essay with a look forward to vast prospects.

title: Retraction Notice: Management of Business Using Machine Learning for Decision Making
authors: Geetha Manoharan, P. Nithya Preetha, Nandhini. S, K. Santhanalakshmi, K.D. Balaji, Vijay Raja
publish: 2024 International Conference on Trends in Quantum Computing and Emerging Business Technologies
abstract: Businesses throughout the world are focusing on extracting more benefit from information gathered from different places. The goal of this investiagtion is to look at the main elements of machine learning (ML) for arriving at optimal economic decisions. Business management are today confronted with a massive amount of data that must be kept, examined, and recovered in order to arrive at successful decisions and gain a competitive benefit. ML is primarily concerned with managing business processes with little or no human participation. The ML approaches allow for the analysis and recognition of patterns in big data sets and offer the required data to business management for successful decision making in various sectors such as economics, advertising, logistics, human resources, etc.ML allows the shift from physically preserved information to digitally recorded information, allows increasing memory, and aids with economic decision-making among additional things. ML additionally allows the extraction of quality signals and predicting information from the dataset and stimulates development. The utilization of ML has become an essential tool that is being utilized in the present compatible sector, and it has provided additional possibilities for business management to leverage a great deal of information. This research is concentrated on tackling the utilization of ML in creating successful economical decision making for businesses management. To explore the role of ML in economical decision making, the project aims to gather information from staff, supervisors, and corporate executives in a variety of sectors.

title: AIEEE 2025 Breaker Page
authors: N/A

title: Federated Prior Learning with Uncertainty Mitigation for Heterogeneous Distributed Devices
authors: Fangyu Li, Xuqiang Chen, Jinghao Liu, Yu Wang, Honggui Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Collaboratively deployed across thousands of networked clients, federated learning (FL) is influenced by the degradation of statistical heterogeneity and noise from mobile devices. Although existing FL approaches adopt optimization solutions for improving reliability, the reliability of the model is difficult to guarantee. As the assessment of reliability lacks the exploration of local data, effectively gauging model performance based solely on inherent data characteristics is challenging. Therefore, we propose an uncertainty-aware federated prior learning (FedPL) to increase the reliability of the global model by mitigating the prediction uncertainty. FedPL constructs a client selection based on the uncertainty of the categorical prior in each client where data uncertainty can be perceived in the server. Furthermore, FedPL rectifies the local uncertainty quantification (UQ) to increase the consistency between the global server and volatile clients. By aligning local models with the global uncertainty level, FedPL fosters a more effective generalization of the local models towards the global objective. In the comparison of the status quo, our experiments demonstrate that FedPL effectively enhances the reliability of the global model in terms of reliability indicators. Furthermore, FedPL demonstrates resilience to noise, delivering reliable predictions that outperform other state-of-the-arts (SOTA) algorithms.

title: Efficient Travel Time Estimation Between Geographical Locations Using Derived Nonlinear Spatial Features for Offline VRP Optimization
authors: Sanghwan Lee, Jinsoo Moon
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Real-world Vehicle Routing Problems (VRPs) often require computing travel times between tens of thousands of geographic locations to plan routes for hundreds of vehicles. For example, during the COVID-19 vaccine distribution in Korea, hundreds of vehicles were tasked with delivering vaccines to thousands of destinations each week. Solving such VRPs necessitates estimating pairwise travel times between origin-destination (OD) pairs, a process that scales quadratically with the number of destinations. Existing travel time estimation methods typically focus on individual routes and rely on rich contextual data such as GPS trajectories, road types, traffic volume, and weather conditions. While accurate, these methods are computationally expensive and impractical for large-scale VRPs due to their input requirements and inefficiency. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an efficient and scalable deep learning-based travel time estimation approach designed for datasets with limited features. Our model uses only geocoordinates and departure times as inputs, and enhances predictive accuracy by incorporating derived nonlinear spatial features specifically, geodesic and Manhattan-style distances.We also investigate the effect of other derived input features, such as second-order polynomials of the basic inputs, to assess whether they contribute to performance improvement. This lightweight input representation enables rapid O(n2) inference, making it suitable for VRP-scale scenarios. We also investigate the effects of architectural choices, including batch normalization, loss function variants, and input normalization, on model performance. When geodesic distance is added as an input feature, the validation loss (MSE) drops to about 14 % of the value obtained with coordinates alone, and the cumulative probability of achieving a relative error of at most 0.2 rises from 25 % to more than 50 %. These quantitative gains demonstrate high predictive accuracy and strong generalization to unseen OD pairs, suggesting that the proposed framework is a practical and effective solution for large-scale, real-world VRP applications.

title: CL-DRW: Curriculum Learning-Based Deep Robust Watermarking for Social Networks
authors: Yingshuai Zhao, Guopu Zhu, Jiantao Zhou, Xiaolong Li, Hongli Zhang, Xinpeng Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: The development of the internet has greatly facilitated the transmission of images over social networks, while also triggering serious copyright issues. Deep robust watermarking serves as a crucial technique for image copyright protection. However, the image distortions caused by Social Network Transmission Operations (SNTOs) make existing deep robust watermarking methods fragile in real-world social network scenarios. To address this, we propose a Curriculum Learning-based Deep Robust Watermarking method, called CL-DRW, to generate watermarks that can be resilient to SNTOs. Specifically, we develop a watermarking model constructed with an invertible neural network and present a multi-stage training framework based on curriculum learning to train it effectively. We incrementally introduce noise attacks based on their disruptive impact on the watermark, from weak to strong, thereby enabling our model to build robustness against SNTOs gradually. Additionally, we design an SNTOs simulation noise layer, which is built upon a transformer-based deep network and incorporates differentiable JPEG, to simulate the black-box distortions caused by SNTOs. Extensive experiments indicate that our proposed CL-DRW outperforms state-of-the-art deep watermarking methods in terms of robustness against real-world social network transmission operations. Source code is available at https://github.com/yingshuai-zhao/CL-DRW.

title: Covert Low-Altitude Economy Networks
authors: Xiuzhao Ji, Bo Li, Jifa Zhang, Hongjuan Yang, Xu Jiang, Nan Zhao, George Karagiannidis, Arumugam Nallanathan
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications
abstract: Low-altitude economy (LAE) has emerged and developed, driven by the advanced technologies and policies to provide a variety of low-altitude services, such as logistics and helicopter taxi. However, LAE suffers from the security problems due to the high probability of line-of-sight (LoS) channel. Compared with other security technologies, covert communication technology can achieve higher security by hiding the information transmission behavior. Therefore, in this article, we investigate the covert communication in LAE. First, we introduce the relevant applications and corresponding advantages in detail, and briefly introduce covert communication in LAE networks. Then, we discuss the approaches to realize covert communication in LAE. Furthermore, a case study is proposed to improve the covertness of a novel bidirectional communication scenario in LAE networks, which maximizes the weighted covert rate by jointly optimizing the user association, aircraft trajectory, and transmit power of users and aircraft. Simulation results show that the proposed scheme outperforms benchmarks. Finally, some challenges and future directions are discussed.

title: Screening Current-Induced Stress and Strain Analysis Considering a Non-uniform Thickness Profile of REBCO Tapes
authors: Yu Suetomi, Shannon Griffin, Hongyu Bai, Mark Bird, Dmytro Abraimov, Adonay Almanza-Enriquez, Noah Gavin, Jun Lu, Iain R. Dixon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Winding compressibility (WCP) is a significant reduction in the effective radial Young's modulus of REBCO pancake coils compared with the sum of the various macroscopic components, due to microscopic asperities on the tape surface and/or a non-uniform tape profile. For pancakes that are impregnated either not at all or with something soft like paraffin, this has a substantial impact on the screening current induced stress (SCIS) calculation. In this study, we propose a modeling technique called Penalty Function with Gap Offset (PGO) that incorporates non-uniform tape profiles as a gap offset distribution within contact boundaries. We also evaluate the effectiveness of reinforcement options—co-winding (CW), over-banding (OB), and outer ring (OR)— by considering winding compressibility.

title: IEEE Computer Society Call for Papers
authors: N/A

title: Concurrent and Orthogonal Software Power Meters for Accurate Runtime Energy Profiling of Parallel Hybrid Programs on Heterogeneous Hybrid Servers
authors: Hafiz Adnan Niaz, Ravi Reddy Manumachu, Alexey Lastovetsky
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Energy predictive models employing performance events have emerged as a promising alternative to other mainstream methods for developing software power meters used in runtime energy profiling of applications. These models are cost-effective and provide a highly accurate means of measuring the energy consumption of applications during execution. Recently, software power meters have been proposed to profile the dynamic energy consumption of data transfers between CPU and GPU in heterogeneous hybrid platforms, thereby effectively addressing the gap between software power meters that measure computations and those that measure data transfers. However, the state-of-the-art software power meters lack fundamental properties essential for achieving accurate runtime energy profiling of parallel hybrid programs on heterogeneous hybrid servers. Two critical properties are concurrency and orthogonality. In this work, we define these essential properties and propose a methodology for developing concurrent and orthogonal platform-level software power meters capable of accurate runtime energy profiling of parallel hybrid programs on heterogeneous hybrid servers. We apply this methodology to develop software power meters for three heterogeneous hybrid servers that consist of Intel multicore CPUs and Nvidia GPUs from different generations. Furthermore, we demonstrate the accuracy and efficiency of the proposed software power meters by using them to estimate the dynamic energy consumption of computation and communication activities in three parallel hybrid programs. Our results show that the average prediction error for dynamic energy consumption by these software power meters is just 2.5% across our servers.
