title: A Deep Learning Model for Integrating Landsat-8 and Sentinel 2 Satellite Images to Improve the Spatiotemporal Fusion Network for Drought Monitoring
authors: Aravinth J, Anand R
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: This study proposes a deep learning model for the integration of Landsat-8 and Sentinel satellite imagery to enhance the spatial, spectral, and temporal resolution of drought forecasting. Landsat-8 offers a superior spatial resolution but lower temporal frequency, whereas Sentinel imagery provides a higher temporal frequency but a reduced spatial resolution. The integration of these datasets mitigates the limitations inherent in each dataset, thereby improving the quality of Earth observation data and creating a more robust dataset for precise monitoring of droughts. Correlation analysis revealed that the fused dataset achieved stronger relationships between VCI and NDWI (r = 0.72) and between VCI and SPEI (r = 0.65) than the relationships achieved using the Sentinel-2 (r = 0.68, r = 0.62) and Landsat-8 (r = 0.60, r = 0.58) datasets. A Bi-Directional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) model was then applied to predict SPEI-12 from the vegetation and hydrological variables. The model achieved an R2; of 0.7946 and an RMSE of 0.5709, indicating a strong agreement between the predicted and observed drought values. Compared with conventional LSTM and Random Forest models, the Bi- LSTM showed approximately 9–12% improvement in R2; and a 15–20% reduction in RMSE, demonstrating superior capability in capturing nonlinear vegetation-climate dependencies.

title: Retraction Notice: Critical monitoring of the crops and conditions though IoT for agricultural systems
authors: Rachit Adhvaryu, Akash Kumar Bhagat
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: A real time management system is the major part of well-designed IoT (Internet of Things). Under IoT methods, wireless networks accomplish energy usage through power management. Sensing nodes, constructed on sensor networks, deliver effectual energy management meant for innovative connections. To encourage smart agricultural systems over conventional methods, it is necessary to execute IoT and other technologies. In a survey of execution and benefits of IoT, mainly three questions have been asked form 70 people. Whose analysis has been presented in the research. After analysis simple IoT system can be affordable but after including extra features increase the cost. Also, in villages there is a problem of poor internet connectivity that leads to lack of transfer of data from farmers and agricultural analysts.

title: Robot Active Task Cognition: Situation-Aware Task Planning with Large Language Models
authors: Ying Zhang, Shaohan Bian, Jin Liu, Renjie Song, Danni Zhu, Cui-Hua Zhang, Changchun Hua
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: This paper introduces a robot active task cognition framework for Situation-Aware Task Planning (SATP), leveraging visual scene understanding to generate action sequences. By integrating object knowledge, user preferences, and Large Language Models (LLMs), SATP interprets the robot’s current visual perception, and creates procedural actions that align with what the robot “sees”. Diverging from conventional methods requiring explicit verbal commands, our SATP framework autonomously performs task cognition, actively formulating robot-executable action sequences directly from visual input. Initially, a novel approach for describing the visual scene is presented, enabling the robot to grasp detailed object-level properties and inter-object relationships based on its observations. Building on this, a knowledge base for active task cognition is constructed using ontology technology. Furthermore, we develop a two-stage dual-feedback task planner, ReProg+, powered by LLMs, specifically designed for situation-aware task planning grounded in visual data. The efficacy, reliability, and advantages of our solution are thoroughly validated in real-world visual scenarios. Additionally, SATP has been tested with a real robot, with results confirming the feasibility and effectiveness of our approach.

title: Temperature- and Energy-aware Dynamic Task Scheduling and Computing Resource Allocation for Satellite Computing
authors: Chao Wang, Xiao Ma, Chuanxiu Chi, Ao Zhou, Ruolin Xing, Shangguang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Satellite computing, as an emerging edge computing paradigm, extends computing and networking services into space. Due to the internal design constraints of low-Earth orbit (LEO) satellites and the challenges posed by the external environment, satellite computing faces inherent limitations, including severely constrained resources, non-rechargeable batteries, poor heat dissipation, and highly dynamic operating conditions, leading to unreliable and unsustainable quality of service. To address the above challenges and fully realize the potential of satellite computing, this paper investigates temperature- and energy-aware dynamic task scheduling and computing resource allocation, aiming to optimize service latency, reduce onboard energy consumption, and enhance operational profit. Solving this problem requires coordinating task scheduling and resource allocation, balancing communication and computation latency, and addressing the challenge of a vast search space. To solve the above challenges, we first formulate this problem as a repeated Stackelberg game by developing temperature and energy models. Through theoretical analysis, we show that this game leads to a convex optimization framework that exhibits exponential complexity. To accelerate the search for the Stackelberg equilibrium solution, we propose a dynamic task scheduling algorithm based on the interior point method, which reduces the computational complexity to polynomial order. Trace-driven simulations demonstrate that the proposed algorithm reduces task scheduling latency by 28.4% and improves utility by 13% on average.

title: Max-Min Computation Optimization in Multi-BS WPT-MEC Networks via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Bincheng Zhu, Shaojun Zhu, Kaikai Chi, Shahid Mumtaz, Wael Bazzi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Wireless power transfer enhanced mobile edge computing (WPT-MEC) has emerged as a key technology to support low-latency and energy-efficient computation in wireless networks. With increasing network density, multi-base-station architectures emerge where wireless devices (WDs) offload tasks to distributed base stations (BSs), creating challenges in maintaining quality-of-service fairness during complex resource coordination in multi-BS WPT-MEC networks. To address these challenges, we investigate a non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA)-enhanced WPT-MEC network comprising multiple WDs and BSs with finite computational capacities. For ensuring fairness, we formulate a max-min problem to maximize the minimum task computation amount by jointly optimizing offloading decisions, NOMA decoding orders, offloading powers and time resource allocation, which results in a challenging mixed integer, sequence and nonlinear programming (MISNLP). To tackle this problem, we propose a two-stage distributed multi-agent algorithm. In the first stage, each BS agent generates offloading preferences based on partial observations, guiding WDs' offloading decisions. In the second stage, given these offloading decisions, we develop an efficient convex-based algorithm to solve the per-BS resource allocation subproblem, jointly optimizing NOMA decoding order, offloading powers and time resource allocation. For effective training, we leverage off-policy training and the centralized training with decentralized execution (CTDE) paradigm with two key innovations: (1) a convex-based critic that evaluates the joint action without bias, and (2) a counterfactual baseline that isolates individual agent credit assignment. The proposed C3MA algorithm achieves six times faster convergence and at least 20% performance improvement when serving more than 20 WDs, compared with existing multi-agent schemes, while maintaining a near-optimal Jain's fairness index of 0.97. Moreover, it sustains an ultra-low execution delay below 5 milliseconds even with 40 WDs, confirming its efficiency and scalability.

title: Gaussian Universality for Diffusion Models
authors: Reza Ghane, Anthony Bao, Danil Akhtiamov, Babak Hassibi
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: We investigate Gaussian Universality for data distributions generated via diffusion models. By Gaussian Universality we mean that the test error of a generalized linear model <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$f(\bf {W})$</tex-math></inline-formula> trained for a classification task on the diffusion data matches the test error of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$f(\bf {W})$</tex-math></inline-formula> trained on the Gaussian Mixture with matching means and covariances per class. In other words, the test error depends only on the first and second order statistics of the diffusion-generated data in the linear setting. As a corollary, the analysis of the test error for linear classifiers can be reduced to Gaussian data from diffusion-generated data. Analyzing the performance of models trained on synthetic data is a pertinent problem due to the surge of methods such as [1]. Moreover, we show that, for any 1- Lipschitz scalar function <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\phi$</tex-math></inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\phi (\mathbf {x})$</tex-math></inline-formula> is close to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbb {E}\phi (\bf {x})$</tex-math></inline-formula> with high probability for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {x}$</tex-math></inline-formula> sampled from the conditional diffusion model corresponding to each class. Finally, we note that current approaches for proving universality do not apply to diffusion-generated data as the covariance matrices of the data tend to have vanishing minimum singular values, contrary to the assumption made in the literature. This leaves extending previous mathematical universality results as an intriguing open question.

title: Bistatic Radar Cross Section of Curved Plates using Curved Screen Uniform Theory of Diffraction
authors: Krishna Mohan Boga, Divyabramham Kandimalla, Arijit De
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radar Systems
abstract: In this paper, the bistatic radar cross section of curved plates has been presented using the curved screen uniform theory of diffraction for a bistatic angle 45°. The reflected field formulations for both convex side and concave side incidences on the cylindrically curved screen are provided for the bistatic case. The incident field and reflected field phase detours are obtained for the bistatic case as they are essential in formulating the diffracted field. These phase detours play a critical role in providing the continuity of the fields at and around the shadow boundaries due to the straight edges of the curved screen. In addition, the reciprocity condition has been verified with respect to the case of grazing incidence at the edges. The electromagnetic scattering due to plane wave incidence on the concave side of the curved screen is also presented using the curved screen uniform theory of diffraction. The predictions of the curved screen uniform theory of diffraction are compared with the results of the method of moments based electromagnetic simulation tool.

title: F-YOLO: Delving into Fuzzy YOLO for Improved Traffic Object Detection
authors: Ning Jia, Jiaxiong Yang, Xianhui Liu, Yougang Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems
abstract: Object detection plays a pivotal role in intelligent transportation systems. In recent years, the rapid advancements in deep learning have propelled object detection to a new level. However, the complexity of traffic environments and the inherent limitations of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) in dealing with feature uncertainty have collectively resulted in a stagnation in the development of traffic object detection. To surmount these challenges, this study explores the combination of fuzzy theory with deep learning object detectors. Specifically, the features are first transformed into the fuzzy domain through fuzzification, and then the improved lightweight fuzzy inference method is employed for information interaction and selection, effectively managing and mitigating feature uncertainty. By merging the fuzzy strategy with YOLOv6 framework, a novel Fuzzy-based YOLO-style detector (F-YOLO) was proposed. F-YOLO is distinguished by three key innovations: the fuzzy fusion module, the fuzzy attention mechanism and the GPBblock. These components respectively bolster multi-scale feature fusion in the neck, refine prediction efficiency in the head, and enhance the global contextual learning of the backbone. Comprehensive experiments conducted across various datasets, including those tailored for traffic object detection, establish F-YOLO's state-of-the-art (SOTA) performance in YOLO-style detectors. F-YOLO demonstrates robustness and wide applicability, notably surpassing comparison models by 20.7% on VisDrone2019 dataset, 1.3% on BDD100K, and 6.2% on UA-DETRAC. Furthermore, F-YOLO also achieved competitive results on the MS COCO dataset.

title: Vacuum Arc Behavior Simulation by Moving Particle Semi-implicit Method + Finite Volume Method with Improved Electron Density Calculation
authors: Yasunori Tanaka, Tatsuya Haneda, Yusuke Nakano, Tatsuo Ishijima, Shinji Yamamoto, Gaku Asanuma, Toshiyuki Onchi
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: This study refines the numerical simulation of arcs in vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs) by improving the electron density calculation within a hybrid moving particle semi-implicit (MPS) and finite volume method (FVM) model. The VCB extinguishes the arc in high vacuum environments by metal vapor diffusion during the current interruption process. In the hybrid method, instabilities in the electron density conversion from MPS to FVM have hindered simulation accuracy. By extending the electron density distribution range in the FVM framework, the 37-mesh model achieved smoother electron and current density distributions than the 9-mesh model, improving numerical stability. These results contribute to the understanding of vacuum arc behavior.

title: Probing and Modeling the Memory Effect in Vacuum Breakdowns
authors: Sophie A. Spencer, Siobhan McKeown, Julien Rault, Chia-Jung Yang, Edgar A. Engel
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum interrupters are a key technology for current interruption in medium- and high-voltage electricity distribution networks. For certification, they must, among other requirements, withstand standardized lighting impulse voltages. This renders efficient and reliable means of assessing withstand capability critical to the design and development of vacuum interrupters. Crucially, the processes underlying failures to withstand an applied voltage are stochastic, so such assessments require statistical testing. These tests are commonly performed under the assumption that the responses (withstand or breakdown) to applied voltage pulses are statistically independent. However, the response of vacuum gaps is known to exhibit memory effects (or “hysteresis”) and can depend sensitively on factors such as experimental setup, testing procedure, and electrode material. In this study, we consider two testing schemes and demonstrate that the resultant estimates of $2 \%$ probability breakdown voltage differ substantially. We further note a strong correlation between breakdown probability and the number of withstood pulses since the last breakdown. To capture this correlation, we propose a novel, history-dependent model of breakdown probability. While this model does not reflect the variety of physical mechanisms that could plausibly induce memory effects, it allows us to reconcile the seemingly conflicting data from both testing schemes. It thereby opens the door to comparing test results obtained in different campaigns using different procedures in a meaningful manner. This in turn promises insights into the withstand performance of vacuum gaps that were previously obscured by inconsistencies due to inadequate treatment of the correlated nature of responses.

title: A Review of Mechanical Condition Evaluation and Fault Diagnosis of High Voltage Vacuum Circuit Breakers
authors: Jie Zhang, Yong Wang, Junxiang Liu, Lu Zhu, Jun Xiao
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Most of the faults in the operation of high-voltage vacuum circuit breakers (CBs) occur in the operating mechanism, and the accidents caused by mechanical failures account for the highest proportion. Therefore, it is of great practical engineering value to carry out the research on mechanical condition evaluation and fault diagnosis of vacuum CBs. In this paper, according to the relevant research on mechanical condition evaluation and fault diagnosis of high-voltage CB at home and abroad in recent years, firstly, the fault mechanism is analyzed from the typical faults of the CB; furthermore, the advantages and disadvantages of the current commonly used methods of mechanical condition evaluation and fault diagnosis of the CB are compared, and it is pointed out that accurate extraction of feature signals is the key to drive the evaluation of the CB’s mechanical condition, and that the multi-source data joint fault diagnosis method based on the artificial intelligence algorithm is the key to the future research. fault diagnosis method is the hotspot and difficult point for future research. Finally, the development trend of mechanical condition evaluation of high-voltage vacuum CBs is further outlooked to lay a foundation for subsequent in-depth research.

title: Greedy Selection Algorithm for Task Offloading in Urban V2V Networks with Traffic Simulation
authors: Shangjie Zhuang, Yihang Liu, Yancong Deng
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: None

title: Selective Wireless Power Transfer Using High-PAPR Signals
authors: Kristaps Gailis, Romāns Kušņins, Juris Grizāns, Dmitrijs Pikuļins
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Wireless power transfer (WPT) using radio frequency (RF) signals offers a promising solution for remote energy delivery. However, a key challenge is ensuring that only intended receivers can efficiently harvest the transmitted power while preventing unintended devices from gaining sufficient energy. In this work, we propose a novel methodology where the transmitter utilizes high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) signals, and power conversion is enabled only through specialized receiver circuitry. Unintended receivers cannot efficiently convert the RF energy into usable power without this dedicated circuit. We present theoretical analysis and simulation results demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach in achieving selective power transfer while minimizing leakage to unauthorized devices.

title: Breakdown Characteristics of Double Vacuum Gaps in Series under Lightning Impulse Voltages with Different Polarities
authors: Jingyu Shen, Haodong Ma, Zhihong Xu, Yingsan Geng, Zhiyuan Liu, Jianhua Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to quantitatively investigate the breakdown (BD) characteristics for double vacuum gaps in series under lightning impulse voltages (LIVs) with different polarities. In the test, the double vacuum gaps were achieved by series connecting two pairs of copper sphereplane electrodes with diameters of 18 and 50 mm, respectively. The experimental results revealed that, there existed a polarity effect of BD voltage for double vacuum gaps. The BD voltage under positive LIV was higher than that under negative LIV. When the total gap distance was 1.5 mm, the difference between the BD voltage under positive and negative LIVs was only 2.1 kV. The increase in gap distance would enlarge this difference and make the polarity effect more significant, which reached 19.5 kV at 3.0 mm. Through the electric field analysis, the polarity effect of BD voltage should be mainly induced by the difference of maximum electric field strengths at cathode under positive and negative LIVs.

title: A Simplified Equivalent Circuit Model for the Post-Arc Sheath in VCBs and Circuit Parameter Calculation Based on the PIC-MCC Method
authors: Xubin Li, Xingyu Guo, Wen Wang, Minfu Liao, Xiaoming Liu, Jiyan Zou
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Post-arc sheath expansion in vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs) is the first critical phase of dielectric recovery. This study employs a simplified equivalent circuit model (SECM), representing the sheath as a parallel capacitor-resistor network. Circuit parameters, including capacitance and resistance, are calculated at different times using the Particle-in-Cell and Monte Carlo Collision (PIC-MCC) model. The postarc current, derived from the combined capacitor and resistor currents under applied TRV, is compared with experimental data to validate the SECM and parameter calculations.

title: Influence of Current Amplitude and Arcing Time on MVDC Switching Capability of Butt and AMF Contact Geometries
authors: Manuel Nierenberg, Timo Meyer, Myriam Koch, Michael Kurrat
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: DC interrupters are a fundamental enabling technology for the implementation of meshed DC grids. When interrupting DC using an artificial current zero, both the arcing time and the current amplitude are critical parameters that influence the interruption performance. For this purpose, butt and axial magnetic field contacts, originally designed for AC interruption, have been subjected to a variety of DC amplitudes and arcing times in a model vacuum interrupter. The interruption behavior of each contact geometry showed a strong dependency on the short circuit current amplitude. In this setup, butt contacts started to fail at lower current amplitudes and arcing times compared to axial magnetic field contacts. Due to high local current densities, an increased amount of metal vapor plasma within the contact gap caused this breakdown behavior. Since the switching performance of vacuum interrupters strongly depends on the amount of charge carriers present in the contact gap at current zero, this phenomenon must be considered when developing contact geometries for DC interruption. This study shows that vacuum interrupters exhibit reduced switching performance when interrupting static constricted vacuum arcs compared to diffuse vacuum arcs. The behavior of rotating constricted arcs, however, remains to be investigated and compared to diffuse arcs.

title: Comparative study on the properties of copper-chromium contacts prepared by two powder metallurgy processes
authors: Xiaoqing Yang, Xiaojun Wang, Peng Li, Yong Wang, Gang Li, Ning Han
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: CuCr material has high voltage resistance and excellent breaking capacity, and is widely used in medium and high voltage vacuum interrupters. The preparation process of CuCr is mainly divided into four types, powder metallurgy process, vacuum infiltration process, vacuum casting process and vacuum arc melting process, among which the CuCr material produced via powder metallurgy is extensively employed as contact material in circuit breaker interrupters under low contact force owing to its superior resistance to welding. At present, the preparation process of CuCr contact materials prepared by powder metallurgy is mainly divided into single press single sinter(SPSS) and double press double sinter(DPDS). This study employs CuCr30 alloy composition to conduct a comparative investigation on the performance of contact materials fabricated using these two preparation processes. The results indicate that the contact material processed by SPSS exhibits lower homogeneity than that processed by DPDS. Specifically, the single-processed material demonstrates approximately $\mathbf{1. 5 4 \%}$ to $\mathbf{2. 2 5 \%}$ lower density, 1.1 to 2.2 HB lower hardness, and $0.1 \%$ to $0.7 \%$ IACS lower electrical conductivity at the edge region relative to the center. In contrast, the double pressed and double sintered CuCr30 contact material shows virtually no difference between edge and central areas.

title: Sun-Tracking Microwave Radiometry with Dynamic Beam Modeling for All-Weather Atmospheric and Solar Characterization at W-Band
authors: M. Biscarini, G. Stazi, L. Milani, G. Brost
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In this work, we present an enhanced Sun-Tracking Microwave Radiometry approach for atmospheric and solar characterization at millimeter-wave frequencies, specifically at W-band. Sun-Tracking radiometry is a ground-based technique that uses the Sun as a stable natural source to simultaneously estimate the Sun's brightness temperature and the atmospheric optical thickness. We propose a dynamic modeling of the Sun–Earth geometry to account for seasonal variations, achieving a 50% reduction in the standard deviation of the Sun brightness temperature compared to previous studies. For the first time, we quantify the impact of Sun brightness temperature estimation errors on the retrieval of atmospheric attenuation, addressing an open issue previously unassessed in the literature. The analysis relies on a long-term dataset collected over three years in Rome, NY (USA), representing one of the few ground-based databases capable of statistically characterizing atmospheric attenuation in all-weather conditions at K-, Ka-, V-, and W-bands. Results confirm that improvements in Sun brightness temperature estimation do not compromise the precision of atmospheric optical thickness retrievals, validating the robustness and reliability of the enhanced Sun-Tracking technique. These findings offer new insights for microwave remote sensing and propagation studies at millimeter wavelengths, supporting next-generation satellite communication and remote sensing systems.

title: Retraction Notice: The Deep Analysis of Accuracy of Performance Level of NBC Algorithm for Diagnosing BC
authors: P. Valarmathi, M Ramchander, Sampathirao Suneetha, P. Sasirekha, Saad Khudhur Mohammed, Ahmed Hussain
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: These days, breast cancer is the foremost predominant cancer among ladies around the world and one of the driving causes of cancer-related mortality. In this ponder, an existing Observation, The study of disease transmission, and Conclusion Comes about (Diviner) dataset is utilized to assess the survival rate of breast cancer patients. Numerous of the profound and machine learning strategies accessible nowadays are so great that they can illuminate a wide course of categorization issues based on precise consider of large-scale datasets. These advances are broadly utilized in most biomedical investigate disciplines. Careful information planning, counting both investigation and visualization, offers pivotal bits of knowledge to support basic decision-making within the field. In this article, Soothsayer breast cancer information is classified utilizing machine learning based strategies. Furthermore, a two-step highlight choice strategy utilizing Foremost Component Examination and Change Edge is utilized to extricate pertinent highlights from the dataset. The dataset is classified utilizing Administered and Outfit learning approaches, counting Ada Boosting, XG Boosting, Incline Boosting, Naive Bayes varieties, and Choice Tree calculations, once the chosen highlights have been removed from the breast cancer dataset. The diverse machine learning techniques are totally overviewed with the utilize of train-test portion and k fold cross-validation. In specific, the Choice Tree calculation works exceptionally well, showing an outstandingly tall accuracy rate in both the train-test part and cross-validation procedures. Subsequently, for the Diviner Breast Cancer dataset, this inquire about illustrates the predominance of the choice Tree over the other elective approaches in Administered and Outfit learning procedures and gives a

title: Retraction Notice: A Deep Assessment of ML Based Procedure used as a Classifiers in the Clinical Field
authors: Kuldeep Sharma, A Madeswaran, Awadhesh Chandramauli, V Narasimha, Laith Jasim, Y. Mary Reeja
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: In the unexpectedly evolving panorama of healthcare technology, the mixing of data mining and machine mastering gives exceptional possibilities for the advancement of sickness prediction fashions. This research paper introduces a unique Machine Learning Smart Health Procedure designed to harness the predictive energy of those era for forecasting illnesses. By meticulously reading ancient healthcare facts, which includes affected individual signs and symptoms and effects, this system leverages cutting-edge algorithms which includes Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and neural networks to expect capacity health problems with accelerated accuracy. This method now not best pursuits to facilitate early and specific evaluation but also strives to noticeably enhance affected individual care and treatment consequences. Through the strategic utility of statistics mining and prediction analysis in the healthcare area, our proposed machine demonstrates the capacity to revolutionize conventional diagnostic techniques, developing a proactive and predictive healthcare model more plausible and effective than ever earlier than.
