title: Retraction Notice: An Empirical Assessment of Wireless Communication Technology Issues in the Smart Home
authors: Rakesh Arya, Manisha Khanduja, Muppidi Somasundara Rao, Raya Rohith Yadav, Anita Gehlot, Keerat Kumar Gupta
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Smart home technology, an Internet of Things (IoT) application, offers families convenience, comfort, and control. The purpose of this study is to construct a full model that can account for a large amount of the diversity in customers' intentions to embrace smart home technologies. To do this, this study creates an integrated model and evaluates it using structural equation modelling (SEM) utilising data acquired from 156 respondents, based on the technological acceptance model, diffusion of innovation theory, and consumer perceptions of innovativeness. The findings suggest that major criteria impacting the adoption of smart home technologies include compatibility, perceived usefulness, and perceived simplicity of operation. This study adds to the corpus of information on the Internet of Things, specifically in the field of research on smart houses. There have been some debates over the theoretical and practical repercussions.

title: Asymptotic Improvements to Provable Algorithms for the Code Equivalence Problem
authors: Huck Bennett, Drisana Bhatia, Jean-François Biasse, Medha Durisheti, Lucas LaBuff, Vincenzo Pallozzi Lavorante, Philip Waitkevich
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: We present several new provable algorithms for two variants of the code equivalence problem on linear error-correcting codes, the Linear Code Equivalence Problem (LCE) and the Permutation Code Equivalence Problem (PCE). Specifically, for arbitrary codes of block length n and dimension k over any finite field Fq, we show: 1) A deterministic algorithm running in 2n+o(n+q) time for LCE. 2) A randomized algorithm running in 2n/2+o(n+q) time for LCE and PCE. 3) A quantum algorithm running in 2n/3+o(n+q) time for LCE and PCE. The second two algorithms improve on recent work of Nowakowski (PQCrypto 2025), which gave algorithms with similar running times but only for code equivalence on random codes and only over fields of order q ≥ 7.

title: Retraction Notice: Computational Intelligence Approach to improve the Classification Accuracy of Brain Tumour Detection
authors: Priyangshu Sarkar, Durgesh Srivastava
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: A brain tumour is one of the most severe illnesses that can strike both children and teenagers. 85–90 per cent of all primary Central Nervous System (CNS) malignancies are brain tumours. Each year, around 11,700 people are diagnosed with a brain tumour. Per cent, males have a 5-year survival rate of around 34 and females have a 5-year survival rate of around 36 per cent when they have a malignant brain or CNS tumour. There are many different forms of brain tumours, such as benign tumours, malignant tumours, pituitary tumours, and so on. Proper therapy, planning, and exact diagnostics should be implemented to increase the life expectancy of patients. The best tool for detecting brain tumours is magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Scanners generate enormous amounts of image data. These photographs are examined by the radiologist. The accuracy of automated classification approaches like Machine Learning (ML) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) has consistently outperformed manual categorization. As a result, providing a system that uses Deep Learning Algorithms like Convolution Neural Networks (CNN), Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), (GLCM), and Transfer Learning (TL) to do recognition and tracking will be advantageous to doctors all over the world.

title: Efficient Multi-Objective Optimization of an Asymmetric Rotor IPMSM with Hybrid Poles
authors: Liyang Liu, Yiming Ma, Lu Sun, Haoyu Kang, Kang Shuai, Ziqiang Zhu, Yang Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: This paper presents a novel hybrid poles asymmetric interior permanent magnet (HPAIPM) motor topology for electric vehicle applications featuring the combined utilization of rare-earth and ferrite permanent magnets (PMs). It fully utilizes the magnetic-field-shifting effect in improving torque density by adding a ferrite at the upper part of the V-shaped asymmetric rare earth PM pole and optimizes the harmonic distribution of the air-gap magnetic field to achieve a significant reduction in torque ripple. In response to the optimization challenges of complex rotor structure motors, this work applies surrogate-assisted methods to achieve rapid optimization. Firstly, a constraint space Latin hypercube design algorithm is proposed to solve the problem of selecting sampling points in a confined space composed of strong constraints on design variables. This not only avoids the generation of invalid points but also optimizes the spatial distribution characteristics of sampling points, reducing the prediction error of the surrogate model by 29.1%. Secondly, a surrogate modeling method based on transfer learning neural network is given, which freezes some hidden layer coefficients of the neural network to avoid repeated training of surrogate models corresponding to different ferrite materials, reducing the number of training samples by 60%. According to the optimal design scheme, the proposed HPAIPM topology can reduce torque ripple by over 80% and maintain high torque density compared to conventional interior PM and asymmetric interior PM topology. Finally, a small prototype of the proposed HPAIPM topology is designed, manufactured and tested for validation.

title: PEP-Policer: Eliminating the On-off Traffic Pattern in PEP over Satellite Networks
authors: Zeyi Deng, Siqi Yang, Zhe Chen, Lin Wang, Wenjun Zhu, Jingjing Zhang, Yue Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Performance Enhancement Proxies (PEPs) are widely used to improve TCP performance in geostationary orbit (GEO) satellite networks, which experience long RTT (approximately 500 ms). As a split TCP-based solution, PEP divides the end-to-end connection into multiple sub-connections, each independently managing its own rate control, including both congestion and flow control. This independence naturally leads to rate imbalances, manifested as an abnormal on-off traffic pattern-a phenomenon confirmed by our experimental observations in real-world GEO satellite networks. Furthermore, we demonstrate that this on-off traffic pattern not only undermines fairness but also reduces throughput, particularly for small-sized flows. To address this problem, we propose PEP-Policer, an automatic rate limiter for PEP to limit the link with higher rate to the lower one. Unlike traditional rate limiting methods that require manual configuration of the target rate, PEP-Policer employs a finite state machine to automatically determine and enforce the appropriate target rate. Moreover, as an add-on, PEP-Policer is compatible with all PEP-based solutions and can be integrated without modifying existing systems. Extensive evaluations in an emulated GEO satellite network show that PEP-Policer improves TCP's fairness and increases goodput by up to 63.0% for Cubic, 49.6% for BBR, and 88.6% for Hybla.

title: Impact of Instruction Methods and Task Size on Human Performance and Physical Workload in Manual Assembly
authors: Mohammed A. Noman, Fahad M. Alqahtani, Wadea Ameen, Mohammed H. Alhaag, Adeeb A. Ahmed, Abd Elaty E. AbdElgawad
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Manual assembly is critical in manufacturing, but it is susceptible to human errors, influenced by task complexity, the clarity of work instructions, and the physical demands on the operator. This study investigates the impact of instruction methods and task size on assembly errors, assembly time, and physical workload in manual assembly processes. Two instruction methods were compared: paper-based and screen-based (animation), in conjunction with two assembly tasks that varied in part size (large and small). The physical workload was assessed by measuring the electromyography (EMG) signals of the participants’ right arm muscles and heart rate variability (HRV). Twenty-eight participants were recruited to perform the assembly tasks under different conditions. A mixed experimental design was used to analyse the effects of instruction method and task size on assembly time, errors, muscle activity, and HRV. The study results indicate that task size significantly influences assembly time and error rates, with small-sized tasks generally associated with higher error rates. Furthermore, the instruction method affects the physical workload, as reflected in the EMG and HRV measurements. The results contribute to a deeper understanding of the interaction between instruction methods, task size, and the ergonomic demands of manual assembly, providing insights for optimizing assembly processes and reducing worker strain.

title: Bibliometrics-based analysis of the current status and hotspots of atopic dermatitis research at home and abroad
authors: Jian Liu, Wenxiu Ji, Xiaoyu Meng, Lulu Jia
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: Objective To investigate the current research status and hot trends of atopic dermatitis (AD) at home and abroad. Methods Based on CNKI and Web of Science databases, we searched the core literature on atopic dermatitis from 2000 to 2024, and used bibliometric methods and COOCcurrence20.5 software to analyse the statistics and emergence of the Chinese and English literature, and to draw a mapping. Results The number of atopic dermatitis-related research articles published increased year by year, with a total of 2968 articles in Chinese and 5590 articles in English; the research hotspots showed that the connection between atopic dermatitis and related skin diseases and allergic diseases attracted much attention both at home and abroad; the domestic focus was more on clinical observation of traditional Chinese medicine treatment, while the foreign focus was more on staphylococcus aureus and filaggrin-related mechanism research. Conclusion This study summarises the current status and hot trends of AD research in the past 25 years, and provides a reference for subsequent clinical decision-making and research frontiers.

title: In-situ investigation on the insulation performance of typical microfeatures of vacuum contact surface
authors: Shilong Tang, Jianyu Wang, Yimeng Li, Xiaomin Zhao, Xuxu Li, Guodong Meng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum interrupter is the critical component within medium and high voltage vacuum circuit breakers. Its vacuum contacts are responsible for interrupting high current. However, surface irregularities on contacts in vacuum can enhance field emission through localized electric field concentration, thereby degrading the insulation performance of the circuit breakers. Therefore, understanding and regulating contact surface microfeatures has become a key research focus for enhancing insulation performance of vacuum circuit breakers. In this work, the insulation performance of different surface microfeatures (Cu substrate and Cr grain) on the vacuum contacts was investigated using an in-situ electrical measurement system. The microtopographical evolution before and after breakdown was also examined. Results show that the breakdown mechanisms differ regionally. On Cu substrate, breakdown is caused by thermal runaway at the anode first (tungsten spheres), vaporization of atoms from anode surface, driven by the electric field or electron impact, results in plasma formation that bridges the gap. For Cr grain, field electron emission initiates at microprotrusions on cathode (Cr grain), with Joule heating accumulating within the grain to ultimately form a molten layer. In addition, Cr grain exhibits a higher breakdown voltage threshold $(387 \mathrm{~V})$ than Cu substrate $(233 \mathrm{~V})$, demonstrating that elevated Cr content in $\mathrm{Cu}-\mathrm{Cr}$ contacts substantially enhances insulation performance. This novel method enables in-situ investigation of breakdown behaviors across typical microfeatures, revealing mechanistic relationship between surface microtopography and insulation performance. These findings are expected to contribute to insulation enhancement and bottom-up contact design for high-performance vacuum circuit breakers.

title: Design of Efficient Lightweight Method for Mobile Eyewear Similarity Retrieval
authors: Henrikas Giedra, Andrius Katkevičius, Darius Plonis, Dalius Matuzevičius
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Eyewear similarity retrieval is a critical component in digital commerce, significantly enhancing user experience, customer engagement, and satisfaction through personalized eyewear recommendations, particularly on mobile platforms. Existing retrieval systems often utilize computationally intensive deep learning methods, posing challenges for deployment on resource-constrained devices.This study presents a novel lightweight approach tailored for mobile eyewear retrieval using efficient contour-based feature representations. The proposed pipeline consists of three stages: contour extraction and preprocessing from input images using edge detection techniques; shape encoding with Elliptic Fourier Descriptors (EFD); and dimensionality reduction via autoencoders, facilitating efficient similarity retrieval through optimized distance-based metrics. Experimental validation was performed using a benchmark dataset containing diverse eyewear images, demonstrating that the proposed method significantly reduces computational complexity while maintaining retrieval accuracy. Thus, the method effectively addresses the mobile deployment constraints for practical commercial applications.

title: Dependence on Breakdown Charge and Energy of Dielectric Strength in Spark Conditioning in Vacuum
authors: Fuma Ueno, Hiroki Kojima, Hideaki Fukuda, Kenta Yamamura, Naoki Hayakawa
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The effects of breakdown (BD) charge and Joule heat, i.e., BD energy, on the electrode surface condition and dielectric strength during spark conditioning in vacuum were investigated. When the BD charge exceeded 0.1 mC, significant melting of the cathode was observed, without adhesion of anode material. In such cases, the sustained component of the discharge current was dominant; however, excessive cathode melting could lead to a reduction in dielectric strength. Conversely, when the BD charge was less than 0.1 mC, more pronounced melting of the anode occurred, accompanied by the adhesion of anode material to the cathode surface. The ratio of BD charge to Joule heat was used as an index of the current waveform characteristics. A higher ratio indicated a dominant sustained component, while a lower ratio reflected stronger oscillatory behavior. Under lower-ratio conditions, increased adhesion of anode material was observed. Furthermore, dielectric strength tended to improve when less anode material adhered to the cathode. These results indicate that improving dielectric strength requires preventing excessive cathode melting and minimizing the adhesion of anode material. Overall, the findings suggest that effective conditioning depends on carefully balancing the sustained and oscillatory components of the discharge current waveform, namely BD charge and energy.

title: Impact of Plasma Electrolytic Polishing on the Field Emission of Molybdenum
authors: Moein Borghei, Sehoon An, Sergey Tsurkan, Madeline Vorenkamp, Frank Hempel, Robin Langtry
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Mechanical abrasion methods, such as fine sanding and ultrasonic cleaning have conventionally been the standard for preparing metal cathodes in field emission studies. However, prior studies revealed that residual contaminants from machining (e.g., tool material) often remain on polished surfaces, potentially influencing the surface composition and emission properties. This paper explores plasma electrolytic polishing (PEP) as an alternative surface finishing method for molybdenum cathodes, evaluating its efficacy in reducing surface roughness and contaminant residues, and the subsequent impact on field emission behavior. Molybdenum samples are subjected to PEP for varying durations between 5 and 15 mins, and the resulting surface characteristics (via optical microscopy, white-light interferometry, and Auger electron spectroscopy) and field emission performance (I-V curves, turn-on voltage, Fowler-Nordheim analysis) are compared with those of conventionally polished samples.

title: Enhancing Hive Monitoring and Sustainability through Video Recognition and Environmental Analysis
authors: Anatolijs Zabasta, Antons Patlins, Nadezhda Kunicina, Uldis Grunde
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This paper presents a video recognition-based solution for an innovative beekeeping system, which we have developed and have evaluated in a prototype. We have designed this solution to improve the monitoring and management of beekeeping operations, a critical aspect for ensuring efficiency and sustainability in modern apiculture. The proposed system enables continuous monitoring of bee colonies, providing real-time insights into environmental changes and bee behavior. In addition, the system's analytical tools can identify and analyze correlations between following factors affecting bee productivity, such as weather conditions, geographical location of the apiary, and other environmental influences.The introduction of this stand-alone beekeeping solution offers beekeepers the ability to remotely track key hive conditions. For instance, it can detect whether the temperature inside the hive is nearing critical levels, or whether the bees are facing food shortages. This timely information allows beekeepers to take swift action to prevent potential harm to the colonies, thereby improving overall colony health and productivity. Such a system must be particularly beneficial during winter, helping to preserve hibernating bee colonies, while also saving valuable time and resources typically spent on manual hive inspections.The autonomous beekeeping system aligns with the broader goals of promoting economically sustainable agriculture, supporting the conservation of agricultural and forestry resources. The introduction of advanced monitoring and control features ensures that beekeepers can maintain optimal hive conditions with minimal manual intervention. Moreover, as the project progresses, we are planning further enhancements, such as incorporating artificial intelligence (AI) techniques, including neural networks, to enhance image processing capabilities. This would significantly expand the system's functionality, providing even more comprehensive data analysis and decision-making tools for beekeepers.

title: Research on intelligent claim model technology based on claim rules
authors: Fang Xu, Jing Gao, Qian Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This study is part of the project “Research on intelligent processing of bill documents based on SVM and LD algorithm”. This study addresses the challenges associated with State Grid Corporation's internal process of medical insurance claims, including demanding workload, varying medical insurance policies in different regions, and medical documents with changing formats and unqualified image quality. It innovatively presents a novel insurance claims processing workflow integrated with intelligent techniques. This solution works with an intelligent mechanism for claims process automation, risk management, and business data monitoring, in a bid to transform claims processing into an AI-powered, efficient system. Using this solution, OCR can automatically extract key information, including units and amounts from medical invoices, while with the support of natural language processing, the conditions and prescriptions listed in diagnosis certificates can be analyzed quickly. Furthermore, it thoroughly screens and verifies medical content, prices and other cost details from medical insurance data. The rule-based system that the system hinges on automatically matches insurance claims with insurance policies, making the verification of medical insurance premiums and corresponding compensation faster and more efficient. In addition to reducing labor costs and raising processing efficiency, this technology also allows for an intelligent compensation self-service procedure, which is conducive to enterprises’ transformation into the digital environment and scale both their economic and societal value creation.

title: AI-enabled Coal Supply Chain Financial Credit Assessment and Loan Optimization Based on Multi-source Data Fusion
authors: Xianao Shi
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In response to the problem of incomplete credit assessment caused by multi-source data silos in the current coal supply chain finance field, this study proposes an AI-enabled credit assessment and loan optimization system under multi-source data fusion. By constructing a four-dimensional data fusion layer (production-end sensor data, logistics GPS trajectory, transaction electronic invoice, and external price/policy data), using knowledge graphs to model the supply chain topology network, and using federated learning to achieve cross-enterprise data privacy protection. A hybrid AI evaluation model is designed, integrating LightGBM/XGBoost to process structured data and GNN to extract supply chain guarantee relationship characteristics, and combined with SHAP interpretable analysis to reveal that inventory turnover rate and price fluctuation sensitivity are core risk factors. The innovative introduction of reinforcement learning dynamic credit algorithm allows the credit limit to be adjusted in real time with coal price fluctuations, and the deployment of blockchain smart contracts enables automatic loan release after goods delivery. Empirical evidence shows that the system has increased the credit assessment F1 value to 91.2%, reduced the bad debt rate to 1.18%, and shortened the loan decision-making time to 2.1 hours, providing a new paradigm of data collaborative governance and intelligent decision-making for coal supply chain financial risk management.

title: LLM-Based QA from Structured Bibliographic Data via Semantic Similarity Understanding Network
authors: Yingyin Fan, Chuxin Pan, Wanyi Li
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In this work, we propose a new method for converting structured bibliographic data into a natural language-based Question Answering (QA) system built on a Large Language Model (LLM). The method, called Semantic Similarity Understanding Network (SSUN), combines a Transformer encoder for identifying semantic relationships between data entries with a text-to-text generation model for producing contextually appropriate answers. To evaluate its effectiveness, we conducted experiments by using paraphrased queries and compared SSUN with several baseline models, including T5-Base, T5-Small, BART, and ProphetNet. The results indicate that SSUN achieves higher accuracy and robustness, particularly in handling queries that are semantically equivalent but phrased differently. Notably, SSUN can also detect and appropriately respond to out-of-domain questions by returning “no relevant information” instead of generating inaccurate results. These findings suggest that SSUN provides a more flexible and semantically aware interface for querying structured bibliographic data through natural language.

title: Co-construction scheme of credit risk control model for small and medium-sized banks based on federated transfer learning
authors: Jiao Geng
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In the context of rapid development of financial technology, credit risk control of small and medium-sized banks is constrained by data silos and sample imbalance. This paper proposes a co-construction scheme of credit risk control model for small and medium-sized banks based on federated transfer learning, and designs an improved federated adversarial transfer learning algorithm. The algorithm strengthens the extraction of key risk features through the attention mechanism, optimizes cross-domain knowledge transfer by using adversarial networks, and realizes model aggregation by adaptive weight adjustment. The experiment uses the UCI credit data set and simulated small and medium-sized bank data, and is carried out under the FATE federated learning framework. The algorithm is compared with five algorithms including FedAvg and XGBoost. The results show that the accuracy of the algorithm reaches 92.3%, which is 7.8 percentage points higher than FedAvg and 5.2 percentage points higher than XGBoost; the recall rate is 89.5%, which is 6.2 and 4.1 percentage points higher than the comparison algorithm respectively; the F1 value reaches 90.9%, which is the best. The model converged stably within 150 iterations, and the convergence speed was 30% higher than that of the traditional algorithm. The privacy attack experiment showed that the scheme could reduce the success rate of member reasoning attacks to 3.2%, significantly protecting data privacy. The experiment confirmed that the scheme effectively improved the performance of the credit risk control model of small and medium-sized banks and achieved safe and efficient model co-construction.

title: Overview of ASSETS 2024
authors: David Flatla, Faustina Hwang, Robin Brewer, Tiago Guerreiro
publish: ACM SIGACCESS Accessibility and Computing
abstract: The 26th International ACM SIGACCESS Conference on Computers and Accessibility (ASSETS 2024) was held October 27th to 30th, 2024 as a hybrid event in St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada. The ASSETS conference is the premier computing research conference exploring the design, evaluation, and use of computing and information technologies with and for people with disabilities and older adults. This year, the ASSETS conference continued its tradition of presenting innovative research on mainstream and specialized assistive technologies, accessible computing, and assistive applications of computer, network, and information technologies. 341 attendees from 24 countries attended the conference, including 233 in-person, 50 workshop-only, and 58 virtual attendees.

title: Semi-Supervised Radar-Based Gait Recognition in Random Walking Conditions
authors: Yang Yang, Junyu Zhao, Beichen Li, Jingxuan Xu, Yue Lang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Addressing angle sensitivity in radar-based gait recognition is placed at the main focus for achieving omnidirection human gait recognition using radar sensors, whereas sufficient data support with full annotations raises a great challenge in this research field. This paper presents a methodology called Tri-SG, which accomplishes gait recognition under random walking conditions by relying solely on a limited amount of radial-moving annotated data support. The Tri-SG is implemented in a semi-supervised manner, incorporating the proposed additional dual consistency mechanisms, resulting in significantly improving the model's efficacy irrespective of human movement directions. Alongside the standard consistency regularization, the first consistency design incorporates domain consistency regularization, which is essential for leveraging the knowledge gained from labeled samples by establishing a knowledge-sharing feature space. The other consistency approach is an elaborated adversarial consistency learning scheme that ensures consistency regularization not being susceptible to the non-i.i.d. scenarios. We conducted radar measurements and subsequently carried out experiments using two datasets derived from these measurements to assess the performance of our model. The comparisons with eight approaches confirm the superiority of the Tri-SG model in this task, and it is surprising that our model achieves over 90% accuracy while utilizing only 2% annotated radial-moving radar spectrograms during the semi-supervised learning process. Ablation studies were carried out to confirm the effectiveness of our designs, while additional parameter studies investigated the model's vulnerability and stability in relation to variations in the relevant parameters.

title: Hidden facial verification scheme in IoT cloud environment based on homomorphic privacy information retrieval
authors: Wenhao Liu, Xu An Wang, Wei Zhao, Weiwei Jiang, Lingling Wu, Haibo Lei, Zhiquan Liu, Dianhua Tang
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the popularization of face recognition technology in IoT-Cloud, the problem of privacy leakage caused by it is becoming more and more serious. Although traditional privacy protection schemes can improve security to a certain extent, there is still a risk of data leakage when facing semi-trusted cloud servers. To this end, this paper proposes an anonymized face verification scheme for IoT convergence scenarios, which achieves real-time retrieval and secure matching of dense face features in virtual device copies by combining homomorphic encryption (CKKS) and privacy information retrieval (PIR) for anonymized face verification. The scheme ensures that the semi-trusted cloud server cannot obtain user-specific index information and matching results. Experiments show that the scheme’s verification accuracy in the ciphertext state on the LFW dataset is consistent with the plaintext, up to 97.06%, and can complete a privacy-protected anonymized facial verification process within seconds. The scheme is feasible in security demanding scenarios.

title: Model Variability in Assessment of Human Exposure to Radiofrequency Fields
authors: Akimasa Hirata, Ilkka Laakso, Francesca Apollonio, Sachiko Kodera, Yoshiki Kubota, Junqing Lan, Kun Li, Micaela Liberti, Dragan Poljak, Kensuke Sasaki, Maxim Zhadobov, Yinliang Diao
publish: IEEE Journal of Microwaves
abstract: The recent advances in computational dosimetry for electromagnetics and thermodynamics are reviewed to assess human exposure to electromagnetic fields in the MHz-to-terahertz range. This review emphasizes model variability in computational dosimetry. Apart from computational electromagnetic methods and their usage, the developments in anatomical phantoms and tissue dielectric properties characterization are also surveyed. In addition, the rationale for dosimetric quantities prescribed in international exposure guidelines, such as the specific absorption rate (SAR) and absorbed power density, is revisited in relation to their correlation with local and core temperature rises in various tissues and populations. A heating factor, which is defined as a steady-state temperature rise per SAR, for the brain, eye lens, skin, and body core is evaluated to estimate heating resulting from exposure to electromagnetic fields. The transition of a physical quantity in the guidelines at 6 GHz, from SAR to the absorbed power density, is discussed along with the optimal spatial averaging volume and areas. Computational evaluations of product compliance, 5G devices, and wireless power transfer systems are also reviewed. This review aims to synthesize the current knowledge, identify key sources of computational model variability and uncertainty, and outline further research needs for setting exposure guidelines and compliance assessment.

title: Active Learning-Based Joint Optimization of Bionic Nose Profile and Water-Entry Strategy for Aerial-aquatic Robots
authors: Mengsen Zhao, Kaihong Huang, Hao Lin, Shiyou Zhao, Hui Peng, Huimin Lu, Junhao Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: The practical application of aerial-aquatic robots is hindered by severe impact loads during water entry. Existing load reduction methods are inefficient for robots requiring rapid, high-frequency aerial-aquatic transitions. Therefore, this study proposes an active learning based joint optimization framework for nose profiles and water-entry strategies, which is fully automated. Specifically, an 8-dimensional parameter space is defined for generating dataset inputs through Latin Hypercube Sampling (LHS). Furthermore, a Deep Kernel Learning (DKL) surrogate model is trained under different water-entry strategies, in order to predict peak impact loads and quantify prediction uncertainty for varying nose profiles. Within each active learning loop, the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III (NSGA-III) guides the selective labelling of samples to expand the dataset, and the DKL model is iteratively retrained until convergence. Compared against state-of-the-art methods, the proposed approach reduces the number of required high-fidelity Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) simulations to 65% of that of the comparison methods, while achieving maximum reductions of 66.9% in axial and 72.8% in normal impact loads across the parameter space, respectively. Notably, under the water-entry strategies employed by the hunting behavior of gannets, the approach yields profiles closely matching the skull morphology of the northern gannet. In this case, this work not only delivers an efficient and reliable impact loads reduction solution for aerial-aquatic robots, but also reveals the role of natural selection in minimizing such loads.

title: SpectFusion: Cross-modal Spectrum-aware Attention Network for Unsupervised Multimodal Medical Image Fusion
authors: Lamei Wang, Xinyu Xie, Youxi Yang, Dongping Xiong, Hong Zhou, Bin Yang, Kok Lay Teo, Bingo Wing-Kuen Ling, Xiaozhi Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Medical image fusion aims to synthesize relevant and complementary information from different modalities, thereby enhancing clinical diagnosis. Current deep learning-based fusion approaches, particularly Transformer-based architectures, have achieved remarkable results due to their strong capacity for modeling long-range dependencies. However, there are still limitations in capturing sufficient global information because of the window-based local attention mechanism. Moreover, existing fusion schemes predominantly focus on spatial features while rarely considering spectral features, thus affecting the fusion performance. To address these challenges, we propose a new unsupervised cross-modal spectrum-aware fusion framework, named SpectFusion, for medical image fusion. Specifically, we devise a spatial-spectrum hybrid block, which effectively extracts fine-grained local features via a gradient retention strategy in the spatial domain, and captures global features with an image-wide receptive field through Fourier convolution in the frequency domain. Furthermore, we develop a novel cross-modal spectrum-aware attention to facilitate spatial-spectrum information interactions during fusion. It dynamically guides the retention of relevant spectral components while integrating multimodal spatial features. Additionally, to achieve more precise alignment image pairs, we incorporate a refined registration module to correct minor local deviations. We also define corresponding frequency and spatial domain losses to jointly constrain the proposed SpectFusion. By leveraging spatial-spectrum information interactions, fine-grained fusion can be adaptively realized. Extensive experiments, including clinical brain tumor image fusion, demonstrate that SpectFusion outperforms other state-of-the-art methods both qualitatively and quantitatively. We show that SpectFusion can boost performance in downstream tasks such as multimodal medical image segmentation. The code is available at https://github.com/PlumW/SpectFusion.

title: Dual-Clamping Coordinated Dual-Waveform Current Inverter and Current Short-Tail Optimization in HTEM System for Enhancing Shallow Detection
authors: Yue Zhang, Yanzhang Wang, Qizhou Gong, Yifei Shao, Menghao Jia, Quan Xu, Zhaowen Liu, Shilong Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Helicopter Transient Electromagnetic (HTEM) instrument systems now require dual-waveform (high/low-energy) current inverters for single-flight shallow/deep detection in complex terrains. Low-energy waveforms require earlier observation windows and stronger excitation to enhance shallow-resolution, but current designs using fixed clamping voltage and long current tails limit shallow data acquisition. This paper proposes a dual-clamping coordinated dual-waveform current inverter. A series-type fast on-off module, without compromising high-energy performance, increases the low-energy waveform clamping voltage from 450V to 720V or higher, amplifying electromagnetic excitation. By modeling parasitic capacitance, damping resistors are optimally selected to eliminate turn-off oscillations. Through damping optimization via extended high-voltage clamping duration, the current tail decay time was shortened from 23.1μs to 10.6μs. Results from forward modeling in complex terrains demonstrate that the proposed current inverter achieved a 2.86-fold increase in the response amplitude variation of the earliest time gate. The dual-clamping current inverter presents an innovative dual-waveform design, significantly enhancing shallow detection performance and providing a practical framework for advancing HTEM applications.

title: Impact Analysis of Algorithm Optimization on Robot Deep Learning Localization Model for Real-Time Execution.
authors: Cédric Melançon, Maarouf Saad, Kuljeet Kaur, Julien Gascon-Samson
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The increased demand for autonomous robots in industries such as healthcare, manufacturing, and logistics is driven by the need to address labor shortages and enhance operational efficiency. A critical aspect of these robots is their ability to navigate complex environments autonomously, which relies heavily on multiple artificial intelligence models, including visual odometry. Visual odometry enables robots to estimate their motion by analyzing visual data, making it essential for navigation and obstacle avoidance. However, ensuring such models operate within real-time constraints is paramount for the robot’s responsiveness, safety, and overall functionality. The complexity and depth of such a model, which utilizes camera images and other sensor data, make it challenging to achieve real-time performance. Thus, this paper thoroughly evaluates the performance of a deep-learning visual odometry model, with a focus on its execution time and computational overhead. Furthermore, it proposes an optimized implementation to meet the stringent real-time requirements for safe and efficient robot operation. The optimization is achieved through algorithm improvement to preserve the model structure and accuracy. Multiple hardware platforms were utilized to demonstrate the resource differences between edge, fog, and cloud deployments, thereby validating the effect of the proposed model optimization. The resource usage is also compared to see the impact of the modification on multiple aspects, including computation, memory, temperature, and energy. The resulting model operationalization improves the execution time while highlighting limitations for some hardware configurations.

title: Optimal-Coupling-Observer AV Motion Control Securing Comfort in the Presence of Cyber Attacks
authors: Farzam Tajdari, Georgios Papaioannou, Riender Happee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The security of Automated Vehicles (AVs) is an important emerging area of research in traffic safety. Methods have been published and evaluated in experimental vehicles to secure safe AV control in the presence of attacks, but human motion comfort is rarely investigated in such studies. In this paper, we present an innovative optimal-coupling-observer-based framework that rejects the impact of bounded sensor attacks in a network of connected and automated vehicles from safety and comfort point of view. We demonstrate its performance in car following with cooperative adaptive cruise control for platoons with redundant distance and velocity sensors. The error dynamics are formulated as a Linear Time Variant (LTV) system, resulting in complex stability conditions that are investigated using a Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) approach guaranteeing global asymptotic stability. We prove the capability of the framework to secure occupants’ safety and comfort in the presence of bounded attacks. In the onset of attack, the framework rapidly detects attacked sensors and switches to the most reliable observer eliminating attacked sensors, even with modest attack magnitudes. Without our proposed method, severe (but bounded) attacks result in collisions and major discomfort. With our method, attacks had negligible effects on motion comfort evaluated using ISO-2631 Ride Comfort and Motion Sickness indexes. The results pave the path to bring comfort to the forefront of AVs security.

title: Optimization of Surface-Emitting UV Nanowire Photonic Crystal Lasers: A Simulation-Driven Approach_supp1-3637012.pdf
authors: Dishiti Gupta
publish: N/A
abstract: There is a large lag in the development of efficient surface-emitting ultraviolet (UV) lasers compared to visible and infrared lasers. Most efforts have been directed towards incremental improvements in fabrication techniques. In this work, a systematic simulation-driven approach is proposed to optimize GaN/AlGaN nanowire (NW)-based photonic crystal (PhC) laser structures, which have potential applications in disinfection, sensing and non-line-of-sight communications. The method employs 1-dimensional and 2-dimensional solvers to prescreen leaky designs and refine the structural parameters, which are then further analyzed using 3-dimensional simulations for the final optimization. A new physical analysis of the PhC mode and its diffracted components is proposed. This analysis provides insight into the interplay between PhC, NW, and air modes and its effect on the performance of NW PhC lasers. A simplified approach to the complex multi-parameter optimization problem for NW waveguide structures is developed that not only improves the performance of UV lasers but also establishes general design principles for surface-emitting NW-based PhC lasers. These guidelines are primarily concerned with ensuring that structures accommodate the PhC mode well, which depend on the layer thicknesses of the NW waveguide. Implementing these guidelines can result in more than a 60-fold improvement in the NW PhC laser performance. It is further suggested to optimize for surface output efficiency rather than Q-factor and introduce absorption losses once a suitable structure has been found. This framework represents a robust and computationally efficient pathway for future development in optimizing the NW waveguide design, paving the way for cost-effective and high performance UV light-emitting devices.

title: From ADC to Baseband: Joint Quantization Design for ML Channel Estimation in Massive MIMO
authors: Fengyu Chen, Yu Tian, Yongming Huang, You You, Chuan Zhang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Power consumption has become a major challenge in massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems, driving the need for more efficient receiver designs. While low-resolution analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) and baseband quantization have been explored, existing methods treat them separately, overlooking their interdependence and resulting in suboptimal designs. This letter proposes a unified framework to jointly optimize ADC resolution and baseband bitwidths under specified performance constraints. Two search-based algorithms, hierarchical search (HS) and improved particle swarm optimization (I-PSO), are designed to solve the integer-constrained problem. Applied to maximum likelihood channel estimation, the proposed methods effectively reduce ADC resolution to 5 bits and baseband bitwidths by 32.17% (HS) and 40.50% (I-PSO), with the performance loss kept within 1 dB compared to unified quantization.

title: Retraction Notice: Retooling Non-IID Metadata at IoT Endpoint with Automated Mentor Training for Algorithms
authors: Sunila Choudhary
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The infiltration of decentralized ml algorithms, such as supervised learning, has been made possible by the increment in computer resources in endpoints. This technology allows for the creation of result obtained that can be trained regionally in the endpoints, trying to improve both utilization and secrecy for model prediction instruction. Although machine learning needs a primary key to coordinate the training of the model, in certain IoT networks the communication across gadgets and transmission lines might be restricted. This hinders the implementation of deep learning. Mentor training, that does not necessitate such an integrator, seems to be a viable way around problem. The security issues with IoT installations, on the other hand, have encouraged the usage of computer science for threat and fault diagnosis. When using supervised methods to solve these issues, the trained samples are often unbalanced, meaning that there are more harmless pieces of information than anomalous. This necessitates the employment of rebalance strategies to demonstrate the effectiveness of the methods. In this research, we present a new mentoring technique, P2PK-SMOTE, which result in increasing to locally s actually the training examples by synthetic production of datasets from either the minority class, to train unsupervised abnormality identification models for machine learning in non-IID contexts. In order to lower the danger of data and improve results in semi contexts, we additionally integrate a method for exchanging a small portion of synthetic data first from minority class between devices. The advantages of our suggested technique are validated by our practices require in actual dataset and IoT image classification across a variety of situations.

title: Development of O-Mode Polarized -Band Multichannel Poloidal Correlation Reflectometry on EAST Tokamak_supp1-3354257.pdf
authors: Gongshun Li
publish: N/A
abstract: A new O-mode polarized <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V$ </tex-math></inline-formula>-band poloidal correlation reflectometry (PCR) has been designed and installed on the experimental advanced superconducting tokamak (EAST) to measure the core density fluctuation in high-density plasmas, especially in internal transport barrier (ITB) discharges. Four probing frequencies (61.2, 65.6, 69.2, and 73.6 GHz) are launched into the plasma simultaneously with an inclined view to ensure the probe waves are perpendicular to the cutoff layer. The reflected waves are received by two adjacent antennas, and this setup enables the system to measure the density fluctuations at eight spatial positions (4 radial <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\times2$ </tex-math></inline-formula> poloidal). The result of the bench test shows that all the key components perform well and meet the system requirements. The launching power of these probe microwaves coupled together is 18.22 dBm, the phase unbalance is lower than 5°, and the amplitude unbalance is below 1 dB. The system was successfully installed in the EAST, and the preliminary result is presented herein to examine the system’s performance. The evolution of core density fluctuations during the density oscillations was observed, which indicated that the system could work well in high-density plasmas.

title: Autocorrelation Bias in Diffuse Correlation Spectroscopy Observable via SPAD Arrays_supp1-3637165.pdf
authors: Melissa M. Wu
publish: N/A
abstract: Diffuse correlation spectroscopy (DCS) is an emerging optical technique for non-invasive cerebral blood flow monitoring. Extraction of the DCS blood flow index typically involves calculating the temporal autocorrelation of the measured light intensity and then fitting its decay to a solution of the correlation diffusion equation. It is well-known that the experimental autocorrelation is a biased estimator of the true autocorrelation. This work explores this phenomenon as it relates to DCS, in particular implementations with single photon avalanche diode arrays (SPAD arrays). After deriving a first-order expression for the bias in DCS, we then quantify its impact as a function of sampling time in both simulation and experiment using SPAD array detection. We then present and explore two bias correction strategies to correct for its impact at fast sampling times (20-200 Hz) and in low-photon regimes.

title: QuadPrior++: Multi-dimension Augmented Physical Prior for Zero-Reference Illumination Enhancement
authors: Haofeng Huang, Yifan Li, Wenjing Wang, Wenhan Yang, Ling-Yu Duan, Jiaying Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Existing low-light enhancement methods typically rely on fitting data mappings (pixel-wise mappings through fully supervised methods or distribution-wise mappings through weakly supervised or self-supervised methods). However, their performance is heavily dependent on specific scenes and fails to adequately model the intrinsic prior of natural images, resulting in poor generalization. To tackle this challenge, we leverage the strengths of powerful generative diffusion models, conditioned on a thoughtfully designed prior, and propose a novel zero-reference low-light enhancement framework that gets rid of dependence on the distribution of low-light images. In detail, we address the most fundamental core by proposing an illumination-invariant prior derived from the theory of physical light transfer, bridging the gap between normal and low-light domains, and enabling zero-shot enhancement without the need for low-light-specific training. A prior-to-image restoration framework is built upon generative diffusion models, pre-trained on normal-light data. During inference, the framework extracts the illumination-invariant prior from low-light inputs and maps them back to high-quality images, naturally for low-light enhancement. Additionally, such intrinsic properties of illumination-invariant prior open up opportunities for distilling diffusion models into compact CNN-based networks. We propose a novel prior-injected distillation paradigm incorporating intensity, frequency, and gradient domain-augmented regularization comprehensively. This distillation framework not only reduces computational costs but also maintains high fidelity and perceptual quality in enhanced outputs, making it more efficient and practical for real-world applications. The approach further extends seamlessly to handle over-exposure scenarios, demonstrating its versatility in addressing complex lighting conditions. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of our framework in various scenarios, as well as its strong interpretability, robustness, and efficiency.

title: A Community-Aware Spatio-temporal Hypergraph Contrastive Learning Method for Social Bot Detection
authors: Feng Liu, Zhenyu Li, Rui Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Social bot detection plays a crucial role in enabling social media platforms and governments to effectively manage and regulate social networks. Existing methods, which typically rely on multi-modal feature fusion, often concentrate on interactions between paired accounts and their immediate neighbors, overlooking the dynamic evolution of social networks over time. To address this gap, we propose a community-aware spatio-temporal hypergraph contrastive learning method for social bot detection, namely BotSTHCL. Specifically, we construct a temporal community-aware hypergraph and apply a contrastive learning framework in a semi-supervised setting, facilitating the effective extraction and representation of node features. Our model not only captures interactions among multiple accounts within a community but also accounts for the evolving nature of social networks. Extensive experiments on publicly available datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our approach. The code is available at https://github.com/FengLiuii/BotSTHCL.

title: Laser-induced arc discharge experiment of spacecraft solar array
authors: Liying Zhu, Dejie Wei, Dong Yang, Jianwen Wu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: With the continuous improvement of high-energy pulsed laser technology in space applications, it is extremely easy to cause damage to the solar array and threaten the safe operation of the spacecraft. In this paper, based on the theory of space arc discharge of solar array, the mechanism of nanosecond pulse laser-induced discharge of solar array is analyzed. The power density threshold and discharge characteristics of nanosecond pulse laser-induced arc discharge of solar array in low earth orbit (LEO) plasma environment are experimentally studied by using space discharge simulation experiment system. The results indicate that the power density threshold of laser-induced solar array discharge in the LEO plasma environment is about $1.08 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2}$, the discharge duration increased by $20 \%$, and the probability of induced discharge is about $\mathbf{6 0 \%}$. This conclusion can provide a reference for the laser protection design of spacecraft solar array.

title: Numerical Simulation of High-Current Vacuum Arcs Under Different Bell-Shaped Axial Magnetic Fields
authors: Xinkun Lv, Zongqian Shi, Ziqiao Zhao, Yongpeng Mo, Jiajia Sun
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: High-current vacuum arc (HCVA) under axial magnetic field (AMF) can be kept in diffuse status. Bell-shaped AMF, which is usually generated by traditional AMF contacts, is the most common AMF distribution. Different bell-shaped AMFs bring different influence to HCVAs. In this paper, the distribution of bell-shaped AMF with declined magnitude near the contact periphery was described by two characteristic parameters, i.e., the radius of center area $\boldsymbol{R}_{\text {center }}^{\text {bell }}$ and the value of central AMF $B_{\text {zcenter }}^{\text {bell }}$. Then, HCVAs under bell-shaped AMFs with different characteristic parameters were simulated and analyzed based on a two-dimensional (2-D) magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model. Simulation results showed that the change of $R_{\text {center }}^{\text {bell }}$ mainly influences the distribution of vacuum arc in the outer region of the arc, and the change of $\boldsymbol{B}_{\text {zcenter }}^{\text {bell }}$ influences the distribution of vacuum arc in the whole region. Besides, relationship between the change of bellshaped AMF and the Hall electric field was also analyzed.

title: Experimental Study on the Removal of Milling Burrs from Aluminum Alloys Using Low-Pressure Discharge
authors: Timo Meyer, Zongqian Shi, Jiajia Sun
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In the aviation industry, weakly rigid thin-walled structural components are typically made of aluminum alloys. Removing burrs from milled aluminum alloy surfaces is a significant technical challenge. Polishing technique via lowpressure discharge, which is mainly developed for copper and steel, has been rarely studied for aluminum alloys. This study explores a deburring method for aluminum alloy using lowpressure discharge. High voltage is applied directly between the anode and cathode under low pressure, using aluminum alloy contacts as the cathode, to remove surface burrs through electrical breakdown. Experiments are conducted in a detachable vacuum chamber. The comparative investigation focuses on how the geometry of the anode contact affects the burr removal performance of two aluminum alloys. Surface changes before and after burr removal are then analyzed using a scanning electron microscope. Optimal polishing configuration is proposed.

title: Development of the Concept and Application of Smart Fabric Thermoregulation with Control of Thermoelectric Elements
authors: Andrejs Podgornovs, Inga Lasenko, Sandra Vasilevska, Pavels Rombovskis
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: In this article is developed the concept of the smart fabric thermoregulation with control of thermoelectric elements which is used clothing and shelters to maintain user comfortable conditions. With the development of modern technologies in an area of the composite micro/nano materials with thermoregulation properties is crucially important to increase comfortable characteristics for maintaining heat, waterproofness and air exchange. However, no matter what thermal insulation characteristics a fabric material has, excess heat or heat leakage occurs during use. A very narrow temperature range (±2°) is required for comfortable use and thermal regulation. At low temperature external conditions, additional heating is required, and in high temperature conditions, cooling is required. The article discusses the use of Peltier elements for thermal management of fabric. Widely available solid Peltier elements have limited use due to their small difference of temperature surfaces. Innovative decision to increase the effect of temperature difference consists of integration of the elaborated composite multilayer material in matrix of which in an orderly manner Peltier elements are placed. Based on the results of the study, recommendations were developed for the use of solid-state Peltier elements not only for heating, but also for cooling the surface. Thus, the use of thermoelements allows to get comfortable conditions inside the sleeping bag. To maintaining a comfortable temperature, control is used via a microcontroller, which monitors the temperature on the inner and outer surfaces of the multilayer material. Experimental data on the limiting capabilities of using typical Peltier elements are also provided.

title: Influence of Superparticle Number on PIC-MCC Simulation Results of the Post-Arc Sheath Stage in VCBs
authors: Xubin Li, Xingyu Guo, Wen Wang, Minfu Liao, Xiaoming Liu, Jiyan Zou
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The Particle-in-Cell and Monte Carlo Collision (PIC-MCC) method is a powerful tool for simulating the postarc sheath stage in vacuum circuit breakers(VCBs), aiding in understanding this complex process. In PIC-MCC simulations, super-particles, sharing the same charge-to-mass ratio as real particles, represent large numbers of electrons or ions, reducing computational costs but introducing noise in results. The impact of super-particle number on simulation results, particularly during the post-arc sheath stage, remains unclear. This study investigates how varying the number of super-particles per cell affects simulation outcomes using a simplified 2D PIC-MCC model. The super-particle number per cell represents a specific plasma density within a cell, enabling plasma characterization at discrete spatial points. Simulations systematically vary this super-particle number per cell across $\mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{2 0} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{4 0} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{5 0} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{8 0} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{1 0 0}$, and 150. Results show that increasing super-particles per cell smooths ion density distribution curves, reducing fluctuations. However, beyond a threshold of around 40 or 50 super-particles per cell, further increases offer minimal improvement. This study provides insights for the optimization of settings of future PIC-MCC simulations.

title: Recent progress on nanostructures deformation behaviors under intense electric fields
authors: Jianyu Wang, Yimeng Li, Guodong Meng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Electric-field-induced damage and deformation at the nanoscale are critical issues for the performance and reliability of electronic devices and electrical equipment. Despite decades of vacuum breakdown research, the morphological evolution of electrode nanostructures under high electric fields remains poorly understood. In this paper, recent progress in numerical simulations and experimental studies on electric-field-induced deformation is reviewed. Atomistic simulations based on Kinetic Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics methods reveal how electric fields induce biased atomic surface diffusion and the growth of nanoprotrusions at grain boundaries or voids. Multiscale-multiphysics model further illustrates the thermal runaway of nanotips during field emission. Experimentally, while most studies focus on surface morphology before and after breakdown, our recent work reports the first direct in-situ observations of nanoprotrusions formation on carbon-coated nanoelectrodes and the shape and dislocation evolution of metallic nanotips under electric fields. The results provide microscopic evidence of shape deformation and the underlying mechanisms of electrical damage and failure in nanostructures under high electric fields. Finally, the challenges in simulations and experimental studies on deformation behaviors of nanostructures under intense electric fields are also discussed.

title: MHD Simulation of Vacuum Arcs Distribution Characteristics under Critical Short Circuit Interrupting Current
authors: Yueheng Yang, Xinquan Li, Hui Ma, Wei Liu, Zihan Zhu, Jian Liu, Yingsan Geng, Yanchao Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to quantitatively determine the vacuum arc plasma parameters under the proportional changes of the contact structure and gaps by the MHD simulation method. In this paper, the conservation of the mass, momentum, and the energy of ions and electrons, the magnetic transport equations were considered. A threedimensional steady-state MHD model of the high-current vacuum arcs was established. The simulation results show that under the critical short circuit interrupting current, after the contact structure and gaps were changed to twice the original, the peak value of the AMF intensity decreased. Compared with the small contact, the axial current density at the anode center is $44.67 \%$ of that of the small contact, the maximum ion number density has decreased by $19.38 \%$. The anode energy current density of the large contact is $\mathbf{2 7. 5 2 \%}$ lower than that of the small contact.

title: Optical and spectroscopic analysis of vacuum arcs in larger gaps
authors: Ralf Methling, Timo Meyer, Dirk Uhrlandt, Sergey Gortschakow, Michael Kurrat
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: With the growing interest in SF6-free technologies, there is an increasing demand for vacuum interrupters (VIs) that can operate at higher voltage levels. To meet these requirements, design solutions such as larger contact gaps and the series connection of multiple VIs are necessary. Larger gaps can lead to a specific behaviour of the arc and the attachment modes at the electrodes which depend in addition on the polarity of the moving contact. This paper focuses on the analysis of arc modes for larger gaps through a combination of electrical and optical data. Experiments were conducted using CuCr25 butt contacts at peak currents of up to 15 kA and a frequency of 35 Hz, with a contact gap of 30 mm at current zero, and with operating the moving contact as the anode or as the cathode. The arc behaviour was observed using a high-speed camera (HSC) and optical emission spectroscopy (OES). The HSC captures the arc dynamics, while a computer-aided evaluation facilitates the analysis of different arc modes. The OES results allow for an estimation of the spatial distribution of copper and chromium atoms and ions in particular in the region of the anode spots. Different arc behaviour and anode attachment modes were observed, particularly influenced by the polarity of the movable contact. The time after contact separation at which the arc changes into a jet mode is longer in case of the moved cathode in comparison with the moved anode.

title: Enhanced Notary Cross-Chain Mechanism with Identity Privacy and Traceability

title: The Influence of Local Thermodynamic Equilibrium State on the Composition Characteristic of the Discharge on Overhead Line Part I: Partial Arc of the Insulator
authors: Wei Meng, Jiayu Li, Qi Li, Konstantinos Kopsidas, Jianlin Hu, Vladimir Terzija, Xingliang Jiang, Zijia Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Partial arcs, spark discharges, and other destructive gaseous discharges frequently occur on overhead line, leading to insulation failure and power outages. Particle composition, as a fundamental parameter, governs discharge characteristics. This study focuses on partial arcs on the insulator-grading ring gap by analyzing rod-plane gap arc discharges under AC/DC voltage through emission spectroscopy. Characteristic species and reactions of arc are identified to construct a two-temperature discharge composition model. To address the model’s strong nonlinearity, a dimensional reduction approach combined with an advanced iterative algorithm is proposed. Numerical validation demonstrates that dimensional reduction compresses variables to the number of elemental species, while the new algorithm achieves a twelvefold speed improvement over conventional Newton iteration with comparable accuracy. Equilibrium analysis reveals that increasing the parameter θ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</sub> yields a non-monotonic ionization effect: electron density rises and then falls (inverse U-shaped profile), whereas neutral particle density decreases monotonically. These findings provide valuable reference data for discharge parameter calculations in insulation coordination and fundamental plasma modeling. The proposed numerical methods further offer efficient tools for investigating discharge physics in overhead line engineering.

title: On the Reversibility of Locality-Sensitive Hashing-based Biometric Template Protections
authors: Seunghun Paik, Chanwoo Hwang, Sunpill Kim, Jae Hong Seo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: With the extensive deployment of biometric authentication systems, the need for biometric template protection (BTP) has been widely recognized. Designing a secure yet efficient BTP is still a long-lasting challenge, and locality-sensitive hashing (LSH) is a promising building block for designing BTPs. In this study, we propose a novel pre-image attack applicable to lots of existing LSH-based BTPs, showing that many of them are in fact reversible. Our attack leverages structural properties shared by several LSH-based BTPs. Through investigation, we formalize a certain class of LSHs vulnerable to our attack, called PMA-LSH, which contains several known LSH-based BTPs, even not-yet-cryptanalyzed ones. Furthermore, the recovered pre-image from our attack is much closer to the original template compared to previous attacks, facilitating recovery of the original biometrics via reconstruction attacks. With existing reconstruction methods, we successfully recovered biometrics from templates protected by several LSH-based BTPs. The recovered biometrics sufficiently resemble the original ones, so they can be further exploited to impersonate other recognition systems, including commercial APIs. To facilitate further study, our source code is publicly available at https://github.com/Cryptology-Algorithm-Lab/Analysis_LSH.

title: A 1.5GS/s 7-bit Charge-Injection SAR ADC using a PVT-tracking 1-bit Metastability Detector
authors: Chae-Eun Lee, Jintae Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This brief presents a 7-bit 1.5GS/s area-efficient asynchronous Charge Injection Successive Approximation Register (CI-SAR) analog-to-digital converter (ADC). The proposed ADC architecture consists of a 6-bit CI-SAR and a 1-bit Metastability Detector (MD), forming a 7-bit ADC. Superior area efficiency is achieved by architecting the CI-DAC in a segmented structure. The Charge Injection Cell (CIC) is biased by a temperature-aware bias generator that maintains the ADC full-scale over a wide temperature range. The g<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</sub>-boosted strongARM comparator helps achieve high sampling speed up to 1.5GS/s. A background-calibrated metastability-detector extracts an additional bit under different process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) conditions. The proposed ADC is fabricated in 28nm CMOS process in an area of 202μm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The peak SNDR is 39.04dB with FoM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">w</sub> = 17.4fJ/conv.-step. The measured SNDR drops by less than 2.7dB across the -40°C to 80°C temperature variation and 0.9V to 1.1V supply voltage variation.

title: AortaDiff: Volume-Guided Conditional Diffusion Models for Multi-Branch Aortic Surface Generation
authors: Delin An, Pan Du, Jian-Xun Wang, Chaoli Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Accurate 3D aortic construction is crucial for clinical diagnosis, preoperative planning, and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations, as it enables the estimation of critical hemodynamic parameters such as blood flow velocity, pressure distribution, and wall shear stress. Existing construction methods often rely on large annotated training datasets and extensive manual intervention. While the resulting meshes can serve for visualization purposes, they struggle to produce geometrically consistent, well-constructed surfaces suitable for downstream CFD analysis. To address these challenges, we introduce AortaDiff, a diffusion-based framework that generates smooth aortic surfaces directly from CT/MRI volumes. AortaDiff first employs a volume-guided conditional diffusion model (CDM) to iteratively generate aortic centerlines conditioned on volumetric medical images. Each centerline point is then automatically used as a prompt to extract the corresponding vessel contour, ensuring accurate boundary delineation. Finally, the extracted contours are fitted into a smooth 3D surface, yielding a continuous, CFD-compatible mesh representation. AortaDiff offers distinct advantages over existing methods, including an end-to-end workflow, minimal dependency on large labeled datasets, and the ability to generate CFD-compatible aorta meshes with high geometric fidelity. Experimental results demonstrate that AortaDiff performs effectively even with limited training data, successfully constructing both normal and pathologically altered aorta meshes, including cases with aneurysms or coarctation. This capability enables the generation of high-quality visualizations and positions AortaDiff as a practical solution for cardiovascular research.

title: A Data-Driven Method for Fast and Accurate Identification of the Wideband Oscillations in Renewable Power Systems
authors: Lingyun Gao, Lei Chen, Xiaorong Xie, Vladimir Terzija, Zhicong Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: Recently, wideband oscillation events have frequently occurred in renewable power systems and made the system unstable. As a result, a method to identify the occurrence of the unstable oscillation event is needed. The existing methods usually use a long window to ensure high identification accuracy, while a long identification time will be introduced. To deal with this problem, this paper proposes a fast and accurate identification method based on a data-driven method, i.e., the cubic spline interpolated fast Fourier transform-random forest (CSIPFFT-RF) method. The CSIPFFT is used to preprocess the waveform data and extract the amplitude variation features of the oscillation component quickly, and the feature data is used to train the RF to identify and classify the oscillations. In simulation tests, the proposed method is compared with the methods that use the traditional FFT and zero-padding FFT to preprocess the data, and the methods that use the back propagation, long short-term memory, and extreme learning machine to identify the oscillation. Results show that the proposed method has much higher accuracy (over 99%) and shorter identification time (about 1 s) than the existing methods under various scenarios. Importantly, the proposed method still has high performance even in untrained scenarios, especially when real data with dynamic harmonics, noise, and missing values are used.

title: Exploring Psychological Disengagement and Social Support as Mediators of Stigma in Dementia Caregiving: A SEM-SVM Hybrid Approach
authors: Zhiting Chen, Yuanrong Wu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: Dementia caregiving is associated with significant psychological burdens, including psychological disengagement and stigma. While social support is considered a protective factor, its effects on caregiver stigma and disengagement remain underexplored, particularly in non-linear contexts. This study employs a hybrid approach combining Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) and Support Vector Machine (SVM) classification to examine these psychosocial factors among 424 Chinese dementia caregivers. SEM revealed that psychological disengagement partially mediates the relationship between social support and stigma. Additionally, an SVM classifier was developed to predict stigma risk, achieving an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.92, highlighting its effectiveness in detecting non-linear patterns. The study underscores the importance of strengthening social support and promoting psychological disengagement as strategies to mitigate stigma. It also demonstrates the potential of SEM-SVM hybrid models in both explanatory and predictive tasks, offering valuable insights for precision intervention design in dementia caregiving.

title:
ALD Deposited Al
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Film for Micro-discharge Mitigation in Space TWTA
authors: Na Zhang, Tiancun Hu, Yun He, Xueman Wan, Tingting Wang, Wan Zhao Cui
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Space travelling wave tube amplifiers, as critical vacuum electronic devices for final stage microwave power amplification in satellite communications systems, are susceptible to micro-discharge phenomena. This effect can cause real-time communication interruptions, data transmission loss in satellite systems, and even more on-orbit failure. To suppress the initiation of micro-discharge phenomenon at triple junctions, an atomic layer deposition method for depositing Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> film on ceramic is developed. Experimental results demonstrate that the deposited film can effectively suppress secondary electron emission, reducing the secondary electron yield form above 6 to below 3.5. And the Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-deposited samples exhibit enhanced flashover voltages and decrease flashover probabilities compared to the untreated ceramic. The work provides a promising surface treatment approach for mitigating micro-discharge effects in TWTA and other vacuum electronic devices.

title: Experimental Study on Arc Characteristics of a Vacuum Contactor in LVDC system
authors: Fanke Zeng, Patrick Vieth, Dirk Bösche, Michael Kurrat
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: With the ongoing electrification of aircraft, there is growing interest in using vacuum contactors in electric aircraft due to their significant advantages. These contactors are particularly valued for their low operating losses, which contribute to higher efficiency, a critical factor in electric propulsion systems. Additionally, their ability to switch rapidly makes them well-suited for the frequent and dynamic switching required during various stages of an aircraft’s mission profile. However, despite these benefits, the electric arc generated during the switching process presents a considerable challenge. This issue is particularly concerning with the increasing use of DC systems in electric aircraft, as DC systems lack a natural current zero-crossing point. In this study, experiments on arc voltages during the opening of a vacuum contactor were conducted. The results show that vacuum arc voltage increases with current but generally remains between 10 V and 30 V across the range of currents investigated in this paper.

title: Pretrained Speech Models Learn Boundaries, Not Patterns: An Analysis of Supervised vs. Unsupervised Capabilities
authors: Abdul Rehman, Kavisha Jayathunge, Jian-Jun Zhang, Xiaosong Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Do pretrained speech models genuinely understand speech patterns, or do they simply learn to classify? We investigate this fundamental question by analyzing 10 state-of-the-art speech models across diverse tasks. We tested models on six speech characteristics (gender, accent, age, emotion, words, speaker identity) using both classification and clustering approaches. While models achieve impressive classification accuracy (up to $\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$ for gender, $\mathbf{9 4 . 9 \%}$ for words), they show poor clustering performance when attempting to discover identical patterns without supervision.
