title: Adaptive Gaze Estimation with Extended Memorization
authors: Jan Glinko
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Appearance-based gaze estimation still lacks generalizability due to anatomical and appearance differences at the human level. Their performance deteriorates significantly during cross-person evaluation and even more during cross-dataset evaluation. These drawbacks can be mitigated by employing subject-specific calibration data to personalize gaze estimation networks. Here, we present Adaptive Gaze Estimation with Extended Memorization (GEM), an adaptive gaze estimation framework. The core of GEM is a few-shot learning system and novel Extended Memorization. As a successful few-shot learner, GEM adapts to any previously unseen subject without overfitting, while Extended Memorization increases the efficacy and stability of the adaptation process. Crucially, GEM avoids the performance plateau seen in other methods; its accuracy improves consistently as calibration samples increase from 1 to 256. This allows it to compete with and quickly outperform prior deep-learning-only approaches with very few samples, and ultimately achieve state-of-the-art performance by continuing to improve as more calibration data is provided. GEM achieves the state-of-the-art performance of 2.32° on the MPIIFaceGaze dataset and 1.68° on the GazeCapture dataset during the cross-person evaluation.

title: Estimation of the Coefficient of Friction in Dissimilar Metals of Cu to SS Friction Weld Joints for NBI Ion Extractor Grid Fabrication
authors: Hardik D. Vyas, Tapan Patel, M. R. Jana, P. Chaudhuri, U. K. Baruah
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: This article investigates friction welding (FW) between electrolytic tough pitch copper (Cu) and 304 stainless steel (SS) in a rod joint configuration with a 16 mm diameter, utilizing the continuous drive FW technique. This welding was conducted by varying friction pressure (FP) and upset pressure (UP), while other parameters remained constant. From the welding parameters, the “coefficient of friction” (COF) was estimated, which is found in the range of 0.18–0.40. The concept of the COF is widely applied in both science and engineering. The variation in COF during the FW process affected the torque, which ranged from 12.13 to 16.2 Nm, and the power, which varied between 2094 and 2902 W. Changes in COF, torque, and power were governed by the applied pressure, which, in turn, influenced the strength of the welded joints. Notably, higher COF values corresponded to significant improvements in the tensile strength of the joint. All samples fractured on the Cu side, away from the interface, with the maximum recorded tensile strength reaching 202 MPa.

title: Robust Control of Heterogeneous Biohybrid Microrobots With Actuator Uncertainty Compensation
authors: Gang Huang, Zhihui Lu, Zhengyang Zhang, Mingsi Tong
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Biohybrid microrobots, which merge living biological matter with synthetic components, hold immense promise to revolutionize medicine by acting as targeted therapeutic agents. A fundamental barrier to their clinical translation, however, is their inherent biological heterogeneity—variations in size, morphology, and function—compounded by imperfections in actuation systems, resulting in unpredictable and unreliable motion. Here, we address this critical challenge by building a control framework that simultaneously compensates for both intrinsic robot-to-robot variability and extrinsic actuator nonlinearities. Our approach integrates real-time time-delay estimation to learn and cancel the unique, unmodeled dynamics of each individual microrobot, with a finite-time terminal sliding mode controller that ensures robust, high-fidelity trajectory tracking despite system imperfections. We demonstrate that this strategy standardizes the behavior of a heterogeneous population of cell-based microrobots (200–500 μm), reducing trajectory tracking errors by 51.3% compared to conventional controllers. By transforming these living constructs into reliable robotic agents, we enabled their precise deployment in a functional task, enhancing the closure rate of an in vitro tissue wound model by 77.8% . This work overcomes a crucial obstacle in biohybrid robotics, establishing a clear pathway toward harnessing the therapeutic potential of engineered living systems for applications in targeted drug delivery and regenerative medicine.

title: Design of a Linear PCB Winding Resolver With Longitudinal End Effect Suppression
authors: Yuhang Ding, Le Sun, Ruiwu Cao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The linear variable reluctance (VR) resolver as a contactless measurement component is essentially a small electric machine and presents a better reliability than other linear position sensors. For the high-density automated store shelves scenarios, the desired position sensor should have features of low-cost, small-size, high-precision, and easy-to-install on a several tens or even one hundred meters rail. The previously proposed linear resolvers for the long-distance application cannot well satisfy the above requirements. To address the issues, this article proposes a linear resolver system, which replaces the mover teeth and wire-wound winding with the printed circuit board (PCB) winding. This slotless structure is good for saving the manufacturing cost but induces a high flux leakage, which then causes a significant signal asymmetry. To suppress this longitudinal end asymmetry and its induced precision issue, this article investigates the PCB winding design. The additional auxiliary coils are added, and the complementary scheme is applied on the PCB. Experiments validate this extremely low-cost solution, which provides a less than 0.2 mm precision in a long rail.

title: Design of a Front-End Stage for Future European XFEL Detectors
authors: A. Ciavarella-Ciavarella, L. Nassi, G. Borghi, M. Carminati, M. Porro, C. Fiorini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: The European X-Ray Free Electron Laser (XFEL) represents a significant advancement in photon science, enabling experiments featuring an excellent temporal and spatial resolution. XFEL sources provide extremely intense and ultra-short (in the order of femtoseconds) X-ray pulses. Within this framework, new X-Ray pixel detectors are required to satisfy the challenging requirements from XFEL experiments, including high frame rates, wide dynamic range, and low noise for single-photon sensitivity. In particular, achieving single-photon resolution while maintaining a large dynamic range of up to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> photons presents substantial challenges in the design of the detector readout electronics. In this article, we present a novel front-end architecture based on a Charge Sensitive Amplifier (CSA) with predictive gain switching and a Flip-Capacitor filter. The CSA is designed for Silicon Pixel Detectors and aims to achieve both a single photon resolution and a high dynamic range up to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> photons by employing an adaptive control of the gain. The novel predictive gain circuit dynamically sets the proper gain by measuring the time needed by the signal to exceed a fixed threshold. The gain is automatically adjusted by adding feedback capacitances in parallel. When the CSA is in its highest gain configuration, a filter is connected to reduce the electronic noise and achieve the single-photon resolution below 1 keV. The filter is based on the Flip-Capacitor Filter concept and implements a fast trapezoidal weighting function. To couple the CSA with the filter, a voltage-to-current converter has been designed. A first prototype of this front-end has been designed in 65 nm CMOS technology, and the design and simulations are presented here.

title: CR-DARTS: Channel Redistribution-based Differentiable Architecture Search
authors: Ali Hassan, Tingting Zhang, Karen Egiazarian, Mårten Sjöström
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Differentiable Architecture Search (DARTS) has shown promising results in automating the design of deep learning models. However, its search process is computationally expensive because it evaluates all candidate operations simultaneously, often leading to an over-parameterized and inefficient search network. To reduce the computational cost, DARTS employs a smaller search network than the final evaluation network, which introduces an architecture optimization gap that limits real-world performance. To overcome this limitation, we introduce CR-DARTS, a multi-stage search framework designed to bridge the architecture optimization gap through an adaptive channel redistribution strategy. CR-DARTS reduces the computational complexity of the search network by compressing the shared input features among candidate operations and restoring the network dimensions via channel-wise feature concatenation. In addition, it progressively eliminates underperforming operations and redistributes the number of channels for more relevant feature extraction, thereby narrowing the gap between the search and evaluation networks. We validated CR-DARTS on two diverse computer vision tasks to assess its generalizability. Experimental results show that the proposed search framework reduces the memory requirement of the DARTS algorithm by up to 4.3×, while addressing the architecture optimization gap. Moreover, in the evaluation phase, the discovered architecture achieves up to 25.3% reductions in computational complexity and 50.6% faster inference time compared to state-of-the-art methods, while maintaining comparable accuracy. It also produces a competitive fire segmentation network that outperforms the state-of-the-art methods while maintaining similar computational efficiency. These results demonstrate that CR-DARTS is a practical solution for neural architecture search. Source code will be made publicly available at https://github.com/Realistic3D-MIUN/CR-DARTS.

title: Platform Policies and Quality Class: When are Hotels Prone to Rating Manipulation?
authors: Lihi Dery, Artyom Jelnov, Pavel Jelnov
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Online platforms depend on trust and reputation, yet these are open to manipulation. This paper develops a game-theoretic model of rating manipulation that accounts for platform enforcement policies, market competition, and class differentiation among service providers. The model shows that stricter sanctions can paradoxically increase incentives to manipulate by reducing competition, while greater competition reduces manipulation. To illustrate the model’s applicability, we analyze hotel reviews from Bangkok collected from Agoda, where only verified customers can post reviews, and TripAdvisor, where reviews are open to all users. The empirical results confirm that lower-class hotels are more prone to manipulation than higher-class hotels, consistent with theoretical predictions. Together, the theoretical and empirical findings provide insights for the design of trust and reputation systems in online platforms, highlighting trade-offs between enforcement, competition, and the integrity of ratings.

title: Optimising Quantum Algorithm Schemes According to the Topology of Quantum Computers
authors: Gabrielius Keibas, Linas Petkevičius
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: The use of quantum algorithms is rapidly expanding in various industries. These algorithms are run on quantum computers. There is no single technology to build quantum computers, so their architecture varies. For this reason, it is important to optimise the design of a quantum algorithm so that it is implemented on a given quantum computer topology. A two-step solution to this problem is proposed. The first step is to find the initial arrangement of qubits in the quantum scheme - qubit mapping problem. The search is for the arrangement with which the rearranged scheme comes closest to the topology of the quantum computer. The second step is the addition of SWAP operators, which is needed if the required path between two qubits does not exist. This optimisation algorithm has been tested with two algorithms, Bernstein-Varizani and a variational quantum classifier. The performance of the optimisation was also verified by running the optimised quantum circuit on a real quantum computer. After applying these algorithms to selected quantum computers, it can be argued that for most quantum computers, the initial qubit-finding setup is not sufficient and SWAP operators should be used. The probability of finding the initial qubit placement depends on the edge density of the computer topology graph. The higher the density, the higher the probability of finding a suitable layout and the less SWAP operators are used. Also, the larger the topology of the quantum computer, the more SWAP operators are used.

title: Adapting Voice Detection Algorithm for Respiratory Rate Determination In Noisy Environments
authors: Bernhards Bertulis, Jevgenijs Telicko, Andris Jakovics
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Respiratory rate is a critical physiological indicator, providing valuable insights into an individual’s physical health and response to various stress factors. Despite its significance, non-invasive and affordable respiratory monitoring solutions remain limited, particularly in non-clinical settings such as sports. This study proposes a reliable and highly potential approach by repurposing existing machine learning models for voice-activity detection to determine the exhale rate, even in high noise-to-signal conditions. A CNN-BiLSTM model was trained on a custom-labelled exhalation dataset and compared against a mathematical filter-based approach in laboratory and real-life gym environments. The deep learning model achieved a high True Positive Rate of 94.9% and a low Mean Absolute Error of 0.46 in clean conditions, with a Mean Square Error of 4.30. It maintained over 90% accuracy at moderate signal-to-noise ratio, outperforming the mathematical approach in low-noise scenarios.

title: Influence of Contact Diameter and Contact Distance on Post-Arc Sheath Development in High-Current Vacuum Interruption
authors: Yuanbing Zhang, Chen Fu, Zewei Lai, Xinquan Li, Hui Ma, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Due to the large size and high interrupting capacity of the contacts, especially in 110 kV and higher voltage level, it is essential to investigate the influence of the contact diameter and the contact distance on the post-arc sheath development in high-current vacuum interruption. The objective of this paper is to investigate the influence of the contact diameter and the contact distance on the development of the post-arc sheath in high-current vacuum interruption. The development of the post-arc sheath, as the initial stage of the dielectric recovery, significantly influences the recovery characteristics. A post-arc sheath model for high-current vacuum interruption was developed using the Particle-in-Cell (PIC) method. Through the simulation of the sheath development process, the characteristics of sheath development under different contact diameters and contact distances were analyzed and determined. For a 70 mm contact distance, as the contact diameter increases from 100 mm to 140 mm, the sheath development time increases from $12.8 \mu \mathrm{~s}$ to $14.0 \mu \mathrm{~s}$, an increase of about $9.38 \%$; For a contact diameter of 140 mm, as the contact distance increases from 50 mm to 70 mm, the sheath development time increases from $\mathbf{1 0. 6} \boldsymbol{\mu}$ s to $\mathbf{1 4. 0} \boldsymbol{\mu}$ s, an increase of about $\mathbf{3 2. 1 \%}$. For the large-sized contacts, the increase in contact spacing has a more significant effect on sheath development than the increase in contact diameter. The results of this paper are helpful to understand the physical mechanism of the post-arc dielectric recovery.

title: A Staged Spectral Acquisition Method for Intermediate-Frequency Vacuum Arcs Under Ruled Curved Contacts
authors: Ziang Tong, Jianwen Wu, Yuan Jiang, Chunpeng Gu, Shengsheng Shi, Dejie Wei
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The parameters of microscopic particles during the arcing process of a vacuum arc are among the crucial parameters reflecting the arc state. Specifically, the parameters of the microscopic components of the vacuum arc serve as important indicators for evaluating the degree of ionization of the gap metal vapor. At present, the research methods for the components of vacuum arcs mainly fall into two categories: measuring the charge to mass ratio of ions and conducting spectral diagnosis of the arc. As a non-contact measurement approach, spectral diagnosis can make use of the fact that each particle component corresponds to a characteristic wavelength spectrum to obtain the percentage distribution of the microscopic components of particles. Since the interruption time of a vacuum arc is usually on the millisecond scale, especially for intermediate-frequency vacuum arcs, the half - wave arcing time is only 1.3 ms. However, ordinary spectral analysis systems can only analyze the spectra of power - frequency arcs and lack the analysis of spectral changes within the arcing cycle. Therefore, this paper proposes a staged arc spectrum acquisition system. Moreover, it analyzes the spectra of intermediate-frequency vacuum arcs under ruled curved contacts and obtains the spectral variation trend of a 360 Hz, 7 kA vacuum arc.

title: The Federated Sample Weight Model: A New Strategy for Precision Medicine
authors: Jiaxuan Li, Zhihe Peng, Liang Xu, Yulong Li, Shuai Zheng, Lingwen Kong, Zixin Quan, Xiaolu Xu, Zhaohong Geng

title: Application of LSTM in the dynamic changes of tourism market in Hunan Province
authors: Meijing Song, Mohamad Idrakisyah Abdullah
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This study aims to analyze the dynamic changes of the tourism market in Hunan Province through the long short-term memory network (LSTM) model, analyze the main driving factors, and predict the total tourism revenue and growth rate data of Hunan Province from 2012 to 2024. The study uses the LSTM model to model and analyze the changes in the tourism market, and preprocesses the data, including missing value filling, standardization and normalization. With the help of the LSTM model, the long-term dependence of the tourism market is modeled to capture the role of seasonal fluctuations, economic changes and policy factors. The experimental results show that the LSTM model can effectively improve the accuracy of the prediction, especially when compared with the traditional ARIMA model, LSTM presents lower prediction errors and higher accuracy. Economic factors, seasonal changes, social behavior adjustments and policy support are identified as the main factors driving changes in the tourism market.

title: Mapping AI's Contribution to SDGs: Insights from a Bibliometric Study
authors: Yang Wang, Bingxuan Liu, Yanli Liu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) require innovative solutions to address global challenges. Artificial intelligence (AI) is a transformative technology with the potential to significantly contribute to achieving these goals. This study used bibliometric analysis to examine the role of AI in advancing the SDGs (AI4SDGs), drawing on data from the Web of Science Core Collection (WoSCC) from 1900 to 2025. Big data analysis, bibliometrics and VOSviewer software were used to analyse a total of 897 publications. The results reveal a substantial surge in AI-related publications since 2021, with a peak anticipated in 2024. China has the highest publication output, followed by India, the United States, and the United Kingdom. Thematic analysis revealed eight key research clusters, including AI applications in healthcare, climate action, sustainable agriculture, and smart cities. Despite the growing recognition of AI's potential, certain social science-related SDGs (e.g. SDGs 1, 5, 8, 14, 16 and 17) remain underrepresented. This study highlights the growing body of research on artificial intelligence for sustainable development goals (AI4SDGs) and suggests that future work should address gaps in social sustainability and integrate AI with social science methods to promote a more holistic approach to sustainable development.

title: A Data-Driven Approach to Predict “Freebie-Seeker” Behaviors in Digital Marketing
authors: Bingjie Xiang, Xiaoying Han, Qian Gu, Fei Chao, Xiao Yang, Xin Fu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: With the popularity of digital marketing, the identification and prediction of the Freebie-Seekers has become particularly critical. This study focuses on two scenarios: live broadcasting and code scanning, aiming to explore and accurately identify such behavior. Traditional identification methods require a lot of manual intervention in model design and parameter adjustment, which not only increases the computational cost, but also makes it difficult to guarantee the accuracy of the final model. We adopt a black-box optimization method to search the parameter space of the model, estimate the conditional probability distributions of the hyperparameters by constructing a Gaussian mixture model, and select the hyperparameter combinations with the best performance based on these distributions. Through feature engineering construction and model selection, we evaluate the LightGBM and XGBoost models. The experimental results reveal that after hyperparameter optimization, both models achieve significant performance improvement, with the F1 value of XGBoost reaching 0.8685 in the QR code scanning scenario, while the F1 value of LightGBM in the live streaming scenario is 0.7662. From the business perspective, our model successfully predicts a large number of Freebie-Seekers in the live streaming and live streaming scenarios. From the business point of view, our model successfully predicts a large number of Freebie-Seekers and reduces the potential economic loss by 20.77% and 1.78% in the live streaming and QR code scanning scenarios, respectively. Therefore, this study not only provides an effective prediction method of Freebie-Seekers, but also provides a strong data support for the strategic decision of digital marketing

title: Prediction of Conductor Displacement Under Wind-Ice Loads
authors: Siyuan Chen, Rui Zhu, Wei Chen, Jiayang Zou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Energy, Power and Electrical Technology (ICEPET)
abstract: As an important factor affecting the safe and stable operation of the power system, the icing of transmission lines is particularly prominent in Xinjiang. In this study, taking a 220kV transmission line in Xinjiang as an example, the finite element analysis method is used to deeply discuss the dynamic response characteristics of the transmission tower-line system under the combined load of wind and ice under icing conditions. By establishing a detailed finite element model of the transmission tower-line coupling system, we fully consider the mechanical properties and structural response of the transmission tower and the conductor. The simulation results show that the icing significantly increases the load on the transmission tower, resulting in a significant increase in the displacement of the members, which threatens the overall stability of the structure. In addition, we systematically studied the effects of different wind angles, wind speeds, and ice thickness on the performance of the transmission tower-line system. Among them, there was a significant positive correlation between wind speed and transmission line displacement, and the impact was the most significant. The wire displacement is the largest at the 0° wind angle; Although the influence of ice cover thickness on displacement is relatively small, the influence of wind load may be aggravated under extreme conditions. In order to better predict and manage the safety risks of transmission lines, this study further uses the nonlinear extreme accumulation function model to fit the wind speed, icing thickness and displacement data, and successfully establishes a prediction model, which provides an important quantitative analysis tool for the design and maintenance of transmission lines.

title: ISDEIV 2025 Copyright Page

title: Retraction Notice: An Integration Of Wireless Communications And Artificial Intelligence For Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Kadambari Raghuram, Ibrahim Altarawni, Vijayalakshmi K, Ajay Kumar, Abhijeetsinh Jadeja, Pankaj Chandra
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The pinnacle of transportation is the development of autonomous driving, which, with the help of CAVs and related traffic management systems, can eventually lead to congestion- and accident-free driving. This vision has as of late prodded extraordinary examination interest in fields including IoV, LTE-V2X, and 5G. In any case, the huge volume of traffic information that CAVs produce makes issues for both the current organizations and the approaching 5G correspondence organizations. For outside network innovations, the VMBS fills in as both a client hub and an edge processing hub. For CAVs, it fills in as a base station and a data caching hub, melding correspondence and calculation. People offer both the VMBS-empowered handset and figuring for CAVs as well as the VMBS-helped wireless innovation for other wireless gadgets to achieve this. It is underlined and addressed that there are a number of research obstacles and open questions. Last but not least, the results of the simulation show that the planned VMBS-CCNA may significantly enhance throughput, latency, and the average amount of links.

title: Retraction Notice: The Novel E-Way of Identifying the Face Mask and To Ware the System in the Crowd Management System
authors: Ashwani Kumar, Sachin Gupta, Nikhitha Yathiraju, Sayantika Bose Chakraborty, Koteswaramma Dodda, Devvret Verma
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Since World War II, the Coronavirus has been the most critical charity test the world has faced. The globe has fought the epidemic with incredible bravery, and the early phases have been particularly heart-breaking. Correctly wearing a veil had shown to be an effective method of limiting the transmission of illness. We're working on developing a technique that will allow us to detect fine-grained veil wear issues. There are three primary obstacles to overcome in this project: 1) a variety of facial expressions, 2) a variety of veil types and instances; and 3) a variety of facial impediments We built a new, reasonable dataset of 4000 photos to figure out what was causing the issues. The proposed method is to leverage SSD with Caffe and MobileNetV2 engineering as a picture classifier to provide continuous veil recognition. The accuracy of this model is 96 percent. On this decent dataset, more high-level models for warm scanning and facial recognition are constructed.

title: A comprehensive study of uterine muscle activity during the third trimester: comparison of singleton and multiple gestations.
authors: Yu Meng, Javier Garcia-Casado, Gema Prats-Boluda, Jose Luis Martinez-de-Juan, Carmen Padilla Prieto, Rogelio Monfort-Ortiz, Vicente José Diago-Almela, Dongmei Hao, Guangfei Li, Yiyao Ye-Lin
publish: IEEE Journal of Translational Engineering in Health and Medicine
abstract: Objective: Electrohysterography (EHG) has been shown to provide valuable information for assessing preterm birth risk. However, few studies have focused on multiple gestations (MG), a well-known risk factor for preterm birth. This study aimed to comprehensively characterize and compare uterine EHG signals between singleton (SG) and MG pregnancies during the third trimester. Method: This prospective cohort study analyzed 383 EHG recordings from 61 SG and 92 MG women during the third trimester. A whole-window approach was used to extract four key EHG features: peak-to-peak amplitude (PPA), Kurtosis of the Hilbert Envelope (KHE), median frequency (MDF) and sample entropy (SampEn). Generalized additive models (GAM) were applied to evaluate temporal trends across gestational age (GA) and gestation type (SG and MG). Results: In SG pregnancies, PPA and KHE progressively increased, with a significant rise in KHE at labour. MDF remained stable until labour, while SampEn gradually declined, especially at term. MG pregnancies showed similar but less pronounced trends: MG exhibited a notably earlier activation of uterine activity than SG before 32 weeks of gestation (WoG), and a slowing-down electrophysiological progression beyond 32 WoG, resulting in similar characteristics with no significant differences. Conclusions: These findings provide electrophysiological evidence suggesting that MG pregnancies may enter a labour-preparatory state earlier, potentially increasing the PTB risk, while the later convergence of EHG features may indicate compensatory mechanisms to delay labour. This work integrates EHG signal analysis with clinical obstetric care, offering valuable insights for clinical management and early PTB risk assessment in MG pregnancies.

title: A Novel Option Policy driven Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Overtaking Maneuver_supp1-3629873.pdf
authors: Neetesh Kumar
publish: N/A
abstract: Autonomous vehicle (AV) driving is a critical task, and among all driving maneuvers, overtaking is considered the most complex. Reinforcement Learning (RL) agents have been utilized for AV driving, leading to human like behavior. Recent advances in Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) have demonstrated impressive performance in handling AV driving maneuvers. However, overtaking involves sequential sub-tasks (lane changes, straight drive) requiring modularized control, and a single RL agent is often ineffective in managing these efficiently. Instead of relying on a single RL agent for the overtaking maneuver, we propose a novel Option Policy driven Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning (OP-HDRL) approach to select different sub-maneuver RL agents for overtaking. Each sub-maneuver RL agent is trained to complete simpler sub-tasks of overtaking. Decomposing overtaking into several sub-maneuvers, such as left lane change, straight drive, and right lane change, and training individual DRL agents for each, governed by a single master policy, reduces training time and improves generalization compared to a single RL/DRL agent. Traffic safety rules can be easily integrated into OP-HDRL for the overtaking maneuver. The proposed approach is evaluated through several overtaking scenarios inspired by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) pre-crash scenarios, using the CARLA simulator.

title: Hyperflex: A SIMD-Based DFA Model for Deep Packet Inspection
authors: Yang Liu, Wenjun Zhu, Harry Chang, Yang Hong, Geoff Langdale, Kun Qiu, Jin Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) has been extensively employed for network security. It examines traffic payloads by searching for regular expressions (regex) with the Deterministic Finite Automaton (DFA) model. However, as the network bandwidth and ruleset size are increasing rapidly, the conventional DFA model has emerged as a significant performance bottleneck of DPI. Leveraging the Single-Instruction-Multiple-Data (SIMD) instruction to perform state transitions can substantially boost the efficiency of the DFA model. In this paper, we propose Hyperflex, a novel SIMD-based DFA model designed for high-performance regex matching. Hyperflex incorporates a region detection algorithm to identify regions suitable for acceleration by SIMD instructions across the whole DFA graph. Also, we design a hybrid state transition algorithm that enables state transition in both SIMD-accelerated and normal regions, and ensures seamless state transition across the two types of regions. We have implemented Hyperflex on the commodity CPU and evaluated it with real network traffic and DPI regexes. Our evaluation results indicate that Hyperflex reaches a throughput of 8.89Gbit/s, representing an improvement of up to 2.27 times over Mcclellan, the default DFA model of the prominent multi-pattern regex matching engine Hyperscan. As a result, Hyperflex has been successfully deployed in Hyperscan, significantly enhancing its performance.

title: Recent Advances in Securing Networked Systems
authors: Trent Jaeger, Chengyu Song
publish: IEEE Security & Privacy
abstract: This special issue examines the security challenges in modern networked systems from the perspective of edge devices, core network, and specialized security services and provide guidance in these areas.

title: Towards Wi-Fi 8 Standard: A Survey of State-of-the-Art Technologies
authors: Shiwen He, Chengzuo Peng, Wei Huang, Zhenyu An, Yurong Qian, Linhua Liu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: With the emergence of new applications such as collaborative mobile robots and immersive communications, the stringent requirements on the reliability and latency are far beyond the capabilities of existing wireless local area networks (WLANs) standards. To meet these demands, IEEE 802.11 standard organization has established a working group to revise the existing WLAN standard with a aim to achieve ultra-high reliability (UHR) and ultra-low latency. This paper provides a comprehensive survey of key technologies on physical layer and medium access control layer discussed in the UHR working group. Specifically, it focuses primarily on the related progress of the technologies, such as double low-density parity-check codeword lengths, a new modulation and coding scheme as well as unequal modulation techniques, distributed resource units, multi-access point coordination techniques, non-primary channel access, and seamless roaming, etc. Meanwhile, this paper further reviews the progress related to the low-high frequency common baseband technologies. Finally, a few potential research directions beyond the state-of-the-art technologies discussed in the working group are discussed for the development of WLAN technologies.

title: To the Stars, Dead or Alive

title: A Reinforcement Learning-Based Attack Generator for Testing the Security of Connected and Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Arman Sargolzaei, Farahnaz Javidi-Niroumand
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs) are employed to enhance the safety and efficiency of transportation systems. However, their connectivity makes them vulnerable to various types of attacks, such as false data injection (FDI) attacks, which can lead to unsafe scenarios. Therefore, there is a need to develop a framework to test and verify the security of CAVs under such attacks. Currently, researchers test the security of CAVs by generating manual and random attacks, but there is no automatic attack generation with proof of convergence. In this paper, for the first time, we look at testing and verification as a feedback control system problem with unknown dynamics. We introduce a novel <strike xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">centralized</strike> multi-agent attack generator designed to evaluate the safety and security of CAVs under FDI attacks. Our approach begins with the development of a verification signal to systematically assess the safety and performance of CAVs. We then design a reinforcement learning-based FDI attack generator, capable of estimating the unknown nonlinear relationship between the injected FDI attack and the verification signal, ultimately generating scenarios that compromise safety. A Lyapunov-based stability analysis is conducted to ensure the asymptotic convergence of the verification signal error. We employ the proposed reinforcement learning (RL)-based FDI attack generator on a cooperative adaptive cruise control (CACC) system as a case study, demonstrating its capability to create challenging and unsafe scenarios.

title: Study on the Equivalence of Vacuum Arc Zero Zone Process Gaps
authors: Jishi Yan, Chongyang Huang, Si Fu, Xiaobo Li, Zhengbo Li
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Taking single-break DC vacuum circuit breakers as the research object, an experimental platform for collecting characteristic information of single-break DC vacuum arcs was established. Images of the zero-zone process of vacuum arcs were captured. Based on image processing technology, characteristic parameters of vacuum arc images were extracted and digitally processed. Using pseudo-color processing, the regions of plasma concentration distribution in the arc were divided, and the curve of changes in the area of plasma temperature regions during the zero-zone process was obtained. Through arc image processing, the growth curves of the area of different temperature regions in the vacuum arc are obtained to investigate the impact of the gap on the rapid dissipation of arc energy. The arc morphology and plasma distribution characteristics of flat contacts and transverse magnetic contacts are compared to study the equivalent influence of the gap between flat contacts and the self-generated magnetic field of transverse magnetic contacts on the breaking performance. The trend of arc area changes under a 6 mm transverse magnetic contact gap and an 8 mm flat contact gap is comparable. The equivalence of gaps is discussed at different stages of arc development. The equivalent relationship between gaps and arc control capability under the same operating conditions for the 卍-shaped transverse magnetic contact structure is established, providing data support for the argument of gap equivalence. This study provides an optimization direction for enhancing the breaking capability of DC vacuum circuit breakers.

title: Post Arc Plasma following DC Interruption achieved by a Vacuum Interrupter
authors: Qiang Tang, Shenli Jia, Zongqian Shi, Yongpeng Mo
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum interrupters (VIs) of various voltage ratings and diverse magnetic coils have been increasingly applied in medium and high voltage direct current circuit breakers (DCCBs) in recent years. Significantly different interruption conditions from AC interruption are imposed in DCCBs which include the rapidly decreasing current before the forced current zero (CZ) and the steep initial transient interruption voltage (ITIV) following the CZ. Post arc current forms as a result of residual plasma driven by ITIV after the CZ. Parameters of the post arc plasma can be estimated by fitting the simulated post arc current to the measured one. The initial density and decay time constant are two concerned plasma parameters and they have been investigated in this paper.

title: Detailed Analysis of High Current Anode Phenomena by Intensified Video Optical Emission Spectroscopy
authors: Sergey Gortschakow, Ralf Methling, Dirk Uhrlandt
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: A novel diagnostic technique - intensified video optical emission spectroscopy was used for study of high-current anode phenomena in switching vacuum arcs. This technique allows for 20 times better temporal resolution comparing to video spectroscopy. High-current anode mode transitions between the spot mode and plume mode were in the focus of the study as they significantly influence the arc plasma properties and accelerate the contact surface degradation. Reversable mode transitions were studied more in detail by combined optical diagnostics, which comprises high-speed imaging, spectroscopic measurements and high-speed thermography. A correlation between arc voltage and anode surface temperature in case of spot-to-plume transition was revealed. Analysis of spatial distribution of excited atomic and ionic copper species points out to possible changes in the current path after anode spot formation.

title: Spectroscopic Studies of Fast Phenomena in Vacuum Switching Arcs
authors: Sergey Gortschakow, Ralf Methling, Dirk Uhrlandt
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Spectroscopic methods have the potential to determine physical properties of vacuum switching arcs with their spatial and temporal distribution. New developments of imaging techniques such as fast cameras and image intensifiers have extended the possibilities considerably in the last years. This paper gives a short review of spectroscopic methods in particular with respect to spatial and temporal resolution, which can be obtained to study fast phenomena without accumulations of recordings. The application of optical emission and absorption spectroscopy, of laser-induced fluorescence and interferometry is shown by examples. Recent achievements are illustrated by studies of fast oscillations of anode spot modes in high-current vacuum arcs.

title: Erosion of cathode materials with different melting temperatures in a pulsed vacuum arc
authors: Vadim Gridilev
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The specific erosion of cathodes made of different materials was measured in a pulsed vacuum arc. The pulsed vacuum arc current was 200 A at a pulse duration of $250 \mu \mathrm{~s}$. It was found that the specific erosion of cathodes with a melting point less than 650 K was many times greater than for more refractory cathode materials with a melting point above 900 K. The measured cathode surface temperature was up to 800 K which is higher than the melting temperature of low-melting cathodes. The COMSOL Multiphysics simulation showed that the cathode surface melting depth per a single arc pulse was tens of micrometers. Control experiments with a silumin cathode also confirmed melting of the cathode material to a depth of several tens of micrometers. It was concluded that the high erosion of low-melting cathodes was due to sputtering of the surface cathode material by the cathode spot and generation of an intense flux of macroparticles.

title: SPSS-Based Correlation and Regression Analysis of Supportive Care Needs and Influencing Factors in Cancer Radiotherapy
authors: Wen-xin Gong, Han-Rong Zhang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: Radiotherapy still plays an indispensable role in cancer treatment but in general, cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy suffer significant psychological as well as physical pain and thus have disparate SCS requirements. In this research, we assessed SCS requirements in patients received radiotherapy, explored these requirements, and estimated their quantitative correlation. In this research, the questionnaires General Information Questionnaire, SCNS-SF34-C were administered via a simple random sample-based method at a cancer tertiary care center in Guangzhou. All statistical computation and processing are conducted through SPSS26. Mean SCNS= 124.51 ± 27.16 in men and 120.60 ± 26.10 in women; Positive correlation between SCNS and marital status (r = 0.147, P < 0.05) and occupation (r = –0.148, P < 0.05), negative correlation to annual income (r =–0.198, P<0.01). The regression identified marital status (β = 0.204, P = 0.002) and income (β = –0.210, P = 0.001).Among all sociodemographic characteristics there was a tendency to see some predictor variables (HMO-001) that emerged interestingly consistent (adjusted R² = 0.083). The use of visual representations, heatmaps, boxplots and bar charts helped explain the distribution of SCNS. Briefly, patients with lower socioeconomic characteristics and married patients were characterized by a higher demand. These outcomes provide a framework for locally-tailored evidence-informed nursing interventions for radiotherapy.

title: Retraction Notice: IP & IoT Based Waterbody Surveillance (Monitoring) Process Implementation for Floods Alert System
authors: Pulkit Giri, Manika Manwal, Pranav Chaudhary, Pragati Tiwari, Rajkumar, Kanhaiya Kumar
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This think about offers a novel strategy for observing riverbed water levels utilizing computer vision, picture handling, and the Web of Things. The coastline and stream levels are decided by analyzing photographs gotten by a vision camera and utilizing boundary discovery innovations. Surge escalated appraisals may be computed by comparing the level of the stream with the shoreline. Client notices are encouraged utilizing Ubidots, an Online of Things (too called IoT) framework that gets concentrated information. Social media destinations are utilized to inform the open when water levels rise over basic levels. As a controlling gadget, the plan coordinating a Banana Pi 3 B show that comes with a Banana Pi 5MP sensor bundle. This work’s fundamental commitment is the integration of picture handling with IoT clouds. creating a cutting-edge surge checking instrument to combat warming temperatures, locate flood zones, and caution individuals to circumstances that may be perilous. The achievability of consolidating IoT foundation, machine learning, and vision for surge checking is affirmed by test discoveries. In this inquire about, stream level and bank level are decided by comparing the adequacy of edge discovery calculations. The device’s potential for down to earth operation is approved by broad testing carried out within the occasion of a surge catastrophe.

title: Prediction of White Matter Hyperintensity Progression: A Systematic Comparison of Preprocessing Methods and Deep Learning Models_supp1-3637138.pdf
authors: HYUN-CHUL KIM
publish: N/A
abstract: White matter hyperintensity (WMH) progression is a critical marker of cerebral small vessel disease; however, its prediction remains challenging due to inter-institutional variability and the inherently non-deterministic nature of lesion evolution. To our knowledge, this is the first study to systematically evaluate preprocessing strategies and prediction frameworks for WMH progression using a large-scale, multi-institutional dataset from the PICASSO trial (67 institutions). We compared three preprocessing pipelines, harmonization, normalization, and their combination, with three prediction frameworks: fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR)-to-FLAIR, WMH-to-WMH, and disease evolution map (DEM). These were assessed in conjunction with multiple deep learning architectures. Our results demonstrate that harmonization substantially reduces inter-institutional variability and that the DEM framework consistently outperforms direct image-to-image prediction in volumetric and spatial agreement. Furthermore, we provide the first direct comparison of U-Net, GAN, and diffusion models under identical experimental conditions, showing that diffusion models deliver balanced performance in capturing non-deterministic lesion dynamics. At the same time, U-Net achieves the highest spatial agreement. Collectively, these findings establish the first comprehensive benchmark of WMH progression prediction across preprocessing strategies, prediction frameworks, and model architectures, and underscore the translational potential of DEM-based prediction with harmonization for individualized risk stratification and clinical decision-making.

title: A Scannable Directional Modulation Secure Communication Method With Time-Modulated Array
authors: Shufan Ge, Siyu Zhou, Xiaonan Zhao, Junping Geng, Jingfeng Chen, Ronghong Jin
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This paper presents a scannable directional modulation secure communication method based on a single-sideband time-modulated array. By optimizing the modulation parameters that generate equivalent amplitude-phase weighting for each antenna element in the radio frequency channel, the main beam of the first-order harmonic and nulls of higher-order harmonics are simultaneously steered toward the desired direction. This enables efficient transmission of signals with bandwidths exceeding the modulation frequency. Furthermore, in contrast to conventional approaches, the proposed method incorporates the degree of harmonic energy aliasing across all orders at non-target directions into the optimization objective, thereby enhancing signal distortion and ensuring robust information security at these directions. Numerical simulations validate the feasibility of the proposed method. Experimental results demonstrate that the communication bit error rate decreases to as low as 1 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup> at the target communication direction, whereas it exceeds 30% at all non-target directions within -40° to 40°.

title: Design of Resistive SFCL to Prevent Short-Circuit-Induced Plastic Deformation in Transformer Windings
authors: Chengxiang Liu, Caiyong Ye, Zhuoyan Zhong, Chenguang Yan, Bing Xue, Zhengyang Tang, Bo Xu, Xiao Yang, Fanya Sang, Xueliang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Transformers are subjected to severe mechanical stress during external short-circuit faults due to intense radial electromagnetic forces, which can lead to winding deformation and structural failure. To address this issue, this study proposes a systematic design methodology for a resistive-type superconducting fault current limiter (R-SFCL) aimed at suppressing fault currents below critical thresholds to protect transformer windings. The proposed approach integrates mechanical finite element (FE) analysis, field-circuit coupling simulations, and electrothermal modeling to determine the critical yielding radial force of transformer windings based on elastoplastic theory, identify the short-circuit currents levels that induce plastic deformation, and optimize high-temperature superconducting (HTS) tape dimensions to achieve effective current limitation while maintaining thermal safety. For a 110 kV/40 MVA transformer, an R-SFCL with 4800 m of HTS tape reduces peak fault current by 42% to 2855 A, limits conductor stress to 60 MPa (50% yield strength), and maintains temperatures below 473 K during faults, demonstrating effectiveness in preventing irreversible mechanical damage of winding.

title: BBD-YOLO: An Improved Object Detection Algorithm for UAV Images Based on Dynamic Sparse Attention and Multi-scale Feature Fusion
authors: Wenfeng Wang, Sheng Liang, Min Xie, Ying Luo, Zhijie Wang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Object detection technology for UAV images holds significant importance in various fields. However, many existing object detection algorithms suffer from limited detection accuracy, along with issues like small-target missed or false detections. Given the resource-constrained UAV devices, balancing model complexity and detection performance is crucial for practical use. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an enhanced object detection algorithm, BBD-YOLO, which incorporates dynamic sparse attention and multi-scale feature fusion. First, a dynamic sparse attention module grounded in bilevel routing is integrated into the backbone network. This integration serves to strengthen the algorithm’s feature extraction capability, thereby boosting the detection accuracy of small targets. Second, the neck network is reengineered through a bidirectional feature pyramid. This modification aims to enhance the algorithm’s multi-scale feature fusion ability, enabling it to perform more effectively in detecting targets of varying sizes. Third, Inner-IoU is introduced to develop a new loss function, Inner-CIoU, which overcomes the poor generalization ability of the original bounding box regression loss function and improves the algorithm’s detection accuracy. Finally, to tackle the problem of substantial feature information loss during down-sampling, an object detection head founded on a unified attention mechanism is designed. This mechanism enhances the feature representation ability of the object detection head, contributing to more accurate object detection. Comparison experiments are conducted on the VisDrone2019 public dataset. The findings reveal that, when compared with the baseline algorithm YOLOv8, BBD-YOLO achieves remarkable improvements in overall performance. Specifically, it has enhanced mAP50 by 4.0%, mAP50:95 by 2.5%, Precision by 3.1%, and Recall by 2.9%, respectively. Notably, these performance gains have been achieved with a parameter count (3.00M) nearly identical to the baseline (3.01M) and an acceptable increase in FLOPs (9.3G vs. 8.1G of the baseline), ensuring computational feasibility for resource-constrained UAV scenarios. Furthermore, on the VisDrone2019 and DOTAv1.0 datasets, BBD-YOLO outperforms multiple algorithms such as SSD, Faster R-CNN, and various models in the YOLO series, including several state-of-the-art object detection models specifically designed for UAV images. This demonstrates its effectiveness and superiority in the field of UAV-based object detection.

title: Accelerating Residual Reinforcement Learning With Uncertainty Estimation_supp1-3636808.mov
authors: Lakshita Dodeja
publish: N/A
abstract: Residual Reinforcement Learning (RL) is a popular approach for adapting pretrained policies by learning a lightweight residual policy that provides corrective actions. While Residual RL is more sample-efficient than finetuning the entire base policy, existing methods struggle with sparse rewards and are designed for deterministic base policies. We propose two improvements to Residual RL that further enhance its sample efficiency and make it suitable for stochastic base policies. First, we leverage uncertainty estimates of the base policy to focus exploration on regions in which the base policy is not confident. Second, we propose a simple modification to off-policy residual learning that allows it to observe base actions and better handle stochastic base policies. We evaluate our method with both Gaussian-based and Diffusion-based stochastic base policies on tasks from Robosuite and D4RL, and compare against state-of-the-art finetuning methods, demo-augmented RL methods, and other Residual RL methods. Our algorithm significantly outperforms existing baselines in a variety of simulation benchmark environments. We also deploy our learned policies in the real world to demonstrate their robustness with zero-shot sim-to-real transfer.

title: Experimental Study of the Effect of Thyristor and Transistor-Based Power Converter Topologies on Alkaline Water Electrolyzer Losses
authors: Manuel Agredano-Torres, Pietari Puranen, Lauri Järvinen, Vesa Ruuskanen, Antti Kosonen, Qianwen Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Large-scale water electrolyzers have the ability to operate as flexible loads, absorbing power fluctuations in power systems with high or full share of variable renewable energy sources (VRESs). For large-scale industrial applications, alkaline water electrolyzers (AWEs) and thyristor-based power converter topologies are commonly used due to their lower cost compared to proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWEs) and transistor-based topologies. However, thyristor-rectifiers have a significant ripple when operated at partial load. A wide operational range is required when electrolyzers operate in a flexible manner, and large current ripples due to the power converter topology increase the power losses in the electrolyzer. Therefore, it is essential to study the impact of the current ripple on AWE performance. This article proposes an evaluation approach to systematically assess the impact of different power converter topologies on AWE losses, including an electrolyzer model for power electronic applications and experimental verification. Realistic current waveforms for industrial applications are obtained from a simulated large-scale electrolyzer system, and these waveforms are tested in a small-scale experimental setup. The experimental results validate the large-scale system simulations and the proposed model and provide quantitative assessment of AWE losses caused by the current ripple. The results also show that the six-pulse thyristor rectifier has the highest current ripples, causing the highest additional losses in the electrolyzer.

title: Latent Diffusion Model with Estimation Posterior Sampling: A Unified Framework for General Medical Image Restoration
authors: Qianhao Chen, Hanzhong Wang, Yi An, Meiyuan Wen, Biao Li, Hairong Zheng, Dong Liang, Zhanli Hu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Clinical imaging protocols designed to accelerate acquisition or reduce radiation dose often lead to degraded image quality, compromising diagnostic confidence. The heterogeneity in degradation types and severities across imaging modalities further challenges the development of generalized restoration solutions. In this work, we introduce a unified framework that formulates medical image restoration as posterior sampling from self-supervised Latent Diffusion Models (LDMs), pretrained on multi-modal high-quality images. At the core of our method is an Estimation Posterior Sampling (EPS) strategy, which enhances both data fidelity and anatomical detail retention. EPS incorporates two key components: (i) estimated diffusion initialization to constrain sampling within the measurement-consistent solution space, and (ii) gradient-balanced optimization to adaptively trade off denoising strength and detail preservation throughout the diffusion trajectory. Unlike traditional task-specific models, our approach enables Plug-and-Play (PnP) deployment, supporting diverse degradations without retraining. Extensive experiments conducted on deterministic degradations (e.g., under-sampled MRI, sparse-view CT) and blind degradations (e.g., low-dose PET) across multiple degradation levels demonstrate superior quantitative and qualitative performance compared to both supervised baselines and state-of-the-art posterior sampling methods. Notably, our method achieves PSNR improvements of up to +2.9 dB (MRI), +1.1 dB (CT), and +0.9 dB (PET) in PnP mode. These results highlight the robustness and broad applicability of our framework for clinical deployment.

title: Retraction Notice: A Review: Study About Techniques to Improve Quality of Services And Security in Manets
authors: Seema Barda, Prabhjot Singh Manocha
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Remote correspondence innovations are assuming a critical part in the plan and execution of Mobile Ad hoc Network (MANET). The portrayal of MANET, for example, dynamism in geography, restricted transfer speed and power usage expands the unlicensed correspondence advancements and intricacies in existing conventions. This paper analyzes the current and not so distant future Wireless correspondence Technologies in the 2.4 GHz band. Additionally, this paper thinks about the features and limits of those advances lastly closes with the need for the improvement of reasonable brought together convention for existing and future remote advances. It has been considered that the overview and correlation introduced in this paper would help specialists and application engineers in choosing a fitting innovation for MANET administrations.

title: A Robust Decomposition-Based RLS Algorithm for Echo Cancellation Applications
authors: Radu-Andrei Otopeleanu, Camelia Elisei-Iliescu, Constantin Paleologu, Jacob Benesty, Cristian-Lucian Stanciu, Cristian Anghel
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Echo cancellation is one of the most popular applications of adaptive filtering algorithms. In this framework, the algorithms have to be equipped with fast convergence/tracking features while should also be robust to different background perturbations. In terms of the convergence criteria, the decomposition-based recursive least-squares (RLS) algorithm represents a very appealing choice. It exploits an impulse response decomposition that relies on low-rank approximations and combines the estimates provided by two shorter adaptive filters using the nearest Kronecker product (NKP). In this paper, we develop a regularized version of the RLS-NKP algorithm with improved robustness features. The regularization components incorporate specific terms related to the background perturbations and model uncertainties, which are evaluated in a simple yet practical manner. Simulation results obtained in the context of network and acoustic echo cancellation support the performance gain.

title: Wire-shorted Rod-pinch Diode for Flash X-ray Radiography and Dynamic X-ray Diffraction
authors: Huantong Shi, Peizhou Zhang, Tongquan Wang, Jian Wu, Xingwen Li, Aici Qiu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The wire-shorted rod-pinch diode (RPD), with a metal wire spanning the anode-cathode gap (AK-gap) of the diode, is a low-impedance variants of the classical vacuum-gap RPD, which excels in X-ray dose level and small focal spot when deployed on low-impedance pulsed power drivers for intense transient X-ray generation. The load configuration is easy to adjust parametrically and does not require extra pulse source needed for other low-impedance RPDs, e.g. the plasma-prefilled RPD. The wire-shorted RPD exhibits promising potential in versatile experiments involving of flash X-ray radiography (FXR) and dynamic X-ray diffraction (DXRD). The wireshorted RPD has been tested on several pulsed power drivers at Xi’an Jiaotong University, China, for the clarification of its radiographic properties and the study of its plasma dynamics and impedance characteristics. It is shown that the diode is capable of generating quasi-spherical hard X-ray spot with dose level $\sim 0.6 \mathrm{rad} \text{@} 1 \mathrm{~m}$, diameter $\sim 0.6 \mathrm{~mm}$ (AWE standard), pulse width $\sim 30 \mathrm{~ns}$ (full-width-half-maximum), and the resolution exceeds 10 line-pairs $/ \mathrm{mm}$ with a $1.5 \times$ magnification. Additionally, the spectrum measured by a bent crystal spectrometer indicates the characteristic lines of anode target excel the bremsstrahlung background, providing $\sim 10^{13}$ probing photons in $\mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{\pi}$ sr within $\mathbf{3 0 ~ n s}$. The brilliance of the source can further reach $\sim \mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{1 4} \sim \mathbf{1 5}}$ photons $/ \mathbf{s} / \mathbf{m m}^{\mathbf{2}} / \mathbf{m r a d}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{0. 1 \%} \mathbf{B W}$ at $\mathbf{3 4 0}$ mm when a polycarpillary lense is deployed, which is significantly higher than X-ray tubes, and comparable with bending magnet beamlines at modern synchrotron radiation facilities. For the applicational aspect, a movable compact radiography device WRPD-1 $(\pm 70 \mathrm{kV}, 250 \mathrm{kA}, 120 \mathrm{~ns})$ is constructed in our laboratory and has been devoted in joint experiments of both FXR and DXRD purposes.

title: Vacuum Arc Characteristics of a Composite Magnetic Field Contact with Fixed Break under Different Fixed Contact Structures
authors: Zihan Wang, Yuanzhao Li, Lei Huang, Hui Ma, Jianhua Wang, Ping Liu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: For reduce the contact resistance of high voltage vacuum interrupters, a novel composite magnetic field contact has been proposed. The objective of this paper is to experimentally compare the vacuum arc characteristics of the composite magnetic field contacts with fixed break under two different fixed contact structures. The composite magnetic field contact consists of a pair of inner movable TMF contacts and a pair of outer fixed AMF contacts. The coil-type AMF contact and the horseshoe-type bipolar AMF contact were adopted as the fixed breaks. The contact diameter was 85 mm, and the contact gap of the fixed break was 14 mm. Drawn arc experiments were carried out with a demountable vacuum chamber. The arc current level was set as 15 kA with frequency of $\mathbf{4 4. 5 ~ H z}$. From the results, for both contact structures, part of arc current can transfer from the inner TMF contact to the outer AMF contact, and the diffused arc duration before current zero can reach $\mathbf{2. 0 ~ m s}$. And the horseshoe-type bipolar AMF contact structure is more suitable for the fixed break in the composite magnetic field contact, for it can achieve higher current transfer rate, reduce erosion of the inner TMF contact and reduce metal drops between contacts before current zero.

title: Temperature rise analysis of 252kV environmentfriendly vacuum circuit breaker
authors: Xu Chen, Chunen Fang, Junping Chen, Wei Li, Yu Liu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: At the high voltage level, because the vacuum interrupter can only dissipate heat through heat conduction, the temperature rise becomes an important factor restricting the development of ultra-high voltage vacuum circuit breaker, so it is of great significance to study the temperature rise of $\mathbf{2 5 2} \mathbf{k V}$ environmentally friendly vacuum circuit breaker. In this paper, the electromagnetic, temperature-fluid multi-physical field coupling model is established by Maxwell and fluent. Firstly, the simulation under normal flow conditions is calculated, and then compared with the temperature rise test. The relative errors between the simulation results of each part and the test results were all controlled within $10 \%$, and the temperature rise change trend showed a high degree of consistency, with the maximum error being $8.3 \%$. Thus, the reliability and accuracy of the numerical simulation method and the simulation results were verified.

title: Annealing temperature effect on the sheet resistance and the secondary electron emission yield of alumina substrates with chromium oxide coatings
authors: Akio Ogura, Souichi Katagiri, Hiromitsu Nogi, Ryu Hasunuma
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: We evaluated the impact of the annealing temperature on the sheet resistance and the secondary electron emission yield (SEEY) of alumina substrates with $\approx 10-\mathrm{nm}$ thick chromium oxide coating. To identify the origin of the observed trend in the SEEY data, we measured the surface morphologies of chromium oxide coatings on silicon prepared in the same way. The results indicate that the SEEY strongly depends on the grain size of the coating, which can be controlled by the annealing temperature.

title: Research on the Transfer Characteristics of Vacuum Arc Current to Parallel Branches under Various Contacts Magnetic Field Modes
authors: Chen Fu, Yuanbing Zhang, Zewei Lai, Hao Cheng, Hui Ma, Yingsan Geng, Jianhua Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: With the development of DC power grids, hybrid DC circuit breakers (HDCCB) have become a research hotspot in DC interrupts. For HDCCB composed of vacuum switches in parallel with IGBTs, the interruption capability is closely related to the current transfer characteristics in hybrid breaking process. The objective of this paper is to determine the effect of various contacts magnetic field modes on the current transfer characteristics in hybrid breaking process. Various magnetic field contact modes have a significant influence on the current transfer time and transfer speed. The results indicate that, as the current increases from 2 kA to 11 kA, the current transmission time in all magnetic field contact modes shows a linear increasing trend. Among these modes, the transfer time of the spiral groove contact increases the fastest (about $790 \mu \mathrm{~s}$ at 11 kA), followed by the radial transverse magnetic field contact (about $730 \mu \mathrm{~s}$ at 11 kA). The growth of the plate contact under pulsating transverse magnetic field is the slowest (only about 630 $\mu \mathrm{s}$ at 11 kA). In terms of transfer speed, the plate contact under pulsating transverse magnetic field slightly decreased at first and then tended to stabilize $(17.1 \mathrm{kA} / \mathrm{ms})$, the transfer speed of the spiral groove contact continuously decreased and then tended to stabilize $(15.0 \mathrm{kA} / \mathrm{ms})$, while the transfer speed of the radial transverse magnetic contact remained stable all the time $\boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{1 4. 7 ~ k A} \boldsymbol{/} \mathbf{m s} \boldsymbol{)} \boldsymbol{.}$

title: Spatio-temporal Prediction of Digital Economic Growth Based on LSTM Networks I Empirical Evidence from Chinese Provincial Data
authors: Long Tang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Digital economy has become an important engine to promote high-quality economic development. This study constructs an LSTM deep learning model and integrates spatio-temporal features to predict the development trend of provincial digital economy. The results show that: the LSTM model can effectively capture the temporal fluctuation characteristics of the digital economy; the digital economic growth shows a trend of gradient diffusion from east to west; the regional digital divide is gradually shrinking; and the spatial autocorrelation feature significantly improves the prediction accuracy. The study provides scientific basis for digital economy policy making and regional synergistic development, and has practical value for promoting balanced development of digital economy.

title: CROMBO: Cross-Modality Bootstrapping for Unified Sketch-Photo Representation Learning
authors: Xingyu Liu, Yan Jiang, Xu Cheng, Hao Yu, Haoyu Chen, Guoying Zhao
publish: ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications
abstract: Sketch-photo recognition refers to matching hand-drawn sketches with their corresponding photos, where the performance essentially depends on how well the presentations of the two modalities are aligned in the feature spaces. Existing works bluntly force model to reduce the representation discrepancy between the modalities, making the learning less effective. Besides, the current symmetric feature extraction framework prefers photo modality for richer information while neglecting sketch modality. Driven by those observations, we argue that, instead of forcefully wiping out the modality discrepancy, we may utilize the discrepancy to enhance the model learning. Thus, we propose a Cross-Modality Bootstrapping learning framework (CROMBO) that utilizes the modality discrepancy to bootstrap the cross-modality representation learning via a differentiated interaction manner. Specifically, we first present a Sketch Implicit Bootstrapping (SIB) module to magnify the recognizable elements in photo modality by utilizing the characteristic of sketch only with contour and key detail. Second, a Photo-driven Sketch Refinement (PSR) module is developed to guide the sketch representation in shared feature extraction by supplementing rich information from photo modality. Moreover, we design a second-order alignment strategy to dynamically align the latent distribution of two modalities in Hilbert space. Also, our CROMBO can learn fewer parameters by freezing the weights of shallow layers in the backbone while making no sacrifice for performance. Extensive experiments on six public datasets verify the superior performance of our CROMBO for sketch-photo based tasks, such as sketch re-identification, sketch-photo face recognition and sketch-based image retrieval.

title: Retraction Notice: They use of NLP in Association with AI Technology for the Purpose of Optimization in Various Fields
authors: Ankita Joshi, Saloni Bansal, Gopal Krishan Gard, Mohammed Al-Farouni, S Srinivasan, Surendra Shetty
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: In the world of Natural Language Processing (NLP), developing structures that not simplest carry out nicely but additionally offer apparent reasoning for their selections is paramount. Traditional gadget mastering fashions, in particular the ones based on deep gaining knowledge of, have excelled in diverse NLP duties. However, the ones models frequently act as “black containers,” providing little to no perception into their selection-making processes. This opacity can undermine the don’t forget and reliability perceived with the useful resource of customers. To deal with this trouble, we advocate a unique generative rationalization framework that endeavors to bridge the distance between high overall performance and explainability in NLP systems. This frameworks designed to concurrently make kind picks and generate unique, terrific-grained causes for the ones choices, integrating an explainable difficulty and minimum chance schooling. By providing human-readable justifications for its predictions, our framework enhances the interpretability and trustworthiness of NLP fashions. Experimental validation on two newly curated datasets demonstrates the framework’s capacity to outperform existing baselines, significantly advancing the sector of explainable AI inside NLP.

title: Retraction Notice: Depression Chatbot using Deep Learning
authors: Dev Singh Chauhan, Arpit Rastogi, Kiran Singh
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This paper is created to offer some relief sorrow. Chatbots are specialists which are utilized to handle a particular assignment, and it tends to be utilized to present an item to a client or take care of relative issues related with an item, in this manner saving HR. The review which is presenting a chatbot to the society which will assist with decreasing the number of discouragement survivors. Through this review work, RNN LSTM encoder decoder model is trying to utilized to know the client's passionate state and as indicated by that chatbot gives the best reaction. We have proposed a multireason discourse model which can be utilized in day by day correspondence rather than for explicit errands. It helps those individuals who are experiencing melancholy and have dread of sharing their sentiments or dread of being judged.

title: Retraction Notice: Evaluation of AI Algorithms used for Non- Masked and Masked Face Recognition
authors: Om Pradyumana Gupta, Arun Prakash Agrawal, Om Pal
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Face recognition is one of the fundamental uses of picture assessment. Total 10 no. of various algorithms and technique are discussed in this paper out of which four are Non-masked face recognition and four are masked face recognition techniques. Comparisons are performed based on accuracy of all the algorithms. It is also discussed that it may be included in areas like Information Security, Access Management, Biometrics, Law Enforcements, Personal Security & Entertainment purposes as well. We use this paper as a medium to assess the performance of various existing state-of-the-art techniques and methods for masked as well as unmasked facial recognition. In the domain of masked facial recognition, it is a known fact that there is a dearth of relevant database available in the publicly accessible zone, even with the Even with the availability of limited dataset, our results depict that the exiting comprehensive techniques are able to deliver an accuracy of more than ninety percent. This paper aims to disseminate information with respect to the methodology followed in every technique and the accuracy level it has achieved.

title: Retraction Notice: Personalized Confederation Training for Smart Iot Systems: A Cloud - Delivered Structure
authors: Jitendra Kumar Katariya, Nivesh
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has significantly impacted many facets of contemporary life, and several sophisticated IoT applications and services are already being developed. Recently, the concept of federated learning has been proposed in order to train a globally shared model on IoT devices utilising a large number of user-generated data samples while stopping data leak. Due to the widespread heterogeneities in device, statistics, and model in complex IoT contexts, traditional federated learning is not suitable for instant implementation. In this paper, we present a cloud-edge architecture for intelligent IoT applications that includes a customised federated learning framework. To address the heterogeneity worries in IoT conditions, we examine imaginative altered united learning calculations that could diminish the unfortunate results brought about by heterogeneities in various aspects. The advantages of edge registering empower smart IoT applications to meet the models for high handling pace and low inertness. At long last, we give a contextual investigation of human movement recognition in light of Web of Things to show the advantages of customisable combined learning for intelligent IoT applications.
