title: Cross-Domain Learning: Evaluation of MoViNet for Thermal-Based Human Action Recognition
authors: Gabriela Vdoviak, Tomyslav Sledevič
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This study investigates the adaptation of MoViNet, a lightweight video classification model pretrained on the Kinetics-600 RGB dataset, for human action recognition in the thermal domain. Three MoViNet models A0, A1, A2 were fine-tuned on a custom collected thermal dataset consisting of three distinct human actions. The impact of temporal resolution was evaluated by varying the number of input frames per clip (25, 40, 60). The experimental results show that increased temporal input consistently improves classification performance, with the MoViNet A2 model achieving the highest accuracy of 98.3% at 60 frames. However, this improvement comes with a substantial increase in computational cost. Among the evaluated models, MoViNet A1 demonstrated the most optimal trade-off, achieving 96.7% accuracy while maintaining moderate computational demands. These findings highlight the effectiveness of leveraging cross-domain learning to efficiently use RGB pretrained models for thermal-based human action recognition, offering valuable insights for developing efficient and accurate action recognition systems suitable for diverse real-world applications.

title: Research on Current Rising Rate of Surface-Flashover Triggered Vacuum Switch under Different Trigger Parameters
authors: Zhanqing Chen, Yutao Han, Kai Zhang, Ailiang Kang, Bangfa Peng, Zhipeng Lei
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: To utilize the technical advantages of vacuum gaps developing pulsed power switch with better performances, overcoming the limitation from its lower discharge power, current rising rate of surface-flashover triggered vacuum switch (STVS) under different trigger parameters are studied in this paper. Test platform for STVS is established with detachable vacuum chamber. Influences of trigger polarity, configurations of flashover materials on current rising rate are compared. And initial arc diffusion processes are also discussed. The results convey that, the insufficient cathode spots at initial period leads to relative slow current rising rate of STVS. The switch with negative trigger pulse can obtain higher current rising rate, and $\mathbf{Z r O}_{\mathbf{2}}$ ceramics is recommended to improve di/dt of STVS. With the increase of operating voltage and the decrease of flashover distance, current rising rate of STVS can be gradually improved. And current rising rate of the switch reaches $2.06 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{s}$ under 10kV gap voltage and 1mm flashover distance. Researches in this paper can provide some basis the optimal design of trigger vacuum switch with larger discharge power.

title: Adding Emotion Conditioning in Speech Synthesis via Multi-Term Classifier-Free Guidance
authors: Radu-George Bolborici, Ana Neacşu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Many recent Text-to-Speech (TTS) models employing zero-shot voice cloning techniques are capable of reproducing the emotional tone present in the reference speech. However, they frequently lack mechanisms for fine-grained emotion control due to the scarcity of labeled resources. The current work proposes a method for adjusting F5-TTS [1] in order to achieve fine-grained emotion control by fine-tuning under low-resource conditions, while aiming to keep the original model’s performance. To enforce the newly added condition, the classifier-free guidance (CFG) mechanism is modified by adding a supplementary term that amplifies the condition’s contribution, at the expense of increased inference time. We show that the proposed method is able to generate natural and intelligible speech with the same voice as the reference audio, but with changed emotion according to the label condition. Moreover, this method enables control over emotion intensity, despite the model not being explicitly trained for this task. Extensive automated evaluations and subjective tests with 20 human participants demonstrate that our method maintains intelligibility, naturalness and allows both emotion class and intensity control.Implementation code and demo samples are available at https://github.com/RaduBolbo/F5-TTS-Emotional-CFG

title: Study on the Erosion Mechanism of Contacts Under Vacuum Arc Conditions
authors: Wei Duan, Jing Li, Bingjie Shi, Chongyang Huang, Si Fu, Yue Fu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum arc erosion severely impacts the service life and reliability of circuit breakers. Investigating the contact erosion characteristics is crucial for the development of vacuum circuit breakers. A contact erosion model under vacuum arc conditions has been established, considering the melting and erosion process of contact materials under different force mechanisms. To analyze the heat transfer and fluid flow phenomena within the contact molten pool, a level-set model incorporating evaporation and splashing has been developed to track phase-change interfaces and simulate the entire erosion process of contact metal during vacuum arc erosion. The study analyzes the characteristics of contact erosion vacuum arc circuit breakers, aiming to identify methods for reducing contact erosion. The results indicate that as the arc energy increases, the form of molten splashing transitions from fluid-dynamics-based splashing along the sides of the molten pool wall to explosive splashing perpendicular to the molten layer surface. Additionally, the rate of molten splashing increases with the arc energy, while the vortices formed within the molten layer are the primary cause of the irregularities on the inner wall of the molten pool.

title: Study on the Operating Overvoltage of Vacuum Circuit Breakers in the Low-Frequency Power Transmission Systems
authors: Ruiqi Liu, Yongpeng Mo, Zongqian Shi, Junhao Niu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The Low-frequency power transmission technology has great potential in offshore wind power transmission. Switchgear equipment is the key component of the lowfrequency power transmission systems. With the increasing awareness of environmental protection, the eco-friendly vacuum circuit breaker has caused many concerns. However, there is still few research on the operating overvoltage of vacuum circuit breakers in low-frequency systems. Moreover, compared with the power-frequency system, the topology of the low-frequency system is more complex, including the M3C frequency converters and offshore wind turbines and other components. The influence of these key parts on overvoltage is still not very clear. Besides, overvoltage has a crucial impact on the interruption of vacuum circuit breakers. In response to the above issues, the causes of overvoltage in a low-frequency power transmission system were investigated. Based on the typical topology of offshore wind power low-frequency power transmission, a typical low-frequency power transmission system model is built. Subsequently, the distribution characteristics and evolution process of vacuum circuit breaker operating overvoltage in low-frequency and powerfrequency systems were analyzed.

title: Effect of Contact Materials on the DC Interruption Characteristics of a TMF Vacuum Circuit Breaker
authors: Takumi Takabayashi, Masahiro Sato, Takahiro Umemoto, Kenta Yamamura, Kazuya Kato, Kunihiko Hidaka, Akiko Kumada
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum DC circuit breakers attract attention because of their advantages; fast operation speed and fire resistance. However, the low voltage of vacuum arcs and complex external circuits remain challenges. In this study, a transverse magnetic field (TMF) was applied to extend the arc length at the electrode ends, increasing arc voltage and enabling interruption using only the vacuum interrupter. The effects of electrode material properties were reflected primarily in magnetic driving time. AgWCCo material, with its superior evaporation characteristics and high thermal conductivity, demonstrated superior cutting performance in DC interruption under TMF application, while CuW material performed poorly. Fast interruption requires rapid arc drive to the electrode edge and rapid cooling of electrode temperature to prevent restrikes.

title: Research on Initial Plasma Current Characteristics of Laser-Triggered Vacuum Switch
authors: Wenjun Xiang, Xubin Li, Gang Lu, Liang Bu, Minfu Liao, Xiongying Duan
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The triggering characteristics of laser-triggered vacuum switches (LTVS) are significantly influenced by the parameters of the laser-generated initial plasma. An experimental setup was constructed to measure the initial plasma current, and the effects of laser energy, ranging from 10 mJ to 25 mJ, and gap distance, from 2.5 mm to 10 mm, on the initial plasma current characteristics of LTVS were investigated. The results reveal that the initial plasma current waveform exhibits an oscillatory decay. The initial charge, calculated by integrating the initial plasma current, increases rapidly with laser energy from 10 mJ to 20 mJ but slows after 20 mJ, which might be explained by the plasma shielding effects. At 20 mJ, the initial charge reaches 42.18 nC, with the initial plasma current peaking at 61.28 ns. Variations in the gap distance also affect the peak time and initial charge. As the gap distance increases from 2.5 mm to 10 mm, the peak time of the initial plasma current increases from 51.92 ns to 57.84 ns, while the initial charge decreases from 26.91 nC to 21.78 nC.

title: Enhancing Music Accessibility through AI Systems for and with d/Deaf Individuals
authors: Suhyeon Yoo
publish: ACM SIGACCESS Accessibility and Computing
abstract: None

title: Supporting Older Adults' Software Learning via Live Assistance and Guided Mockup
authors: Teerapaun Tanprasert
publish: ACM SIGACCESS Accessibility and Computing
abstract: Older adults are increasingly integrating technology into their daily lives but often need guidance to navigate new tools effectively. Some benefit from real-time support from family members, while others prefer self-paced, asynchronous help. To meet their diverse needs, I propose two solutions: HelpCall and SoftBox. HelpCall provides synchronous guidance through an assistive video overlay, helping older adults follow instructions from remote family members. In contrast, to support asynchronous assistance, SoftBox generates guided interactive software mockups from screencast demonstrations to allow learners to independently explore and learn new features in a sandbox-like environment. Through user studies with older adults and their family members, these projects offer complementary insights into synchronous and asynchronous support, advancing accessible technology for diverse learning needs and contexts and moving toward universal accessibility in digital tools.

title: Retraction Notice: An Enhanced Role of AI in SDLC in Implementing Maintenance System
authors: Yogendra Kumar, Ch.Raja Kishore Babu, Maha Medha Deorari, Laith Jasim, Komal Sharma, K Vinothkumar
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: In the hastily evolving domain of software development, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a pivotal pressure reworking software checking out from its traditional, exertions-intensive methodologies to greater sophisticated, computerized techniques. This research paper delves into the multifaceted effect of AI on software checking out, elucidating the way it now not only augments the performance and precision of testing however also appreciably reduces the time to market for software products. By integrating AI technology which include gadget mastering, deep studying, and herbal language processing, this study illustrates the ability of AI to revolutionize best assurance practices with the aid of facilitating smarter automated trying out techniques, improving check case generation, and improving fault detection mechanisms. Furthermore, the studies highlight AI’s instrumental function in addressing the complexities of modern software programs, in the end leading to the development of strong, blunders-loose software program solutions. The findings underscore the transformative capability of AI in software program trying out, heralding a brand-new generation of innovation and performance inside the software program development lifecycle.

title: Retraction Notice: Fully Automated Wheatstone Bridge-Based Transducer Problem Identification with Classifier for Verilog HDL
authors: Sunila Choudhary
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This study describes how artificial neural networks (ANNs) were used to develop automated defect monitoring & diagnosis programs in a type of Wheatstone bridge-based actuators. The results indicate that the proposed fault detection is perfect for incorporating awareness within the devices in a form that is interacting with humans. The automated problem detector that is currently exhibited detects the 7 flaws that are frequently found in a category of such actuators. In this study, a two classifying system built on an ANN is used to teach the recommended automated defect detectors. The railway is identified using Verilog in able to differentiate among the outputs at either 1 of its failures, that is strong (1), and the result at the other 3 defects, who are lower (0).Verilog HDL is used to recognise a subway principles, i.e., mass & prejudices from the neurological connectivity toolkit of MATLAB & feedback voltage levels obtained from OrCAD apps, in sequence to differentiate among the outcome at whatever one of the failings, that is elevated (1), & the outcome at the remainder 3 defects, that also are small (0).

title: Retraction Notice: Analyzing the differences between SVM and Naive Bayes for Feature Extraction
authors: Pardeep Jindal, Swapnil Parikh, Rishi Sikka, Sura Rahim Alatba, Sangita Babu, G.V. Sriramakrishnan
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The goal of this research is to look at object classification using SVM and compare it to Naive Bayes prediction accuracy. Materials and Methods: The object classification 10000 samples in this paper are gathered from datasets available on GitHub. The training dataset (n = 7000 [70 percent]) and test dataset (n = 3000 [30 percent]) are used to partition the samples. The accuracy values are calculated using the Support Vector Machine. An 80% rate of pre-test quality analysis was performed. In contrast to 52 percent for Naive Bayes, a Svm Classifier has a 72 percent overall accuracy. With a significance level of 0.182 (P>0.10) and a sig value of 0.1, there's no discernible difference between the research groups. In this object categorization investigation, Support Vector Machine forecasts outperform Naive Bayes recommendations in terms of accuracy.

title: Isolated High Step-Up Converter With Soft Switching and Active Clamping Property
authors: Rong-Jong Wai, Kuan-Pin Huang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study proposed an isolated high-step-up DC-DC converter with an interleaved coupled-inductor scheme and active-clamped technique for renewable energy systems. In the proposed converter, an interleaved-boost structure is adopted on the primary side to reduce input current ripple and achieve a higher voltage gain. Moreover, the design of active-clamped circuits reduces the voltage stresses on the active switches, and they recycle stray currents from the leakage inductance to achieve zero-voltage-switching (ZVS) turn-on capability for each active switch. Since the voltage stresses on active switches are decreased, semiconductor switching components with lower turn-on resistance (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DS-ON</sub>) can be selected to reduce conduction losses. In a conventional interleaved boost structure, two separate magnetic cores are typically required for the two input inductors. In this study, a magnetic core integration approach is adopted, allowing both input inductors to share a common core. Therefore, their current ripples can be reduced while avoiding the risk of local core saturation so that the utilization of the magnetic core can be improved. A laboratory prototype with an input voltage of 25V, an output voltage of 400V, and a 2kW maximum power is built to verify the effectiveness of the proposed converter. According to experimental results, the maximum power conversion efficiency reaches above 97%.

title: Listwise Preference Alignment Optimization for Tail Item Recommendation
authors: Zihao Li, Chao Yang, Tong Zhang, Yakun Chen, Xianzhi Wang, Guandong Xu, Daoyi Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Preference alignment has achieved greater success on large language models (LLMs) and drawn broad interest in recommendation research. Existing preference alignment methods for recommendation either require explicit reward modeling or only support pairwise preference comparison. The former directly increases substantial computational costs, while the latter hinders training efficiency on negative samples. Moreover, no existing effort has explored preference alignment solutions for tail-item recommendation. To bridge the above gaps, we propose <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">LPO4Rec</small>, which extends the Bradley-Terry model from pairwise comparison to listwise comparison, to improve the efficiency of model training. Specifically, we derive a closed-form optimal policy to enable more efficient and effective training without explicit reward modeling. We also present an adaptive negative sampling and reweighting strategy to prioritize tail items during optimization and enhance performance in tail-item recommendations. Besides, we theoretically prove that optimizing the listwise preference optimization (LPO) loss is equivalent to maximizing the upper bound of the optimal reward. Our experiments on three public datasets show that our method outperforms 10 baselines by a large margin, achieving up to 50% performance improvement while reducing 17.9% GPU memory usage when compared with direct preference optimization (DPO) in tail-item recommendation.

title: Robust Egoistic Rigid Body Localization
authors: Niclas Führling, Giuseppe Thadeu Freitas de Abreu, David González G., Osvaldo Gonsa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: We consider a robust and self-reliant (or “egoistic”) variation of the rigid body localization (RBL) problem, in which a primary rigid body seeks to estimate the pose (i.e., location and orientation) of another rigid body (or “target”), relative to its own, without the assistance of external infrastructure, without prior knowledge of the shape of the target, and taking into account the possibility that the available observations are incomplete. Three complementary contributions are then offered for such a scenario. The first is a method to estimate the translation vector between the center points of both rigid bodies, which unlike existing techniques does not require that both objects have the same shape or even the same number of landmark points. This technique is shown to significantly outperform the state-of-the-art (SotA) under complete information, but to be sensitive to data erasures, even when enhanced by matrix completion methods. The second contribution, designed to offer improved performance in the presence of incomplete information, offers a robust alternative to the latter, at the expense of a slight relative loss under complete information. Finally, the third contribution is a scheme for the estimation of the rotation matrix describing the relative orientation of the target rigid body with respect to the primary. Comparisons of the proposed schemes and SotA techniques demonstrate the advantage of the contributed methods in terms of root mean square error (RMSE) performance under fully complete information and incomplete conditions.

title: Output-Feedback Safety-Critical Path-Guided Herding Control of MIMO Nonlinear Agents Based on Finite-Time Neural Predictor
authors: Siming Cong, Nan Gu, Dan Wang, Weidong Zhang, Zhouhua Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of safety-critical path-guided herding control for multiple-input multiple-output multi-agent systems under incomplete state measurement, safety constraints, and limited communication resources. Specifically, an output-feedback finite-time neural predictor is proposed to identify both model uncertainties and unknown state information. Subsequently, a distributed path-guided herding control strategy is designed, including patrolling, gathering, enclosing, and expelling. Control barrier functions are formulated as safety constraints, and a quadratic optimization problem is established. By using the neurodynamic optimization to solve the optimization problem, the optimal control law satisfying both safety constraints and state constraints is generated. Furthermore, a dynamic event-triggered communication method is proposed to reduce unnecessary communication, especially during the transient phase. By using the proposed herding control approach, the collision-free herding is guaranteed for input-to-state stability, and simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the approach.

title: Multimodal Biosignals for Affective State Recognition Using Differential Multimodal Transformer
authors: Muhammad Saleem, Deok-Hwan Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The primary objective of affective computing is the precise and automated identification of human affective states. In recent years, affective recognition has gained substantial attention owing to its broad potential for enhancing human–computer interactions. Contrary to conventional approaches that frequently overlook the intrinsic relationships between different modalities and mostly rely on a single modality, this study presents a differential multimodal transformer with an end-to-end multimodal affective state recognition framework that integrates heterogeneous data sources. The architecture is organized into three parts: a differential multi-scale feature extractor (DMFE) module to align signals and emphasize meaningful temporal changes, a global cross-attention encoder (GCE) to model relationships across modalities, and difference-augmented weighted fusion (DWF) to merge features by applying two self-attention pooling layers to highlight the fused representation, which is then fed to the classifier. Specifically, on the DEAP dataset, the model achieved 94.23% (valence) and 93.91% (arousal) accuracies with corresponding F1-scores of 94.89% and 94.92%. In WESAD, the framework attained 94.63% accuracy and a 93.82% F1-score. Performance on CogLoad reached 92.08% accuracy and 92.91% F1-score, while on MOCAS, it achieved 92.04% accuracy and a 91.89% F1-score. The results clearly demonstrate the superiority of the proposed architecture over existing models. Furthermore, ablation studies have confirmed the individual contributions and significance of core architectural components.

title: HMTC: A Hybrid Mamba-Transformer Model for Calibration of Low-Cost Air Quality Sensors
authors: Georgios F. Angelis, Dimitrios Karanassos, Alexandros Emvoliadis, Georgios Tatsis, Anastasios Drosou, Dimitrios Tzovaras
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: The assessment of Low-Cost Sensors (LCS) for air quality multisensor systems performance is a critical aspect of the Air Quality (AQ) monitoring framework. The calibration model for these devices is one of the key drivers of overall performance. Field calibration is increasingly recognized as the best approach for calibrating air quality monitoring devices. However, to achieve high-quality calibration results, low-cost sensors must be co-located with reference stations. To address this challenge, we propose a comprehensive solution that leverages self-supervised pretraining on LCS data to learn meaningful representations for pollution data calibration. In the first stage, our model undergoes unsupervised pretraining inspired by masked autoencoders. In the second stage, supervised fine-tuning is applied to enhance the accuracy of pollution data calibration. Additionally, we introduce a novel architecture that combines state-space models, specifically Mamba, with Transformer layers. Our model is rigorously evaluated on two publicly available research datasets, consistently outperforming all baseline methods. Furthermore, we present a newly designed ESP32 microcontroller based system to validate the effectiveness of our approach in real-world scenarios. The results demonstrate that our calibration technique is well-suited for microcontrollers with limited resources, significantly reducing the cost of IoT solutions for air quality and pollution monitoring.

title: Knee-Inspired Hinge Absorbs Longitudinal Impacts to Enhance Robot-Environment Interaction Safety_supp1-3637130.mp4
authors: Zhihua Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: As robots integrate into human society, ensuring safe robot-environment interaction, particularly in the event of collisions, has emerged as a growing design priority. A promising solution is introducing proper compliance into existing rigid robots, akin to musculoskeletal systems, to absorb impacts in various directions. However, mimicking longitudinal compliance seen in biological joints to absorb compressive impacts along limbs, such as the role of cartilages like menisci, remains a challenge shadowed by the complexity of joint architecture. Here, exploring and adapting the elastic longitudinal movement structure of knee, we incorporated traditional mechanical hinges with a compact buffer structure to enable both simple rotational motion and effective longitudinal impact absorption. Under longitudinal loading, the buffer structure functions as a mechanism transmitting the limited compression to amplified deformations of elastic elements, thus producing resistance against load. The resistive load-displacement relationship is tailorable by tuning diverse elastic components, allowing for a high-static-low-dynamic stiffness to improve energy absorption efficiency. Drop tests and walking robot demonstrations confirm that the proposed knee-inspired hinge not only mitigates acceleration transmitted to the robot's main body but also reduces ground reaction forces, thereby improving robot-environment interaction safety. This work highlights the design paradigm of adapting natural solutions to mechanical systems, and holds potential for direct integration into diverse robots, exoskeletons, and prostheses.

title: Coexistence of electrode-dependent resistive switching and negative differential resistance effect in α -MoO 3-x memristor
authors: Ravindra Kumar Nitharwal, Ravindra Kumar, Subhajit Chatterjee, Arige Sumanth, Renu Yadav, Abhishek Misra, M. S. Ramachandra Rao, Tejendra Dixit, Sivarama Krishnan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Materials for Electron Devices
abstract: This work presents the filamentary resistive switching (RS) of transition metal oxide thin film planner memristors, specifically focusing on α-MoO3, a distinguished n-type wide bandgap semiconductor. The study uncovers the metal electrode-dependent negative differential resistance (NDR) effect and memristive behavior of α-MoO3 thin films for next-generation non-volatile memory and neuromorphic computing applications. The silver (Ag) electrode exhibits superior bipolar RS than the titanium (Ti) electrode because of Ag ion diffusions, the nature of the Ag/MoO3 junction, and interfacial effects. Likewise, significant NDR is observed for the Ag electrode compared to the Ti, owing to thermally activated transport, residual ionic motion, and redox processes at the Ag electrode. Transient measurements reveal stronger spike-like current responses for the Ag electrode, emphasizing its potential for neuromorphic devices. Besides, the optical absorption and photoluminescence analysis show that oxygen vacancies create Mo+5 defect states and split the Mo d-level owing to the crystal field effect, which affects the electronic structure and visible light emission of α-MoO3 thin film. These findings demonstrate the essential role of metal electrodes and defect engineering in controlling filamentary RS and NDR effect, advancing α-MoO3 thin films for future neuromorphic computing and optoelectronic devices.

title: Leveraging Swin Transformer for enhanced diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease using multi-shell diffusion MRI_supp1-3636745.pdf
authors: Quentin Dessain
publish: N/A
abstract: Objective: This study aims to support early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease and detection of amyloid accumulation by leveraging the microstructural information available in multi-shell diffusion MRI (dMRI) data, using a vision transformer-based deep learning framework. Methods: We present a classification pipeline that employs the Swin Transformer, a hierarchical vision transformer model, on multi-shell dMRI data for the classification of Alzheimer's disease and amyloid presence. Key metrics from DTI and NODDI were extracted and projected onto 2D planes to enable transfer learning with ImageNet-pretrained models. To efficiently adapt the transformer to limited labeled neuroimaging data, we integrated Low-Rank Adaptation. We assessed the framework on diagnostic group prediction (cognitively normal, mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease dementia) and amyloid status classification. Results: The framework achieved competitive classification results within the scope of multi-shell dMRI-based features, with the best balanced accuracy of 95.2% for distinguishing cognitively normal individuals from those with Alzheimer's disease dementia using NODDI metrics. For amyloid detection, it reached 77.2% balanced accuracy in distinguishing amyloid-positive mild cognitive impairment/Alzheimer's disease dementia subjects from amyloid-negative cognitively normal subjects, and 67.9% for identifying amyloidpositive individuals among cognitively normal subjects. Grad-CAM-based explainability analysis identified clinically relevant brain regions, including the parahippocampal gyrus and hippocampus, as key contributors to model predictions. Conclusion/Significance: This study demonstrates the promise of diffusion MRI and transformer-based architectures for early detection of Alzheimer's disease and amyloid pathology, supporting biomarker-driven diagnostics in data-limited biomedical settings.

title: Retraction Notice: Kidney Stone Prediction Using Neural Network Classifier
authors: Pavithra, Sanjurajan, Chitradevi, Sherin Eliyas, Angeline Benitta, Sathish Kumar

abstract: kidney stone disorder is a frequent hassle in the World today. The majority of kidney stones is tiny and bypass on their own. Overwork, which suppresses human antibodies, excessive sodium intake, and worse exterior surroundings stipulations such as bloodless and dampness too are effortless reasons of kidney illnesses nowadays. title: Interruption of Direct Current with Parallel Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Jinchao Chen, Siyuan Liu, Yifan Chen, Hongyi Chen, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The parallel installation of vacuum interrupters (VIs) is an effective approach to enhance the current interruption capacity of direct current circuit breakers (DCCBs). However, parallel configurations pose challenges in achieving balanced current distribution between branches during the arcing process. In this study, a 40 kV mechanical DCCB equipped with two parallel VIs in the main branch is constructed, where each VI is operated independently by their own mechanism. A series of DC current interruption experiments is conducted to investigate the current sharing characteristic and its influence on interruption performance. The results reveal that the current-sharing condition prior to the injection of high-frequency current critically influences the subsequent artificial current zero behavior. In scenarios with poor initial current sharing, the VIs interrupt sequentially, with zero-crossing time deviations on the order of tens of microseconds. These findings underscore the importance of accounting for current-sharing dynamics when coordinating the operation of DCCBs with parallel VIs.

title: Spectral Lines Overlap in Vacuum Arc Plasmas of CuCr Electrodes
authors: Xu Huikai, Huang Xiaolong, Le Xiaoxi, Zhong Xuewen, Zhao Lihua, Jia Shenli
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Optical Emission Spectroscopy (OES) is widely used for diagnosing vacuum-arc plasmas, yet excessive spectral broadening can lead to line overlap and reduce diagnostic accuracy. In this work, we assess the separability of Cu and Cr species lines by performing spectral measurements with pureCu and pure-Cr electrodes. Pseudo-Voigt profile fitting combined with a sliding-window analysis (0.005 nm steps) was used to compute an overlap ratio for each line. Our results reveal that several commonly used lines exhibit significant blending with adjacent features. We further identify spectral windows in which line overlap remains below $25 \%$, offering guidance for selecting reliable diagnostic lines in CuCr electrode vacuum arc studies.

title: Simulation Study of Multi-Species Vacuum Arc Based on Magnetohydrodynamics
authors: Liu Junxiang, Yuan Zhao, Xiong Jun, Xiao Jun, Li Yida, Huang Xiaolong, Jia Shenli
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs), being an environmentally friendly substitute for SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf>, present fast dielectric recovery along with high economic efficiency. With the growing demand for high-voltage and high-current applications, it is of great importance to enhance their interruption performance. In order to get a clear understanding of the motion and distribution traits of arc species, this paper sets up a multi-species MHD model that takes into account ionization and recombination processes. Then, it undertakes three-dimensional numerical simulations under CuCr50 contact materials. Moreover, optical diagnostic experiments are carried out to analyze the spatial distribution of atoms and ions in various ionization states during high-current vacuum arcs. The experimental results are contrasted with the simulation outcomes for the purpose of validating the model. The findings contribute to a deeper comprehension of the evolution of arc species in vacuum switchgear and offer theoretical backing for the development of high-voltage, large-capacity VCBs.

title: Analysis on Anode Ablation in DC Vacuum Circuit Breakers with Transverse Magnetic Field
authors: Xingwang Wang, Yuanyuan Zhao, Xiaoming Liu, Hai Chen, Jiayuan Zheng, Shang Qian
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The $12 \mathrm{kV} / 1250 \mathrm{~A} / 25 \mathrm{kA}$ DC vacuum circuit breaker (VCB) with transverse magnetic field (TMF) was selected as the research object. And the combination of threedimensional magnetic field finite element parametric modeling analysis and experimental investigation was employed to establish an equivalent model of the anode thermal process in DC vacuum arcs. Moreover, the evolution patterns of the anode surface molten pool dynamics, and the interaction between arc motion under TMF and anode thermal processes were investigated. And the effects of different composition ratios of copper-chromium alloy in contact electrodes on the anode ablation process had been further analyzed. Theoretical support was provided for improving the ablation resistance and breaking capacity of DC VCBs.

title: Advanced Techniques for Derating Vacuum Circuit Breakers
authors: Martin Leusenkamp, Bao Lihua, Wang Yifeng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Circuit breakers fitted with Vacuum Interrupters are type tested according to international standards, with the most prevalent being the relevant IEC and IEEE standards. For the DC time constant of the rated short-circuit breaking current during asymmetrical current switching tests, the standard value of 45ms is typically used. While some special case time constants are mentioned in the standards, they are not used for tests unless specifically requested. In recent years more applications are seen where Vacuum Circuit Breakers are directly connected to large Power Transformers, (small) generators, or motor buses with large Medium-Voltage motors. Consequently, the standard DC time constant often does not suffice. Power-system analysis software is capable to accurately calculate the actual breaker requirements in the system, but the results rarely match the tested breaker data. Comparing analysis results with circuit-breaker nameplate information or test data from manufacturers is challenging for many. This paper addresses the derating of Vacuum Circuit Breakers when applied in networks with DC time constants (or X/R-ratios) that differ from those the circuit breaker was originally tested with. Various derating methods will be discussed along with their pros and cons.

title: Control Method for Closing Bounce in Vacuum Circuit Breaker Spring Mechanism Considering Tolerance Interval Uncertainty
authors: Xingwang Wang, Ao Liang, Xiaoming Liu, Hai Chen, Jingjie Yang, Shang Qian
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Mechanism closing bounce is a critical factor affecting the closing reliability of vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs). To suppress closing bounce and achieve reliable closing characteristic, this study focuses on a 10 kV VCB spring operating mechanism. Kinematic simulation was analyzed to obtain the mechanical characteristic curves during the closing process. And an optimized design scheme considering the uncertainties in insulating rod material parameters, dimensional tolerances, and contact spring parameters was proposed. The results demonstrate that the proposed design scheme, which accounts for uncertainties in insulating rod material parameters, dimensional tolerances, and contact spring parameters, can reduce the maximum closing bounce displacement while simultaneously ensuring the mechanical reliability and cost-effectiveness of the operating mechanism.

title: Research on Supply Chain Collaboration Mechanism and Optimization Path of Cross-border E-commerce Platforms
authors: Mengying Cui, Ju Ye
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In order to improve the stability and efficiency of cross-border e-commerce platforms in complex supply chain collaboration, this paper adopts computer-aided simulation techniques, system dynamics, and multi-subject modeling methods to study the platform-led benefit distribution mechanism, risk sharing mechanism, and collaborative governance path. A digital simulation system based on advanced computing technology is constructed and typical scenarios are set up for experimental verification. The results show that the optimized path can effectively improve the collaboration efficiency, reduce the response delay, and enhance the system resilience, which has a good promotion value.

title: Fintech and green innovation - evidence from Chinese listed firms
authors: Jinrui Zhang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This paper examines how fintech influences green innovation based on panel data from Chinese A-share listed firms. Fintech covers artificial intelligence, blockchain, big data, cloud computing and biometrics, and reshapes core financial links such as payment, risk control and investment and financing through digital innovation. We construct a novel fintech adoption index and employ a Poisson model to assess its effect on firms’ green patenting performance. The results indicate that fintech facilitates green innovation primarily by enhancing firms’ adaptive capacity. In contrast, no significant mediation effects are found via absorptive capacity or integration capability. These findings enhance the understanding of how fintech enables green innovation and provide guidance for firms and policymakers aiming to promote sustainability through digital transformation.

title: M-Net: MRI Modal Conversion Network Based on Multi-scale Convolution and Edge Loss
authors: Xiangqi Miao
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics

title: Investigation of Current Interruption in Vacuum Using Long Gaps up to 45 mm: A Comparison of Different Contact Geometries
authors: Timo Meyer, Dietmar Gentsch, Michael Kurrat
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Current interruption tests were conducted up to 31.5 kA for frequencies of 50 Hz and 35 Hz. Thereby, two contact design were used: transverse magnetic field (TMF) and axial magnetic field (AMF). The key focus for TMF contacts involved the analysis of arc rotation and operational arc modes, while the study of AMF contacts concentrated on the formation of non-constricted arcs at similar higher gaps. For these investigations 8 test series for TMF and 3 for AMF-conducted to examine the influence of larger gaps, material and current. The results show, that both contact design are feasible for current interruption of gaps up to $\mathbf{4 5 ~ m m}$ and current up to $\mathbf{3 1. 5}$ kA. Thereby, differences in the contact design were found in the analysis of the charge density of anode surfaces

title: Multi-Source Asynchronous Cell-Free Massive MIMO Systems for mURLLC: Performance Analysis and Optimization
authors: Jie Wang, Jiamin Li, Pengcheng Zhu, Dongming Wang, Bin Sheng, Xiaohu You
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems, which employ distributed access points (APs) to serve all users, have emerged as a promising solution for massive ultra-reliable and low-latency communications (mURLLC). However, the signal propagation delay caused by its distributed architecture at AP side is significantly different, which interacts with the initial time offset caused by low-cost oscillators at user side to form multi-source asynchronous effect in cell-free systems. This asynchronous effect destroys pilot orthogonality and causes phase distortion, resulting in huge energy loss and access delay. To systematically characterize the this effects, this paper first establishes a comprehensive model for cell-free multi-source asynchronous effect and derives minimum mean-square error (MMSE) channel estimation, thus revealing the critical issues of pilot orthogonality destruction and phase-shift matrix-induced interference. Furthermore, we derive closed-form expressions for both the achievable uplink spectral efficiency (SE) and decoding error probability. Finally, we propose a novel asynchronous compensation framework based on multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MADRL) for adaptive transmission time adjustment and optimized receive vector design. Theoretical simulation investigates the adverse effects of the multi-source asynchronous effect based on different key parameters. Numerical results demonstrate that our MADRL-based framework achieves superior SE and access success probability, effectively compensating asynchronous impairments and proving particularly suitable for mURLLC requirements.

title: Fixed-time Virtual Inertia-Damping Control for Frequency Stability in Interconnected Microgrid Systems
authors: Mohamed Zaery, Syed Muhammad Amrr, S.M. Suhail Hussain, Vijay Vittal, Mohammad A. Abido, Hossam Ali
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: The growing integration of renewable energy sources (RESs) has led to a significant reduction in power system inertia, posing challenges for grid stability. Unlike traditional power systems, which rely on physical inertia, modern microgrids (MGs) require virtual inertia support from external energy sources such as energy storage systems (ESSs). Electric vehicles (EVs) can be utilized as existing energy resources to improve inertial response, thereby minimizing the need for additional ESS and associated costs. To meet the demand of inertia, this paper introduces a novel fixed-time integral sliding mode virtual inertia and damping (FxT-ISM-VID) control strategy, designed to enhance frequency stability in multiarea MG that typically lack synchronous generation. A key feature of the proposed controller is its ability to quickly resolve frequency deviations within a predefined time frame, regardless of the initial system conditions. This ensures accelerated and predictable stabilization times. Moreover, the ISM control provides robustness against model uncertainties, fluctuations in RESs generation, and system parametric variations. A thorough analysis using Lyapunov based method is developed to validate the stability of the designed control strategy within a fixed time. Simulation and HIL results of a two-area interconnected MG with stochastic load-generation variations, nonlinear generation, and realistic communication delays validate the effectiveness of the proposed FxT-ISM-VID control approach. It outperforms existing strategies, achieving an 87.6% reduction in frequency deviation, 86.56% faster stabilization time, and significant improvements in tie-line power fluctuations during heavy load integration.

title: Innovation Helix Models: Theory, Practice, and Emerging Trends
authors: Grazielle F. G. Teixeira, Anderson L. Szejka, Osiris Canciglieri Junior
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: This paper presents a semi-systematic literature review of Innovation Helix Models (Triple, Quadruple, and Quintuple), examining their conceptual evolution, empirical applications, and emerging trends. The mixed-methods approach combining bibliometric mapping and thematic analysis identified five core domains: actor interaction, framework development, entrepreneurship, efficiency and effectiveness, and historical perspectives. The findings delineate the state of the art, while simultaneously exposing underlying divergences and conceptual lacunae. These gaps are articulated through a set of prospective research questions, systematically organised by model perspectives, actors, and salient characteristics. Findings confirm the predominance of the Triple Helix, while highlighting theoretical limitations that have motivated the development of higher-order models. Although the Quadruple and Quintuple Helices introduce societal and ecological dimensions, their operationalisation remains limited. On this basis, the study advances a structured synthesis designed not only to orient subsequent scholarly inquiry but also to enhance the practical deployment of innovation helix models in engineering and technology management.

title: Retraction Notice: Recognition of Emotions in Speech
authors: Ankur Chaprana, B. Balamurugan
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: In human-computer user applications, extracting recognition from the discourse signal is an investigation theme for quite a long while. to recognize the emotions from the discourse signal, a few frameworks are created. During this undertaking report discourse, emotion recognition upheld the past innovations that utilized various classifiers for which the feeling recognition is checked on. Discourse has numerous trademark alternatives like effortlessness and strength, which makes it an excellent interface medium. It's feasible to exact emotions and mentalities through this research. To recognize feelings through discourse, changed discourse choices were removed. Upheld these discourse choices classification of the emotions has been done and the order execution of the model. Here feeling recognition is finished for different emotions like neutral, happy, sad, dissatisfaction, anger, and fear.

title: Dual-Locking Learned AI Models: A PIN-Based Sparse QIM Watermarking and Adaptive Index Permutation Approach
authors: Iva Vasic, Jesúus Mu˜ñoz-Cádiz, Bata Vasic
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: We present a dual-locking method for securing trained neural networks, combining key-driven index permutation with PIN-based watermarking via Sparse Quantization Index Modulation (QIM). To incorporate cryptographic randomness into the locking mechanism, we independently apply a uniform random permutation to every row of the adaptively selected index vectors. The second stage embeds a robust, blind binary watermark into the bias coefficients, modulating its quantized values, and binding the network to a user-defined Personal Identification Number (PIN). Without the correct key, the network retains its architecture, but becomes functionally impaired due to disrupted internal representations. Unlocking is achieved through inverse permutation, fully restoring model accuracy. Simultaneously, the embedded watermark remains imperceptible, concealed within the host bias structure without affecting functionality. Upon extraction, it verifies the key association and confirms model authorship. To enhance both robustness and recoverability, we apply an adaptive key selection strategy that redistributes highmagnitude weights to low-sensitivity positions and vice versa. This maximizes degradation when locked, while ensuring full recovery when unlocked. Experiments on MNIST, CIFAR-10/100, and ImageNet-1K using fully connected networks, ResNet Convo-lutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and transformer architectures demonstrate that our method sharply reduces accuracy when locked to below 10& and even 0.5& for CNNs, while fully restoring it with the correct key. The embedded watermark does not degrade performance and reliably authenticates ownership. Embedding analysis across transformers and CNNs reveals the method’s diagnostic potential, where characteristic shifts in embedding distributions may indicate undertraining or suboptimal design. Overall, this approach offers strong protection and traceability for neural network models.

title: Content-First Design: Moving Content Forward: Sarah Johnson: [Book Review]

title: Localization-Driven 3D Codebook Design and Intelligent Beam Training for Millimeter-Wave Cell-Free Massive MIMO Systems
authors: Xiaoyu Sun, Chang Sun, Jiamin Li, Pengcheng Zhu, Dong Han, Dongming Wang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: The high mobility of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) imposes stringent requirements on the angular accuracy of three-dimensional (3D) beams and beamforming time in the millimeter-wave cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF mMIMO) systems. This paper presents an intelligent 3D beam alignment scheme with two-stage optimization protocol to achieve rapid and efficient mmWave beam alignment. During the codebook design phase, the system can extract UAV positions from local real-time information and customize highly directional 3D beam codebooks. During the beam training phase, an enhanced multi-agent deep Q-network (EMADQN)-based intelligent beam training algorithm is proposed to significantly accelerate training convergence speed, while ensuring the output of an effective 3D beam selection. The simulation results confirm that the proposed intelligent 3D beam alignment scheme can swiftly attain performance on par with that of the exhaustive search method, demonstrating its superiority and practicality in low-altitude coverage scenarios.

title: A Novel Multi-Perspective Framework for Molecule Pretraining: From Atom to Motif Views
authors: Wei Wang, Dengzhen Lu, Suyu Dong, Gongning Luo, Kuanquan Wang, Shanzhuo Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Predicting molecular properties is vital for drug discovery, but experimental measurement is costly and limited by scarce labeled data. Self-supervised molecular pretraining can leverage large unlabeled datasets, reducing dependence on extensive annotations. However, most methods struggle to preserve domain-specific chemical knowledge, especially clinically relevant substructures such as motifs. Random masking and generic graph augmentations often degrade critical chemical information and harm interpretability. Many approaches also work at a single scale-either atom or motif-missing opportunities for cross-scale integration. We propose A2M-Mol, a multi-perspective molecular pretraining framework that combines atom-level and motif-level views through four parallel graph constructions. This design enables cross-view alignment and multiscale fusion, explicitly encoding chemical knowledge. A2M-Mol employs a suite of self-supervised tasks, including cross-view correspondence, atomic reconstruction, global topology modeling, and property constraint enforcement, all coordinated via tailored contrastive learning. Extensive experiments across benchmarks and backbone architectures show consistent improvements over state-of-the-art methods. Ablation studies confirm strong synergies among the tasks. A2M-Mol maintains robust predictive accuracy across data scales, demonstrating effectiveness for real-world molecular property prediction and potential to accelerate drug discovery.

title: MOOC Dropout Prediction Using Explainable Relational Graph Convolution
authors: Yang Guo, Yijia He
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study addresses the issues of high rates of student attrition and the paucity of explainability of predictive models in Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) by proposing a framework for predicting student attrition based on an Explainable Relational Graph Convolutional Network (ERGCN). The model captures co-learning relationships among students and latent associations between courses by constructing a multidimensional relationship between students, courses, and behaviors. The proposed approach incorporates a dynamic temporal segmentation method with a 10-day cycle, in conjunction with a long short-term memory (LSTM) network, to extract fine-grained behavioral sequence features. The experimental results demonstrate that the validation based on the xuetangx data set indicates that ERGCN exhibits a remarkable predictive effect on the dropout ofMOOCstudents in higher education, with an F1 value of 92.56±0.04% and an AUC value of 88.84±0.03%. In comparison with the conventional benchmark model (logistic regression and support vector machine), the absolute enhancement of the AUC is 10.31-19.33 percentage points, and the relative enhancement is 13.1% -27.8%. The study utilizes an explainability module analysis to identify the key factors that influence dropout. The study provides MOOC platforms with a prediction tool that combines high accuracy and transparency. This facilitates the implementation of customized intervention strategies by educators for students who are at risk. For instance, they can prioritize the delivery of customized learning resources to the top 10% of students with the highest probability of dropping out. The present research proffers methodological references for relationship graph modeling and explainable artificial intelligence in the context of educational data mining.

title: Residual Reinforcement Learning Enhanced with Unsuccessful Episode Buffer
authors: Peter Farkas, Tamas Becsi, Szilard Aradi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents have proven to be highly effective in many control domains; however, despite their generally promising performance, they may still encounter difficulties in certain challenging scenarios. To address this limitation, we propose a two-stage learning framework, where an initial pre-trained policy is extended with a second set of networks, aiming to correct the base agent's knowledge and preserve its behavior. Both modules are trained with the conventional RL loop, while the second learning system is also faced with an increased number of training samples from those problematic scenarios to provide more exploration possibilities across them. We evaluated the effectiveness of the proposed framework on various environments from the robotic and vehicle control domains. The results showed that the final agent demonstrates improved performance and can successfully complete a broader range of scenarios compared to the baseline agents, while also maintaining the control quality.

title: Retraction Notice: The Impactful Analysis of DL Algorithms Isolated Observing Support Models Design: A Systematic Review
authors: Rakesh Kumar, Ajay Sharma, Chandan Roy, Mohammed Al-Farouni, Jyotsana Suyal, K Prashanth Kumar
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This study offers a singular technique for the type of multisensory city far flung sensing statistics utilizing a deep studying decision fusion approach. By leveraging the strengths of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), stacked sparse autoencoders, and choice-level fusion techniques, the framework adeptly procedures complicated spectral-spatial information inherent in urban landscapes. The method begins with the extraction of deep functions, utilising the combined spectral-spatial statistics, accompanied by means of class through a tender-choice classifier. A selection-level fusion mechanism similarly refines these classifications, integrating the consequences of numerous fashions to decorate usual accuracy. Finally, context-conscious item-based totally postprocessing is hired to enhance the precision of the category consequences. Tested on the hard dataset from the GRSS data fusion contest, this technique demonstrates enormous improvements over traditional class strategies. This study underscores the ability of deep gaining knowledge of in revolutionizing remote sensing facts evaluation, paving the way for greater correct and certain urban environmental tracking.
