title: Retraction Notice: Convolutional Neural Network-Based Anomaly Detection for Cyber Security: A Survey
authors: Neha Agarwal, Amandeep Kaur
publish: 2023 3rd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: There are many security risks as computer and communication technologies continue to advance. To reduce these worries, several different kinds Numerous processes with cyber-security enabled have been developed. Anomaly detection is one of these methods. Finding anomalies involves employing a variety of approaches and procedures to identify various patterns that do not adhere to predetermined characteristics of the entire body of data. Deep learning techniques have recently been accepted as an adequate option due to their capacity to take data properties directly from the data. Convolution neural network (CNN) is employed primarily because it can handle input with many dimensions. This study offers a thorough analysis of the use of CNN as a primary tool for anomaly identification. The majority of the known remedies have been compiled and categorized in the literature. Additionally, this research provides a bound together cross framework that mimics complete anomaly detection methods that were previously offered examinations, as per the information source. In-depth assessment from a brought together cross system upgrades this paper’s top to bottom conversation of how CNN is utilized in the writing’s response to the irregularity identification issue. Finally, this article makes a number of recommendations for future study areas that the audience may find useful in their own further activities in this area.

title: Numerical Study on the Anode Deformation Considering the Interaction between Arc Column and Anode
authors: Ze Yang, Jiangling Tan, Dongsheng Cai, Lijun Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In this paper, the interaction among cathodic plasma, anode vapor and anode melting pool is studied. A selfconsistent model is established based on magnetohydrodynamic model and volume of fraction method. The simulation results predict that the anode vapor has great effect on the anode deformation. In addition, the movement of the melting pool can affect the anode temperature distribution, which can affect the anode vapor in turn. This indicates that it is necessary to use a self-consistent model to analyzed the anode deformation.

title: Design of Non Partial Discharge Single-Phase/Three-Phase Isolated Grounding Safety Switch For Experimental Hall
authors: Shang Di, Wang Lei, Yan Hongyu, Wang Ding, Ji Xiaozhen, Qiu Huahua
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: At present, the non partial discharge grounding isolation safety switch used inside the transformer test hall has problems such as large installation space during operation, inability of wiring terminals to withstand high stress, complex mechanical linkage mechanism, uneven distribution of circuit electric field, and inability to switch single-phase and three-phase outputs. An integrated and intelligent non partial discharge single-phase/three-phase isolation grounding safety switch is proposed. This article simulates the electric field of the main electrical components of the switch. The switch is designed with a circular arc to control the concentrated distribution of the electric field, which can reduce circuit corona. And the switch can operate independently for all three phases, which can meet various test conditions and effectively improve the reliability of the isolation/grounding switch.

title: Study on Ion Sputtering-Induced Gap Breakdown between Molybdenum Grid Electrodes in Vacuum
authors: Haoyan Liu, Wenxuan Liu, Yuelin Liu, Liwei Zhang, Anbang Sun, Guanjun Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In ion thrusters, the grid electrodes are subjected to high-voltage biases for ion extraction and acceleration, but their performance is significantly impacted by vacuum breakdown. To enhance the longevity of ion thrusters and optimize the design of grid electrodes, a systematic investigation is conducted on the vacuum DC gap breakdown characteristics induced by ion sputtering. This study involved seven-aperture grid electrodes fabricated from molybdenum exposed to sputtering by $\mathrm{Ar}^{+}$and $\mathrm{Xe}^{+}$ions at energies of 400 eV and 1000 eV for durations ranging from 0.5 to 8 hours. The results indicate that the initial breakdown voltage, which means the first breakdown voltage after sputtering, typically decreases with increasing sputtering time. However, with repeated discharges, the breakdown voltage tends to increase rapidly. The surface of the molybdenum electrode forms depressions in the sputtering area, with numerous nanoscale particles observed. These surface microstructures and particles significantly reduce the breakdown voltage, leading to insulation degradation. Additionally, sputtering with $\mathrm{Xe}^{+}$ions induces greater fluctuations in breakdown voltage during repeated discharges, likely due to its higher sputtering yield. Measurements of dark current and calculations of the field enhancement factor are performed to examine the relationship between the local electric field and breakdown voltage. Furthermore, micro particles are identified as key contributors to the initial breakdown events. Based on these findings, two distinct discharge mechanisms are proposed: one involving cascade discharges induced by micro particles and the other driven by field emission effects.

title: Design and Simulation of DC Circuit Breaker with Fault Current Limiting Capability
authors: Yufei Tao, Siyuan Liu, Jinchao Chen, Ziao Yuan, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: With the rapid development of DC microgrid, rail transit, multi-electric aircraft, ship power and other fields, higher requirements are put forward for the safety and reliability of DC power supply system. However, compared with the AC system, the DC system current does not have natural zero crossing, and when the short-circuit fault occurs, the fault current rises rapidly, which puts forward higher requirements for the speed and reliability of the DC circuit breaker(DCCB). Therefore, this paper proposes a novel DC circuit breaker based on coupling inductance, which has the ability to limit the rise rate of fault current. This paper introduces the research status of DC circuit breakers at first, and then introduces the working principle and mathematical model analysis of the proposed circuit breaker. Next, the performance of the circuit breaker is analyzed in detail through the simulation, and the feasibility of circuit breaker is verified.

title: Smart MobilityX: An Intelligent Transportation System for Sustainable Commuting
authors: Mary Jane Samonte, Jeriell Emmanuel Gallinera, Franchezcka Giannah Mari Pascual, Francis Andrei Santos, Marcus Ram Garcia, Marc Conrad Reyes
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: None

title: Conceptual Framework for Automated Quality Assessment and Monitoring of Geospatial Web Services
authors: Guntis Mosāns, Gusts Linkevičs, Jānis Kampars, Oskars Grauzis, Dāvis Immurs, Niklāvs Kadikis
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Traditional geospatial service monitoring solutions often fail to provide sufficient quality control. They are either not designed specifically for geospatial service monitoring, lacking comprehensive quality assessment capabilities, or, in the case of specialized tools, they do not address the full scope of monitoring challenges and are not user-friendly. These solutions do not check data quality, such as whether returned images match expected results, maintain sufficient resolution, or contain all necessary data. Natural changes in road networks, land use, and hydrography create variations between reference and newly retrieved images, making it necessary to evaluate whether these differences reflect real-world updates or inconsistencies in the service output. This paper presents GeoSense, a conceptual framework that combines simple service check algorithms with machine learning to verify both service availability and data integrity. The method detects service failures, analyzes returned images, and distinguishes between expected environmental changes and data inconsistencies. By integrating automated checks with intelligent analysis, GeoSense enhances reliability, reduces manual validation efforts, and improves the overall assessment of geospatial services.

title: Towards Hungarian-English Code-Switching Speech Dataset Construction by using Multi Speaker-adaptive Text-to-Speech Synthesis
authors: Piroska Zsófia Barta, Péter Mihajlik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: In this work, we present the first version of a novel Hungarian–English code-switching dataset derived from VoxPopuli. The dataset includes two subsets – a randomly aligned set and a partially synthesized, context-preserving set – each specifically designed to support code-switching research. We evaluated three different ASR models on this dataset. Zero-shot results indicated that among the examined models, Canary 180M Flash was inherently the most capable of handling codeswitched speech. However, the best fine-tuned performance was achieved with the Whisper-large-v3-turbo model, attaining a multilingual WER of $8.07 \%$ and a CER of $3.74 \%$ on the test set. This represents a relative improvement of $89.84 \%$ in WER and $94.37 \%$ in CER compared to the zero-shot results. With the new dataset, we were able to improve the monolingual WER results for both languages, as well.

title: Detecting Audio Deepfakes on the Edge: Lightweight SSL-Based Detection in a Browser Plugin
authors: Octavian Pascu, Dan Oneata, Horia Cucu, Nicolas M. Müller
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Audio deepfakes are a growing challenge for the general public, as well as for journalists and fact-checkers. The latter need reliable tools to verify the authenticity of their sources, while at the same time keeping their information private. Commercial deepfake detection solutions rely on cloud-based processing, which raises privacy concerns. To solve this problem, we propose an on-device audio deepfake detection model. We show that a truncated self-supervised backbone with a simple logistic classifier is both very fast and often more accurate than existing solutions. Our solution outperforms the baseline AASIST by $10 \%$ and improves inference speed by $40 \%$. We integrate this model into a browser plug-in, which allows journalists and fact-checkers to detect deepfakes easily and securely. Code for the plugin is available at https://github.com/OctavianPascu97/ Audio-Deepfakes-Browser-Plugin.

title: 3D transient modeling and simulation of vacuum arc considering the interaction with anode melting pool
authors: Jieli Chen, Lijun Wang, Xiangyu Wang, Hongjian Wang, Tianlu Liu, Zhefeng Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: During the opening process of vacuum circuit breakers, the arc will cause the anode to heat up and melt. This will have a negative impact on the circuit breaker and reduce its life. In this study, a 3D transient model will be established to simulate the interaction between arc and anode. The process of electrode melting under arc heating and electrode evaporation affecting the arc is considered. In this study, a axial magnetic field contact made of pure copper with a diameter of 41 mm was used. The opening distance is 10 mm and the current is 17.5 kA (rms). The simulation results show that the electrode melts and generates an outside flow. The anode temperature is near the melting point of the metal. Meanwhile, due to the high plasma pressure, the anode did not change to an active mode. The phenomena observed in simulation and experiment are consistent.

title: Study on the Influence of Structural Parameters of 126kV Vacuum Interrupter on Electric Field Distribution
authors: Yinghui Chai, Wenbo Wang, Wenjun Xiang, Xubin Li, Minfu Liao, Xiongying Duan
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Under the dual-carbon strategy, reducing the application of SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> in power systems has become an industry trend. Vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs), owing to their environmental friendliness and compact design, are widely used in medium and low voltage applications. However, their insulation performance limits their development in high-voltage applications. As the core component, the insulation strength of the vacuum interrupter (VI) directly determines the equipment’s performance. This study focuses on a 126 kV VI, establishing a two-dimensional axisymmetric model based on finite element simulation platform to analyze the influence of tank structure (diameter and length), contact fillet radius and contact gap on electric field distribution. Through parameter optimization, the selected design combines a 640 mm diameter and 2650 mm length for the tank, along with 21 mm contact rounding and 46 mm gap spacing, achieving a maximum field strength of $21.50 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ within the vacuum interrupter while maintaining the surface field strength at the ceramic interface at $5.98 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$.

title: Credit Card Transaction Trend Forecasting Based on Graph Neural Network
authors: Xiaoguo Wang, Yuheng Zheng, Hongming Zhu, Chao Chen, Huanzhang Li
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: None

title: Empirical Analysis of Artificial Intelligence Leveraging Data Mining on Green Technological Innovation in Enterprises
authors: Xiaolin Sun, Wenxin Pi
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is a key driver of enterprises' digital and intelligent transformation. Through machine learning and deep learning, it reshapes operational logic and enhances decision-making intelligence, thus promoting sustainable development. This study empirically examines the impact of AI on green technology innovations by Chinese companies listed on the A-share market between 2014 and 2023. It finds that AI significantly enhances green innovation. This is achieved via two mediating effects: increased R&D investment and enhanced total factor productivity. External factors also play a moderating role: high financing constraints mitigate the positive impact of AI on green innovation, whereas a stronger competitive market position amplifies it. Interestingly, non-capital-intensive firms demonstrate more pronounced AI-driven green innovation than their capital-intensive counterparts. These findings enrich our theoretical understanding of the role of AI in sustainable innovation and provide practical insights into how firms can use AI to promote green technological advances, particularly under different financial and market conditions.

title: Simulation study on vacuum arc drawing process with arc starting position offset
authors: Yulu Yang, Xiaolong Huang, Chenxi Yang, Huikai Xu, Lihua Zhao, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In the process of vacuum arc breaking, the axial magnetic field generated by the axial magnetic contact promotes the arc diffusion, and the initial arcing condition has an important influence on the successful breaking. However, with the increase of the current level and the increase of the opening distance, the arc starting position mostly appears in the edge area of the contact piece, which has an adverse effect on the arc breaking. In this paper, a three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model is used to focus on the arcing of the high-current vacuum arc (HCVA) boundary arcing, and the different diffusion conditions in the arcing process are simulated. Two characteristic events are selected, one is the diffusion process of the arcing position of the unilateral edge, and the other is the diffusion process of the arcing position of the bilateral edge. The variation of physical parameters such as ion temperature, density and axial current density with the arcing process was studied, and the simulation results were compared with the experimental results. The simulation results are helpful to understand the arc development process and physical mechanism of offset arcing under large opening distance.

title: Current Conditionning Process for Vacuun Interrupters Manufacturing
authors: Xavier Godechot, Renaud Carlen, Lifeng Luo, Baochung Song
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum Interrupters are industrially manufactured for the medium voltage market and to a lesser extend for high voltage. Quality and performances are the mean objective. This including long lifetime, reliability in operation, and very high performances as rated current switching, short circuit current making, capacitive current switching, and interruption to pass power tests according to international standards. To get those performances, they need to perform different steps of industrial process including current conditioning, voltage conditioning and high vacuum tests. We will present in this paper the latest finding about current conditioning manufacturing process of Axial Magnetic Field and Radial Magnetic Field contacts. It was found that the contact conditioning area is strongly affected by parameters among which, the current amplitude, current wave shape and to some extend the electrical circuit. Current conditioning of specific area of the contact was also investigated with modification of the experimental setup. The metal vapor deposition on ceramic were different after different conditioning process. The dielectric performances, i.e., basic impulse level, are strongly correlated. Therefore, it’s possible to select the optimum current conditioning process to make the voltage conditioning easier and improve the dielectric performances of VI.

title: A Computer Scientist Walks Into a Magazine
authors: Sean Peisert
publish: IEEE Security & Privacy

title: Hyperparameters Optimization for Diffraction Ring Detection in Magnetic Tweezers Experiment Data
authors: Tautvydas Naudžiūnas, Guoda Perminaitė, Povilas Treigys
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: A substantial amount of visual data is created while conducting molecular research experiments using magnetic tweezers. Since optical tweezers dominate molecular research, few algorithms exist specifically for magnetic tweezers. Existing algorithms, when available, often have significant limitations. Many require purchases of expensive, specialized equipment, making them inaccessible for smaller and less funded laboratories. Additionally, some of these tools are not readily available, requiring them to be shared by those with access. This study was motivated by the lack of accessible and practical solutions.This study aims to develop an algorithm capable of processing low-quality, noisy images, effectively removing noise while preserving essential features such as diffraction rings. The algorithm seeks to reliably detect and track the changes of these rings throughout the experiment, which result from molecular length changes of the molecule connected to the magnetic tweezers. To enhance the performance of diffraction ring detection, we utilized Optuna search for hyperparameter optimization. The results from Optuna optimization were compared to those obtained from manual optimization. By providing a fast, accessible, and efficient method for image analysis, this solution would simplify the experimental process for researchers, making it possible for a broader range of laboratories to conduct molecular studies using magnetic tweezers. To detect these subtle changes accurately, it is essential to identify the optimal hyperparameters that enable the algorithm to perform effectively, which is the focus of this study.

title: The Analysis of Time Delays Stability in an FPGA-based Wave-Union Time-to-Digital Converter Core
authors: Jakovs Ratners, Jacek Goczkowski, Marek Wojcikowski, Arturs Aboltins
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Wave-union-based Time-to-Digital converters are one of the few emerging technologies that allow event time tagging in the range of a few picoseconds and below. So far, the most effort in implementing such a technology has been done using Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) due to their logic reconfigurability and cost efficiency. The main component of a wave-union time-to-digital converter (TDC) is a tapped delay line (TDL) which consists of logic elements that act as fixed delays. Due to high dependency of FPGA on such factors as process-voltage-temperature (PVT) changes, clock-network jitter and device-to-device discrepancies, the behavior of delays of the logic elements over a course of measurements offer some degree of nonlinearity.This work focuses on the time delays quantization stability and effects of nonlinear delay distribution for a wave-union core developed for a Microchip’s IGLOO2, a general-purpose field-programmable gate array (FPGA). It is demonstrated that while controlling core voltage supply and external factors such as electro-static discharge (ESD) and temperature to be at a constant low level, the nonlinearity was still present in the processed data in the form of large random spikes, but the instability of estimated bin delays has decreased.

title: Research on the Current Situation and Influencing Factors of Death Coping Ability of Undergraduate Nursing Students via Multiple Linear Regression
authors: Jiamin Lan, Qiuling Chen
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: Background: Gaining an in-depth understanding of the current status and influencing factors of death coping ability among nursing students is crucial for designing effective death education courses, enhancing nursing students' death coping ability, and ultimately improving the overall quality of nursing services. Objective: To investigate the current status of death coping ability among undergraduate nursing students and analyze its influencing factors. Methods: The convenience survey method was adopted. And the investigation was conducted using the Sense of Meaning in Life Scale, the Simplified Version of the Death Coping Ability Scale, and the Chinese version of the Death Attitude Description Scale. Based on these data samples, descriptive statistics, t-tests, ANOVA, Pearson correlation, and multiple linear regression were applied to analysis influencing factors of death coping ability. Results: The death coping ability score of undergraduate nursing students was 45.70±13.27, indicating a moderate level. Meaning in life, natural acceptance, death fear, and death escape were identified as influencing factors of the death coping ability level among undergraduate nursing students (P<0.05). Conclusion: The death coping ability of undergraduate nursing students is generally at a moderate level. Meaning in life and natural acceptance are significantly positively correlated with death coping ability, while death fear is significantly negatively correlated with it. The lack of death education and insufficient practical experience are important factors restricting the improvement of death coping ability among undergraduate nursing students. It is recommended to strengthen the systematic and practical nature of death education courses in nursing education and focus on cultivating nursing students' sense of meaning in life and psychological resilience.

title: Research on the Construction of the Prediction Model of the Elderly's Physical Health Based on Deep Learning
authors: Yue Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: None

title: A Study on Diabetes Diagnosis Method Integrating Ensemble Learning and SHAP
authors: Boyi Yang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: This paper deals with the necessity of early-stage diagnosis of diabetes through suggestions of the technique ensemble learning and SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) to diagnose diabetes. By using the Pima Indians Diabetes Dataset, the medical indicators of patients under analysis were compared to compare the performance of eight models of machine learning to diagnose the diagnosis. Such models are Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors, Support Vector Machine, Naive Bayes and Ensemble models, including Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost and LightGBM. The analysis of the experiment shows that the Random Forest model performs better compared to other models in terms of three or more evaluation measures, and accuracy is 77.273%. Moreover, the SHAP method was used to clarify the component of the best model to find out interpretability, and the main variables to affect a diabetes diagnosis include glucose level, BMI, and age. The suggested technique helps to enhance the performance of early diabetes detection and offers interpretable decision-making assistance to the clinicians.

title: Lightweight Intelligent Detection System for Personal Protective Equipment in Laboratories of Higher Education Institutions
authors: Han Liao, Xuting Hu, Feng Wang, Zhanzhan Liu, Maowang Wu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Laboratory safety in higher education institutions (HEIs) is an important issue in research and teaching, especially in high-risk environments such as chemical and biological.With the increasing demand for laboratory safety management, traditional manual checking methods face inefficiency and poor real-time performance. Therefore, introducing an automated intelligent detection system has become important to improve laboratory safety management. In this paper, a lightweight laboratory personal protective equipment detection system (LabPPE-DS) based on cross-stage partial darknet (CSPDarknet) is proposed for real-time detection of personal protective equipment (PPE) in laboratories. The system achieves high-precision PPE detection through cross-scale feature-focused fusion. It adopts pruning and knowledge distillation technology to significantly improve the system’s computational efficiency and resource adaptation capability. Through experimental validation, LabPPE-DS outperforms existing mainstream detection models in several detection metrics, effectively balancing precision and inference speed. In addition, the system is successfully deployed on computing devices without graphics processing unit (GPU) support, verifying its effectiveness in resource-constrained environments. In addition to enhancing laboratory security management, the system has a wide range of potential applications.

title: Incentive Mechanism Design for Resource Management in Satellite Networks: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Nguyen Cong Luong, Zeping Sui, Duc Van Le, Jie Cao, Bo Ma, Nguyen Duc Hai, Ruichen Zhang, Vu Van Quang, Dusit Niyato, Shaohan Feng
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Resource management is one of the challenges in satellite networks due to their high mobility, wide coverage, long propagation distances, and stringent constraints on energy, communication, and computation resources. Traditional resource allocation approaches rely only on hard and rigid system performance metrics. Meanwhile, incentive mechanisms, which are based on game theory and auction theory, investigate systems from the "economic" perspective in addition to the "system" perspective. Particularly, incentive mechanisms are able to take into account rationality and other behavior of human users into account, which guarantees benefits/utility of all system entities, thereby improving the scalability, adaptability, and fairness in resource allocation. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of incentive mechanism design for resource management in satellite networks. The paper covers key issues in the satellite networks, such as communication resource allocation, computation offloading, privacy and security, and coordination. We conclude with future research directions including learning-based mechanism design for satellite networks.

title: UaBMA-OLPP: A Novel Manifold-Inspired Technique for sEMG-based Hand Movement and Object Grasp Recognition
authors: Saibal Ghosh, Amitava Chatterjee, Sugata Munshi
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Hand-related impairments from stroke and neuromuscular diseases are rising globally, increasing the demand for prosthetic hands using surface electromyography (sEMG) for hand movement and grasp activities. sEMG systems also support human-robot interaction (HRI), aiding assistive robots in manipulator tasks. However, sEMG sensors often struggle to capture comprehensive muscle activity and are vulnerable to external hazards. In such scenarios, classical dimensionality reduction techniques often underperform, particularly when the intrinsic spatial structure of the data is overlooked. Addressing this limitation, local manifold-inspired learning techniques, such as locality preserving projection (LPP), are investigated in this study. In particular, orthogonal LPP (OLPP) helps extracting features from high-dimensional data by leveraging the orthogonal properties of nonlinear mappings from input to feature space. Nevertheless, traditional projection kernels are typically constructed based on Euclidean similarity between data points, making them highly sensitive to noise and outliers. To overcome this challenge, we have incorporated two additional similarity measures derived from the complex Euler space and Grassmannian manifold, which effectively explore the local structure in Riemannian spaces. A novel uncertainty-aware Bayesian model averaging (UaBMA) approach is proposed for integrating similarity weights from various manifolds, thereby enhancing the projection discriminability. Extensive experimental studies on both laboratory-acquired and benchmark NinaPro datasets demonstrate superior performance of the proposed technique over existing methods.

title: Deep Learning for Clinical Ultrasound Imaging: From Supervised Approaches to Foundation Models
authors: Keshi He, Donglai Wei, Bryan Ranger
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Deep learning models have traditionally been developed and trained to perform specific tasks, which limits their generalizability across different domains. Recently, the field has experienced a paradigm shift toward foundation models, wherein AI systems are pre-trained on extensive datasets to support a broad range of tasks across multiple domains. This shift is particularly promising for ultrasound imaging, a relatively low-cost and versatile modality in clinical practice. However, their adoption remains limited due to challenges such as scarce labeled data, domain-specific variability, and the need for user expertise. This review first outlines the workflow and design principles of deep learning based ultrasound clinical applications, with emphasis on advancements in supervised and self-supervised learning, discriminative models, generative AI models, foundation models, and other miscellaneous models. Recent literature on ultrasound image analysis is then reviewed in detail. Furthermore, deep learning-based ultrasound clinical applications are summarized, and the potential of foundation models to enhance diagnostic performance and expand the scope of ultrasound in clinical settings is highlighted. Finally, key challenges are discussed, and future directions for deep learning in clinical ultrasound are proposed.

title: Smart Electromagnetic Skin for Near-Field mmWave Communications: Design, System Implementation, and End-to-End Link Evaluation
authors: Álvaro F. Vaquero, Sergio M. Feito, Álvaro Pendás-Recondo, Marcos R. Pino, Manuel Arrebola
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This work presents the design, RF evaluation, and demonstration of a communication link using a Smart Electromagnetic Skin (SES) operating in the millimeter-wave (mmWave) band within a realistic indoor environment. Two metasurface-based antennas are developed: one emulating a base station (BS) with high-gain directive beams, and a second metasurface acting as an SES to generate coverage and mitigate a static blind spot. The SES is designed considering that the blind spot lies in the near-field region and, to ensure a cost-effective solution, employs a unit cell topology based on a single dielectric layer with patch-type metallizations. Although this topology does not provide a full 360∘ phase cycle, it remains cost-efficient. This limitation is explicitly incorporated into the synthesis process, enabling near-field beam shaping while accounting for practical implementation constraints and the actual field distribution generated by the BS on the SES, without relying on a plane-wave approximation. Both antennas were designed, fabricated, and experimentally validated. The BS antenna was characterized in an anechoic chamber, while the SES was evaluated in a realistic indoor scenario. The measured radiation patterns confirm the effectiveness of the proposed synthesis method and the capability of the SES as a cost-efficient solution for mitigating static near-field blind spots. Furthermore, a near-field end-to-end communication link is implemented using the designed antennas, a complete RF chain, and modulated signals generated with software-defined radio (SDR) devices. This link is validated through error vector magnitude (EVM) and symbol error rate (SER) measurements within the SES coverage. The results validate not only the electromagnetic performance of the SES but also the feasibility of near-field (not short-range) mmWave communications in realistic conditions.

title: HybridTabNet-QC: A Transformer-Based Clinical Feature Fusion Framework for Heart Disease Risk Prediction
authors: Fuad Mahmud, Ashim Chandra Das, Md Shujan Shak, Nabila Rahman, Arifa Akter Eva, M. F. Mridha, Md. Jakir Hossen
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Computer Society
abstract: Heart disease remains the leading cause of mortality worldwide, highlighting the need for accurate and interpretable risk prediction models. This study proposes Hybrid Tabular Network with Clinical meta-features and Quality-Control Mechanisms (HybridTabNet-QC), a hybrid deep learning framework designed to enhance clinical decision support systems. By combining a transformer-based tabular encoder with medically engineered meta-features, the model delivers interpretable, generalizable, and noise-robust predictions for heart disease risk. Unlike conventional deep learning models that treat features as raw inputs, HybridTabNet-QC fuses attention-based learning with domain-specific indicators, such as body mass index (BMI), pulse pressure, and cholesterol-glucose interaction scores that ensure predictions are both statistically sound and clinically grounded. The model was evaluated on two publicly available datasets, the Heart Disease dataset and the Cardiovascular Disease dataset from Kaggle. On the combined dataset, HybridTabNet-QC achieved 90.1% accuracy, 90.0% F1-score, and 93.6% AUC-ROC, outperforming traditional machine learning and standard deep learning baselines. The framework demonstrated strong robustness under feature noise and consistent generalization on external validation subsets. Interpretability analyses using LIME and SHAP confirmed that the model prioritizes clinically relevant features, supporting its suitability for real-world clinical decision support systems. These findings demonstrate the model's suitability for deployment in real-world healthcare environments where interpretability, robustness, and scalability are critical.

title: A 240 × 180 Event-Based Vision Sensor ROIC With Global Threshold Voltage Calibration Technology
authors: Yanwen Su, Hao Li, Kaiyue Li, Ang Hu, Yiwen Liu, Zhichen Yang, Luxin Yan, Dongsheng Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper presents a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$240\times 180$</tex-math> </inline-formula> event-based vision sensor (EVS) readout integrated circuit (ROIC) that incorporates global threshold voltage calibration technology. Conventional EVS suffer from error events and intra-array mismatch. This paper delves into four types of error events and presents effective solutions for them. This paper proposes a global threshold voltage calibration (GTVC) technique to minimize the impact of mismatch in the pixel array. The pixel size measures <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10\times 10~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\mathbf {2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, using 40 nm CMOS technology. The analog pixel circuits work with supply voltages of 2.5 V and 1.1 V, while the power consumption of this chip is 12.16 mW. By using the global threshold voltage calibration technology, which incorporates eight reference pixels for determining the input voltage of event comparators, the error in the detection result is reduced to 2.84 mV. The maximum event rate reaches 360 Meps with a 40 MHz system clock, boasting a dynamic range of 97.3 dB. Further, the event power efficiency stands at 29.6 Ge/W.

title: A Unified Approach to Critical Clearing Time Estimation considering Rotor Angle, Voltage and Frequency Stability
authors: Najia Qaiser, M. M. Aman
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Critical Clearing Time (CCT) is an important parameter in determination of power system stability because it helps in deciding the protection relay settings. A wrong CCT value results in unstable power system operation which may cause catastrophic accidents, cascading outages and blackouts. Previous literature primarily determines CCT based on rotor angle stability, which does not ensure complete system stability since voltage collapse and frequency deviations also contribute to system instability. It is therefore quite significant to determine the CCT by considering the rotor angle, voltage, and frequency (CCTδ,V,f).This paper proposes a novel approach for determining comprehensive CCTδ,V,f by simultaneously considering rotor angle, voltage and frequency stability. This proposed method is implemented using in PSS®E software on the IEEE 9-bus test system and IEEE 14-bus system respectively. In IEEE 9-bus system, simulation results show that while rotor angle based critical clearing time (CCT) value is 180 ms, the proposed CCTδ,V,f value is 80 ms, reflecting rigorous and more realistic protection requirement. These results confirm that relying solely on rotor angle based CCT may lead to maloperation of circuit breakers and compromise system instability, whereas configuring the settings based on CCTδ,V,f ensures overall system stability and protection reliability. The proposed method is also validated on IEEE 14-bus system. It shows that the proposed method provides a robust framework for dynamic security assessment and more reliable protection coordination.

title: Ultra-Low-Voltage Rectifiers
authors: Marcio Bender Machado, Xing Liu, Mohamad Sawan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive investigation of one of the most significant analog circuit blocks in use today: the rectifier, particularly in applications involving extremely low voltages. It systematically analyzes classical and state-of-the-art topologies, including the half-wave rectifier, voltage multiplier, Dickson charge pump, and cross-coupled rectifier, with an emphasis on their operation at voltages below 150 mV. Analytical models are derived for each topology, and validations are performed against experimental results obtained with commercial Schottky diodes, showing strong agreement within the sub-1 V range. The measurements demonstrate power conversion efficiency (PCE) levels higher than 60% for a 0.5 V input amplitude and above 30% for inputs below 200 mV, consistent with theoretical predictions. The discussion also summarizes the trade-offs between input amplitude, device characteristics, load conditions, and circuit implementations, providing quantitative guidance for design optimization. These findings establish a direct link between modeling and practical performance, providing a reliable reference for designing high-efficiency rectifiers that operate at extremely low voltages.

title: Self-Refined Generative Foundation Models for Wireless Traffic Prediction
authors: Chengming Hu, Hao Zhou, Di Wu, Xi Chen, Jun Yan, Xue Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: With a broad range of emerging applications in 6G networks, wireless traffic prediction has become a critical component of network management. However, the dynamically shifting distribution of wireless traffic in non-stationary 6G networks presents significant challenges to achieving accurate and stable predictions. Motivated by recent advancements in Generative AI (GenAI)-enabled 6G networks, this paper proposes a novel self-refined Large Language Model (LLM) for wireless traffic prediction, namely TrafficLLM, through in-context learning without parameter fine-tuning or model training. The proposed TrafficLLM harnesses the powerful few-shot learning abilities of LLMs to enhance the scalability of traffic prediction in dynamically changing wireless environments. Specifically, our proposed TrafficLLM embraces an LLM to iteratively refine its predictions through a three-step process: traffic prediction, feedback generation, and prediction refinement. Initially, the proposed TrafficLLM conducts traffic predictions using task-specific demonstration prompts. Recognizing that LLMs may generate incorrect predictions on the first attempt, this paper designs feedback demonstration prompts to provide multifaceted and valuable feedback related to these initial predictions. The validation scheme is further incorporated to systematically enhance the accuracy of mathematical calculations during the feedback generation process. Following this comprehensive feedback, our proposed TrafficLLM introduces refinement demonstration prompts, enabling the same LLM to further refine its predictions and thereby enhance prediction performance. Evaluations on two realistic datasets demonstrate that the proposed TrafficLLM outperforms LLM-based in-context learning methods, achieving performance improvements of 23.17% and 17.09%, respectively.

title: Decoupling-based Cross-layer Connection Removal for Compact Remote Sensing Image Classification_supp1-3636678.pdf
authors: Yuqi Han
publish: N/A
abstract: Cross-layer connections can couple different layers of neural networks in diverse paths, improving the classification accuracy of remote sensing images. However, some structures are unnecessary for inference and not conducive to be deployed on starboard/airborne platforms. Roughly removing them lengthens the backpropagation path and causes the gradient vanishing problem, degrading the performance of existing end-to-end training based lightweighting methods. To address this issue, we propose a decoupling-based cross-layer connection removal framework, which decomposes the complete deep network into multiple shallower stages based on the density of connections. By optimizing each stage independently, the backpropagation path is shortened and the gradient vanishing problem is expected to be alleviated. Moreover, to approximate the original network in each stage, we perform concret reconstruction error suppression on branches, layers and channels respectively. Combining these strategies, redundant structures are removed while maintaining performance. Extensive experiments on multiple public datasets and hardware platforms demonstrate that this compact architecture achieves substantially improved deployability and inference efficiency at the cost of only marginal accuracy degradation.

title: Suppression of Disturbances and Packet Losses in Networked Control Systems: A Data-Prediction Equivalent-Input-Disturbance Approach
authors: Guangpu Huang, Luting Liu, Wenjie Lin, Xiang Wu, Fanghong Guo, Hui Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Network-induced delays pose a significant challenge for high-performance disturbance suppression in networked control systems (NCSs), particularly when compounded by data packet losses. To address the challenge, this article proposes a data-prediction-based equivalent-input-disturbance (DPEID) method. First, the impact of short delays is modeled as a delay-induced disturbance and treated as part of a lumped disturbance. Second, a DPEID estimator is developed that utilizes a long short-term memory (LSTM) neural network-based predictor to improve the disturbance-suppression capability in the presence of packet losses. Meanwhile, a radial basis function (RBF) neural network is integrated into the observer to approximate the system uncertainty, thereby improving the estimation accuracy of system states and the disturbance. Furthermore, a dual-structure control strategy is constructed based on a DPEID estimator and a networked predictive controller. This design enables the system to achieve satisfactory control performance despite the communication constraints. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of the algorithm are verified by experimental results.

title: Retraction Notice: A Technical Review on Composite of Components Used in Textile Industry Identification using ML Algorithm
authors: Yashwant Singh Bisht, S Rama Sree, N. Prameela, Ramy Riad Al-Fatlawy, Meenu Khurana, Sudha Arogya Mary Chinthamani
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This check delves into the fusion of device gaining knowledge of with textile-based totally sensors, aiming to pioneer smart wearable products for fashionable human motion tracking. Utilizing the progressive combination of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and spandex cloth (PET/SP), we engineered stretchable fabric sensors. These sensors aren’t truly sensitive and bendy however, even as blanketed with device gaining knowledge of algorithms, pave the manner for a wearable technology able to real-time, correct human movement kind. This research stands on the intersection of advanced substances technological expertise and computational intelligence, providing a completely unique technique to wearable technology. It demonstrates the potential of smart textiles superior with device studying to revolutionize non-public healthcare and athletic overall performance evaluation. The very last consequence of this exploration is a promising step toward wearable devices that now not best provide unique movement detection but also introduce a new size to tracking and know-how human physiology and motion styles in remarkable detail.

title: Hyperspectral Image Classification Based on Normalized Grouping Fused Comprehensive Relative Position Transformer Network
authors: Ying Cui, Mengru Jia, Liguo Wang, Shan Gao, Liwei Chen, Chunhui Zhao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In hyperspectral image (HSI) classification, Transformer and CNN are widely used because they complement each other in extracting features. Nevertheless, existing Transformer-based methods still struggle to capture fine-grained local spatial details and positional relationships. Meanwhile, CNN-based attention mechanisms typically process all spectral bands simultaneously to obtain global features, often overlooking locally salient information. To address these challenges, we propose an innovative normalized grouping fused comprehensive relative position transformer network (NG-CRPTN). Specifically, NG-CRPTN comprises two core modules: the comprehensive relative position module (CRPM) and the normalized mutual information band division (NMIBD). The former employs tokens of different dimensions as its foundation, modeling local-to-global spatial structures and relative positional relationships through the local independent relative position transformer (LIRPT) and global independent relative position transformer (GIRPT), while incorporating a local complementary enhancement fusion module (LCEFM) to deeply integrate high and low-frequency information from spatial features across different dimensions. The latter achieves adaptive band grouping of HSI spectral bands to better focus on locally salient features in the spectral dimension. Extensive experiments conducted on four HSI datasets demonstrate that the proposed NG-CRPTN achieves superior classification accuracy with relatively few training samples compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Surface secondary electron emission and charge trap parameters: physics, measurement and applications
authors: Guan-Jun Zhang, Guangyu Sun, Changchun Qi, Fangzheng Zou, Xiong Yang, Baipeng Song
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Secondary electron emission (SEE) refers to the electron emission phenomenon from the surface of solid material while being bombarded by particles with certain energy. Charge trap (CT) is defined as the local energy state that captures electron or hole in a solid dielectric, due to defects, impurities, chemical bond breaks, and atomic reconstructions, etc. SEE and CT are two key coupling physical parameters, which are ubiquitous in electrical engineering, aerospace engineering, pulse power, electro-vacuum, high-energy physics and other fields. It is hence critical to elucidate the internal correlation mechanism between these two parameters, explore the characteristics of surface SEE under electron bombardment, and reveal the physical relationship among SEE, CT state and charge transport on material surface, so as to provide theoretical support and technical approaches for promoting the development of major projects and basic studies of different fields. A novel model of SEE considering CT (SEE-CT) is proposed to explain the physical relationship between CT and SEE. It is found that the increase of trap density decreases the secondary electron yield (SEY). When the surface of the dielectric is charged and the CT state is filled, and CT’s ability to capture electrons is lost, so that the SEY increases with the increase of the trapped electron amount. Meanwhile, a new instrument of Secondary Electron emission and Trap state in-situ Combined (SETiC) measurement for dielectric materials is constructed. It can realize the joint measurement of SEE and CT characteristics under a wide range of incident electron energy ($20 \mathrm{eV} \sim 50 \mathrm{keV}$), and sample temperature ($-120 \sim 200{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$) with a vacuum degree of $10^{-7} \mathrm{~Pa}$. So far, SEE and CT characteristics of more than $\mathbf{2 0}$ materials and more than $\mathbf{1 0 0}$ samples have been tested. Several kinds of corresponding dielectric charging and discharging (DCD) suppression approaches are proposed, which considerably increase the surface discharge threshold. This work can guide the dielectric material design and optimization for improving the surface insulation performance.

title: Numerical Investigation on the Detection of Vacuum Interrupter Pressure Based on Pirani Method
authors: Xutong Jin, Zongqian Shi, Yongpeng Mo, Jiajia Sun
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum has excellent electrical insulation properties, and high vacuum is a decisive factor in the normal operation of the vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs). When the pressure in vacuum interrupter is higher than $10^{-1} \mathrm{~Pa}$, the dielectric strength will be significantly reduced and seriously affect the current breaking. For vacuum interrupter, monitoring the vacuum state continuously is of great importance to the stability of the VCBs and the safe operation of the power system. In this paper, the vacuum state detection scheme based on the Pirani method is investigated. A small iron sheet is welded to the outside of the shield, which can be heated by applying a high-frequency magnetic field. The pressure inside the interrupter is determined by detecting the variation of the resistance of the iron piece when it cools down, which depends on the pressure in the interrupter. The influence of the thickness of the target piece and the size of the welding point was analyzed with COMSOL Multiphysics. According to the simulation results, the lowest pressure that can be distinguished by this method is expected to be lower than $10^{-2} \mathrm{~Pa}$.

title: Low- And Very Low Frequency Current Interruption In Vacuum
authors: Dietmar Gentsch, Andreas Lawall, Sergey Gortschakow
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum interrupters are a safe and reliable part of electrical power systems. Those devices are designed for a broad operation frequency range from $50 / 60 \mathrm{~Hz}$ [1] in conventional networks down to $16.7 / 25 \mathrm{~Hz}$ in rail electrical power systems [2]. Expanding green energy applications such as wind turbines, pumped storage, DC and AC converters in solar parks and shipboard applications bring new requirements to vacuum interrupters as they can generate temporary fault conditions with very low frequencies. Depending on phasing, the long arcing times and high transferred charge may occur, making current interruption at the current zero (CZ) difficult. In the present work the interruption performance limit to frequencies between 2 and $\mathbf{4 H z}$ based on the test performed at 16.7 and 50 Hz was calculated. The contact erosion rates were also grouped into two different categories as a function of current. The interruption operations are examined at frequencies between 2 and $\mathbf{4 H z}$ and rms currents in the range $1000 \ldots 2000 \mathrm{~A}$ in a test-set up to observe the behaviour of the vacuum arc dynamics and to calculate the heat build-up of the contacts. The test setup was equipped with three different contact types: Butt, TMF and AMF with a diameter of between 70 and 90 mm. Finally, the arc dynamics have been analysed by means of high-speed camera technique.

title: A Study on the Impact of China-US Bilateral Relations on China's Stock Market
authors: Chang Liu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This study systematically assesses the impact of U.S.–China bilateral relations on the Chinese stock market. It does this by quantifying changes in these relations and analysing their potential transmission mechanisms. The aim is to provide policymakers and investors with valuable insights. First, event data related to U.S.-China bilateral relations from 2018 to 2023 were collected using GDELT text data mining technology. Based on these data, an effective U.S.-China bilateral relations index was constructed and used as a core independent variable in subsequent empirical analyses. Next, the constructed index and several other indices were used as independent variables and the Shanghai Composite Index was used as the dependent variable. Empirical analysis was then conducted using the TVP-VAR model. The results of the empirical analysis are as follows: the Chinese stock market is indeed influenced by U.S.-China bilateral relations, economic growth, market capitalisation growth, market sentiment and global stock market performance, all of which have a significant positive effect. Regarding U.S.–China bilateral relations, their impact on China's stock market is significant and manifests in diverse forms under different event contexts. Specifically, the impact of U.S.-China bilateral relations on China's stock market can be summarised as follows:1. The response sequence pattern; 2. Enhanced sensitivity during special periods; 3. Sustained risk identification under adversarial contexts; 4. Long-term confidence under cooperative contexts. To further enrich the analysis, theoretical discussions on transmission mechanisms were conducted. The results suggest that the China-U.S. bilateral relations index affects China's stock market via eight channels: corporate intrinsic value, market sentiment, macroeconomic performance, the RMB exchange rate, import and export trade, foreign investment, the level of technological development, and supply chain stability. Based on these findings, several policy and investment recommendations are proposed. The policy recommendations will help policymakers maintain financial market stability, while the investment recommendations will help investors safeguard their personal assets.

title: Noise Performance Study of FPGA-based and Analog Chaos Oscillator Synchronization
authors: Ruslans Babajans, Deniss Kolosovs, Darja Cirjulina, Sergejs Tjukovs, Nikolajs Bogdanovs, Dmitrijs Pikulins
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This article is devoted to studying the synchronization noise immunity of chaos oscillators implemented as analog circuits as well as the chaos oscillators implemented in the field-programmable gate array (FPGA) that exhibit similar behavior to their analog counterparts. The increasing use of analog and FPGA-based chaos oscillators for secure communication applications such as security improvement and information carriers lead to the idea of utilizing both oscillators in designing a chaos-based data transmission system. The hybrid analog-discrete implementation of chaos allows for more complex modulation schemes for wireless sensor networks. The core of such an approach is the possibility of synchronizing analog chaos with its discrete counterpart implemented on the FPGA. As data transmission is done in the wireless channel, the noise immunity of such synchronization is crucial to investigate, which is the focus of this work.

title: Investigation on high-speed zero-crossing interruption of vacuum interrupter for DC circuit breaker
authors: Xiyuan Liao, Shenli Jia, Xiaolong Huang, Saikang Shen, Chenxi Yang, Junyu Lu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In existing DC circuit breakers, the vacuum interrupter (VI) is inherited directly from AC designs, and its high-speed zero-crossing interruption capability is limited. Improving this capability is crucial for increasing the counter current oscillation frequency of DC breakers and reducing overall machine cost. To evaluate the high-speed zero-crossing interruption performance of typical commercial VIs, a swastika-type transverse-magnetic-field (TMF) based VI and a quadrupolar axial-magnetic-field (AMF) based VI were selected as test specimens. A dedicated high-speed zero-crossing test platform was constructed, capable of offering current up to 15 kA at 20 Hz, and generating rate of change of current (di/dt) at current zero crossing (CZC) of $200-500 \mathrm{~A} / \mu \mathrm{s}$. These findings offer valuable information for the design of a VI specifically optimized for DC breaking applications.

title: Surface Parameter Regulation of Electrode-Insulation and Its Effect on Vacuum Flashover
authors: Chengyan Ren, Yu Tang, Shuyu Chen, Chuansheng Zhang, Cheng Zhang, Tao Shao
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The surface flashover phenomenon in vacuum is a general problem for vacuum insulation in multiple fields. The present methods for surface withstand voltage enhancement in vacuum mainly focus on insulating materials. So it is difficult to comprehensively explain the effect mechanism of flashover characteristics by material modification. The integrated modification for surface parameters of electrode-insulation system was carried out based on the initiation and developing process of vacuum surface flashover. The insulating film was sprayed on the electrode surface by surface coating. The electric field strength distortion of cathode triple junction was improved, and the electron emission from the cathode was restrained, which enhanced vacuum surface flashover voltage of the electrode-insulation system. The surface parameter regulation by plasma deposition and electron beam irradiation was also introduced in brief. The vacuum surface flashover experiment of polymeric materials was developed in different voltage forms, and the material modification of both electrode and insulation can improve the surface flashover voltages.

title: Investigation on Vacuum Arc Characteristics and Anode Temperature of 16.7 Hz Vacuum Interruption
authors: Jun Xiao, Junxiang Liu, Lu Zhu, Yong Wang, Jie Zhang, Jun Xiong, Xiaolong Huang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Low-frequency vacuum circuit breakers face prolonged arcing durations, intensifying contact ablation. This study establishes a 3D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model under 16.7 Hz to investigate vacuum arcing at three half-wave instants ($\mathbf{3 ~ m s}, \mathbf{1 5 ~ m s}, \mathbf{2 5 ~ m s}$). Key plasma properties (ion temperature, pressure, velocity, density, current density, energy flux density.) are calculated, and anode temperature evolution is simulated using arc energy flux as a boundary condition. Results show that interruption at current zero-crossing yields more uniform and lower anode temperatures, providing insights for improving breaker performance.

title: Analysis on surface flashover along vacuum interrupter insulator surface in environment-friendly tank vacuum circuit breaker
authors: Shuai Du, Wenlong Lu, Xian Cheng, Guowei Ge, Hui Chen, Hongbo Bai
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Under the Paris Agreement and Dual Carbon Goals, environment-friendly tank multi-break vacuum circuit breakers, which utilize dry air insulation and vacuum interruption, has become the effective approach to replace SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> circuit breakers in high-voltage filed. However, the surface flashover along vacuum interrupter insulator surface in dry air is one of the obstacles for expanding the application field of vacuum circuit breakers. Thus, this paper investigates the surface flashover characteristics of vacuum interrupters, and the surface flashover mechanism along vacuum interrupter insulator surface is analyzed considering the influence of main shield. The surface flashover simulation was conducted, and the electron density distribution is obtained, which shows that the surface flashover development process of vacuum interrupter with main shield on insulator surface is accelerated. The surface flashover experiments are performed under various conditions, and the surface flashover voltage of vacuum interrupters is reduced with main shield on insulator surface, which validated the surface flashover mechanism analysis.

title: Modeling and Simulation of Vacuum Arc Deflection under Different Magnetic Fields
authors: Zhang Jie, Wang Yong, Xiong Jun, Xiao Jun, Li Yida, Huang Xiaolong, Jia Shenli
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: To investigate the influence of magnetic field conditions on the deflection behavior of vacuum arcs, a three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model considering the actual structure of the vacuum interrupter chamber was developed. The arc morphology under various combinations of transverse and longitudinal magnetic fields was simulated at a fixed current of 20 kA. The results show that the transverse magnetic field causes a significant deflection of the arc column between the electrodes, leading to a nonuniform distribution of plasma pressure and energy flux density on the anode surface. The longitudinal magnetic field induces arc rotation and suppresses deflection, maintaining the arc in a diffuse state. An appropriate combination of transverse and longitudinal magnetic fields achieves both rotational motion and stability of the arc column, resulting in a more uniform energy distribution. The study reveals the dominant role of magnetic field parameters in determining the spatial distribution of the vacuum arc and provides a numerical basis for understanding its deflection mechanism.

title: Classification of pre-strike arc shape in vacuum interrupter with different contact structures under capacitive switching
authors: Minju Xu, Yun Geng, Xiaofei Yao
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: During the capacitor bank making operations, the high frequency inrush current generated in the circuit can cause the prestrike phenomena in vacuum interrupters with the occurrence of prestrike arcs. Prestrike arcs may erode and weld the contacts. During the breaking operations, there may be restrike phenomena and even the breaking will fail. It is of great significance to do research on the arc shape under high frequency inrush current and the effect rule different magnetic field types on the prestrike arc shape under making inrush current. The research in this paper is about the classification of prestrike arc shape under high frequency inrush current on the basis of a capacitive synthetic test circuit laboratory and operations of vacuum interrupters of three different contact structures. The three contact structures include cup-type transverse magnetic field contacts, cup-type axial magnetic field contacts with grooves and cup-type axial magnetic field contacts without grooves. The prestrike arc shapes under inrush currents whose peak value can be $5 \mathrm{kA}, 10 \mathrm{kA}$ or 20 kA are measured, analyzed and further classified.

title: Investigation on High-Power Switching with Series-Connected Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Thomas Heinz, Radu-Marian Cernat, Stephan Wethekam, Stefan Giere, Sylvio Kosse, Jörg Teichmann
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Supported by climate action programs, in the recent decade, vacuum switching applications have been widely extended beyond the power distribution level to the power transmission level replacing SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> gas circuit-breakers with a CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> e neutral technology. Whereas single-break vacuum circuitbreakers are available for voltage levels of up to $245 / 252 \mathrm{kV}$, for applications at higher voltages, multi-break vacuum interrupter systems become increasingly important. In this study, we report on investigations of high-power switching with multi-break vacuum interrupter systems. During the tests, voltage and current probes have been attached to individual vacuum interrupters applied in series to enable the study of the performance of individual vacuum interrupters as well as their interaction during different high-power switching test duties. Results for high-power switching test duties are presented, analyzed, and discussed. It is concluded that vacuum switching can safely be applied to voltages of 420 kV and above as a robust technology for CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>e neutral switchgear.

title: Latent Insights: Exploring Phoneme Diversity in Natural and Synthetic Speech through Latent Representations
authors: Diptasree Debnath, Helard Becerra Martinez, Andrew Hines
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: The growing use of synthetic speech highlights the need to understand its differences from natural speech. Synthetic speech provides potential advantages in data augmentation, including privacy, security, and ethical data sourcing. However, the naturalness of synthetic speech is both a limitation and a risk, with deepfakes facilitating misinformation and fraud. These challenges underscore the need for improved methods to evaluate synthetic speech quality and deepfake detection. This research investigates whether latent representations from self-supervised models can identify and quantify differences between natural and synthetic speech regarding phoneme type, stress, manner, and roundedness. Our objective is to determine if models learn all phoneme categories equally or if certain groups present greater challenges, revealing limitations in synthetic speech. We pre-trained two wav2vec 2.0 models using matched natural and synthetic speech datasets. We mapped the learned codeword dictionaries to labeled test data with phoneme-level annotations and analysed the distribution and diversity of these latent representations across different phonemic categories. Our findings indicate a general lack of phonetic diversity in synthetic speech, with stress and manner showing the largest disparities. Vowels and diphthongs consistently exhibit reduced diversity. Identifying and quantifying differences in latent representations can be applied to enable enhanced synthetic speech generation, improve classification accuracy, and help to develop robust quality measurement metrics for synthetic speech.

title: Degradation Characterization and Fault Operation State Identification of AC Contactor Contact Systems Based on CW-SDAE and Dual-Channel Neural Networks
authors: Chaojian Xing, Shuxin Liu, Yankai Li, Zhe Li, Jing Xu, Jing Li
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Due to the AC contactor is susceptible to various factors during operation, its characteristic parameters show the characteristics of non-stationary, multi-attribute and noise, and the traditional single-channel neural network cannot fully capture the multi-dimensional information and detail changes in the data, which brings great challenges to AC contactor fault diagnosis. In order to effectively deal with these challenges, this paper proposes a degradation characterization and fault diagnosis method for AC contactor contact system combining Variational mode decomposition (VMD), feature weighting, stacked denoising Autoencoder (SDAE) feature fusion and dualchannel neural network.

title: Optimal design of electric field in three junction area of 252kV single-break vacuum circuit breaker
authors: Yu Liu, Chun’en Fang, Junping Chen, Wei Li, Jiawang Liu, Haodong Ma
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: For the 252 kV vacuum interrupter with multistage suspension shield, the electric field in the three junction regions is prone to distortion, which leads to flashover along the surface of the porcelain shell, in this paper, a cross-shielding shield structure is proposed to improve the electric field in the three junction regions inside the arc extinguisher, and the electric field distribution in the three junction regions is improved by adding a pressure equalizing ring on the outer surface of the porcelain shell of the interrupter, and the influence of different shielding structures on the electric field distribution is discussed. When the shielding method of equalizing ring is used in the suspension shielding cover, the electric field shielding effect in the three-junction area is the best, and this optimized structure can be used as a reference for the design of high-voltage vacuum interrupter.

title: Study of the effect of eccentricity on the drawn vacuum arc characteristics
authors: Junhao Niu, Ruiqi Liu, Jinhong Liu, Jiajian Zhang, Yongpeng Mo, Zongqian Shi
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum circuit breakers have many advantages such as environmentally friendly, and are now widely used in the medium-voltage power system. The vacuum arc characteristics is important to improve the interrupting performance of vacuum interrupter. Previous studies mainly focused on the vacuum arc characteristics under normal operating conditions. In order to get a better understanding of the vacuum arc, the influence of contact eccentricity on the vacuum arc characteristics was studied with drawn vacuum arc experiment. The experimental results indicated the arc voltage in the eccentric case is significantly higher than that in the noneccentric case. The cathode spot tends to constrict and the constrict time is longer. Moreover, the cathode spots in the eccentricity case rarely spread to the place where the cathode and anode contacts are not in contact. The number of cathode spots moving to the side of contact is also higher with contacts eccentricity.

title: Assisted Diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus Based on Multilayer Perceptron with Deepened Network
authors: Xiaoou Liu, Liming Xu, Yufang Sun, Shan Xiao
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
