title: Matrix-Learning Particle Swarm Optimization for Multiobjective Multiagent Pickup and Delivery With Time Windows
authors: Tong Qian, Xiao-Fang Liu, Jing Xu, Jun Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: Multiple heterogeneous agents are popular for executing pickup and delivery tasks for multiple pairs of customers. The scheduling solutions of agents are expected to complete each task within time windows, even under disturbances. Existing problem models tend to evaluate solutions through multiple simulations based on disturbances. This is time-consuming and implicit. In contrast, this article defines a robustness optimization objective based on the relationship between the agent’s arrival time and the time windows for explicit evaluation. Taking robustness together with makespan and cost, the problem is modeled as a triobjective optimization problem. To solve the problem, this article proposes matrix-learning particle swarm optimization (MLPSO) to obtain diversified and high-quality solutions for decision-makers. In MLPSO, solutions are represented as an adjacency matrix of task sequences and an allocation matrix of agents to tasks. Corresponding to the matrix-based representation, solutions are constructed by planning the task order for execution and assigning agents to tasks. A matrix-distance-based learning (MDL) strategy is developed to select neighbors in the decision space for particle update. In this way, good task segments and allocation pairs can be extracted from learning exemplars and current positions to provide stable updating directions for generating high-quality solutions. To further enhance solution convergence and diversity, a dual-space local search (DSLS) is performed on elite and sparse nondominated solutions. Experimental results on 36 instances with various scales show that the proposed MLPSO is significantly better than state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of solution quality and diversity.

title: Distributed Load Restoration for Integrated Transmission and Distribution Systems with a Robust Model Projection Method
authors: Gang Zhang, Jianqiang Yu, Feng Zhang, Hongda Liu, Lei Ding, Xin Zhang, He Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Systems
abstract: The restoration efficiency can be significantly improved through the coordination of transmission and distribution systems. However, this process is hindered by challenges related to information aggregation, model complexity, and the uncertainty introduced by the penetration of renewable generation (RG). For this purpose, this paper proposes a novel distributed load restoration model for integrated transmission and distribution systems (ITDS) using the robust model projection method (RMPM). To achieve the distributed approach, the non convex restoration model for active distribution systems (ADSs) is first reformulated as a second-order cone programming (SOCP) problem using a sequential SOCP algorithm (SSA). The resulting high-dimensional SOCP model for ADSs is then projected into a low-dimensional space via a vertex-searching method (VSM). Next, the uncertainty of distributed RG in ADSs is considered, and the robust feasible region for the ADS restoration model is determined using the column and constraint generation (CCG) algorithm. This robust, convex feasible region is then integrated into the transmission system (TS) restoration model, which is formulated as a two-stage, three-level robust model considering the RG uncertainty. By adopting this restoration scheme, optimal coordination between ADSs and TSs is achieved with limited information exchange, thereby alleviating the communication burden. Moreover, the model's solvability can be ensured due to its low-dimensional, convex structure. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method, as well as its superiority over existing approaches, is validated through numerical experiments.

title: Spatiotemporal Dynamics Modeling of Brain Activity for Human–Robot Cognitive Interaction: ADistributed-Lumped Parameter System Framework
authors: Jingting Zhang, Lianchi Zhang, Fengjun Mu, Zonghai Huang, Chaobin Zou, Rui Huang, Cong Wang, Hong Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: This article investigates the system modeling problem for the dynamical process of human brain activity in human–robot cognitive interaction (HRCI). An important novelty of the proposed approaches is to build a computational model of a human-distributed robot-lumped parameter system (HDRLPS) that describes the inherent dynamical principle of human brain activity (with spatiotemporal-varying characteristic) undergoing the interaction between the intrinsic cognitive dynamics and extrinsic robot stimuli. A deterministic learning (DL)-based spatiotemporal dynamics identification scheme is proposed to accurately identify the spatiotemporal dynamics of HDRLS and obtain the associated knowledge as a constant radial basis functional neural network (RBF NN) model. A spatiotemporal dynamics estimator is designed with this model, which can accurately evaluate and monitor the dynamical process of human brain activity in real-time HRCI by the generated dynamics-synchronized state. The effectiveness and practicability of the approaches in the dynamics identification and evaluation for the human brain activity in HRCI are validated by the thorough analysis, including the mathematical proof, the simulation study, and the brain–computer interface (BCI) experiment using publicly available datasets. Our method is compared with state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods, such as LGGNet, EEGNet, Tsception, EEG-Deformer, EEG-Transformer, and EEGViT. The results show that our method can outperform these methods with better recognition accuracy and macro-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$F1$</tex-math> </inline-formula> scores. The source code can be found at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/alonexing/source_code/tree/master</uri>

title: Unbalanced spectrum tensor based multi-band 3D spectrum cartography_supp1-3637026.pdf
authors: Bin Shen
publish: N/A
abstract: Spectrum cartography (SC) based on tensor completion has been extensively studied in recent years, with most algorithms operating in two-dimensional (2D) regions and based on balanced spectrum tensors only. To meet the growing demand for three-dimensional (3D) SC, expanding the 2D tensor completion algorithms to 3D versions is either straightforwardly applicable with an intrinsic accuracy deficiency or technically challenging to process the 3D-structured spatial data meticulously. Additionally, these algorithms suffer significant performance degradation when encountering unbalanced spectrum tensors. To address these issues, we propose multi-band 3D SC algorithms based on unbalanced spectrum tensors sporadically collected in 3D space across multiple bands. The unbalanced spectrum tensors are first transformed into balanced tensors using the 3D-based ket augmentation algorithm (3DKA), overcoming the unbalanced tensor’s incapability to leverage its low rank for estimating the entire tensor. Subsequently, tensor train matricization is employed to obtain more balanced matrices and improve tensor completion accuracy. Finally, tensor completion is accomplished using either the 3DKA-aided parallel matrix factorization (3DKA-PMF) or the Frobenius norm-based singular value decomposition-free (3DKA-SVDF) algorithm. Simulations show that the 3DKA-PMF algorithm achieves a minimum improvement of 20.06% over the conventional PMF algorithm. Notably, the 3DKA-SVDF algorithm exhibits slightly inferior performance but significantly shorter runtime—at most 58.3% of that of the 3DKA-PMF algorithm.

title: Analysis of Maritime Loitering Patterns with Discrete AIS Sequences using Transformer Model Reconstruction and Classification
authors: Tuan Manh Tao, Changha Lee, Thanh Lam Tran, Chan-Hyun Youn
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Loitering vessel behavior—characterized by prolonged, irregular, or circling maneuvers within a confined area—often indicates illicit maritime activities such as illegal fishing, covert rendezvous, or surveillance operations. Detecting such behaviors remains challenging due to the discrete, noisy, and intermittent nature of Automatic Identification System (AIS) transmissions, as well as the scarcity of labeled training data. This paper proposes a Transformer-based framework that unifies AIS trajectory reconstruction and loitering behavior detection at the segment level. The proposed approach addresses two critical limitations of prior studies: (1) the inability of lightweight filtering models to recover meaningful motion continuity under long AIS gaps, and (2) the dependence on manually engineered features (e.g., spectral entropy, heading variance) and static classifiers (e.g., Random Forest) that lack temporal context. Our proposed model, based on a cross-attention–enhanced Transformer architecture, learns vessel motion dynamics directly from raw, fragmented AIS sequences, enabling both long-gap interpolation and automatic identification of loitering segments without handcrafted heuristics. Each detected loitering segment is further classified into six interpretable categories based on learned spatiotemporal attention patterns. By leveraging self-attention and self-supervised learning, the model robustly recognizes loitering even from discrete or partially missing AIS sequences. Experiments on real-world AIS data demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves high accuracy in loitering classification and maintains stable detection performance under severe AIS sparsity.

title: A computational model of infant sensorimotor exploration in the mobile paradigm_supp1-3635281.pdf
authors: Matej Hoffmann
publish: N/A
abstract: We present a computational model of the mechanisms that may determine infant behavior in the “mobile paradigm”. This paradigm has been used in developmental psychology to explore how infants learn the sensory effects of their actions. In this paradigm, a mobile (an articulated and movable object hanging above an infant’s crib) is connected to one of the infant’s limbs, prompting the infant to preferentially move that “connected” limb. This ability to detect a “sensorimotor contingency” is considered to be a oundational cognitive ability in development. To understand how infants learn sensorimotor contingencies, we built a model that attempts to replicate infant behavior. Our model incorporates a neural network, action-outcome prediction, exploration, motor noise, preferred activity level, and biologically inspired motor control. We find that simulations with our model replicate the classic findings in the literature showing preferential movement of the connected limb. An interesting observation is that the model sometimes exhibits a burst of movement after the mobile is disconnected, shedding light on a similar occasional finding in infants. In addition to these general findings, the simulations also replicate data from two recent more detailed studies using a connection with the mobile that was either gradual or all-or-none. A series of ablation studies further shows that the inclusion of mechanisms of action-outcome prediction, exploration, motor noise, and biologically inspired motor control was essential for the model to correctly replicate infant behavior. This suggests that these components are also involved in infant sensorimotor learning.<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>

title: PMCW radar processing using mismatched filter blocks and soft fusion
authors: Çağan Önen, Hanqing Wu, Ashish Pandharipande
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Phase modulated continuous wave (PMCW) radar sensors have received recent attention for their design flexibility and high antenna scalability needed in imaging radars for automotive driving applications. A challenge in digital radars is the detection of weak, distant targets in the presence of self-interference and any strong targets in the proximity, which places a high dynamic range requirement. Conventional matched filters used for range processing in digital radars provide limited dynamic range. To address this problem, we present a mismatched filter (MMF) framework that employs parallel MMFs, each optimized for a distinct low correlation zone. Fusion approaches to combine the resulting range-Doppler maps (RDMs) are proposed to reduce computational complexity. Under typical automotive driving target scenarios, we show that the proposed MMF design outperforms matched filter designs in achieving high dynamic range conditions under self-interference and nearby strong targets. The designed soft fusion approach is also shown to provide better performance in comparison to hard fusion of the RDMs.

title: New Algorithms for Enabling High-Dimensional Aperiodic Planar Antenna Array Optimization
authors: Jacob T. Young, Vincent F. Tabib, Luke T. Young, Sawyer D. Campbell, Douglas H. Werner
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: As 6G and beyond technologies are stepping into the spotlight, phased arrays are becoming increasingly promising candidates for agile antenna systems. In particular, aperiodic phased arrays provide many desirable traits for such technologies, such as reduced mutual coupling, sidelobe suppression, and grating lobe elimination. However, the design of such systems creates a complex, high-dimensional optimization space due to the competing traits. Traditional optimization methods often fail to scale well when applied to such high-dimensional problems. To this end, three promising algorithms that claim to perform well for such complex and large problems have been identified: Trust region Bayesian optimization (TuRBO), hybrid remora crayfish optimization algorithm (HRCOA), and the zeroth-order optimization toolbox (ZOOpt) featuring a sequential randomized coordinate shrinking classification algorithm (RACOS). The study allows maximal freedom in optimization through using free-floating elements and suggested minimum spacing through weights in the cost function. Two cases of 256 and 625 element arrays, 512 and 1250 variables, respectively, are studied using these three algorithms and compared against the covariance matrix adaptation evolutionary strategy (CMA-ES). The convergence characteristics of each algorithm are analyzed, and their robustness for application in high-dimensional antenna array optimization problems is examined.

title: SFNet: A Two-Stage Source-Filter-based Neural Network for Real-Time Speech Bandwidth Extension
authors: Lingling Dai, Yuxuan Ke, Andong Li, Xiaodong Li, Chengshi Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Speech bandwidth extension (BWE) is a technique designed for generating more broadband and higher quality of speech from its bandwidth-limited version, further increasing speech naturalness and intelligibility. This paper proposes a novel two-stage architecture named SFNet for real-time BWE tasks in a neural source-filter fashion, in which the first stage extends both periodic and aperiodic excitation signals, and the second stage estimates the spectral envelope. Specifically, we introduce a sinusoidal synthesizer and a neural excitation generator to restore the excitation signal, followed by a lightweight neural magnitude filter for post-processing. By decoupling the generation process from the source-filter perspective, SFNet exhibits good interpretability and effectively reduces trainable parameters while achieving promising results. To further improve the perceptual quality of reconstructed high-frequency components, the proposed network is trained in an adversarial way. The experimental results demonstrate that incorporating prior knowledge of acoustics such as the speech production model facilitates the generation of high-quality speech and SFNet yields competitive performance for application scenarios with a target sampling rate of 48 kHz when inputting speech signals with different band limits. Besides, we derive a lite version of SFNet, namely SFNet-lite, for on-edge deployment.

title: Game Theoretic Analysis of Age of Federated Information for Participatory Data Ecosystems
authors: Alessandro Buratto, Alessio Mora, Armir Bujari, Leonardo Badia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: We investigate a scenario where multiple sources independently and voluntarily contribute status reports, which are then aggregated through a federated process. To address the challenge of partial participation in distributed systems, we introduce the age of federated information (AoFI), a novel metric that quantifies data freshness. This metric is specifically designed to bridge the gap between classical age of information, which is unsuitable for collaborative tasks, and the often impractical age of correlated information, which requires full participation. To model distributed optimization across multiple independent sources, we adopt a game-theoretic framework. In this framework, users strategically minimize their individual penalty, computed as a global-local combination of the overall AoFI on the common receiver’s side and their individual energy expenditure. We derive the worst-case Nash equilibrium of this game and compare its efficiency with the centralized optimization optimum. Our efficiency analysis reveals a critical design tradeoff for practical industrial internet of things (IIoT) deployments: while decentralized coordination is highly efficient in high-participation regimes, performance in low-participation regimes is paradoxically optimized by actively restricting the number of sources to prevent strategic inefficiencies.

title: Inverse Model of Electromagnetic Metasurfaces via Physical Mechanism and Multilevel Collaborative Optimization
authors: Wuxia Miao, Lamei Zhang, Bin Zou, Di Zhuang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents an inverse model of electromagnetic metasurfaces (IM-EM) that integrates physical mechanism with a multilevel collaborative optimization framework for accurate and physically consistent metasurface inversion. Unlike conventional regression or purely iteration methods, IM-EM embeds physical constraints by transmission-line theory into a hybrid optimization strategy that combines genetic algorithm (GA) with sequential quadratic programming (SQP). The tailored optimization function balances amplitude, spectral trend, and physical regularization, ensuring stable convergence within a physically feasible solution space. The method achieves convergence within 20 iterations, yielding normalized root mean square error (NRMSE) below 0.05 and correlation coefficients above 0.98 across broadband 1–12 GHz. Robustness in additive Gaussian noise and different structures is confirmed, which illustrates the strong generalization for complex EM designs.

title: False Alarm Reduction in DC Series Arc Detection Using Asymmetrical Gini Impurity
authors: Weiyu You, Genke Yang, Changjiang Ju, Lin Wang, Zekai Chen, Yiming Wang, Po Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The power generation and loads of photovoltaic (PV) systems are inherently intermittent, periodic, and stochastic, resulting in non-stationary dynamic fluctuations in line currents. These dynamics have overlapping spectral features with DC series arcs, which increases the likelihood of false alarms and reduces the accuracy of arc detection. To address this problem, a DC series arc diagnosis method based on asymmetrical Gini impurity is proposed to reduce false alarm rate while ensuring accuracy. First, arc fault current data under various operating conditions are collected through experiments. To mitigate the impact of periodic fluctuations and enhance the detection of transient current changes, a multi-step differential processing method is employed. Second, the time-domain and frequency-domain features of arc faults are extracted from the differential signal to construct a high-dimensional feature vector. To reduce redundant features, the clustering algorithm is applied to identify and group features demonstrating analogous classification performance, and the asymmetric Gini impurity (AGI) is introduced to analyze feature significance. Finally, a random forest model based on AGI is utilized for DC series arc diagnosis. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method not only achieves high diagnosis accuracy and effectively reduces the false alarm rate, but also completes fault detection within 60 ms.

title: Retraction Notice: Examining the Intersection of Artificial Intelligence and Biosensors in Healthcare: Complex Neurodegenerative Issues
authors: Sandeep Bisht, Dharmesh Dhabalia, Ahmed Al-Ansari, Angeline Benita, Waleed Sadeq Jaaywel, Ali Abdulkareem Mezaal, Muntather Almusawi, Ban Sefeer
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This paper delves into the transformative capability of artificial intelligence (AI) and biosensor technologies in revolutionizing healthcare, with a selected attention on dealing with complex neurodegenerative sicknesses. In recent years, the healthcare industry has witnessed a significant inflow of records from wearable sensors, medical imaging, and health records, necessitating advanced analytical methods. Leveraging AI, we advocate a framework that integrates biosensor facts to enhance diagnostic accuracy, screen ailment development in actual time, and tailor treatments to person affected person needs. Our evaluation covers the trendy advancements in device mastering algorithms for medical imaging, precision medicinal drug, and the mixing of Internet of Things (IoT) biosensors. The dialogue extends to the challenges of records-driven AI, consisting of privateness worries and the reliability of biosensor gadgets, while also exploring future possibilities in part computing and federated mastering. This paper highlights the critical position of AIpushed biosensor technology in personalizing healthcare and enhancing effects for sufferers with neurodegenerative conditions.

title: Retraction Notice: Artificial Intelligent Based Smart Electricity Billing Management System
authors: N. Bhuvaneswary, K. Muralidhar Reddy, A. Umesh Chandra Reddy, A. Lakshmi, B. Sandeep Kumar
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: These days, innovation has been created to a progressed level, so clients request frameworks with automation and tall security. The paid ahead-of-time meter is imperative in making the customer have a perception about his or her vitality utilization along with in settling the issues confronting by the utility labour in receiving the perusing of ordinary meter and killing the blunder brought about in bills issuance. These inquiries about objectives to upgrade a current routine vitality meter coordinated with paid ahead of time framework and security system. The outlined paid ahead of time meter encompasses a Raspberry pi 3B+, customary vitality meter, GSM component, current measuring device, and hand-off. The proposed model encompasses two parts: GSM innovation and overcurrent security, while GSM innovation is utilized for transmission and stock up reason; overcurrent assurance is done with a current sensor and hand-off working together.

title: Research on Cross-border Electronic Commerce Inventory Prediction Model according to C-A-XGBoost Algorithm

title: Enhancing LLM Performance in Asset Selection: Investigating the Integration Challenges of Traditional Quantitative Signals
authors: Xingyou Li
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This study examines the application of LLM to the field of financial asset selection. The primary objective of this study is to examine the impact of integrating traditional quantitative signals (predictions from OLS and XGBoost) into LLM. Initial experimental results show that LLM significantly improves the fund selection efficiency of ETFs compared to traditional quantitative models. However, when OLS and XGBoost predictions are provided as supplementary information to the LLM, its performance deteriorates and in some cases it fails to produce even valid outputs. In view of this, the present paper explores further how the integration of external information affects the prediction process of LLM. A series of experiments were conducted to investigate the impact of external information on the performance of LLM. The experiments involved the use of different external information, the adjustment of prompts and the application of different LLMs.The results demonstrate that additional information has a significant effect on the output of the LLM. In most cases, the predictive performance of LLM is significantly diminished. It is evident that providing more detailed information or advanced models does not result in a substantial improvement in the outcomes. Final conclusions: Despite LLM's strong capabilities in financial asset selection, further improvements to its predictive performance are a complex challenge. It is clear that information aggregation, prompts and the use of more advanced models alone will not suffice.

title: The Application of Blockchain Technology in International Commercial Arbitration
authors: Xin Yang, Ziqing Zhang, Yi Zhou
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Due to the cross-border enforcement benefits, arbitration is predominantly used for international commercial dispute settlements. Simultaneously, blockchain technology provides potential to transform the arbitration into something that can be more efficient and less costly, yet transparent and consistent vis-à-vis norms. In this paper, it is asserted that blockchain technology is redefining a way to enforce rules directly. Records in blockchain are legally valid, and such records support legal evidence and enforcement processes under the existing international treaties and national laws. Records on blockchain may also be employed as secure and reliable means in legal processes.

title: Data Security Analysis and Safeguarding Strategies in ADS-B Systems
authors: ZhenWen Zhang, HaoJian Liang, BeiYa Zhu, Hui Xu

title: Evaluation of Monocular Depth Detectors in Eyeglasses Segmentation Scenario
authors: Ervinas Gisleris, Artūras Serackis, Dalius Matuzevičius
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Monocular depth estimation has become increasingly significant due to its wide-ranging applications in computer vision tasks, including segmentation, object recognition, and augmented reality. This study investigates the performance of several state-of-the-art monocular depth detectors in scenarios specifically focused on eyeglass segmentation. Accurate eyeglass segmentation from monocular images is a challenging but valuable task, given its implications for face recognition, virtual try-on systems, and visual effects rendering. This paper benchmarks three prominent monocular depth detectors: UniDepthV2, Depth Anything V1, and Depth Anything V2 to assess their ability to reconstruct depth maps conducive to effective segmentation of eyeglasses. The synthetic image data set was used for performance evaluation. Segmentation effectiveness was quantitatively evaluated using the Intersection over Union (IoU) metric, providing clear insight into the accuracy and reliability of each depth detector’s output. The results indicated performance variations among the models evaluated, and Depth Anything V2 demonstrated superior capability in generating accurate depth maps suitable for eyeglass segmentation, evidenced by its consistently higher IoU scores. These findings contribute valuable benchmarks that can guide the future development of monocular depth detectors, emphasizing the importance of precision in depth reconstruction tasks that involve detailed object segmentation, such as eyeglasses. Further research is suggested to explore the applicability of these detectors in real-world imaging conditions and their integration into practical segmentation pipelines.

title: Adaptive Multidimensional E-Learning Systems
authors: Nadezhda Kunicina, Kamila Rakhimova, Jelena Caiko, Madina Mansurova
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: In recent years, adaptive learning systems have gained significant attention as a means to personalize education and enhance student outcomes. This study focuses on the development of a multidimensional adaptive e-learning system based on feedback mechanisms and data-driven decision-making. The proposed system aims to improve the learning experience by continuously analyzing student performance and adjusting educational content accordingly new data driven technologies [1].To achieve this, we employed a combination of data collection, processing, and analysis methods. The system gathers information from both primary and secondary sources. Primary data is obtained directly from students through surveys, tracking their demographic characteristics, learning preferences, and academic performance. These data points are used to build individualized learning profiles and identify deviations from expected progress [2]. The system also records user interactions, such as task completion rates, number of attempts, and error types, allowing for detailed behavioral analysis. Secondary data, including findings from authoritative research on adaptive learning, were used to refine the system’s decision-making algorithms.Machine learning techniques play a crucial role in data processing. We utilized the k-means clustering algorithm to categorize students [3] based on similar learning behaviors, such as average scores and time spent on tasks. This segmentation helps tailor instructional strategies to specific student groups [4], [5], thereby increasing engagement and effectiveness. The clustering approach was implemented using Python’s scikit-learn library, and the results were visualized to facilitate interpretation.The system was developed using modern web technologies: Flask for the backend, PostgreSQL for database management, and React.js for an interactive user interface. Data analysis was conducted in Jupyter Notebook using libraries such as pandas and scikit-learn.The practical significance of this research lies in its potential application in educational institutions to enhance teaching quality. By automating data analysis and generating personalized recommendations, the system reduces the burden on educators while improving student support. Additionally, the system can be expanded to analyze collaborative learning interactions and predict long-term academic performance.Future work will focus on integrating natural language processing (NLP) and neural network models to further refine personalization and feedback mechanisms.This study contributes to the advancement of adaptive learning technologies [6] by demonstrating a scalable and efficient approach to personalized education.

title: Experimental study on arc discharge characteristics under different excitations of spacecraft solar array
authors: Wei Dejie, Wu Jianwen, Zhu Liying, Tong Ziang, Xia Shangwen
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Arc discharge is easy to occur on the surface of space solar array under different excitations, which seriously threatens the safe operation of spacecraft. In this study, based on the ground simulation experiment system, the physical characteristics of arc discharge of solar array under LEO (Low Earth Orbit) plasma excitation and laser excitation are tested. The influence of bias voltage on discharge time, peak current and discharge energy under LEO plasma excitation is analyzed. The power density threshold of laser induced-discharge under three different working conditions is obtained, and the arc discharge plasma characteristics are measured by colorimetric temperature measurement method. This study can provide important technical support for the protection design of spacecraft solar array.

title:
Surface Withstand Voltage Performance of Al
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Ceramics Modified with Cr/Mn/Ti Coating
authors: Dandan Feng, Xueying Han, Xiaojing Wang, Zhiqiang Yu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: With the advancement of vacuum electronic devices toward higher power, higher frequency, and miniaturization, the demand for enhanced vacuum withstand voltage of ceramic components has become increasingly critical. In this study, Cr/Mn/Ti coatings were prepared on Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> ceramic surfaces using a dipping process. The microstructures, secondary electron emission yield (SEY), surface resistance, and vacuum withstand voltage of the Cr-, Cr/Mn-, and Cr/Ti-coated Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> ceramics were systematically investigated. The results demonstrate that Cr, Cr/Mn,, and Cr/Ti coatings significantly enhance the vacuum withstand voltage of Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> ceramics. Notably, in the Cr/Ti coating, Ti ions were reduced during heat treatment under wet hydrogen condition, leading to the formation of oxygen vacancies, which significantly reduced the surface resistivity of the ceramic and improved its vacuum withstand voltage performance. The optimal Cr/Ti-coated Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> ceramic achieved a maximum withstand voltage of $\mathbf{3 5} \mathbf{~ k V}$, representing a $40 \%$ increase compared to uncoated Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> ceramics.

title: Vacuum Breakdown Mechanism Classification Based on Class Weight Optimization
authors: Jie Fang, Shimin Li, Chaohai Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Breakdown mechanisms classification is essential for vacuum circuit breaker insulation improvement. This paper proposed breakdown mechanism classification based on class weight optimization of imbalanced breakdown samples. Three models with different network layers were built on PyTorch. Three different class weights were set on imbalanced breakdown samples in each model. The weight optimization performance was analyzed and compared. The results showed that in each model, when the class weight of the minority breakdown samples increased, the accuracy increase in all breakdown samples fluctuated around $1 \%(1.54 \%, 1.85 \%$, $0.61 \%$) and the accuracy increase in the minority breakdown samples ranging from $6.13 \%$ to $16.33 \%(12.25 \%, 16.33 \%$, $\mathbf{6. 1 3 \%)}$. The breakdown mechanism classification based on class weight optimization showed high improvement in imbalanced breakdown samples, especially for the minority samples, which showed promise in practical applications.

title: Evolutionary Law of Contact Condition and Prestrike Characteristics in VI Under Inrush Current Erosion
authors: Pu Chen, Xianglin Lu, Jiemin Huang, Jing Yan, Yun Geng, Hanyan Xiao, Tianxin Zhuang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs) are widely used in reactive power compensation systems for switching capacitor banks due to their high reliability, low maintenance requirements, suitability for frequent operations, and environmental friendliness. Understanding the impact of inrush current erosion on the contact surface condition is crucial for improving the performance of VCBs in capacitor bank switching and for studying the dispersion of prestrike behavior. At the same time, the prestrike characteristics of VI after inrush current erosion were obtained. This study investigates the contact surface condition during the closing process based on a method for measuring the contact surface condition under DC voltage. The contact surface condition is characterized by the field enhancement factor $\boldsymbol{\beta}$. The relationship between $\boldsymbol{\beta}$ and the prestrike gap was established. This study provides theoretical reference for the insulation design of vacuum arc chambers and the vacuum breakdown mechanism research.

title: Semiconductive Glaze for Enhancing Surface Flashover Voltage of Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Liang Zhang, Longwen Wu, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In high-voltage vacuum interrupters (VIs), surface flashover on the alumina ceramic envelope can occur at a certain applied voltage, the value of which is significantly lower than that of the breakdown voltage of the ceramic envelope itself. This phenomenon severely limits the overall performance of the associated VI. Typically, a layer of insulative glaze is applied to the ceramic envelope surface, which primarily serves to enhance the contamination resistance and thermal runaway tolerance of the ceramic envelope. However, due to its high resistivity, the dissipation of accumulated charges on the surface is restrained, thus limiting the surface flashover voltage. In this work, semiconductive glaze is proposed instead of the conventional insulative counterpart, in anticipation of charge dissipation facilitation and consequently improvement of the surface flashover voltage. The effects of glaze resistivity and environment (air and vacuum) on the surface flashover voltage were systematically investigated. Results show that for the glazed ceramic with sheet resistance of $120 \mathrm{M} \Omega /$ sq, the flashover voltage attains the peak value, with $48.4 \%$ increase in air and $66.5 \%$ increase in vacuum compared to the pristine alumina, in terms of the plate samples. The corona discharge of the alumina coated with various semiconductive glaze was investigated. With the resistivity increasing, the corona onset voltage first increases and then decreases, arriving at the highest value for the glazed ceramic with sheet resistance of $120 \mathrm{M} \Omega /$ sq, which implies that the enhancement of surface flashover voltage with semiconductive glaze should be related to the charge dissipation facilitation. This work opens a new way to improve the surface flashover performance of the high-voltage vacuum interrupters.

title: Plasma-cathode interaction in vacuum, unipolar and high-pressure arcs
authors: Helena T. C. Kaufmann
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The understanding of the plasma-electrode interaction in arc discharges is still one of the most important research topics across many industries and applications. Cathode spots appearing on electrodes of vacuum interrupters are responsible for the current and energy transfer between the arc and the cathode but also cause erosion of the electrode material. Unipolar arcs triggered in fusion devices are a source of impurities in the plasma and may lead to instabilities during operation of the device. The state-of-the-art description of the interaction of high-pressure arcs with their electrodes usually assumes local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE) in the whole calculation domain; however, deviations of the LTE occurring in the near-electrode regions are relevant for an accurate understanding of the mechanisms of arc welding and related applications. Numerical simulation has become a very important tool for the development and testing of complex theorical models describing the physics of the plasma-electrode interaction. A detailed model for the simulation of the plasma-cathode interaction is presented and its application to different conditions of arc discharges is discussed.

title: Field emission parameter extraction method for semiconductor nanowire emitters
authors: Eugeni O. Popov, Zhipeng Zhang, Haoshen Cao, Sergei V. Filippov, Anatoly G. Kolosko, Mikhail S. Nechaev, Sergey A. Sokov, Jun Chen
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The methods for extracting the main emission parameters are compared when processing the current-voltage characteristics of large-area field emitters made of semiconductor materials. The field emission data from multi-tip zinc oxide nanowire emitters coated and uncoated with thin In<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> films are investigated. The new method of numerical selection of effective field emission parameters for complex high-precision Murphy-Good equation and the Stratton equation is proposed and compared with classical methods.

title: Numerical Simulation of Copper Electrode Erosion under DC Arc Discharge using a Level-Set Method
authors: Yubin He, Chao Zhang, Wanbin Ren
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Erosion of electrodes caused by electric arc discharge extremely limits the electrical lifetime of electromechanical current switching devices. The interactions between the arc discharge and the molten pool on the electrode surface are not fully understood compared with the arc behaviors. In this work, we present a unified time-dependent numerical model to investigate the erosion behavior of a copper electrode under DC arc discharge. This model integrates arc magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) with the thermal and fluid pressure-driven erosion dynamics of the molten pool using a level-set method. Possible physical mechanisms, including phase change and recoil pressure are considered simultaneously in the model. The effect of arc-induced forces on the molten pool is investigated explicitly, and the relationship between arc dynamics and molten pool morphology is analyzed.

title: Impact of Text Origin and Real-Synthetic Data Ratio in TTS-Augmented Low-Resource ASR
authors: Dalai Mengke, Wuyerigen, Péter Mihajlik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: The development of automatic speech recognition (ASR) for low-resource languages is severely hindered by the lack of sufficient training data. While traditional data augmentation methods have long been employed to alleviate this issue, recent advances in speech synthesis technologies have shown promising potential for further boosting ASR performance. However, a key research gap remains regarding the impact of different textual sources used for speech synthesis and how synthetic and real speech should be optimally combined during ASR training. This study addresses this gap by systematically investigating (1) what mixing strategy between real and synthetic speech yields the best recognition results for low-resource languages and (2) how synthetic speech generated from different text sources affects downstream ASR performance. Our results show that a 1:1 ratio of real to synthetic speech achieves strong performance across both in-domain and out-of-domain test sets, suggesting it as an optimal training configuration for balancing data quality and quantity. Furthermore, our results also show that text translated from a high-resource language can indeed improve the ASR performance for low-resource languages to some extent. However, using native spoken utterances as the text source for TTS leads to consistently better performance in downstream ASR tasks.

title: Research on strong electromagnetic field induced discharge of high voltage solar arrays in spacecraft
authors: Yuning You, Ruhui Lian, Falun Song, Jianchao Wu, Baipeng Song, Guanjun Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: High-voltage components are single points of failure that can lead to the malfunction of an entire satellite, making their reliability crucial for the safe operation of satellites in orbit. The discharge phenomenon of high-voltage components caused by charging and discharging has become a bottleneck problem restricting the development and safe use of satellites. As an important energy component of spacecraft, space solar arrays are vulnerable to strong external electromagnetic pulse in future confrontation. When exposed to strong electromagnetic field, the space solar arrays are easily induced to produce discharge damage. To investigate the discharge damage effects induced by strong electromagnetic field coupling in space solar arrays, a three-dimensional electromagnetic model was developed based on the structural dimensions of a typical solar array configuration. By simulating the electric field coupling characteristics and patterns at the triple junction region under different excitation source parameters, we identified the most vulnerable areas prone to discharge and damage on the array surface. The resulting localized strong coupling electric fields provide essential data for subsequent analysis of discharge mechanisms in solar arrays. The research findings provide a valuable reference for the electromagnetic protection design of space solar arrays.

title: Simulation Study on Cathode Spot Initial Diffusion Considering Plasma Density Domain
authors: Runming Zhang, Lijun Wang, Xinyi Liu, Cong Wang, Tianlu Liu, Xuanrui Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Current understanding of cathode spot proliferation mechanisms remains limited. This study establishes a cathode spot diffusion model that accounts for plasma cloud density under the influence of self - inductance and external axial magnetic fields. The model explores how plasma cloud density, current magnitude, and magnetic field strength affect cathode spot proliferation and diffusion. Simulations, using the experimentally observed initial distribution of cathode spots during the early stages of the diffusion phase as the initial condition, were performed to investigate the initial diffusion process of cathode spots triggered in vacuum arcs. The simulated cathode spot distribution and diffusion velocity show good agreement with the experimental results. The simulation results unveil the impact of plasma cloud density on the location of new spot formation.

title: A BERT-Based Empirical Analysis of Medical Aesthetic Health Risks — A Study on the "Rednote" Platform
authors: Haotian Liu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics

title: Photorealistic Text-to-3D Avatar Generation with Constraints for Decoupled Geometry and Appearance
authors: Yuanyou Xu, Zongxin Yang, Yi Yang
publish: ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications
abstract: This paper presents SEEAvatar, a novel approach to generate photorealistic 3D avatars from text descriptions. Despite the fact that recent text-to-3D avatar generation methods have shown promising results, their joint representation and optimization of geometry and appearance often yield coarse results and limits practical applications. Our method introduces novel constraints for decoupled geometry and appearance. First, we constrain geometric optimization using a template avatar, which evolves periodically to enable flexible shape generation while maintaining decent human shape. The detailed geometry features in faces and hands are also preserved from static human priors. Second, we leverage diffusion models to guide a physically based rendering pipeline for texture generation, incorporating a lightness constraint on albedo textures to suppress incorrect lighting effects. Experimental results demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing methods in both global and local geometry quality as well as appearance fidelity. The high-quality meshes and textures produced by our approach are directly compatible with traditional graphics pipelines, enabling immediate practical applications. Project page at: https://yoxu515.github.io/SEEAvatar/.

title: Videos Online: The integration of contemporaneous videos to enhance online education
authors: Tobin Lopes, Kelly McKenna
publish: eLearn
abstract: None

title: 2-D Even-Mirror Fourier Method-Based Digital Predistortion With Triangular Encoding for Joint Impairment Mitigation
authors: Tianfu Cai, Shuman Kong, Mingyu Li, Yao Yao, Zhijiang Dai, Weimin Shi, Jingzhou Pang, Yi Jin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article presents a pruned 2-D even-mirror Fourier phase summation (P2DEMFS)-based digital predistortion (DPD) method for joint compensation of power amplifier (PA) distortion and in-phase/quadrature (IQ) imbalance, offering an alternative to conventional polynomial-based solutions. The proposed approach extends the 1-D even-mirror Fourier model characterized by triangular basis functions, to the 2-D complex domain through Kronecker product operations. By applying product-to-sum trigonometric identities, the nonlinear multiplicative interactions among triangular functions are reformulated into the triangular encoding process with linear phase combinations of the IQ components, which can enable the basis function generation using adders and lookup tables (LUTs). To further prune the model, the basis functions in the static and memory-cross models are first optimized, followed by sparse selection of memory and memory-cross parameters owing to the compressibility of the triangular encoding scheme. Radio frequency (RF) measurements verify that the proposed method achieves normalized mean square error (NMSE) improvements of 1.79 and 1.52 dB compared with the three-input (TI) model, for a 3.8 GHz Doherty PA at a 160 MHz bandwidth [with a running complexity of 1070 floating-point operations (FLOPs)] and a 4.7 GHz Class-A PA at a 100 MHz bandwidth (with 466 FLOPs), respectively.

title: Novel modelling and simulation of Superconducting System based on J (MATLAB)- A (COMSOL) Model
authors: Hanlin Zhu, Jun Ma, Bin Feng, Zhixuan Zhang, Nick Simpson, Phil Mellor
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The J formulation based on integral methods enables fast simulation of the operating states of superconducting tapes. However, the traditional J formulation is not applicable in scenarios where ferromagnetic materials are present in the computational domain. In the author's previous work, this limitation was addressed by introducing the J–Φ coupled model. However, the construction process of the original J–Φ model is highly complex, particularly in building the magnetic network (Φ model). Compared to finite element models, the magnetic network requires significantly more time and effort to set up. Moreover, any change to the physical model necessitates a complete reconstruction of the magnetic network, greatly limiting its flexibility and general applicability. To address this limitation, this work replaces the Φ (magnetic network) model in the original J–Φ framework with a static magnetic field computation (A model) based on COMSOL Multiphysics. The improved J(MATLAB)-A(COMSOL) model significantly reduces the modeling complexity and retains the ability to simulate when ferromagnetic materials are present.

title: PCQ-SP: A Privacy-Preserving, Cost-Aware, and Quality-Enabled Service Planning Scheme for Multi-Task Spatial Crowdsourcing
authors: Kejia Fan, Jiali Liu, Jianheng Tang, Anfeng Liu, Tian Wang, Yunhuai Liu, Mianxiong Dong, Houbing Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Spatial Crowdsourcing (SC) has become a popular paradigm for executing spatiotemporal tasks, such as urban sensing, ride-hailing, and last-mile delivery. In many of these service applications, it is common for workers to undertake multiple tasks simultaneously, as this allows them to efficiently complete tasks with a convenient route. In multi-task SC, location privacy, movement cost, and service quality constitute the three most critical factors. However, the inherent contradictions among these factors pose significant challenges in simultaneously ensuring them all, and to date, no existing work has addressed all three factors concurrently. To fill the research gap, in this paper, we propose a Privacy-Preserving, Cost-Aware, and Quality-Enabled Service Planning (PCQ-SP) scheme for multi-task SC. First, we introduce a secure distance acquisition method with additive homomorphic encryption and garbled circuits, which enables the calculation of distances between workers and tasks while preserving both their location privacy. Second, we design a Thompson Sampling-based quality evaluation method to assess each worker's service quality by balancing exploration and exploitation. Third, we propose a minimum-cost flow-driven service planning method to derive the optimized service plans, which aims for high quality and low cost while preserving location privacy. To our knowledge, our PCQ-SP scheme is the first to simultaneously consider location privacy, movement cost, and service quality in SC systems. Extensive evaluations demonstrate the effectiveness of our PCQ-SP scheme in enhancing service quality, reducing movement costs, and ensuring location privacy.

title: Experimental Study on 650-V Trench-FS CS-SJ-IGBT Based on 45-μm Multi-Epi SJ-Pillar
authors: Luping Li, Qiansheng Rao, Yuanzhen Yang, Zehong Li, Peng Chen, Haifeng Qin, Ming Li, Li Wan, Wei Li, Yuzhou Wu, Min Ren, Bo Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: A Multi-Epi-based 650-V/30-A trench field-stop carrier-storage superjunction-insulated gate bipolar transistor (CS-SJBT) is designed and experimentally presented in this work, whose cell structure, main process flow, and measured static/dynamic parameters are demonstrated. Advanced commercial trench/micropattern-trench (MPT) field-stop N-drift IGBT (NDBT) are comparatively measured to evaluate the performance improvement of SJ-pillar. Measured BV/ $\textit{V} _{\text {th}}$ / $\textit{V} _{\text {on}}$ / $\textit{J} _{\text {C}}$ of CS-SJBT are similar to commercial NDBTs; meanwhile, $\textit{t} _{\text {d,on}}$ / $\textit{t} _{\text {r}}$ / $\textit{E} _{\text {on}}$ / $\textit{t}_{\text {d,off}}$ / $\textit{t} _{\text {f}}$ / $\textit{E} _{\text {off}}$ of CS-SJBT are reduced from Trench-NDBT and approximate to MPT-NDBT under the effect of SJ-pillar. Overall, FOM of trench-SJBT is 2.8 times as trench-NDBT and 1.7 times as MPT-NDBT, respectively, which demonstrates that 45- $\mu $ m SJ-pillar in 650-V CS-IGBT can obtain no weaker $\textit{V} _{\text {on}}$ – $\textit{E} _{\text {on}}$ / $\textit{E} _{\text {off}}$ – $\textit{t} _{\text {sc}}$ tradeoff by reducing $\textit{E} _{\text {on}}$ / $\textit{E} _{\text {off}}$ than 1.6- $\mu $ m MPT by reducing $\textit{V} _{\text {on}}$ .

title: Attention-Driven Semantic Transmission Scheme for AI-Native Wireless Communications
authors: Ki-Ho Lee, Hyun-Ho Choi, Jung-Ryun Lee
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: This letter proposes an attention-driven semantic transmission scheme for AI-native wireless communications. Leveraging self-attention scores from a pretrained bidirectional encoder representations from Transformers (BERT) model, the framework prioritizes semantically important tokens in both initial transmission and retransmission stages, without task-specific supervision. Experiments on sentences from public web sources confirm consistent improvements over conventional baselines in semantic fidelity, measured by cosine similarity and BERTScore. This model-agnostic approach provides a practical solution for robust and bandwidth-efficient communication, supporting future AI-native systems that prioritize meaning preservation over exact symbol reconstruction.

title: MD-GWO: A Meta-Heuristic-Driven Quantizer for Low-Complexity MIMO Detection
authors: Hao Ning, Yuwei Zeng, Yongming Huang, You You, Chuan Zhang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Effective quantization can reduce implementation redundancy in multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems by achieving reduced bit-width while preserving system performance. However, the unified quantification (UQ) and current hybrid-precision quantization methods fail to achieve optimal bit-width reduction due to quantization coarseness or deficiencies in global search capabilities. To address these issues, this letter proposes a meta-heuristic-driven automatic quantization method for MIMO detection, named multi-population discrete grey wolf optimizer (MD-GWO). The proposed method introduces three key techniques: 1) a cosine-annealed convergence factor adaptation scheme, 2) a constrained fitness function that balances bit-width and performance loss, and 3) a multi-population cooperative optimization framework. Numerical results demonstrate the superior performance of MD-GWO when applied in the minimum mean square error (MMSE) and channel hardening-exploiting message passing (CHEMP) detectors under 16-QAM modulation. The method achieves an average fractional bit-width reduction of up to 61.63% and 32.31% in comparison to UQ and the state-of-the-art, respectively, without sacrificing system bit error rate (BER) performance.

title: High Temperature Stable 850-nm VCSELs with Improved Device Thermal Conductivity
authors: Yun Sun, Wenjing Jiang, Meng Xun, Guanzhong Pan, Bingxin Yao, Runze Zhang, Weichao Wu, Dexin Wu
publish: IEEE Photonics Technology Letters
abstract: In this work, we present the highly temperature-stable 850-nm oxide-aperture vertical cavity surface-emitting lasers with via-hole device structure. The temperature dependence of static and dynamic characteristics of devices are investigated. The output power of 7.13 mW saturating at high thermal rollover current of 12.5 mA at 29 °C and only 2.7 GHz 3-dB optical bandwidth drop over the temperature range from 29 to 85 °C is observed for the VCSEL with a ~ 4.6 μm oxide-aperture diameter. The thermal resistance of the VCSELs and the internal device temperature are analysed by using the measured optical spectra. The results clearly indicate that the high temperature stability of our devices can be attributed to both improved thermal conductivity benefited from via-hole device structure and optimized quantum well gain-to-etalon wavelength offset.

title: NeuroCognitor: Unified EEG-Language Framework for Cognitive Load Analysis via Instruction-Tuned Multi-task Learning
authors: Miao Cong
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Cognitive load estimation from electroencephalography (EEG) is pivotal to safety-critical domains where mental state monitoring is essential, such as healthcare, education, aviation, and human–computer interaction, yet prevailing deep models remain (i) task-specific and brittle across datasets, (ii) weakly aligned to language semantics, and (iii) sensitive to inter-/intra-subject variability and noise. Existing EEG foundation models also lack a pathway to instruction-tuned multi-task reasoning because semantically aligned EEG–text pairs are scarce. There is no unified framework that (a) discretises EEG into language-compatible tokens, (b) aligns their latent distributions with text without paired supervision, and (c) supports instruction-driven generalisation across heterogeneous EEG tasks. To address these challenges, we propose a unified EEG–language (NeuroCognitor) framework that (1) performs modality-aware vector-quantised tokenisation of time–frequency EEG segments, (2) enforces distributional cross-modal alignment via adversarial learning with gradient reversal, and (3) pretrains a multi-stream autoregressive prior with a stair-stepping causal mask before instruction-tuned multi-task adaptation on a causal LLM. On three diverse datasets, NeuroCognitor attains competitive performance and strong cross-task generalisability: on TUAB abnormality detection, NeuroCognitor-L achieves balanced accuracy 0.83 and AUROC 0.92; on TUEV event classification, it reaches Cohen’s κ = 0.71 and weighted F1 0.88. Ablations confirm the benefits of codebook size (∼8,192 entries), distributional alignment over fragment-level pairing, tokenization granularity, and strict temporal causal masking. Casting EEG as discrete tokens in a shared vocabulary with text enables a single instruction-following model to support abnormality screening, event detection, and sleep staging, thereby reducing per-task engineering and maintenance. Pair-free EEG–text alignment lowers annotation burden and facilitates deployment in data-sparse settings. Cross-dataset robustness and compatibility with standard 10–20/10–10 montages improve portability across sites and devices, while the tokenized interface provides auditable, integration-ready outputs for decision support and human–machine monitoring workflows.

title: Fixed-Time Consensus Tracking Control for Nonlinear Multi-Agent Systems: A Dynamic Edge/Self-Triggered Approach
authors: Mingliang Liu, Yanning Guo, Guangtao Ran, Ju H. Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This brief investigates the fixed-time consensus tracking (FTCT) problem for nonlinear multi-agent systems (MASs) via a dynamic edge-triggered (DET) control mechanism. Unlike traditional node-based event-triggered (NbEvT) methods, which synchronously update all neighbor information at triggering instants, edge-triggered designs individual conditions for each edge, enabling asynchronous updates and thereby reducing communication burden at most of the time. A novel DET-based FTCT control strategy is proposed, ensuring fixed-time convergence and Zeno-free phenomenon. Furthermore, a novel DET-based self-triggered mechanism is designed to avoid continuous monitoring and further reduce energy consumption. Simulation results are provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

title: A deep cross-domain tree species classification framework via local maximum mean discrepancy and few-shot learning
authors: Long Chen, Yifan Xie, Xinyi Han, Jing Wu, Erxue Chen, Xiaoli Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Limited sample collection in complex forest stand is a serious challenge for automatic high-precision classification of multiple tree species. Few-shot learning (FSL) have significant advantages in handling small-sample problems, especially in transferring domain-invariant feature representations/meta knowledge from the source domain (SD) to the target dataset (TD). However, domain shift, significant differences in ground categories between SD and TD, is commonly present in cross domain FSL. A novel TSDCFSL framework is proposed, which decouples domain-invariant feature transfer from domain specific feature extraction in a two-stage manner to solve the small-sample and domain shift problems simultaneously. Its core contribution is to align the global and related subdomain distributions of SD and TD via local maximum mean discrepancy in the pre-training, thereby enhancing the domain-invariant feature representation, which is beneficial to extracting domain specific features using FSL supervised contrastive learning, and data augmentation in the fine-tuning to improve the discriminability of TD samples. Five hyperspectral datasets including three SDs and two TDs are adopted to conduct thorough experiments. Taking the XiongAn as SD, the training set contains 5 samples per class on each TD, the overall accuracy (OA) of the optimal model on GaoFeng-A and GaoFeng-B is 90.74% and 90.02%, which is better than the SD of Chikusei and HanChuan. As the training set increases to 20 samples per class, the OA reaches the highest 98.51% and 95.26% on GaoFeng-A and GaoFeng-B, respectively. The outstanding results indicate that our TSDCFSL has great potential in training high-precision tree species classification models.

title: Retraction Notice: A Comprehensive Survey on the New Generation Intelligent Depression Detection Systems: Techniques, Applications and Research Challenges
authors: S Sageengrana, S Selvakumar, P Ponnaruvi
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: This paper emphasizes the diagnosable mental disorder in university students. In a recent national survey 16% of university students are depressed because of negative impact on their studies. Mentally disturbed students look extremely dull and will not be interested in their routine activities. Also, they will maintain a strategic distance from swarmed places to isolate themselves and used to continuously think something in their psyche. Students with stressed mindset commonly have the symptoms of feeling useless, self-pity, guilty, and less motivated. The main objective of this paper is to cautiously identify the upset students in the beginning stage itself in order to avoid any unpleasant consequence which might even lead to an extreme level, of committing suicide. A significant number of research papers were being published on the idea of depression detection in the beginning stage. This survey summarizes various depression detection methodologies and recognizes the best methodology that can produce better result in the future research work.

title: Influence of Internal Shields on External Dielectric of Vacuum Interrupter
authors: Karen Flügel, Dietmar Gentsch, Michael Kurrat
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: As a consequence of sulphur hexafluorides global warming potential the external insulation of switchgear is an important area of research. This paper analyses the influence of internal shields in vacuum interrupters on the external dielectric. For this purpose, vacuum interrupters with variation of metal vapour condensation shield are simulated and tested with lightning impulse voltage. The statistical withstand voltage shows a reduction of up to $\mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{\%}$ with positive polarity and an increase of up to $14 \%$ with negative polarity while the flashover path does not change. The maximum electric field strength in the triple points seems to be the most important factor for the achievable withstand voltage by variation of internal shield.

title: Research on Cathode Material Migration Characteristics of Vacuum Surafce Flashover in Vacuum Interrpter
authors: Minglu Feng, Xueyue Wang, Jingshi Wang, Haomin Li, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The vacuum surface flashover along alumina ceramic shell limits the development of vacuum interrupter towards high voltage level. The material migration during the vacuum surface flashover process in the vacuum interrupter will change the surface state and affect the surface insulation characteristics. However, the cathode material migration characteristics caused by surface flashover in vacuum interrupter are not clear. In this paper, the morphology and element distribution characteristics of cathode material migration caused by vacuum surface flashover in vacuum interrupter are studied via scanning electron microscope and energy dispersive spectrometer. The results show that the end of the cathode shield ring and the cathode triple junction are both the initial positions of the surface flashover. The cathode metal material migrates to the surface of the ceramic shell locally in a state of micron-scale flat flakes, making cathode triple junction move forward.

title: Investigation on Vacuum Insulator Surface Electrical Performance under Main Pulsed Voltage with Reversed Polarity Voltage
authors: Feng Li, Qingzhou Wu, Wenjie Yang, Le Xu, Ziping Huang, Jianjun Deng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The surface flashover usually occurs on the interface between the insulator and vacuum in pulsed power facilities and high voltage devices, the reliability of facility would be influenced by insulator performance. The pulsed voltage waveform parameters would obviously affect the insulator flashover voltage. We usually consider the influence of peak voltage, voltage duration to evaluate the insulator performance, but the reversed polarity voltage due to the low-resistance load in electrical circuit was seldom considered. We carried out the experiments to research the insulator flashover voltage and surface charge accumulation characteristics under reversed polarity voltage to investigate the influence of reversed polarity pulsed voltage. The experiment results shown that the insulator performance with reversed polarity voltage was lower than that with uni-polarity voltage. The surface charge was easily accumulated under reversed polarity voltage. The flashover process and charge characteristics with reversed polarity pulsed voltage were also discussed. We speculated that the secondary electron avalanche would be still developed with reversed polarity pulsed voltage after main voltage. The electrons movement direction would be changed under reversed polarity pulsed voltage. The cathode region and anode region would be converted due to the reversed polarity voltage. The insulator surface charge would be distributed complexly. The flashover channel was formed more easily. Based on the experimental results, we suggest that the design of design of rep-rate pulsed power facility should carefully consider the influence of the reversed polarity pulsed voltage.

title:
Effects of substrates on electrical properties of Al
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    ceramics with a mixed Cr
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    O
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    -based coating
authors: Jie Yang, Xin Chen, Chen Li, Jialong He, Ping Liu, Zhen Qin, Wei Zhao, Jie Li, Tao Wang, Pan Dong
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Alumina $\left(\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)$ ceramics with high surface insulation capability are greatly demanded in electrical vacuum devices. Plenty of effort, especially surface modification, has been tried to improve the surface hold-off voltage performance. However, the effects of ceramic substrates on the the electrical properties of the modified ceramics have been rarely studied. Herein, mixed Cr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>-based coating has been prepared on the surface of two kinds of $95 \mathrm{wt} \% \mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$ ceramics, $\mathrm{CaO}-\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}-\mathrm{SiO}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{C a O}-\mathbf{M g O}-\mathrm{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}-\mathrm{SiO}_{2}$ (abbreviated as CAS and CMAS, respectively), via dip-coating and high-temperature sintering method. Compared to the coated CAS ceramics, the CMAS-based coated specimens exhibit a slightly coarser microstructure, a marginally lower secondary electron emission coefficient, and a significantly reduced surface resistivity, resulting in a much higher hold-off voltage performance.

title: Study on the Plasma Flow Behavior in the Vacuum Arc Ion Source of Deuterium Storage Cathode
authors: Hongjian Wang, Lijun Wang, Xiangyu Wang, Jieli Chen, Xinyi Liu, Yiduo Xie
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The ion source is widely used in facilities such as vacuum arc ion thrusters, surface modification, and accelerators. In this paper, the flow and diffusion processes of plasma during the steady-state discharge of the vacuum arc barloop model ion source were mainly studied to study the mechanism of heavy and light ion acceleration. The results show that during the steady-state discharge, the plasma is greatly affected by the pressure gradient, leading to differences in angular fluxes for ions of different species. The simulation results are consistent with the experimental results, which proves that in the vacuum arc ion source of the composite deuterium storage cathode, there is a phenomenon of separation between light and heavy ions during the plasma acceleration process.

title: A Novel Halbach Array with a Dynamically Adjustable Magnetic Field for Regulating the Vacuum Arc
authors: Ziao Yuan, Siyuan Liu, Jinchao Chen, Yufei Tao, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum interrupters (VIs) are widely applied due to their excellent dielectric recovery performance, compact size, and environmental friendliness. Axial magnetic field (AMF) is crucial for controlling vacuum arcs and enhancing arc extinguishing capabilities, but traditional AMF generation methods suffer from issues such as high energy consumption or static magnetic field instability. This paper proposes an innovative solution: integrating a permeability-tunable device (iron core wrapped with coils) into the Halbach array to modulate AMF strength dynamically. When the arc exists, energizing the coil saturates the iron core, diverting magnetic flux to the central region of the interrupter to maintain the arc in a diffuse mode. Before the current zero, cutting off the coil current weakens the field to facilitate plasma dissipation. Simulation results show that the central axial magnetic field reaches 76.2 mT when energized, effectively controlling the arc, and drops to 8 mT when de-energized, promoting dielectric recovery.

title: The Mediating Effect of Illness Uncertainty on the Relationship Between Family Support and Self-Perceived Burden in Patients with Coronary Heart Disease: A K-means Clustering Approach
authors: Cuiyan Li, Wenrui Li
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: Coronary artery disease (CAD) remains one of the leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide and is often associated with prolonged recovery time and complex caregiving needs. This often leads to a higher levels of perceived self-burden (SPB) by patients, manifested as a feeling of guilt, anxiety, and depression owing to their role in need of others. A number of previous studies have revealed family support as a buffer that attenuates the perceived self-burden level by patients, however, the psychological process by which the effect arises remains unknown. This paper aims to explore the mediating effects of the illness uncertainty between the linkage of family support and the perceived self-burden level in a sample of CHD patients. In this study, standard psychometric tools and a machine learning method via K-means cluster algorithm were applied to clusterize data according to relevant patterns. It is found that illness uncertainty plays a significant mediating role in the relationship between family support and the perceived self-burden level of patients, thereby showing that the improvement of family support level correlates with a lower level of perceived psychological burden with the CHD patients, and mainly due to the decline of patients’ perceived uncertainty level on their illness. This study thus stresses the importance of emotional and informative support application, alongside the intelligent data analytics, to improve patients-centered care, relieve their perceived psychological burden levels, and ultimately, enhance their adherence to an ongoing CHD treatment plan.

title: Research on Symptoms of Social Alienation among the Elderly and Its Influencing Factors Based on Random Forest Regression
authors: Pei-Xin Lin, Wei-Yang Zhang, Yan-Ling Li, Xiao-Yi Liu, Mei-Yuan Zhou, Ting Han
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: None

title: Confidence-Importance Balanced Replay and Restricted Knowledge Distillation for Incremental Learning in Remote Sensing Semantic Segmentation
authors: Zhe Zhao, Jiali Su, Jiangbo Xi, Zhenhong Li, Okan K. Ersoy
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Incremental learning is a crucial approach for enabling models to acquire new knowledge without forgetting previously learned information, addressing the catastrophic forgetting problem. However, remote sensing semantic segmentation poses additional challenges due to the multi-scale nature of land cover categories and the vast amount of information contained in high-resolution images. Moreover, issues such as data imbalance and background shift further complicate the incremental learning process. To tackle these challenges, we propose a Confidence-Importance Balanced Replay and Restricted Knowledge Distillation (CIBR-RKD) framework for incremental semantic segmentation of remote sensing images. Specifically, high-confidence samples are selected from the model's predictions in the current learning task, ensuring that the replayed data is both accurately labeled and feature-distinctive. Additionally, importance-balanced replay is designed to mitigate data imbalance by computing importance values based on the global class distribution and per-task frequency, ensuring a more balanced selection of replay samples. Furthermore, restricted knowledge distillation preserves knowledge of old classes by restricting the distillation process to replay data without accessing new class data, effectively addressing background shift and maintaining segmentation consistency across tasks. Extensive experiments on high-resolution remote sensing datasets, Vaihingen and Potsdam, demonstrate that our proposed method significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art incremental learning approaches in remote sensing semantic segmentation.

title: An Improved Large-Signal Model for Accurate Transient Analysis of DDV-PLL under Large Grid Disturbance Conditions
