authors: Yazhao Yang, Li Zhang, Qi Liu, Diaa-Eldin A. Mansour
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: To against the variation of grid voltage amplitude, directly dividing the d-axis voltage phase-locked loop (DDV-PLL) is widely used due to its simple structure. However, conventional DDV-PLL models fail to describe the transient behavior under large grid disturbance conditions accurately. Thus, a more accurate large-signal model for DDV-PLL is proposed, which fully considers the effects of grid voltage phase, frequency, and amplitude disturbances. Then, a domain of attraction (DA) estimation method based on the time-domain Maclaurin series expansion is proposed as a quantitative criterion for transient behavior and the DDV-PLL d-axis filtering parameter design guideline. Theoretical analysis and experimental results validate the high accuracy of the proposed scheme and the effectiveness of the proposed design guideline under large grid disturbance conditions.

title: Driver State Classification: Identifying High Cognitive Load and Drowsiness Through Driver Performance and Physiology
authors: Suzan Ayas, Dengbo He, Birsen Donmez
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This study investigates the effect of high cognitive load and drowsiness on driving performance (speed, lane position, steering wheel movement) and driver physiology (cardiac activity, skin conductance) and uses these measures in classifying high cognitive load, alert, and drowsy driver states. A within subject driving simulator experiment was conducted with twenty-seven participants (14 females, mean age: 36.7). High cognitive load was induced via the n-back task (1-back, 2-back), a commonly used auditory-verbal recall task. Drowsiness was induced by monotonous driving (i.e., extended periods of low cognitive load), and was rated by trained observers. Mixed linear models were used to analyze the differences between the driver states, while machine learning models were used for multi-class classification. Compared to alert driving with no additional cognitive load, high cognitive load was associated with greater physiological arousal and speed variation and reduced speed and standard deviation of lane position (SDLP). Drowsiness was associated with lower physiological arousal and increased speed, SDLP, and standard deviation of steering wheel angle. Tree-based ensemble models (i.e., random forest, XGBoost) performed the best in classification. With simple features such as the average and SD, high cognitive load, drowsiness, and alert states were classified with up to 76% average accuracy. These measures could differentiate high cognitive load states with around 85% AUC and drowsiness with around 79% AUC within one model. These findings can help in the selection of metrics for driver monitoring systems that can differentiate driver cognitive overload and underload and inform the design of real-time intervention systems.

title: User Distribution and Throughput Model Based Antenna Tilt Optimization
authors: Hideaki Kinsho, Rie Tagyo, Akihiro Shiozu, Kazuhisa Yamagishi
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Mobile network operators are working on tuning antenna tilts to improve Quality of Service (QoS) of cellular networks and expect it to be automated since tilt-tuning is a complex and time-consuming task. To improve QoS of users in an area, operators need to consider various factors such as cell coverage, interference with neighboring cells, and cell attributes and then allocate users to cells appropriately. Conventional methods address these tilt optimization problems by using User Equipment (UE) data such as UE location and throughput of each UE to adjust tilt for each UE and improve their QoS. However, there are cases where UE data cannot be used due to user privacy, and in these cases, these conventional methods cannot be applied to optimize tilts. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a method to optimize tilts using only cell data such as the number of active UEs and cell throughput. Specifically, we estimate the user distribution and cell throughput from cell data, instead of using UE location and individual user throughput directly, and we formulate the tilt optimization problem as a black-box optimization problem that consists of the user distribution and the throughput model, and then we optimize it using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), which is a black-box optimization method. After that, we verify the effectiveness of the proposed method in both simulation environments and real environments and use statistical tests to show that the throughput obtained by the proposed method is comparable to that obtained by operators.

title: Improvement in ASM and GaN HEMT Model for RF Applications
authors: Abdullah Hannan, Abdulkadir Gurbuz, Muhammad Imran Nawaz, Haitham Darwish, Erdem Aras, Ekmel Ozbay
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Gallium nitride (GaN) high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs) are widely used in high-frequency and high-power applications because of their exceptional electrical properties. Accurate modeling of HEMT is crucial for reliable circuit design, particularly as the device dimension scales. The measurement-based models are reliable but dependent on the periphery and do not offer flexibility to the designer. These can be used to design impedance-matching networks and perform small signal simulations only of the complete MMIC design. In this work, we have proposed an improvement in advanced Spice model for HEMT (ASM-HEMT) for better <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${S}_{{22}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> performance at low frequencies by implementing an additional series RC network to address the parasitic path between the drain and the source through the buffer. Also, an electromagnetic (EM)-based modeling approach for obtaining scalable extrinsic parasitics is described. Equations are developed as a function of the number of gate fingers and gate widths from extrinsic parasitics of the gate, the drain, and the source. The proposed model was validated by fabricating six different peripheries of HEMTs. The S-parameters were verified from 400 MHz to 26.5 GHz for the quiescent bias of 28 V and 100 mA/mm. Large-signal validation for output power and power-added efficiency (PAE) was also performed on devices with the sizes of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$6\times 100~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$8\times 100~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m, and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10\times 100~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m, confirming the accuracy of the model under large-signal excitation. This work provides a comprehensive and scalable modeling solution for GaN HEMTs, suitable for advanced RF and microwave circuit design.

title: Deep Learning With Data Privacy Via Residual Perturbation
authors: Wenqi Tao, Huaming Ling, Zuoqiang Shi, Bao Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Protecting data privacy in deep learning (DL) is of crucial importance. Several celebrated privacy notions have been established and used for privacy-preserving DL. However, many existing mechanisms achieve privacy at the cost of significant utility degradation and computational overhead. In this paper, we propose a stochastic differential equation-based residual perturbation for privacy-preserving DL, which injects Gaussian noise into each residual mapping of ResNets. Theoretically, we prove that residual perturbation guarantees differential privacy (DP) and reduces the generalization gap of DL. Empirically, we show that residual perturbation is computationally efficient and outperforms the state-of-the-art differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DPSGD) in utility maintenance without sacrificing membership privacy.

title: Machine Unlearning for Source-Free Unsupervised Partial Domain Adaptation in Remote Sensing
authors: Jielong Yang, Peiran Li, Xialun Yun, Xionghu Zhong, Di Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Source-Free Unsupervised Domain Adaptation (SFUDA) enables model adaptation to unlabeled target domains without accessing source data. However, when the source domain contains classes absent in the target domain, existing methods suffer from negative transfer: knowledge of irrelevant source-only classes interferes with target class recognition, significantly degrading classification accuracy. We propose Machine Unlearning-based SFUDA (MUSFUDA), which addresses this problem by selectively unlearning source-only class knowledge from the pre-trained model rather than adding compensatory mechanisms. This machine unlearning approach allows the model to focus on shared classes, fundamentally eliminating negative transfer. Remote sensing images with large intra-class variations and high inter-class similarity cause over-unlearning of target classes when forgetting source-only classes, thus we design the Model-Disruption Based Dual-Teacher Unlearning Strategy (MDUS), which uses dual teachers to manage target class preservation and source-only class erasure through knowledge distillation. MDUS is lightweight and easily integrated into existing SFUDA frameworks. Experiments on remote sensing datasets demonstrate that combining MDUS with representative baselines consistently reduces negative transfer and improves classification performance, maintaining high efficiency, validating the effectiveness and generalizability of our approach.

title: Principle and Limit for Guaranteeing the Mean Access Delay in S-ALOHA
authors: Zhenyu Cao, Hu Jin, Swades De, Jun-Bae Seo
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: The access delay of Slotted ALOHA (S-ALOHA) is intricately coupled with backoff intervals and the number of backlogged users, while new arrivals continuously join the system according to the input rate. Consequently, guaranteeing a mean access delay constraint is a challenging problem since the system must control these interdependent variables. This work proposes an optimization framework that determines the maximum allowable input rate to satisfy the access delay constraint, where a throughput-maximizing backoff algorithm based on the extended Kalman filter (EKF) is developed. To solve the optimization problem, extensive analysis of S-ALOHA is conducted with access delay characterization. The results demonstrate that while the input rate is constrained through the proposed framework, the proposed EKF-based backoff algorithm successfully guarantees the access delay without the knowledge of the exact backlog size.

title: A Simple Unified Uncertainty-Guided Framework for Offline-to-Online Reinforcement Learning_supp1-3633997.pdf
authors: Hechang Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Offline reinforcement learning (RL) provides a promising solution to learning an agent fully relying on a data-driven paradigm. However, constrained by the limited quality of the offline dataset, its performance is often suboptimal. Therefore, it is desired to further finetune the agent via extra online interactions before deployment. Unfortunately, offline-to-online RL can be challenging due to two main challenges: constrained exploratory behavior and state–action distribution shift. In view of this, we propose a simple unified uncertainty-guided (SUNG) framework, which naturally unifies the solution to both challenges with the tool of uncertainty. Specifically, SUNG quantifies uncertainty via a variational autoencoder (VAE)-based state–action visitation density estimator. To facilitate efficient exploration, SUNG presents a practical optimistic exploration strategy to select informative actions with both high value and high uncertainty. Moreover, SUNG develops an adaptive exploitation method by applying conservative offline RL objectives to high-uncertainty samples and standard online RL objectives to low-uncertainty samples to smoothly bridge offline and online stages. SUNG achieves state-of-the-art online finetuning performance when combined with different offline RL methods, across various environments and datasets in the D4RL benchmark. Codes are made publicly available in https://github.com/guosyjlu/ACBR

title: InfoBFR: Real-World Blind Face Restoration via Information Bottleneck
authors: Nan Gao, Jia Li, Huaibo Huang, Zhi Zeng, Ran He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Previous blind face restoration (BFR) methods have primarily leveraged facial priors from pretrained GAN or diffusion models. These neural BFR models suffer from diverse neural degradations, such as prior bias, topological distortion, textural distortion, and artifact residues, which limit their real-world generalization in complex real-world scenarios. In this paper, we propose an effective framework, InfoBFR, to address neural degradation from an information-theoretic perspective, which achieves BFR boosting in diverse wild and heterogeneous scenes. Specifically, on the basis of the results from pretrained BFR models, InfoBFR considers information compression by using a manifold information bottleneck (MIB) and manifold information compensation (MIC) with efficient diffusion LoRA to conduct information optimization. InfoBFR effectively synthesizes high-fidelity faces with texture and structure boosting. Comprehensive experimental results demonstrate the high boosting performance of InfoBFR (nearly 82%) for state-of-the-art GAN-based and diffusion-based BFR methods, as it can complete BFR tasks in approximately 70 ms and has 4M trainable parameters. It is promising that InfoBFR is the first unified postprocessing restorer universally employed by diverse BFR models to overcome the limitations of neural degradation.

title: IEEE Magnetics Society Information
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics

title: 2025 Index IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Systems: Systems
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems

title: ISCAS Guest Editorial Special Issue Based on the 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
authors: Jiafeng Xie, Yuan Du, Xinmiao Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers

title: Compact, Wideband, and All-Metal Evanescent Mode Filter With Enhanced Out-of-Band Suppression
authors: Da Yi, Xiaoyi Zhang, Jia-Qi He, Ming-Chun Tang
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a compact and wideband evanescent mode filter (EMF) based on novel resonator configurations arranged in an in-line topology. The designed slotted coaxial resonators and arcuate resonator pairs enable significant miniaturization, wide working bandwidth, and extended out-of-band suppression. The configurations inherently provide cross-coupling paths to generate transmission zeros (TZs) close to the upper edge of the passband, thereby enhancing stopband attenuation. A prototype is designed, fabricated, and measured, demonstrating a size of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.45\lambda _{c} \times 0.22 \lambda _{c} \times 0.1\lambda _{c}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 33.5%, and 40-dB suppression up to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5.22f_{c}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. The proposed EMF combines the advantages of miniaturized size, large bandwidth, enhanced out-of-band suppression, and all-metal configuration.

title: Design of Liquid Metal Electromagnetic Drive Structure for Improving the Heat Dissipation Capacity of Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Yanlin Zhang, Xiaolong Hu, Hang Hu, Saikang Shen, Lihua Zhao, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum interrupters(VIs) have taken a dominant position in the field of medium and low voltage distribution due to their excellent breaking capacity and environmental friendliness. However, the heat dissipation problem of VIs has become one of the main issues limiting their rated current carrying capacity, hindering their development towards high voltage levels. At present, the traditional heat dissipation methods for VIs mainly involve shortening the current flow path and increasing the contact surface of the contacts during closing. However, these methods can lead to an increase in the size of the VIs or damage to the contact structure. Therefore, introducing new heat dissipation methods to improve the heat dissipation efficiency of VIs and enhance their rated current carrying capacity has significant practical significance. This study proposes a method of actuation based on electromagnetic effect to drive the flow of liquid metal to improve the heat dissipation effect of the static guide rod in a VIs. To explore the effectiveness of new heat dissipation methods, based on electromagnetic effect, this study established a simulation model of $\mathbf{2 5 2 k V}$ VIs with coupled electromagneticfluid multi-physical fields, and conducted research on the convective heat transfer efficiency of electromagnetic actuation liquid metal heat dissipation. In addition, the channel structure was optimized to study the influence of different channel structures on the flow velocity of liquid metal, and the reliability of the simulation results was experimentally verified. The research results have verified that the electromagnetic driven heat dissipation method of liquid metal significantly improves the flow velocity of liquid metal. These results provide valuable suggestions for the design and optimization of the heat dissipation structure of VIs.

title: Novel Contact Structure for Enhanced DC High-Frequency Vacuum Interruption
authors: Tengfei Li, Wenhui Zhang, Ke Mi, Qingming Lin, Hang Hu, Xiaolong Huang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Under high-frequency DC interruption, mechanical DC vacuum circuit breakers often face severe residual magnetism at the current zero point. This affects arc extinction and causes breaking failure. To improve magnetic field distribution in the arc region, a new contact structure is designed. Several structural optimizations are applied. These include radial slotting of the contact plate, increased slot length, reduced helical angle of the contact cup, vertical slotting at the bottom of the cu p connected to the spiral slot, different helical angles for moving and fixed contact cups, and replacement of pure copper with copper-chromium alloy. Simulation results show that during high-frequency interruption, eddy currents form axial circulation paths inside the contact. Slotting structures cause clockwise components between the contact plate and cup. A strong residual magnetic field appears in the arc region. This field dominates the longitudinal magnetic distribution. The new structure reduces magnetic field intensity at current zero and peak current. At current zero, the field intensity drops by about $19.2 \%$. The effect of residual magnetism is mitigated.

title: Comparison of 1D, Simplified 2D, and Full 2D PICMCC Models for the Post-Arc Sheath Stage in VCBs
authors: Xubin Li, Xingyu Guo, Wen Wang, Minfu Liao, Xiaoming Liu, Jiyan Zou
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The Particle-in-Cell and Monte Carlo Collision (PIC-MCC) method is widely used to simulate the post-arc sheath stage in vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs), leading to the development of various models. This study compares onedimensional (1D), simplified two-dimensional (2D), and 2D models, focusing on axial sheath expansion dynamics. The simplified 2D model developed considers a small radial section with a periodic boundary condition, while the 2 D model incorporates contact geometry and the shield with complex boundary conditions. Results show that the 1D and simplified 2D models yield similar outcomes, but the simplified 2D model enables direct visualization of electron and ion distributions, which the 1 D model lacks. A comparison between the 2 D and simplified 2D models indicates nearly identical results, with only minor radial diffusion effects, which can be ignored when focusing on axial sheath dynamics. However, the 2D model requires significantly more computation time than the simplified 2D model.

title: Investigation on the Current Distribution Characteristic of a Parallel-Connected Vacuum Circuit Breaker
authors: Xianzhao Wang, Yaxiong Tan, Yuan Liu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Parallel-connected vacuum circuit breaker is an effective method to increase the rated current. However, the unbalanced current distribution between vacuum interrupters is a big problem, which may threat the operation of circuit breaker and power system. This paper investigates the current distribution characteristic of parallel-connected circuit breaker. Meanwhile, an optimization method is proposed. By designing suitable parallel connecting rod, a good current distribution state would get without additional components. Parallel rod impedance and parallel branch current distribution state are discussed under the influence of different factors in six-parallelconnected vacuum circuit breaker. Research find decreasing the center distance of parallel rod is a bad way to achieve current balance. Increasing the length of rod can improve current unbalance effectively, but existing saturation trend. This research is a foundation for increasing the rated current research of vacuum circuit breaker.

title: Application of the PIC Method in Simulating Atom Dissipation After Current Zero in VCBs
authors: Xubin Li, Xingyu Guo, Wen Wang, Minfu Liao, Xiaoming Liu, Jiyan Zou
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Metal vapor atom dissipation after vacuum arc extinction significantly impacts dielectric recovery in vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs). Previous Particle-in-Cell (PIC) simulations focused on the post-arc sheath stage, neglecting atom dissipation. This study employs the PIC method, treating atoms as superparticles, to simulate both post-arc sheath expansion and atom dissipation. Two atom types, including superparticles and background gas, are compared for their effects on sheath dynamics. Results show that modeling atoms as background gas effectively reduces computational costs without compromising accuracy. For atom dissipation, the influence of charged particles on this process is investigated through comparative analysis, showing that their effect is minor. Besides, PIC simulation results closely match the predictions of the Rich-Farrall model, validating the effectiveness of PIC method for simulating atom dissipation. Suggestions for improving the atom dissipation simulation accuracy using the PIC method are then given.

title: Vacuum Arc Voltage Characteristics of Low-Voltage DCCB Based on Parallel Capacitor
authors: Chenxi Yang, Shenli Jia, Xiaolong Huang, Xiyuan Liao, Junyu Lu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum circuit breakers have long service life, environmental friendliness and excellent breaking performance, and have been widely used in the field of medium and high voltage, but there are not too many applications in the field of low voltage. The low-voltage DC circuit breaker based on parallel capacitor uses the vacuum circuit breaker, capacitor and lightning arrester in parallel, and uses the transfer capacitance current generated by the vacuum arc voltage applied to the parallel capacitor to realize the current transfer process, so as to complete the breaking, which has the potential advantages of high economy, short arcing time and fast breaking speed. The working principle and influencing factors of the low-voltage DC circuit breaker based on parallel capacitors are analyzed, and then the voltage characteristics of the vacuum arc in the DC circuit breaker are studied in detail, and it is found that the parallel capacitor has a certain inhibitory effect on the voltage rise rate of the vacuum arc, and the suppression effect increases with the increase of capacitance value, and the influence of the suppression effect on the transfer capacitance current of the circuit breaker is analyzed.

title: Electric Field Stress Sharing in TVCB Interrupters
authors: Jiyan Zou, Zhihui Chen, Yi Zhang, Lizhi Wang, Yongxing Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The advancement of transmission-level highvoltage vacuum circuit breakers (TVCBs) to replace SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> circuit breakers is a strategic initiative to achieve the “China’s “dual-carbon” goals (carbon-peaking & carbon-neutrality)”. The saturation effect of breakdown voltage relative to contact gap is forcing the electrode design to be scaled up geometrically, resulting in new multi-physics challenges and increasing production complexity and costs. A novel approach and its implementation rules for the electric field stress (E-stress) sharing of the TVCB interrupter unit are proposed. First, the conventional TVCB electrode system is reconfigured into a back-to-back series structure of vacuum interrupter pair, each sub-gap operates in the linear part of the breakdown-gap curve, so as to realize the longitudinal sharing of E-stress. Additionally, an auxiliary gap channel is established in parallel with the main gap to share the E-stress laterally. Combined with the design of 252 kV interrupter pair, the equivalent electrical network modeling and simulation are completed, and the prototype of interrupter pair is designed and fabricated. Using the high-voltage testing equipment for factory inspection of vacuum interrupters, voltage parameter tests have been conducted on the pair prototype to verify the effect of E-stress sharing. Results from simulation and empirical research indicate that E-stress sharing is a practical strategy for increasing the working voltage of TVCB. The interrupter pairs within the same spatial dimensions can enhance series efficiency and dynamic insulation level. Additionally, the separate welding seal and assembly of the interrupter pair can also significantly reduce the manufacturing difficulty and production costs of TVCB.

title: Phenomenological description and modeling of vacuum breakdown
authors: Camila Cró, Helena Kaufmann, Nelson Almeida, Pedro Almeida, Mário Cunha, Mikhail Benilov
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The first stage of breakdown is modeled using a phenomenological approach to the description of field emission. The field enhancement factor is calculated from the current and voltage measurements during the onset of breakdown, available in the literature. The calculation is based on the Murphy and Good formalism, combined with solving the heat-conduction equation in the electrode body. Based on the available experimental data, the field enhancement factor is not constant, but instead undergoes a gradual increase in time. It is shown that an arc can be ignited solely by means of the enhanced field emission and heating of the electrode due to the Nottingham effect. The sheath voltage does not play a role in the onset of breakdown, but it is a determining factor in whether the ignited arc can be sustained or not. The field emission center radius is found to be around 1 micrometer; field emission centers larger than this either require a field enhancement factor of order much higher than the values typically reported in the literature, or they cannot lead to sufficient heating, while smaller field emission centers produce a current that is too low compared to the experimentally measured currents in the course of a breakdown.

title: QoS-based Routing in Context-Aware Computer Networks
authors: Ints Meijers
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: With the rise of the ubiquitous dynamic, heterogeneous computer networks, Quality of Service (QoS)-based routing within context-aware networking environments has become increasingly significant. This paper explores the integration of QoS parameters such as bandwidth, latency, jitter, and reliability into routing decisions influenced by contextual information. We examine existing frameworks, propose enhancements to context-aware QoS routing strategies, and evaluate the performance impact through simulation-based analysis. Results demonstrate that incorporating context-awareness substantially improves network efficiency and service satisfaction.

title: ParkinAid: A Multimodal System for Parkinson's Diagnosis through Motor and Speech Disorder Analysis using Machine Learning and Computer Vision
authors: Liyang Han, Yu Sun
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 13th International Conference on Computer and Communications Management
abstract: Early diagnosis of Parkinson's Disease (PD) is critical for effective intervention. However, traditional diagnostic methods rely on in-person consultations with specialists and expensive clinical evaluations, making them both costly and time-consuming. Existing software-based diagnostic tools often focus on a limited subset of physiological symptoms and are not widely accessible to the public.

title: Research on the Construction of Customer Precision Marketing Strategy Driven by RFM Data
authors: Benyu Zhao, Yan Hu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In order to build an accurate customer marketing strategy, based on the combination of RFM model and customer network analysis, we analyzed how to identify different tiers of customer groups through customer behavior data. Through data cleaning, standardized processing and similarity algorithm, the similarity matrix of 4728 customers is constructed, and the customers are successfully classified into five categories by using PageRank centrality and CLV as indicators. The experimental results show that the average transaction amount of strategic core customers is $5234.8, the average PageRank value is 0.00591, and the conversion rate is 48.7%; the conversion rate of marginal fluctuation customers is only 6.1%. The model performs well in improving the accuracy of customer categorization and the response rate of marketing strategy, and has high application value.

title: Analysis and governance of willingness to use digital RMB based on BP neural network
authors: Meng Luo
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: This papper try to study the infact of willingness to use digital RMB. These factors include age, education level, technological understanding, risk perception, social awareness, and policy implementation. Adopt questionnaire survey methodology and BP neural network, we found that each examined factor significantly impacts residents' willingness to adopt digital RMB. Through this research, the goverment can take some specific aspects to effectively improve people's reception.

title: Research into the integration of blockchain technology and full life cycle auditing of PPP projects
authors: Yanru Kong, Jiawu Yue
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The public-private partnership (PPP) model meets the public's demand for infrastructure while easing the government's financial burden. To ensure the standardisation and orderly development of PPP projects, a comprehensive audit of all economic activities throughout the project life cycle is necessary, from initiation to handover. However, challenges inherent in PPP auditing, such as lengthy audit cycles, the involvement of multiple entities, and complex audit requirements, increasingly conflict with traditional auditing methods. Blockchain technology, with its unique features including tamper-proof timestamps and smart contracts, provides an effective solution to these challenges. This study analyses the necessity and feasibility of integrating blockchain technology into the full lifecycle auditing of PPP projects. Additionally, it proposes a practical integration framework to facilitate the application of blockchain in PPP auditing, aiming to improve audit efficiency and reliability.

title: Predicting Purchase Intentions from E-Commerce User Behavior: A Hybrid Modeling Approach for Data-Driven Marketing
authors: Yu Bin Hou
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Many samples of user activity were collected from an e-commerce platform, and their user characteristics, navigation patterns, and product characteristics were analyzed. As the business world is undergoing a rapid transformation, data from the behavior of consumers has become a critical resource for analyzing consumer preferences and analyzing the behavior of consumers. To address the problem of predicting purchase intent, we propose a supervised learning framework that combines a multi-class logistic regression with a decision tree classifier. The analysis reveals a prototypical funnel-shaped purchase process with significant discrepancies between interest signals and the actual buying decision. The drogue identifies the main predictors such as total visits, average session duration, and gender, while the decision tree identifies complex associations. The hybrid model can balance between interpretability and the ability to capture nonlinear feature dependencies. The empirical results show that the clickstream and carting behavior are good indicators of the purchase intention, and that the intensity and temporal dynamics of the behavior have a significant effect on the purchase intention. We use cross-validation and randomization to optimize the model to improve the model's stability and generalization. The proposed approach provides practical insights for enhancing personalized recommendation systems and optimizing data-driven advertising strategies in e-commerce settings.

title: Interpretable Machine Learning for Predicting Sleep Disorders among University Students: A SHAP-XGBoost Framework Based on Psychological Traits
authors: Yujing Wei, Bolin Xu, Binjie Cai, Hongjuan Wen
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: Sleep disorders are becoming increasingly widespread among university students, often associated with cognitive and emotional vulnerabilities. This research introduces an interpretable machine learning framework designed to detect students at elevated risk for sleep-related issues based on psychological factors. Data were collected from 1,089 participants through validated self-report instruments evaluating rumination, psychological resilience, and self-efficacy. Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost were trained, using five-fold cross-validation and tested on a 20% hold-out sample. Among these three classification algorithms, XGBoost demonstrated superior performance across multiple metrics, including accuracy, AUC, and F1 score. To enhance model transparency, SHAP values were employed to explain the influence of each predictor, identifying symptom rumination, interpersonal assistance, and reflective pondering as the most impactful variables. These findings underscore the predictive value of psychological traits in early identification of sleep disorder risks. The proposed model presents a feasible and scalable approach to campus mental health screening, especially in settings with limited clinical resources.

title: Lightweight and Computationally Efficient Direct Localization Based on Subspace Reconstruction_supp1-3636667.pdf
authors: Jianfeng Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Direct position determination (DPD) outperforms traditional two-step methods in accuracy. However, its practical application is hindered by two primary challenges: (1) the necessity to transmit raw data to the fusion center, which imposes significant demands on bandwidth and hardware resources, and (2) the absence of a closed-form solution for DPD, necessitating exhaustive search techniques and resulting in high computational complexity. To overcome these challenges, we introduce a subspace reconstruction-based DPD approach designed for an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) with a mounted array. This method requires a data transmission amount equivalent to that of two-step localization, specifically angle-of-arrival (AOA) localization while achieving performance comparable to the existing DPD method based on subspace data fusion (SDF). Furthermore, we introduce a numerically convergent solution based on majorization-minimization (MM) that guarantees convergence to a stationary point, thereby significantly reducing computational complexity and grid quantization errors (GQE) by eliminating the exhaustive search process. We validate the proposed method through computer simulations and real-world measurements conducted with a rotary-wing UAV, demonstrating its effectiveness and advantages.

title: Retraction Notice: Ensemble Classifier with Hybrid Feature Transformation for High Dimensional Data in Healthcare
authors: B Gunasundari, S Arun
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: In recent years, the growth of high-dimensional data applications has posed a significant challenge to data analytics, particularly high-dimensional data classification. To solve this problem, efficient feature selection and extraction approaches are paramount to the success of classification analyses. The dimensionality problem of high-dimensional data, which comprises a large number of variables and complicated data matrices, is a big barrier in the health care research domains. We propose an Ensemble Classifier with Hybrid Feature Transformation for handling extremely complex dimensional data. This is proven to be efficient for selecting and extracting features from a very large dataset in a classification task. The proposed approach has been applied to the classification of an unbalanced dataset of gene expression RNA-Seq data in five types of cancer. In the hybrid feature transformation approach, the original datasets are transformed in two stages. The first phase selects the highest score features from the original dataset, which are then sent to the second phase of feature transformation. As part of the second phase, features are transformed into a new set of features. Finally, a dataset with six features is applied to the ensemble classifier which achieves 99.96% accuracy by averaging the probability systems of the groups of classifiers. The findings clearly show that the proposed approach outperforms the existing methods for high-dimensional data classification.

title: Retraction Notice: Sentiment Analysis using Supervised Machine Learning
authors: Hritik Chauhan, Kanishka Singh Rathore, V Gokul Rajan
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The dataset is the IMDB dataset which comprise of the reviews of 50k movies and it is available on the Kaggle, which has 2 columns in it. The two columns in the dataset contains the reviews and the sentiment which will help us to identify the reviews is a positive review, or a negative review about the movie. Machine Learning is a modern-day concept in which the machine can be trained in the same manner as an infant baby learns the things in an environment, with the use of machine learning certain patterns are used from the data to give the machine a learning, reasoning and predicting ability. The aim is to train and build a machine learning model that will be able to predict whether a movie review provided is a positive or negative review, this is also known as binary text Classification which will be done by using Scikit-learn library, which is a very common machine learning library used in python programming language.

title: A Balanced Quadrature Coupler Featuring Switchable Coupling Paths and Tunable Power-Dividing Ratio
authors: Yuxia Zhang, Xiangguan Tan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This work proposes, for the first time, a planar multifunctional reconfigurable balanced quadrature coupler capable of both coupling-path switching and power-dividing ratio tuning. To realize these functions, a novel tunable unit replaces the conventional <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\lambda $</tex-math> </inline-formula>/4 transmission line, enabling coupling-path reconfiguration and mode-dependent power-dividing ratio control. Closed-form design equations are developed to guide the synthesis. A 2.0-GHz prototype is designed, fabricated, and measured for validation. Measurement results verify that the proposed coupler supports reconfigurable operation between forward coupling (FWCP) and backward coupling (BWCP) paths. In the FWCP mode, the power-dividing ratio can be tuned from –5.8 to 6.0dB, with the differential-mode (DM) return loss and isolation exceeding 17 and 16.7 dB, respectively. In the BWCP mode, a tuning range of –6.4 to 5.6 dB is achieved, while maintaining DM return loss and isolation greater than 16 and 16.6 dB, respectively, throughout the tuning process. The simulated and measured results show good agreement. Moreover, across all configurations, the coupler exhibits stable DM characteristics, high common-mode (CM) suppression, and low cross-mode conversion.

title: Online Learning-Based Multistep Predictive Control for PMSM Drives With a Small DC-Link Capacitor
authors: Mohammad Sadegh Orfi Yeganeh, Arman Oshnoei, Nenad Mijatovic
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Power converters with a small dc-link capacitor are designed to increase the lifetime by replacing bulky electrolytic capacitors or power factor correction circuits, presenting an attractive solution. However, when these power converters are connected to a weak grid, a resonance can occur between the line-side impedance and the dc-link capacitor. This resonance can lead to issues such as increased total harmonic distortion (THD) of the line current due to ac line harmonics. This article proposes an advanced finite control set model predictive control (FCS-MPC) methodology with a multistep ahead prediction horizon for a three-phase diode rectifier system equipped with a small dc-link capacitor, driving a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM). The FCS-MPC cost functions are designed to control the currents on both the load and dc-link sides, aiming to reduce THD and suppress harmonics in the grid-side current. To adapt the system to varying operational conditions and ensure stability under variable load, torque, or speed conditions, two brain emotional learning-based intelligent controllers (BELBIC) are employed to design the weighting factors, aiming for a significant reduction in harmonics on both the grid and load sides. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through experimental tests.

title: SIM: Accelerating Distributed DNN Training by Exploring Gradient Similarity
authors: Jin Ye, Yijun Li, Wenliang Li, Xiaojuan Lu, Qichen Su, Jiawei Huang, Jianxin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Networking
abstract: Synchronous stochastic gradient descent (SSGD) has been widely used in distributed deep learning. However, since the local gradients need to be shared among workers at every iteration, SSGD performance is significantly influenced by network bottlenecks caused by either heterogeneous environment or bandwidth contention. To solve this problem, asynchronous parallel (ASP) strategy allows each worker to update parameters independently without synchronization, while suffering from accuracy loss and convergence inefficiency. In this paper, we propose a novel similarity-based synchronization scheme called SIM, which mitigates the impact of network bottlenecks and ensures convergence efficiency. Specifically, SIM reduces the number of aggregation workers based on the gradient similarity between global and local gradients, therefore shrinking the waiting time for the stragglers. We provide a theoretical analysis of convergence efficiency and conduct large-scale testbed experiments on CIFAR-10 and SQUAD dataset. The experimental results show that SIM reduces the convergence time of four classical deep learning models by up to 40%.

title: Experimental Results for a Modular and Redundant PocketQube Platform Core: Design, Implementation, and Testing
authors: Tibor Herman, Károly Kazi, Levente Dudás
publish: IEEE Journal on Miniaturization for Air and Space Systems
abstract: PocketQubes are an emerging class of picosatellites that offer affordable access to space for educational and technology demonstration missions. However, a significant proportion of PocketQube missions fail due to design limitations and lack of subsystem redundancy. This paper presents the HUNITY platform core – a modular, redundant module designed to handle critical satellite functions and improve mission reliability. We describe the system architecture, key implementation and integration challenges, and the testing methodology. The module has undergone vibration and thermal vacuum testing using the flight model hardware, achieving Technology Readiness Level 7 (TRL 7) in accordance with standard environmental qualification procedures.

title: Neural Adaptive Finite-Time Tracking Control for Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems and Application to Robotic Manipulators
authors: Xiaoping Liu, Na Wang, Cungen Liu, Tianfei Chen, Lijun Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This article addresses a neural adaptive finite-time tracking control problem for n-th order strict feedback systems. By utilizing the backstepping design method, neural networks technology and finite-time stability theory, a tracking controller is constructed step by step. In contrast to the previous results, a (n−j)-th order differentiable piecewise function is introduced at step j so that the corresponding virtual controller is differentiable up to the order of n−j, all known terms in the original system and the derivatives of virtual controllers are treated as known and linear terms are introduced in virtual controllers and actual controllers. The proposed control strategy guarantees that all the closed-loop system variables remained bounded and the reference trajectory is well tracked in finite time. Finally, the efficacy of the proposed controller is verified by comparative experimental results for a 6-degree-of-freedom robotic manipulator. Test results confirm that the tracking controller with linear terms, virtual control derivatives and known terms has higher control accuracy.

title: Optimal Feasibility and Economic Analysis of Futuristic OilBot for Online Internal Cleaning of Power Transformers
authors: Dhruba Kumar, Wong Jee Keen Raymond, Hazlee Azil Illias, Hazlie Mokhlis, Mohamadariff Othman, Chee-Onn Chow, Joon Huang Chuah
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: The recent development of robotics has opened up the possibility of an online internal cleaning system for power transformers. This paper presents an innovative approach to the internal cleaning of power transformers during online operation. The proposed solution is an "OilBot"—a robot equipped with a multi-layered shielding capsule, a sophisticated cleaning system, and various sensors. The shielding design, which includes mu-metal, aerogel, polyimide, and silver nano-sheets, is described in detail. The cleaning system is equipped with an ultrasonic cleaner, micro-jet accumulator, centrifugal separator, coarse and fine filters, chemical and absorption layers, a thermal treatment component, and a vacuum dehydrator, all optimized for performance. The engineering drawing and compact view of the OilBot is presented. The control system of the OilBot is driven by a PID controller and model predictive control, with cleaning points determined by a mix of pre-programmed and AI-generated waypoints. The controller’s accuracy in following these waypoints is evaluated. The performance of the OilBot is tested. The long-term economic analysis, benchmark, process optimization on OilBots and chemical kinetics are also provided. This methodology provides a unique solution for maintaining transformer cleanliness and enhancing performance without disrupting operation.

title: A Unified Contrastive Learning Framework for Neurological Disease Diagnosis from VGRF and IMU Gait Data
authors: Zhangli Lu, Depeng Kong, Huiying Zhou, Shuyao Zhou, Lipeng Chen, Yong Tao, Geng Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Accurate early diagnosis of neurological diseases (NDs) can effectively facilitate intervention and help with neural healthcare. While wearable informatics like Vertical Ground Reaction Force (VGRF) and Inertial Measurement Unit(IMU) offer complementary gait insights, a key challenge is fusing these heterogeneous modalities, especially when the data are unaligned and scarce. In this study, our primary contribution lies in proposing a novel contrastive learning framework designed specifically to unify VGRF and IMU gait data for ND classification. This framework learns a shared representation space during training, enabling the final trained model to perform accurate diagnosis from data streams of either a single VGRF or a single IMU modality. We evaluated this approach on the classification of four NDs–Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and stroke-against healthy controls using two public VGRF datasets and one real-world IMU dataset. As a key result, our model achieved 98.21% accuracy in the binary task (disease vs. healthy) and 96.99% accuracy in the multi-class classification. The high performance demonstrates the potential of our method to advance neural health diagnostics, providing a robust approach for gait-based neurological assessment using heterogeneous wearable sensors.

title: Generative AI-Driven Ergonomics: A Virtual-Real Hybrid Experiment for Human Factors Engineering
authors: Peijun Ye, Yijia Li, Imre J. Rudas, Fei-Yue Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: Ergonomics or human factors engineering (HFE) mainly exploits human experiments to discover one’s cognitive and behavioral mechanisms. Such a paradigm, however, suffers from the scale of subject group and the extent to which they can stand for the whole studied population. Additionally, for real-time human–machine tasks, the experiment-modeling-validation-application path may not be applicable since the experiment cannot be flexibly conducted to update cognitive models, leading to a failure of the online system control and management. To solve the dilemma, this article proposes the generative artificial intelligence (GAI)-driven ergonomics to augment the HFE research. By introducing GAI techniques, virtual-real hybrid experiments are combined and supplement more heterogeneous samples, enhancing the input diversity for cognitive modeling and behavioral learning. The case studies of human–machine cooperative driving and aerospace robotic arm operation indicate that the innovative paradigm can effectively and efficiently augment the human experiment data. It can elevate the generality and robustness of human models.

title: On the Performance of RSMA-based Visible Light Communication Systems with Multicolor LED
authors: Manh Le-Tran, Thai-Hoc Vu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In this work, we analyze the performance of rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) in visible light communication (VLC) systems using multicolor light emitting diodes (LEDs). The system splits data of users into a common stream decoded by all users and user-specific private streams, maps these streams onto the color channels of a multicolor LED and uses successive interference cancellation (SIC) at receiver side to exploit color diversity. Closed-form expressions are derived for the key performance metrics such as outage probability, coverage probability, and ergodic sum rate under the Lambertian channel model. To concurrently mitigate multi-user interference, which arises from cross-color coupling, and optimize the power division between the common and private data streams, a joint precoding and power allocation strategy is implemented. More specifically, the resulting non-convex optimization problem is efficiently solved by an equivalent convex reformulation to efficiently obtain the optimal power allocation coefficients. Numerical results demonstrate that in the low-to-moderate common rate regime, RSMA demonstrates superior performance over conventional scheme regarding coverage probability and ergodic sum rate. This improvement further enhances the reliability and spectral efficiency for VLC systems that employ practical multicolor LED configurations.

title: Closed Form Continuous Time Neural Networks for Audio Packet Loss Concealment
authors: Yashvardhan Joshi, Miles Thorogood
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Packet Loss Concealment (PLC) for Network Music Performance (NMP) has facilitated musical interaction by taking advantage of data streaming through time-sensitive network communication. The ambiguous and dynamic audio signals in contemporary NMP music present challenges for PLC technology. To address the issue, this paper investigates using Closed-form Continuous Time Neural Networks (CfC), which transforms static neural network model and the time dimension of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN) into a continuous vector field, thus enabling the model to have dynamic and adaptive learning for nonuniformly sampled data for audio packet loss concealment in a simulated packet loss environment. To provide a comprehensive comparison, this paper presents the results of the CfC time neural network with an Auto-Regressive model and ground truth analysis.

title: Closed-form inverse dynamic modeling and identification system parameters for intra-operative mobile O-Arm
authors: Mohammad Sajad Sokout, Nima Fetanat Didar, Ashkan Ghorbanian, Mobin Salehi, Borhan Beigzadeh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Intraoperative fluoroscopic imaging systems have attracted increasing research attention in recent years. Numerous efforts have been devoted to reducing X-ray radiation exposure and enhancing fluoroscopic image quality. These efforts include improving software and hardware algorithms to precisely estimate the location of the Region of Interest (ROI), thereby reducing the amount of imaging and enhancing image quality. Furthermore, kinematic modeling of portable intraoperative imaging systems enables automatic repositioning to standard imaging location without exposing the surgeon or patient to additional radiation. Most of these studies assume that the patient remains static during imaging. However, movements such as breathing and heartbeats can make simple kinematic modeling of fluoroscopic systems insufficient for precise imaging, necessitating ROI tracking. Therefore, extracting a dynamic model of these devices can be essential. This study aims to derive an accurate dynamic model of a fluoroscopic imaging system. The model was developed using the Euler-Lagrange method, and its base parameters were extracted through an innovative approach. To validate the model, a detailed implementation was carried out in SolidWorks and Simscape based on the catalogs and datasheets of a real system. Additionally, a one-third-scale prototype model was used to validate the method for extracting the dynamic model and base parameters. For the rich input, the highest Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) corresponds to the tilt joint, with a value of 0.95 N.m. The average RMSE for the rich input is 0.3. Additionally, for the validation input, the highest RMSE value is 4.2 N.m.

title: A Compact 11-state Beam-Steering Dielectric Resonator Antenna Based on Magneto-electric Dipole
authors: Lei Li, Yuting Jia, Xiaomeng Wang, Yanting Wang, Jingchang Nan
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents a compact 11-state pattern reconfigurable dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) based on the magneto-electric (ME) dipole principle. The proposed antenna consists of a cylindrical DR in TM01δ mode excited by a central coaxial probe, operating as a vertically polarized electric monopole (E-monopole). Four identical multi-patch structures are innovatively proposed to realize four complementary magnetic monopoles (M-monopoles), which can be integrated on the DR symmetrically for compactness. By switching the PIN diodes loaded on the multi-patch structures, different M monopoles are triggered, incorporating with the shared E monopole to generate switchable ME-monopoles. By activating different ME-monopoles, up to 11 beam states can be steered, including an omnidirectional beam, two bidirectional beams, and eight directional broadside endfire beams with 45° steps. The fabricated antenna features a compact dimension of π×0.25λ 2 0 ×0.1λ0. The actual test results show that the antenna can fully cover the 5G industrial, scientific, and medical (ISM) band (5.725–5.875 GHz), and the peak gain of the antenna is 4.28 dBi. This solution meets the requirements of future wireless communication for compact beam-scanning antennas.

title: IEEE Circuits and Systems Society Information
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers

title: A DC-to-30 GHz NMOS Attenuator with Constant MOSFET On-Resistance
authors: Gaoyuan Zhao, Xiangyu Meng, Pengfei Bai, Baoyong Chi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: This paper presents a 5-bit CMOS attenuator employing an NMOS on-resistance self-locking technique to address temperature drift and process variations in millimeter-wave phased arrays. Unlike conventional polysilicon resistor networks, the proposed design features an all-NMOS attenuation network operating in the deep linear region, leveraging transistor parasitic capacitance for intrinsic phase compensation. A closed-loop feedback mechanism dynamically stabilizes on-resistance by real-time gate bias adjustment, eliminating external tuning while suppressing PVT variations across DC–30 GHz. Measurement results demonstrate 0.46 dB RMS amplitude error and 1.77° RMS phase error, with cross-chip comparisons revealing process variation tolerance: inter-chip discrepancies remain below 0.06 dB (gain) and 1.36 ° (phase). The self-locking loop achieves fully automatic impedance stabilization with 868 μW power consumption and 0.0148 mm² core area in 65 nm CMOS.

title: Conditioning and Deconditioning Effects on Surface Discharge and Dark Current of Organic Insulator Processed by Pulse Voltage Conditioning in Vacuum
authors: Yuki Hagiwara, Yasushi Yamano, Yasushi Toma
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: We report the conditioning and deconditioning effects of pulse voltage conditioning on the surface discharge of organic insulators in a vacuum. A DC high-voltage application test was carried out after pulse voltage conditioning. As a result, the withstand voltage after the conditioning was higher than that of an as-received sample. However, after the excessive flashovers for conditioning, the organic insulator was carbonized due to the energy of the flashover current, and the withstand voltage became much lower than before carbonized.

title: Augmented Transfer Learning for Synthetic Speech Detection
authors: Irina Mutica, Serban Mihalache, Gheorghe Pop, Dragos Burileanu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Speech synthesis models pose significant risks, as modern text-to-speech (TTS) and voice conversion (VC) systems can generate highly realistic synthetic voices that can be exploited for fraud, impersonation, or disinformation. In this paper, we focus on a single, highly effective transfer learning solution: a pretrained EfficientNetV2 backbone model using augmented spectrogram inputs. We employed and evaluated a suite of spectrogram augmentation techniques (adaptive resizing, SpecAugment, and Mixup), regularization methods (dropout, stochastic depth, label smoothing, selective layer freezing), as well as a progressive resizing approach and optimization and learning rate strategies. For the Fake-or-Real (FoR) dataset, a reference benchmark in the field, comprising speech samples both genuine and generated by modern TTS/VC models, our system achieves $97.2 \%$ validation accuracy and $91.1 \%$ test accuracy, surpassing prior performance by up to $19.6 \%$, reducing the generalization gap, and indicating that focused augmentation on a single pretrained network yields state-of-the-art performance with minimal complexity increase.

title: Magnetic Field Degradation in AMF Contacts Under High-Frequency Artificial Zero-Crossing
authors: Mengze Yu, Yanfeng Wang, Jinchao Chen, Siyuan Liu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The artificial current zero (ACZ) method is a promising approach for direct current interruption. It creates current zero through high-frequency reverse current injection. Under such conditions, the magnetic field characteristics induced by the contact differ significantly from those in power frequency $\mathbf{A C}$ interruption. This paper investigates the magnetic behavior of cup-shaped axial magnetic field (AMF) contacts at high frequency and during ACZ interruption using finite element analysis. The results indicate that the distribution of magnetic field concentrates around slots on contact surfaces at high frequency. Furthermore, at the current zero point, the eddy current generates a substantial residual magnetic field. The magnetic field strength during commutation process and at current zero is much higher compared to AC case. These findings demonstrate that in DC interruption applications, the magnetic field in cup-shaped contacts undergoes significant distortion, which adversely affects the interruption performance. Therefore, optimizing the contact structure for DC interruption is necessary to improve performance.

title: Energy-Efficient Autonomous Systems-Capacity Building Cross-Border Educational Initiative
authors: Nadezhda Kunicina, Darius Plonis, Rasa Bruzgiene, Anton Rassõlkin
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: The rapid integration of autonomous systems into industries such as transportation, logistics, and manufacturing necessitates engineers who are proficient in energy-efficient and secure system design. This paper presents an educational initiative under the Nordplus Higher Education Program, aimed at equipping future engineers in the Nordic and Baltic regions with advanced knowledge and practical skills in secure and energy-efficient autonomous systems. Through a collaborative network of five universities - Riga Technical University (Latvia), Kaunas University of Technology, Vilnius Gediminas Technical University (both from Lithuania), Tallinn University of Technology (Estonia), and Tampere University (Finland) - the project fosters academic activities, such as mobility, knowledge exchange, and hands-on training. The paper discusses the project's structure, learning ecosystem, curriculum development, industry collaborations, mobility programs, and anticipated outcomes, highlighting its role in bridging theoretical knowledge with real-world applications and contributing to the future workforce in autonomous system engineering.

title: The Impact of Exercise on Physical and Mental Health of Drug Addicts: A Randomized Controlled Trial Protocol
authors: Hui Xiong, Tianyong Chen
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: None

title: Co-design of B+-tree Index with Emerging Zone Interfaces for Small-sized Key-value Pairs
authors: Jinlei Hu, Bo Chen, Hong Jiang, Miaosong Zhang, Jing Hu, Jianxi Chen, Dan Feng
publish: ACM Transactions on Architecture and Code Optimization
abstract: None

title: Contrasting Daytime and Nighttime Characteristics and Driving Mechanisms of Surface Urban Heat Islands Across Local Climate Zones – Beijing as a Case Study
authors: Bowen Ju, Rongrong Li, Yong Xu, Bo Huang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The urban heat island (UHI) effect poses critical challenges to urban sustainability, yet the driving mechanisms of the daytime and nighttime surface urban heat island intensity (SUHII) remain insufficiently understood. This study employs an integrated approach combining remote sensing and GIS to produce a high-accuracy Local Climate Zone (LCZ) classification in Beijing, and utilizes satellite-derived land surface temperature data to analyze the spatial distribution of SUHII across different LCZ types. The XGBoost model, combined with SHAP values, is used to quantify the contributions of nine urban morphological parameters to SUHII and to assess the spatiotemporal differences in these impacts. The results reveal substantial variations in daytime and nighttime SUHII across different LCZs. The highest daytime SUHII occurs in LCZ 8 with an average of 8.48°C, while the highest nighttime SUHII occurs in LCZ 1 and LCZ G, with averages of 3.68°C and 3.64°C, respectively. Crucially, different parameters dominate SUHII at different times: building surface fraction and average building volume are key drivers of daytime SUHII, whereas sky view factor and distance to water play dominant roles at night. Moreover, some parameters, such as average building height and its standard deviation, exhibit contrasting effects between day and night, highlighting the necessity of separate assessments for daytime and nighttime conditions. These findings emphasize the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of SUHII driving mechanisms, underscore the value of LCZ-based classification in disentangling UHI complexity, and demonstrate the importance of quantifying daytime–nighttime differences for designing targeted urban heat mitigation strategies.

title: Mitigating the Impact of Malware Evolution on API Sequence-based Windows Malware Detectors
authors: Xingyuan Wei, Ce Li, Qiujian Lv, Ning Li, Degang Sun, Yan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: In dynamicWindows malware detection, deep learning models are extensively deployed to analyze API sequences. Methods based on API sequences play a crucial role in malware prevention. However, due to the continuous updates of APIs and the changes in API sequence calls leading to the constant evolution of malware variants, the detection capability of API sequence-based malware detection models significantly diminishes over time. We observe that the API sequences of malware samples before and after evolution usually have similar malicious semantics. Specifically, compared to the original samples, evolved malware samples often use the API sequences of the pre-evolution samples to achieve similar malicious behaviors. For instance, they access similar sensitive system resources and extend new malicious functions based on the original functionalities. In this paper, we propose a framework MME(Mitigating the impact of Malware Evolution), a framework that can enhance existing API sequence-based malware detectors and mitigate the adverse effects of malware evolution. To help detection models capture the similar semantics of these post-evolution API sequences, our framework represents API sequences using API knowledge graphs and system resource encodings and applies contrastive learning to enhance the model’s encoder. Results indicate that, compared to regular Text-CNN, our framework can significantly reduce the false positive rate by 13.10% and improve the F1-Score by 8.47% on five years of data, achieving the best experimental results. Additionally, evaluations show that our framework can save on the human costs required for model maintenance. We only need 1% of the budget per month to reduce the false positive rate by 11.16% and improve the F1-Score by 6.44%.

title: Implications of Public Charging Stations with Pay-Per-Use Service Mode on Electric Vehicle Adoption
authors: Ting Peng, Wei Yan, Yu Xiong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Although many researchers have found that EV adoption depends heavily on charging infrastructure, few studies have investigated whether and how additional public charging stations operating under the Pay-Per-Use (PPU) mode affect EV adoption. In this mode, consumers pay for usage but do not obtain ownership of the product. To fill this gap, we develop two theoretical models in which a manufacturer sells EVs and private charging piles, while an independent operator provides public charging stations via the PPU mode. We confirm that the entry of public charging stations improves EV adoption. However, contrary to conventional wisdom, our analysis reveals that, although the PPU mode reduces the optimal quantity of private charging piles, it may increase private charging piles' optimal prices and profits. Moreover, decreasing the operational costs of public charging stations benefits the manufacturer and consumers but may not always be profitable for the operator. To assess the robustness of our findings, we extend the models to two scenarios: including multiple EV manufacturers and considering consumer waiting at public charging stations. Besides confirming our main results, the extensions yield two additional findings: (i) As the number of manufacturers in the market increases, the operator's profits decrease. (ii) Consumer waiting costs, dependent on the proportion of public charging infrastructure, negatively affect the public charging and EV markets while benefiting the private charging pile market.

title: Self-Paced Learning for Images of Antinuclear Antibodies
authors: Yiyang Jiang, Guangwu Qian, Jiaxin Wu, Qi Huang, Qing Li, Yongkang Wu, Xiao-Yong Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is a critical method for diagnosing autoimmune disorders such as Lupus, Sjögren’s syndrome, and scleroderma. Despite its importance, manual ANA detection is slow, labor-intensive, and demands years of training. ANA detection is complicated by over 100 coexisting antibody types, resulting in vast fluorescent pattern combinations. Although machine learning and deep learning have enabled automation, ANA detection in real-world clinical settings presents unique challenges as it involves multi-instance, multi-label (MIML) learning. In this paper, a novel framework for ANA detection is proposed that handles the complexities of MIML tasks using unaltered microscope images without manual preprocessing. Inspired by human labeling logic, it identifies consistent ANA sub-regions and assigns aggregated labels accordingly. These steps are implemented using three task-specific components: an instance sampler, a probabilistic pseudo-label dispatcher, and self-paced weight learning rate coefficients. The instance sampler suppresses low-confidence instances by modeling pattern confidence, while the dispatcher adaptively assigns labels based on instance distinguishability. Self-paced learning adjusts training according to empirical label observations. Our framework overcomes limitations of traditional MIML methods and supports end-to-end optimization. Extensive experiments on one ANA dataset and three public medical MIML benchmarks demonstrate the superiority of our framework. On the ANA dataset, our model achieves up to +7.0% F1-Macro and +12.6% mAP gains over the best prior method, setting new state-of-the-art results. It also ranks top-2 across all key metrics on public datasets, reducing Hamming loss and one-error by up to 18.2% and 26.9%, respectively. The source code can be accessed at https://github.com/fletcherjiang/ANA-SelfPacedLearning.

title: VDSV: Client Selection in Federated Learning Based on Value Density and Secondary Verification
authors: Weichao Ding, Zhou Zhou, Qi Min, Fei Luo, Wenbo Dong, Hengrun Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Client selection has been widely considered in Federated Learning (FL) to reduce communication overhead while ensuring proper convergence performance. Due to data heterogeneity in FL, a representative subset of participants should take into account both intra-and inter-client diversity. While existing works usually emphasize on one of them, this paper proposes a VDSV (client selection based on Value Density and Secondary Verification) framework, which optimizes the client selection strategy from both sides. Therein, intra-and inter-client diversity are respectively measured based on a designed client data score as well as gradient distance and direction. Afterwards, a client selection model is established based on a proposed metric, called client value density. Besides, a secondary validation method is developed to dynamically tweak the current client selection and model aggregation strategies. The general idea of the above design is based on the theoretical convergence analysis and the observation that the client contribution to the global model can get changed throughout the learning process. The experimental results demonstrate that VDSV can achieve higher convergence rates and ensure comparable model performance. In specific, our method can reduce the communication rounds by an average of 37.88%, which saves noticeable communication overhead.

title: Writing and Designing Manuals and Warnings, 5th Edition: Patricia A. Robinson: [Book Review]
authors: Marcia Shannon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Professional Communication

title: DCLA: Deep Cooperative Learning for Advancing Automated Annotation of Electronic Medical Records in Cerebral Palsy
authors: Meirong Xiao, Qiaofang Pang, Xiyuan Yang, Yuxia Chen, Xiaoying Wu, Min Zhong, Nong Xiao, Wensheng Hou
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Automated annotation of electronic medical records for patients with cerebral palsy (CP) is crucial for downstream clinical applications. However, most existing methods lack mechanisms to verify model predictions before their acceptance and suffer from labeled data scarcity. To address this challenge, we propose a Deep Cooperative Learning for Automated Annotation (DCLA) framework. DCLA integrates named entity recognition (NER) and relation extraction (RE) models that employ the multi-head attention mechanism and the global pointer to handle complex entities and relations. Building on this foundation, a cooperative learning (CL) mechanism is introduced to evaluate prediction quality through score matrices for sample ranking and selection. Low-quality predictions are verified by annotators, while high-quality predictions are accepted automatically, enabling iterative retraining with cooperatively labeled data. Experiments on a CP-specific corpus demonstrate that DCLA's NER and RE models outperform state-of-the-art methods, while the CL mechanism enhances proofreading efficiency. Overall, DCLA enhances proofreading efficiency, mitigates data scarcity, and supports continuous model refinement.

title: Reachable-Set-based Trajectory Sampling for Local Planning of Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Yongjae Lim, Youngmin Yoon, Jeonghyun Byun, Sangyoon Kim, H. Jin Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Local planning is an essential module for Autonomous Driving Systems (ADS), in order for a vehicle to safely reach its destination by adapting to rapidly changing road conditions. Although some simple heuristic approaches may satisfy the real-time requirements of the local planning module, they tend to struggle in complex and dynamic scenarios. While a variety of approaches—including reachability-based, optimization-based, sampling-based, and learning-based methods—are capable of handling more complex scenarios in simulation, their practical effectiveness remains uncertain due to long computation time or limited experimental validation. In this paper, we propose an efficient and adaptable sampling-based local trajectory planning method to handle diverse scenarios while ensuring computational efficiency and robust performance in real-world environments. The proposed method leverages the Lateral Recursive Feasible Set (LRFS) to define the control input range based on road boundary constraints, ensuring sampled trajectories within the boundary. To further enhance trajectory sampling efficiency, we introduce a truncated normal distribution for control input sampling, allowing trajectories to remain within safe regions. The effectiveness of our method, LRFS-MPPI, is demonstrated through comparisons with existing sampling-based methods in terms of execution time, sampling efficiency, the quality of the determined trajectory in simulation, and validation through hardware experiments. The results show that LRFS-MPPI efficiently generates collision-free trajectories suitable for real-time autonomous driving.

title: Secure Coding Scheme for the Gaussian Broadcast Wiretap Channel With Common Message and Partial Feedback
authors: Hua He, Changsong Ma, Haoheng Yuan
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: In the literature, it has already been shown that a feedback control based coding scheme enhances the secrecy capacity of the Gaussian broadcast wiretap channel (GBC-WTC) with common message, and it performs better than the conventional random key based feedback scheme. However, note that the previously proposed scheme is based on the assumption that both the two receivers can send their received signals back to the transmitter via two feedback channels, which may not be available when a certain feedback channel fails to work. In this paper, we study the GBC-WTC with common message and partial feedback, where only one legitimate receiver can send his received signal back to the sender via a perfect feedback channel.
