title: GRACE-FL: Green Resource-Aware Communication-Efficient Federated Learning_supp1-3636489.pdf
authors: Dipanwita Thakur
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across distributed clients while preserving data privacy, but its deployment on resource-constrained devices is hindered by high communication overhead, inefficient energy usage, and poor convergence under non-IID data distributions. To address these challenges, we propose GRACE-FL: a Green Resource-Aware Communication-Efficient Federated Learning framework that explicitly incorporates device energy capacity into training. Each client adapts its learning rate, number of local epochs, and gradient quantization bit-width based on its available energy, allowing high-capacity devices to sustain more intensive training while low-capacity devices operate with lighter configurations. A novel energy-weighted aggregation strategy ensures that clients with greater energy resources contribute more significantly to the global model while maintaining fairness. Theoretically, we show that GRACE-FL achieves an unbiased gradient estimate and guarantees convergence at a rate of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$O ( 1 / \sqrt{T} )$</tex-math></inline-formula> under standard non-convex assumptions, even in the presence of quantization noise. Extensive experiments demonstrate that GRACE-FL consistently outperforms baseline methods, achieving 20–30& energy savings and up to 28& lower communication costs while preserving competitive or superior accuracy under both IID and non-IID settings. Finally, on-device validation with five Raspberry Pi 4B clients and fine-grained energy profiling confirms these gains in practice with SimpleCNN and ResNet-18, GRACE-FL delivers faster convergence, improved fairness, and substantial energy efficiency, paving the way for sustainable and practical FL in real-world edge deployments.

title: A Generative Graph Augmentation Neural Network for Traffic Risk Prediction on Online Crowd Queries
authors: Mengmeng Chang, Zhiming Ding, Zhi Cai, Zilin Zhao, Yafei Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: In the existing traffic prediction scenarios, the lack of accompanying event data, noise interference and insufficient supervised signals seriously restrict the effect of actual traffic prediction. Meanwhile, currently prevalent graph neural networks often struggle to capture effective semantic structures when dealing with learning tasks involving diverse specific events, consequently exhibiting limited generalization and transfer capabilities. This study focuses on crowd gathering events in transportation scenarios and conducts quantitative analysis of their potential risks to traffic network. Relying on the massive online crowd query data produced in Location Based Services (LBS), we propose a generative strategy for node and edge augmentation based on event-traffic interactions, which seeks to generate richer supervised signals. Furthermore, in response to the generative graph structure derived from event chains that fail to match the contextual semantic information, we utilize comparative learning for self-supervised training as the auxiliary proxy task of time series prediction. Experiments on the benchmark datasets of real road networks show that the proposed method is effective in identifying the traffic risk of road segments, especially when the breakdown probability is greater than 50%.

title: M-Ring: A Lightweight Ring for Gesture Interaction and User Authentication with Multimodal Fusion
authors: Shilin Chen, Yuqi Cheng, Yuling Tan, Chaonan Tang, Qian Zheng, Yongpan Zou, Victor C. M. Leung, Kaishun Wu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In extended reality (XR) virtual interaction environments, both flexible user interaction and reliable authentication are essential. However, current wearable systems relying on single-sensor data suffer from insufficient data dimensionality, often failing to simultaneously achieve fine-grained gesture recognition and continuous authentication. Multi-sensor systems, while more capable, tend to be bulky, comfort-compromising, and computationally demanding for edge deployment. Furthermore, inefficient parallel processing and the decoupled pipeline for gesture and authentication tasks degrade computational efficiency, ultimately hindering practical adoption. To overcome these limitations, we propose M-Ring, a lightweight ring-based system equipped with a compact, optimized sensor layout that synchronously captures impedance and IMU signals. By fusing complementary physiological and behavioral cues, M-Ring enables accurate hand-state perception. We design an adaptive-scale convolutional network with a parameter-separated and progressively routed architecture (PLE), which effectively captures intrinsic correlations within multimodal data and enhances synergy between gesture recognition and user authentication, all while minimizing computational overhead. For fine-grained authentication, we propose a dual-factor framework that integrates Siamese networks with contrastive learning to enhance inter-user discriminability. By jointly modeling physiological activations and kinematic patterns, our approach enables both seamless gesture-based interaction and non-intrusive continuous authentication. Experiments demonstrate that M-Ring achieves 97.8% gesture recognition accuracy and 97.5% identity authentication accuracy under complex conditions, while maintaining low enrollment cost, power efficiency, low latency, and strong edge deployment capability.

title: Bridging Emotion and Technology: Customer Involvement and Acceptance of Robo Advisory Services
authors: Aruna Polisetty, Sowmya G, Debarun Chakraborty, Appolloni Andrea
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: Enabled by advancements in AI, robo-advisors are transforming financial services by automating investment and wealth management. However, customer acceptance of robo advisory remains challenging, as financial services are perceived as more complex and personal than non-financial tasks typically managed by robots. This study examines the impact of trust, perceived value, and customer-robot compatibility on the acceptance of robo-services in banking. Using a mixed-method approach, we surveyed 550 respondents and conducted in depth interviews with six participants to capture lived experiences with robo-advisors. The findings of narrative inquiry were used to explore various factors affecting robot service acceptance. Further these insights served as meta-inferences for developing the proposed framework and quantitative study. Our findings reveal that trust- and empathy-driven interactions have a significant impact on customer perceptions, thereby enhancing service robot acceptance. We emphasise the role of robot empathy responses and active customer involvement as critical moderators in fostering trust. Practical implications suggest that humanising robo-services can reshape banking standards by increasing customer confidence and adopting AI-driven financial solutions. This study contributes to the growing literature on human-robot interaction in financial services, highlighting strategic pathways for banks to leverage AI for enhanced customer engagement.

title: Generatrix Deflection Method for Profile Measurement of Micro-Aspherical-Cylindrical Lens Array with Steep Surfaces
authors: Xiang Liu, Peng Yao, Jimiao Xu, Shuoshuo Qu, Dongkai Chu, Xuwei Du, Xi Wang, Kailei Luo, Chuanzhen Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: High slope microstructure array has been widely used in fields such as beam shaping, three-dimensional imaging and micro-optical systems, requiring sub-micron profile accuracy and nanoscale surface roughness. However, the small size and high slope lead to measurement interference, probe slip, and low reflected light intensity. Existing profile measurement methods for micro-aspherical-cylindrical lens array (MACLA) cannot meet processing requirements. In this paper, a generatrix deflection method (GDM) was proposed to enhance the measurement accuracy of MACLA profile. By tilting the workpiece being measured, the method reduced the contact measurement slope, effectively avoiding measurement interference and probe slip. A constant scallop-height grinding method was used for binderless tungsten carbide (BWC) to product uniform surfaces and consistent structures, achieving a surface roughness of 80 nm. The principle of GDM reducing measurement slope and error were explained by slope calculation and force analysis. Additionally, a data processing technique and a standardized evaluation framework were developed for measuring MACLA profiles with different measurement systems. A comparison between the GDM method and existing measurement methods showed significant improvements in accuracy. When the generatrix deflection angle was 50°, the deviation extreme value between measurement results and the reference profile with the GDM method was 0.881 μm, with a Gaussian fitting mean of 0.27 μm and a standard deviation of 0.186 μm. Compared to the optimal results from other measurement methods, the proposed method improved accuracy by 53%, 41%, and 55%, respectively. These results demonstrate the superiority and effectiveness of the GDM method, providing valuable data for the precision evaluation and compensation machining of MACLA.

title: Retraction Notice: Leaf Health Monitoring and Disease Detection Using Image Processing
authors: M. Sakthimohan, Podaralla Ganesh Kumar Reddy, Thathannagari Narendra, Bobburi Venkatesh, Rani. G. Elizabeth
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Recognizing the confirmation of leaf spot identification through image processing is also one of the most important factors in saving plants from several diseases. Leaf disturbance testing means an examination of the visible models that appear on a plant. Farmers need good crops to survive in the nation and we see how farmers deal with their crops many diseases that can cause and farmers will face many difficulties and it requires some external energy to be used over time. Therefore, the image is used in the area of leaf disease. Acknowledging contamination includes methods such as image acquisition, prior coping, image classification, feature removal and collection. In this paper we present a systematic diagnosis of leaf diseases using imaging techniques. The presented framework is a product response to systematic identification and calculation of higher rates of plant leaf disease. The handle frame consists of four basic improvements, first the shading of the RGB image for details, at which point, the image is split, and the key pieces. are separated, eventually more rates are registered. By further observation, diseases, thought to be present in the leaf of a plant are examined. fares are calculated based on the distance traveled. The fare is deducted from the rechargeable card.

title: Development and Evaluation of a Cost-Effective Behind-the-Meter Synchronized Measurement Unit for Enhanced Grid Integration
authors: Yuru Wu, Biao Sun, Wenpeng Yu, He Yin, Wei Qiu, Yilu Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: This paper presents the development of the Inverter Based Resource Monitor (IBRM), an innovative behind-the-meter synchronized measurement unit (SMU) tailored for integration with inverter-based resources (IBRs). The IBRM distinguishes itself as a highly accurate and cost-effective SMU, offering facile deployment and connectivity to IBRs. It is equipped to conduct real-time voltage and current waveform analyses, serving as a phasor measurement unit (PMU) with exceptionally rapid synchrophasor transmission capabilities. The device incorporates a cutting-edge dual-core architecture designed to minimize sampling delays inherent to its microprocessor, thereby enhancing the precision of synchronized waveform measurements. Moreover, the IBRM is adept at recording high-fidelity waveform data, capturing nuances such as waveform distortions, high-order harmonics, and wide-band oscillations prevalent in power grids with substantial IBR presence. A prototype of the IBRM has been constructed and subjected to rigorous testing to assess its functional capabilities and measurement precision, utilizing both idealized signal generators and a real-world off-grid inverter setup as benchmarks.

title: HybridMoE: LoRA-Based LLMs Fine-Tune With Hybrid Mixture of Experts
authors: Shengchuan Lin, Yufei Ma, Sen Liu, Junhua Shi, Linbo Jin, Dehong Gao, Shanqing Yu, Qi Xuan, Xiaoyan Cai, Libin Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) of Large Language Models (LLMs) in multitask scenarios is cutting-edge research currently. This paper introduces an innovative PEFT approach, named HybridMoE, by applying the Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) network into the Mixture-of-Expert (MoE) architecture. Considering the similarity and diversity between multiple tasks, we introduce the Multi-A MoE and Multi-B MoE architectures to allow experts of MoE to share either the decomposition $A$ matrix or $B$ matrix among themselves. HybridMoE integrates the Multi-A and Multi-B architectures, and the multiple tasks automatically learn to choose either of them through a gating network. Extensive experiments show that HybridMoE outperforms MoLoRA in performance on the HuggingFace Open LLM benchmark with various open-sourced LLMs, including LLaMA-2, Baichuan2, Qwen, and Yi. By sharing the parameters, HybridMoE requires fewer trainable parameters and is more efficient. The experimental results demonstrate that HybridMoE provides a novel solution for fine-tuning LLMs, striking a balance between performance and resource allocation, and opening up possibilities for broader research directions.

title: Flood Detection in Optical Systems: A Novel Approach to Overcome Cloud Cover With DEM Data
authors: Aluizio Brito Maia, Camilo Daleles Rennó, Evlyn Márcia Leão de Moraes Novo, Ítalo Rafael Costa de Mira
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Floods are complex hydrological phenomena influenced by precipitation patterns and basin morphology. Although optical remote sensing is widely used for flood mapping, its effectiveness is often limited by cloud cover, which leads to data gaps and misclassifications. This study presents a novel method for detecting flooded areas in cloud-contaminated optical imagery by integrating hydrological and morphometric attributes derived from Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). The approach includes a customized cloud and shadow mask generated using the Rpart classifier, designed to reduce false positives while preserving surface water signals. The method employs a two-step Random Forest (RF) classification process. The first step (RF1) integrates optical imagery with DEM attributes to identify visible surface water. The second step (RF2) uses only DEM-derived features to replicate RF1 and extend flood mapping beneath cloud-covered regions. The method was validated using synthetic cloud data, achieving an Out-of-Bag Global Accuracy (GA) of 94% and a Jaccard Index of 0.94 for the RF2 replication task. In independent validation, the model showed strong performance: for randomly sampled test data, GA reached 94.06% with a Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC) of 72%; for stratified sampling, GA reached 88% with an MCC of 78%. These results highlight the model's robustness across diverse conditions. The proposed cloud-aware flood detection method provides a fast and accurate tool for post-disaster mapping, supporting emergency response efforts and enhancing flood risk management by mitigating the limitations of optical-only approaches.

title: Retraction Notice: Optimizing Guidance Management through AI for Agricultural Ground and its analysis
authors: Ramanuj Tewari, Zahraa Weaam Qasim, Nizar Abdel Amir, Ramy Riad Al-Fatlawy, Athraa Hafid, Ali Abdulkareem Mezaal
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: The paper introduces “guidance managemet system and it is a completely unique education framework that synergistically combines the guidance management systems and management system-primarily based semi-supervised analysing. Specifically, it integrates the sturdy semi-supervised gaining knowledge of method of label propagation with the effective predictive abilities of guidance management systems during various architecture sand agricultural works collectively with feed-in advance networks, convolutional guidance management systems (CNNs), and prolonged quick-term memory (LSTM) recurrent guidance management systems. This integration helps using both labelled and unlabelled facts, enhancing the model’s training overall performance and predictive ordinary overall performance. The framework employs a management system-regularised purpose that encourages similar hidden representations for neighbouring nodes, thereby improving generalization and allowing scalable training thru stochastic gradient descent. This approach is especially exceptional in scenarios wherein categorised facts is scarce, making it a robust device for large-scale and complex datasets wherein traditional techniques falter.

title: Super-Resolved Structural MRI for Detection of Mild Cognitive Impairment
authors: Ovidijus Grigas, Darius Plonis, Rytis Maskeliūnas
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging (sMRI) is a brain imaging technique that allows evaluating the brain of patients for any structural pathologies and is one of the main diagnostic tools used in Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) recognition. However, High-Resolution (HR) tomographs that can capture brain images with high spatial resolution are expensive. Therefore, Super-Resolution (SR) technique can be used to improve spatial resolution of the MRI images captured with lower resolution tomographs. State-of-the-art SR methods applied to medical images are prone to over-blurring the output images, due to focusing only on the pixel correctness aspect, but not on the perceptual quality of the generated images. We employ Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN) with advanced degradation techniques to train SR model, that produces not only sharp, but also fine details preserving images. We also empirically prove, that using SR in MCI diagnostic pipeline can improve classification performance by 1–4%.

title: Simulation Analysis of the Electric Field Characteristics of the Vacuum Interrupter Arranged in the Metal Tank
authors: Minhao An, Shixin Xiu, Shuo Li, Xingyu Lin, Jiaxin Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The development of tank vacuum circuit breaker based on vacuum breaking technology and environmentally friendly gas insulation technology is an important direction for the application of high-voltage vacuum interrupter. In this paper, the three-phase vacuum interrupter is arranged in the metal tank, the internal structure of the tank is designed, the geometric model of 126 kV tank vacuum circuit breaker is obtained, and the electric field simulation model is established to explore the electric field distribution of each component of the tank when the vacuum interrupter is in the open and closed states. The results show that for the components inside the vacuum interrupter, the components with high electric field strength are movable and fixed contacts, and the maximum values of movable and fixed contacts are $26.4 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ and 26 $\mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ under different open and closed states. For the components inside the tank, the components with high electric field strength are mainly the end of the shield of the movable and fixed end conductors. The maximum field strength on the shield of the movable end conductor reaches a maximum value of $25.2 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ when the voltage is applied to the movable end of the edge phase vacuum interrupter in the open state. For the shield of the fixed end conductors, the maximum field strength is $24.2 \mathrm{kV} / \mathrm{mm}$ when the voltage is applied to the fixed end of the edge phase interrupter in the open state.

title: The Influence of the Grading Capacitors and Asynchronism of the Double-Break Vacuum Circuit Breaker on the No-Load Closing of a Transformer
authors: Dehua Xiong, Xubin Li, Xiongying Duan, Jiexin Hu, Guanghui Yang, Minfu Liao
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: When an unloaded transformer is closed by a double-break vacuum circuit breaker, the influence of grading capacitors and closing asynchronism on the inrush current magnitude is urgently in need of study. To address this issue, this paper first analyzes the variation law of residual flux density under static voltage distribution after opening operation. Then, the breakdown process of the vacuum circuit breaker is studied, and an equivalent circuit model is constructed. The characteristics of grading capacitors in double-break vacuum circuit breakers and the influence of closing asynchronism on magnetizing inrush current are theoretically analyzed. Finally, a simulation circuit for closing an unloaded transformer with a double-break vacuum circuit breaker is established to simulate the variation law of inrush current during the closing process. The results indicate that after opening operation, residual flux density is converted into dynamic magnetic flux by grading capacitors. The average value method can be adopted in calculations to avoid extreme conditions. During the closing process, the influences of closing asynchronism and grading capacitor imbalance on magnetizing inrush current are found to be minimal.

title: Field Emission Characteristics of Plasma-Treated Carbon Nanotube/Polystyrene Large-Area Field Emitters
authors: Sergei V. Filippov, Oleg S. Medvedev, Anatoly G. Kolosko, Konstantin A. Nikiforov, Eugeni O. Popov
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Field emission properties of plasma treated carbon nanotube/polystyrene field emitter in deuterium gas environment are studied. Varying the duration of treatment difference in threshold fields has been shown. Optimal duration of surface plasma treatment has been found.

title: Modeling and Simulation Study of Large-Size Vacuum Arc Ignition Process
authors: Junjie Li, Xiaolong Huang, Xiaoxi Le, Huikai Xu, Lihua Zhao, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum circuit breaker adopts vacuum environment as insulation and arc extinguishing medium, which can effectively improve the safety of the power system and reduce the operation and maintenance cost, and it is a kind of ideal zero-carbon and fluorine-free environmentally friendly power switchgear. At present, with the development of the power industry and the increase of system capacity, the size of the vacuum circuit breaker is also increasing, and its breaking performance and arc-firing characteristics are affected by the size. Therefore, this paper establishes a magnetohydrodynamic model (MHD) of a large-size vacuum arc with a diameter of 140 mm, and investigates the whole process of vacuum arc ignition under different opening moments. The results show that the plasma pressure, current density, electron and ion temperatures are positively correlated with the current and negatively correlated with the ion velocity. The increase of arc current leads to the uneven radial distribution of plasma, and the parameter distribution first contracts and then expands with the arc-firing process, lagging behind the current change. The region of high ion pressure is unfavorable for acceleration, and the ion velocity is opposite to the pressure distribution. The contraction of the arc toward the anode increases the ion collisions, the conversion of kinetic and internal energies leads to an increase in the ion temperature, and the Joule heating increases the electron temperature. The results of the study can provide theoretical support for the development of vacuum circuit breakers with larger size and high opening current.

title: Adaptive Elderly Health Management via Joint Optimization of Voice Cloning and Domain-Specific Large Language Models
authors: Jiahui Chen, Xiaoling Feng, Xiaofei Wang, Li Wang, Chen Xu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics

authors: Ping Wang, Shishir Nagaraja, Aurélien Bourquard, Haichang Gao, Jeff Yan

title: Secure OTFS Transmission: A Theoretical Framework Based on Discriminatory Channel Estimation
authors: Zhuangzhuang Tie, Zan Li, Jia Shi, Jiangbo Si
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: This letter investigates physical-layer security for orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS) systems under a discriminatory channel estimation (DCE) scheme that exploits the block-circulant structure of the delay–Doppler channel and coarse prior knowledge. We derive a fixed-point characterization of the linear minimum mean square error (LMMSE) channel-estimation error that captures the impact of pilot power, interference and multipath richness. A closed-form expression for the secrecy rate is obtained, showing that secrecy improves with pilot power at low-to-moderate levels but deteriorates in the high-power regime. Numerical results validate the analysis and reveal trade-offs among pilot allocation, path diversity and secrecy performance.

title: IEEE Professional Communication Society Publication Information
authors: N/A

title: Beyond Directional-RIS Aided NOMA-ISAC Networks: A DRL Approach for Sum-Rate Optimization
authors: Ahmad Faisal Mirza, Ali Arshad Nasir, Haejoon Jung, Aamir Mahmood, Syed Ali Hassan, Mikael Gidlund
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Future sixth-generation (6G) networks require efficient resource management to support a variety of services. This paper addresses the issue of maximizing user rates in a beyond directional reconfigurable intelligent surface (BD-RIS)-assisted network with non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) and integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) users. However, exploiting the gains offered by these frameworks necessitates joint tuning of BD-RIS phases and NOMA power, which is an inherently non-convex problem. We model this coupling as a continuous-action Markov decision process and solve it using twin-delayed deep deterministic policy gradient (TD3) reinforcement learning. The learned policy adaptively selects power-allocation factors and BD-RIS phase shifts, thereby boosting both communication and sensing rates under quality-of-service constraints. Simulation results confirm that the proposed deep reinforcement learning (DRL) scheme significantly outperforms conventional heuristics, demonstrating its potential for real-time resource optimization in 6G networks.

title:
Dynamic Investigation of a Dual-Enzyme WO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    NPs/MoO
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Acetylcholine Sensor Based on Amperometry Integrated With Microfluidics
authors: Po-Hui Yang, Yu-Wei Chen, Chih-Hsien Lai, Jung-Chuan Chou, Yu-Hsun Nien, Po-Yu Kuo, Xin-Han Chen, Hong-Wei Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Acetylcholine plays a pivotal role as a neurotransmitter, regulating neuronal communication and contributing to overall nervous system function. Dysregulation of ACh levels has been linked to neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases. This study aims to develop an ACh sensor with an ultralow detection limit, based on a molybdenum trioxide (MoO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>) thin film modified with hydrothermally synthesized tungsten trioxide (WO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>) nanoparticles (NPs). MoO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> thin films were fabricated using radio frequency (RF) sputtering, and WO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> NPs were deposited via drop casting for enhanced hydrogen ion sensitivity. Differential pulse voltammetry (DPV) was employed to suppress background currents, while integration with a microfluidic platform minimized sample volume. The optimal flow rate was determined to be <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$20~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>L/min. The sensor exhibited reliable sensitivity (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$33.39~\mu \text {A} \cdot \text {decade}^{-{1}} \cdot \text {cm}^{-{2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), an ultralow limit of detection (LOD) (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$8.83\times 10^{-{14}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> M), and satisfactory anti-interference performance. These findings offer a promising approach for the detection of trace levels of ACh.

title: Defense against Poisoning Attacks on Federated Learning with Neighborhood Coulomb Force
authors: Bo Wang, Youliang Tian, Yina Guo, Hongtao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across untrusted devices while preserving data privacy. However, malicious participants can still launch attacks, especially poisoning attacks, during model aggregation. To defend against poisoning attacks, we propose a Coulomb Force-based Federated Learning (CFFL), a physics-inspired defense framework that integrates neighborhood Coulomb force into FL security mechanisms. CFFL effectively addresses detection failures in poisoning attacks arising from the “distance concentration” among high-dimensional data. Specifically, firstly, we establishes a local update model for clients, where the similarity between model updates is quantified through local Coulomb resultant force (LCRF), effectively distinguishing malicious and benign updates; Secondly, we develop a k-nearest neighbor (KNN)-based Coulomb resultant force anomaly detection (NCFAD) model that identifies malicious updates by isolating top-k outliers with largest neighborhood factor; Finally, experiment results validate that CFFL outperforms state-of-the-art (SOTA) baselines in defense performance and achieves model accuracy equivalent to the baseline FedAvg on NCI-1, PROTEINS_full, and MNIST datasets (90.82%, 92.23%, and 96.49%, respectively). This indicates that CFFL effectively mitigates the impact of poisoning attacks without compromising the benign performance of the aggregation model.

title: Auditing MLaaS Inference Service Quality without Ground Truth via Mutual Information
authors: Jiang Zhu, Qingqing Ye, Haibo Hu, Li Bai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Machine Learning as a Service (MLaaS) paradigm offers an appealing solution for clients that have limited computational resources. It allows entities to train models with collected dataset and powerful cloud resources, and to deploy these models for inference. However, MLaaS currently faces significant challenges in ensuring trustworthy inference and service quality. The clients cannot verify that the inference results returned by service provider (SP) are the model’s actual inference results. Moreover, even if clients manage to ensure that the results are obtained through model inference, they are unable to determine the model’s service quality without ground truth. To address these concerns, we introduce an innovative framework to audit inference quality and integrity in MLaaS through a novel deep neural network (DNN) inspection method. In specific, our approach represents the inherent behavior of the model by collecting its intermediate layer outputs and quantifying the mutual information (MI) values derived from them. By benchmarking the model during the training process, the SP can record the characteristics of the correct model and its corresponding service quality. After receiving the auditing request, the auditor can evaluate the quality of the service by estimating its accuracy via mutual information. Moreover, it can confirm the integrity of the returned results by inspecting the intermediate layer output. In addition, we thoroughly analyze our scheme for various potential adaptive attacks. Through empirical studies, we verify the correctness, effectiveness, and robustness of our scheme for trustworthy MLaaS inference service.

title: Enhancing Large Medical Equipment Health-Aware Control with Bayesian Graph Attention Transformer-Based Probabilistic Remaining Useful Life Prediction
authors: Huamao Jiang, Keqin Li, Zhonghua Liu, Chien-Ming Chen, Jianhui Lv
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Large medical equipment such as MRI, CT scanners, and linear accelerators are critical healthcare infrastructure. The health status of these systems directly impacts diagnHealth-Aware Control osis accuracy, treatment efficacy, and overall healthcare quality. However, current maintenance approaches often rely on fixed schedules or reactive strategies, leading to unnecessary downtime, increased costs, and potential patient care disruptions. This lack of uncertain information hinders robust decision-making in health-aware control (HAC) and maintenance scheduling. Therefore, this paper proposes a novel probabilistic remaining useful life (RUL) prediction method for large medical equipment based on a Bayesian graph attention transformer. First, we construct a graph attention network to extract complex non-Euclidean spatial relationships between multiple sensor signals from medical equipment. We then integrate this graph attention mechanism into the transformer's temporal multi-head attention module, combining graph attention networks' spatial feature extraction advantages with transformer models' temporal feature extraction capabilities. This integration enables joint extraction of spatiotemporal relationships in sensor data. Simultaneously, we employ an improved Bayesian network to quantify prediction uncertainty, providing point estimates of RUL and corresponding confidence intervals. The resulting framework supports HAC decisions that balance large medical equipment performance and longevity. Experiments conducted on two medical equipment operation datasets (CT and MRI) demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of our approach compared to existing methods, achieving more accurate and reliable RUL predictions that enable optimized maintenance scheduling and enhanced HAC strategies.

title: Stitching Meaning: Practices of Data Textile Creators_supp1-3634255.pdf
authors: Sydney Purdue
publish: N/A
abstract: Tens of thousands of people have represented data by creating data-encoding textile pieces like blankets, scarves, and more. A prototypical example is the temperature blanket, which represents the weather through rows or blocks of different colors mapped to temperature ranges. While researchers have used fiber arts mediums to create exploratory projects, data visualization and physicalization research has largely not engaged with examples from this enormous and diverse community. We explore the space of data textiles, or fiber arts that encode information, by surveying creators (i.e., data fiber artists) on their projects and processes. We create a corpus of 159 examples of data textiles and present a schema characterizing the data encoding methods used in these projects. We also gather insights into creators' data workflows as well as their motives and discoveries through making with their data. Creators of data textiles use distinct processes to map their data, building fabric from component structures and substructures while using material properties like color and texture. From diverse data-tracking procedures, creators use and relate to data in varied ways. Working on these pieces also contributes to the creators' personal growth and data understanding. Our findings point to new opportunities for visualization, including opportunities to support fiber artists with tools formatted to their needs and opportunities to incorporate concepts from data textiles into other types of visualization (e.g., using texture, structural layouts, colorways).

title: CellScout: Visual Analytics for Mining Biomarkers in Cell State Discovery_supp1-3636102.mp4
authors: Zelin Zang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cell state discovery is crucial for understanding biological systems and enhancing medical outcomes. A key aspect of this process is identifying distinct biomarkers that define specific cell states. However, difficulties arise from the co-discovery process of cell states and biomarkers: biologists often use dimensionality reduction to visualize cells in a two dimensional space. Then they usually interpret visually clustered cells as distinct states, from which they seek to identify unique biomarkers. However, this assumption is often invalid due to internal inconsistencies in a cluster, making the process trial-and error and highly uncertain. Therefore, biologists urgently need effective tools to help uncover the hidden association relationships between different cell populations and their potential biomarkers. To address this problem, we first designed a machine-learning algorithm based on the Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) technique to identify meaningful associations between cell populations and biomarkers. We further developed a visual analytics system CellScout–in collaboration with biologists, to help them explore and refine these association relationships to advance cell state discovery. We validated our system through expert interviews, from which we further selected a representative case to demonstrate its effectiveness in discovering new cell states.

title: Zero-Shot Video Translation via Token Warping
authors: Haiming Zhu, Yangyang Xu, Jun Yu, Shengfeng He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: With the revolution of generative AI, video-related tasks have been widely studied. However, current state-of-the-art video models still lag behind image models in visual quality and user control over generated content. In this paper, we introduce TokenWarping, a novel framework for temporally coherent video translation. Existing diffusion-based video editing approaches rely solely on key and value patches in self-attention to ensure temporal consistency, often sacrificing the preservation of local and structural regions. Critically, these methods overlook the significance of the query patches in achieving accurate feature aggregation and temporal coherence. In contrast, TokenWarping leverages complementary token priors by constructing temporal correlations across different frames. Our method begins by extracting optical flows from source videos. During the denoising process of the diffusion model, these optical flows are used to warp the previous frame's query, key, and value patches, aligning them with the current frame's patches. By directly warping the query patches, we enhance feature aggregation in self-attention, while warping the key and value patches ensures temporal consistency across frames. This token warping imposes explicit constraints on the self-attention layer outputs, effectively ensuring temporally coherent translation. Our framework does not require any additional training or fine-tuning and can be seamlessly integrated with existing text-to-image editing methods. We conduct extensive experiments on various video translation tasks, demonstrating that TokenWarping surpasses state-of-the-art methods both qualitatively and quantitatively. Video demonstrations are available in supplementary materials.

title: Retraction Notice: Classification & Detection of Epilepsy Using IEEG Application
authors: R. Kishore Kanna, Kapil Joshi, Kamreed Udham Singh, Ambali Pacholi, Mathar Mohideen Nagoor Thangam, X.S. Blessing NimaSajai
publish: 2024 4th International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: More than only cognitive loss and impairment, epileptic seizures may seriously harm one’s intellect. Early seizure detection is essential to minimize the harm caused by their possessions. Presently, medical professionals use optical testing of electroencephalographic (EEG) data for project labeling, which may be a labor-intensive and delayed procedure. By resolving EEG data using the best spatial convolutional interconnected system-long temporary thought (1D CNNLSTM) model, this study offers a revolutionary pattern for always identifying seizures. Before the raw EEG dossier is augmented into a 1D CNN that pulls appearance data from the dossier, it is preprocessed and standardized. Hence, worldly faces are extracted using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) layers, which are then combined into various suitably linked coatings for capture recognition. The projected model’s representation was evaluated using the UCI epileptic capture acknowledgment dataset. For the twofold and five-class taking acknowledgment tasks, respectively, the outcomes show an exceptional acknowledgment veracity of 99.39 % and 82.00 %. The predicted model achieved better act when compared to existing machine intelligence setups and additional deep education models. These rulings highlight the promise of the proposed method for accurately diagnosing seizures in patients who are experiencing muscular spasms and acknowledge the potential for improved impartial outcomes.

title: RYOLO-LWMD-Lite: A Lightweight Rotating Ship Target Detection Model for Optical Remote Sensing Images
authors: Zhaohui Li, Sheng Qi, Haohao Yang, Haolin Li, Hongyu Jia
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Combining optical remote sensing images for ship monitoring is a practical approach for maritime surveillance. However, existing research lacks sufficient detection accuracy and fails to consider computational resource constraints in ship detection processing. This paper proposes a novel lightweight rotating ship target detection model. First, we enhance the detection accuracy by expanding the YOLOv8n-obb model with Large Selective Kernel (LSK) attention mechanism, Weight-Fusion Multi-Branch Auxiliary FPN (WFMAFPN), and Dynamic Task-Aligned Detection Head (DTAH). Specifically, the LSK attention mechanism dynamically adjusts the receptive field, effectively capturing multi-scale features. The WFMAFPN improves the capacity of feature fusion by the multi-directional paths and adaptive weight assignment to individual feature maps. The DTAH further enhances detection performance by improving task interaction between classification and localization. Second, we reduce the computational resource consumption of our model. This technique is developed by pruning based on layer adaptive magnitude on the enhanced architecture and designing the DTAH module with shared parameters. Considering the above improvement, we name our model RYOLO-LWMD-Lite. Finally, we constructed a large-scale dataset for rotating ships, named AShipClass9, with diverse ship categories to evaluate our model. Experimental results indicate that the RYOLO-LWMD-Lite model achieves higher detection accuracy while maintaining a lower parameter count. Specifically, the model's parameter count is approximately 2/3 that of YOLOv8n-obb, and the test accuracy on AShipClass9 reaches 48.2% (in terms of AP<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">50</sub>), a 6% improvement over the baseline. In addition, experiments conducted on the DOTA1.5 dataset validate the generalization capability of the proposed model.The source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/QSuser/RYOLO-LWMD</uri>.

title: Rescue Robots for Casualty Extraction: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Roni Permana Saputra, Ahmad AlAttar, Estiko Rijanto, Rilo Berdin Taqriban, Athanasia Amanda Septevani, Nemanja Rakicevic, Petar Kormushev
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The development of robotic systems for search and rescue (SAR) operations holds great potential in reducing risks to rescue workers and enhancing the likelihood of successful rescue operations. Although many studies have been conducted on search and rescue robotics, more emphasis should be placed on developing rescue robots, especially those intended for physical rescue interventions, such as loading and transporting injured individuals (i.e., casualties) to a secure area—the process known as casualty extraction. The enabling technologies for such robots remain challenging due to the complexity of the tasks, significantly high safety considerations, and strict standards—since the robots are designed to interact with casualties physically. In addition to academic institutions, most research and technical implementations of state-of-the-art casualty extraction robots are carried out by military organisations. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the current state of the art in developing mobile rescue robots for casualty extraction. The existing casualty extraction robot proposals publicly available in the literature are discussed and evaluated in terms of their design and morphology. Moreover, this review details the proposed casualty extraction procedure that corresponds to the robot designs, the operation method, and the levels of autonomy of these robots. The existing state-of-the-art technologies are discussed and compared to evaluate the pros and cons of each system, providing a guideline for further research into areas where more effort could be applied. Based on the review and evaluation of the existing state-of-the-art, we identify critical research gaps that require further investigation to enhance the current state of the art and facilitate long-term development in rescue robotics research.

title: Unsourced Random Access: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Mert Ozates, Mohammad Javad Ahmadi, Mohammad Kazemi, Deniz Gündüz, Tolga M. Duman
publish: IEEE Communications Surveys & Tutorials
abstract: Multiple access communication systems enable numerous users to share common communication resources, playing a crucial role in wireless networks. With the emergence of the sixth generation (6G) and beyond communication networks, supporting massive machine-type communications with sporadic activity patterns is expected to become a critical challenge. Unsourced random access (URA) has emerged as a promising paradigm to address this challenge by decoupling user identification from data transmission through the use of a common codebook. This survey offers a comprehensive overview of URA solutions, encompassing both theoretical foundations and practical applications. We present a systematic classification of URA solutions across three primary channel models: Gaussian multiple access channels (GMACs), single-antenna fading channels, and multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) fading channels. For each category, we analyze and compare state-of-the-art solutions in terms of performance, complexity, and practical feasibility. Additionally, we discuss critical challenges such as interference management, computational complexity, and synchronization. The survey concludes with promising future research directions and potential methods to address existing limitations, providing a roadmap for researchers and practitioners in this rapidly evolving field.

title: A Hyperspectral Change Detection Method For Small Vehicles
authors: Shuyi Xu, He Sun, Xu Sun, Li Ni, Lianru Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Small vehicles (SV) detection is crucial for urban security and traffic management. However, detecting such targets from a single image presents significant challenges due to the difficulty in discerning their dynamic movements. In this paper, we propose a deep joint image-level and feature-level processing network, IFNet, designed for detecting changes in SV using bi-temporal hyperspectral images. At the image-level, a new Gumbel Softmax trick (GS)-based band selection strategy is introduced to address the problem of inconsistent spectral resolutions of bi-temporal images. At the feature-level, to tackle the challenge of capturing edge and shape details of SV, we propose a feature-based edge enhancement module, it can extract the target edge using high-level difference features, and the refined change map will be generated with the guidance of the edge map. Moreover, current deep learning-based hyperspectral change detection (HCD) methods are limited by HCD datasets. Therefore, we propose a benchmark dataset, the Hyperspectral Vehicle Change Detection (HVCD) dataset, which consists of 201 pairs of aerial hyperspectral images, each with a size of 256 × 256, and exhibits inconsistent spectral resolutions across the bi-temporal data. Extensive experiments conducted on the HVCD dataset demonstrate that our IFNet obtains state-of-the-art performance with an acceptable computational cost.

title: Interplay Between Security, Privacy and Trust in 6G-Enabled Intelligent Transportation Systems
authors: Ahmed Danladi Abdullahi, Erfan Bahrami, Tooska Dargahi, Mohammed Al-Khalidi, Mohammad Hammoudeh
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Advancements in sixth-generation (6G) wireless technology are expected to transform the transportation sector by enabling faster, more reliable, and more intelligent mobility services. 6G-enabled Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS) offer ultra-low-latency communication, massive connectivity, and advanced analytics that support safer, more efficient, and more sustainable mobility. Despite these benefits, 6G-ITS introduces significant security, privacy, and trust challenges that must be addressed to ensure safe deployment and sustained public confidence. This paper reviews the opportunities and challenges of 6G-ITS with a focus on security, privacy, and trust, including the dual role of quantum technologies that strengthen cryptographic mechanisms while introducing novel attack surfaces. The paper highlights the benefits of 6G for transportation, including improved communication performance, enhanced device interoperability, advanced data analytics, and increased automation across transportation management and communication systems. A taxonomy of attack models in 6G-ITS is provided, alongside a comparison of security threats in 5G-ITS and 6G-ITS and corresponding mitigation strategies. The findings highlight the need for a comprehensive, multi-layered security framework that spans physical infrastructure, network protocols, data management, application security, and trust mechanisms to ensure the integrity and resilience of future 6G transportation ecosystems.

title: A Physics-Based Perspective for Understanding and Utilizing Spatial Resources in Line-of-Sight Holographic Communications
authors: Hui Xu, Jun Wei Wu, Rui Wen Shao, Zhen Jie Qi, Hao Tian Wu, Jieao Zhu, Qiang Cheng, Linglong Dai, Tie Jun Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: To satisfy the increasing demands for wireless transmission rates, it is necessary to exploit spatial resources of electromagnetic (EM) waves. In this context, EM information theory (EIT) has emerged as a hot topic by integrating the theoretical framework of deterministic mathematics and stochastic statistics to explore the transmission mechanisms of continuous EM waves. However, the previous studies were primarily focused on the analysis of the spatial degrees of freedom, with limited exploration of a comprehensive understanding of the essential physical characteristics of EIT. In this paper, a three-dimensional (3D) line-of-sight channel capacity formula is proposed, which captures the vector EM physics and accommodates both near- and far-field scenes. A novel channel model is established based on the rigorous mathematical equation and the physical mechanism of fast multipole algorithm, and it is revealed that the scattered EM waves have finite angular spectral bandwidth, which determines the eigenvalue distributions of the communication system. Furthermore, a series of orthogonal basis are constructed for the currents on the transmitter and the fields on the receiving aperture, thus supporting the optimal design of the spatial precoder and combiner. Comprehensive analyses are made to investigate the relationship among the noise, transmitted power, and spatial degree of freedom, thereby establishing a rigorous upper bound of channel capacity. Finally, a series of simulations are conducted to validate the theoretical model and numerical method. This work offers a novel perspective and methodology for comprehending and leveraging spatial resources of wireless channels, and provides a theoretical foundation for the design and optimization of the holographic communications.

title: Hybrid Differential Game Guidance Law of Missile against Actively-Defended Target
authors: Jiliang Xie, Kemao Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: A hybrid differential game guidance law is proposed for a missile intercepting an actively-defended target. For the missile, the successful evasion from the defender, i.e. the miss distance being larger than the defender's killing radius, is considered a prerequisite of attacking the target. For the evading phase, the differential-game-of-kind theory is used to give the escape zone described by the range in which the missile's guidance commands take values. The guidance laws of all players in the engagement are given by solving the differential-game-of-degree, with the value range obtained from the differential-game-of-kind serving as the feasible region for the missile. All players' guidance laws form the equilibrium solutions of the hybrid differential game in the three-player engagement. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the design.

title: HyperFPGA: A scalable reconfigurable platform for computing paradigms research
authors: Werner Florian Samayoa, Maria Liz Crespo, Sergio Carrato, Agustin Silva, Maynor Giovanni Ballina Escobar, Andres Cicuttin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In recent years, the limitations of von Neumann-based supercomputers in terms of energy efficiency and performance scalability have stressed the need for alternative computing paradigms. This paper introduces the HyperFPGA, an open SoC-FPGA cluster designed for experimental research of novel supercomputing architectures and paradigms. Unlike existing platforms, the HyperFPGA offers flexibility across a wide range of configurations, from electrical standards for data transmission to distributed computing models. Additionally, it is equipped with multiple power consumption monitors to independently measure different computational and hardware aspects, separating data movement from computation. The paper details the design and implementation of the HyperFPGA and demonstrates its basic functionality and scalability through a custom computational solution for the non-attacking n-queens problem, a well-known distributed computing problem. These preliminary tests demonstrate the ability of the HyperFPGA to efficiently handle computationally intensive and distributed tasks, showcasing its potential for fine-grained reconfigurable supercomputing solutions addressing a broad spectrum of scientific and engineering problems. The platform is available for open collaborative projects focused on energy-efficient supercomputing and computational physics.

title: From Lab to Field: Practical Deployment and Evaluation of a Speaker Recognition System
authors: Raluca-Ionela Costan, Mihai Coca, Ştefan-Adrian Toma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: In the field of speech signal processing, both the duration and quality of audio recordings significantly influence system performance and response time. This work presents a comprehensive evaluation of a speaker recognition system developed using the SpeechBrain toolkit and deployed within a containerized application.Six experimental scenarios were designed to reflect real-world usage conditions and explore various dimensions of system performance. The evaluation includes a comparison of two voice activity detection (VAD) models — SpeechBrain and Silero — in multi-speaker noisy environments using the VoxConverse dataset; a speaker re-identification test measuring Equal Error Rate (EER) across multiple segmentation configurations; and a set of scalability tests analyzing the impact of CPU threading, number of enrolled users (up to 15,000), and test audio duration (up to 24 hours) on processing time. Additionally, system performance was measured under full hardware utilization using all available CPU cores and GPUs. Results offer valuable insights into the efficiency, robustness, and practical deployment considerations of open-source speaker recognition solutions.

title: Surface Microstructural Design of Alumina Ceramics to Enhance Surface Flashover Voltage in Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Yuwen Zeng, Xin Liao, Yongjia Luo, Saikang Shen, Xiaolong Huang, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Surface flashover along the ceramic inside vacuum interrupters significantly degrades insulation performance. At present, increasing the ceramic length is the main approach used to improve insulation, but this inevitably leads to larger interrupter size and higher manufacturing costs. Therefore, enhancing the surface flashover voltage per unit length of ceramics under vacuum conditions is critical for downsizing vacuum interrupters, reducing costs, and improving reliability. In this study, a method involving the etching of periodic triangular grooves on the ceramic surface is proposed to improve vacuum surface flashover performance. A systematic investigation was conducted to study the influence of groove periodicity (ranging from 0.1 mm to 0.4 mm) on the surface flashover voltage of ceramics under direct current (DC) conditions. Additionally, a vacuum surface flashover simulation model was developed based on the Particle-In-Cell with Monte Carlo Collision (PIC-MCC) algorithm, and the suppression effect and underlying mechanism of surface grooves were analyzed in combination with experimental results. The findings indicate that surface microstructure design has strong potential for enhancing the vacuum surface flashover voltage of ceramics. Specifically, the breakdown voltage corresponding to a $\mathbf{5 0 \%}$ flashover probability was increased by more than $50 \%$, offering a promising strategy for optimizing the structural design of ceramic enclosures in vacuum interrupters.

title: World – Novelty in dielectric steering of floating potentials in Vacuum Interrupter
authors: Dietmar Gentsch, Kai Gorlt
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum circuit breakers (VCBs) are favored in the medium voltage range due to their gas- and $\mathbf{S F}_{6}$ - free, environmentally friendly operation and relatively low maintenance costs compared to other interrupters. To increase the operational voltage level, a common approach is to use a single or double break device. A classical solution for symmetrizing the voltage distribution over a single contact gap vacuum interrupter (VI) is to use a floating one-part or multipart shielding solution, even on floating potential, along with external grading capacitors. Similarly, for a double contact gap vacuum interrupter, a floating one-part or multi-part shielding solution is given, even on floating potential, and external grading capacitors can be used to balance the voltage distribution. This approach enhances the symmetry of the voltage distribution across the vacuum interrupter and the floating shielding [1]. To enhance overall dielectric performance, this paper presents the integration of additional field grading and shielding electrodes within single and double-breaking vacuum interrupters to symmetrize the voltage distribution [2, 3]. First, the shielding behaviour of the arrangement is analysed as such and “free-standing” and using a grounded flat metal electrode placed at 50 to 100 mm to disturb the symmetric field distribution [4, 5, 6]. Second, the symmetrizing behavior is analyzed through detailed electric field simulations of the grading components within the vacuum interrupter, both before and after implementing the novel design. The basic modular design of the novel vacuum interrupter arrangement is presented and investigated in detail using the EField simulation method. This paper explains how the design improves voltage distribution along the vacuum interrupter and maintains robustness even when an earthed environment is placed close to the interrupter.

title: Voltage Distribution Analysis of 252 kV Vacuum Interrupter under AC and Lightning Impulse Conditions Based on Stray Parameter Modeling
authors: Saikang Shen, Xin Liao, Xiaolong Huang, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: This study investigates the voltage distribution of a 252 kV vacuum interrupter with six ceramic segments under AC and lightning impulse (LI) voltages. An equivalent circuit model was developed based on stray parameters extracted via COMSOL and simulated in PSpice. Results show that the resistance and inductance of the conductive rods have negligible impact on the overall potential distribution. Compared with COMSOL results, the proposed equivalent circuit model produces consistent voltage-sharing ratios across the ceramic segments of 252 kV VI. This confirms its reliability in reproducing potential distribution and providing a practical basis for optimizing the design of 252 kV and 550 kV vacuum circuit breakers.

title: Simulation of Metal Vapor Characteristics Caused by Micro-particles Impact in Long Vacuum Gaps under High Voltage
authors: Shuchen Liu, Yulong Gao, Shichen Deng, Hui Ma, Zhiyuan Liu, Yingsan Geng
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The micro-particle impact phenomenon is one of the important factors leading to vacuum breakdown in long vacuum gaps The objective of this paper is to investigate the characteristics of the crater and metal vapor caused by the micro-particle impact phenomenon. The process of micro-particle impact was calculated by the Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) method. Characteristics of the crater and the density and distribution of the metal vapor released after the impact were analyzed. The results indicate that the radius of the crater after the impact increases from $2.18 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ to $3.80 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, and the depth of the crater increases from $1.87 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ to $5.26 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ when the impact velocity increases from $600 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ to 2400 $\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$. And at $10 \mu \mathrm{~s}$ after the collision, the density of the metal vapor at a distance of $22.5 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ from the electrode surface is sufficient to cause breakdown This paper could provide some useful information to solve the problem of vacuum insulation under high voltages and long vacuum gaps.

title: Experimental study on enhancing surface flashover voltage by metallization on the side of the ceramic
authors: Yayu Hao, Lei Chen, Ao Xu, Yuanjie Shi, Wei Zhong, Mengmeng Wang, Pingping Gan, Jialin Yang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Alumina ceramic is a kind of insulation medium commonly used in electric vacuum equipment. In order to make alumina ceramics and metal electrodes tightly connected, the surface of alumina ceramics is required to be metalized and then welded. In this paper, the flashover voltage characteristics of alumina ceramics before and after side metallization were experimentally studied in a dynamic vacuum system under pulse voltage condition. The experimental results show that the flashover voltage of metalized ceramic sample increases compared with the unmetalized ceramic sample. Besides, the flashover voltage of the ceramic samples without metallization but undergoing metallization environment is basically the same as that of the blank samples. It may because the change of cathode or anode triple junction which has a significant effect on the surface flashover voltage. This provides a support for further study of the flashover characteristics of ceramics.

title: Classification of prestrike arc shape in vacuum interrupter under capacitive switching
authors: Zongyao Ge, Yun Geng, Xiaofei Yao
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: When closing a capacitor bank, high-frequency inrush currents generated in the circuit can cause prestrike phenomena in the vacuum interrupter, accompanied by the formation of prestrike arcs. These prestrike arcs can ablation the contact surface or lead to fusion welding, potentially causing re-strike or failure of the circuit breaking process in the vacuum interrupter. Experimental studies on the arc shape of high-frequency inrush currents prestrike arcs are of significant importance in understanding the impact of different contact materials on the prestrike arc shape during closing inrush currents. This paper is based on experiments conducted in a capacitive synthetic circuit laboratory, where two types of contact materials, $\mathrm{CuCr30}$ and WCu10, are used in vacuum interrupters to investigate the classification of prestrike arc morphologies under high-frequency inrush currents. The prestrike arc shape is measured and analyzed at inrush current peak values of $5 \mathrm{kA}, 10 \mathrm{kA}$, and 20 kA, and the arc forms are categorized accordingly.

title: Field Emission Properties Affected by Work Function Distribution
authors: Sergei V. Filippov, Fernando F. Dall’Agnol, Konstantin A. Nikiforov, Thiago A. de Assis, Anatoly G. Kolosko, Eugeni O. Popov
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Field emission current - applied field curves were obtained in a computer simulated emitter, taking into account different distributions of the work function over its surface. We aim to quantify the variation in the applied field necessary to generate 1 microampere.

title: External Electric Field Distribution Calculation and Analysis of High-voltage Vacuum Interrupter in Metal Tank
authors: Shuaibing Wang, Wei Luo, Jiangang Ding, Zaixing Peng, Yuan La, Wei Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The objective of this paper is to investigate the external electric field distribution of high-voltage vacuum interrupters (VIs) encapsulated in metal tanks. The effects of geometric parameters, including shielding configurations, tank diameters, and shielding clearances on the external electric field distribution were determined in this work. A two-dimensional finite element model was established to simulate the electric field characteristics. Comparative studies were conducted on configurations with and without an external end shield, supplemented by parametric analyses of tank diameter and shielding clearance. Key findings reveal that the external end shield significantly reduces the maximum electric field intensity at the gas-solid-electrode triple junctions by $94.5 \%$, demonstrating its critical role in the mitigating field concentrations. Furthermore, the tank diameter exhibits an inverse correlation with localized field magnitudes, while shielding clearance shows a positive correlation near triple junctions and an inverse correlation in distal regions. These results emphasize the importance of geometric optimization in balancing field uniformity and insulation reliability for tank-type VIs.

title: A mechanical DC disconnection technology based on vacuum arc control
authors: Wenkui Liu, Gang Liu, Hang Zhou, Xiaomin Zhao, Yaopeng Lu, Xuxu Li
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The multi-terminal flexible DC distribution network is an effective means for the local consumption of a high proportion of renewable energy such as photovoltaic and wind power and for the highly reliable and flexible energy supply of the power system. The DC load switch is the key to ensuring the safe and stable operation of the DC distribution network. This paper proposes a mechanical DC breaking scheme with low cost, small size and high reliability. By regulating the arc voltage of the vacuum arc, a high-frequency oscillating current is generated between the main branch and the transfer branch to achieve rapid zero-crossing and breaking of the load current. First of all, build a topological structure simulation model and study the matching relationship of key parameters. Secondly, the characteristics of fast mechanical switches are studied, and the design methods of parameters such as opening and closing capacitors and charging voltages are proposed. Finally, a prototype of $\pm \mathbf{1 0 k V}$ mechanical DC load switch based on vacuum arc regulation is developed and experimental tests are conducted. The results show that the prototype can break the 3000A system current within 5 ms, meeting the engineering application requirements of DC load switches.

title: Prostate Cancer Identification from Pathology Diagnosis Descriptions in Lithuanian Language
authors: Tomas Griguola, Giedrė Smailytė, Linas Petkevičius
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This research address the analysis on automating medical diagnosis extraction from medical diagnosis description. The methodology involved investigating several multilingual models, such as Google-Gemma-2-2B and EuroLLM-9B, to classify data based on the described cancer groups. Results showed that it is possible to classify Lithuanian pathological diagnosis with varying performance across different models. After checking all the results, the most stable model was Gemma-2-2B. When classifying T and N values the best results were obtain by Gemma-2-2B with respectively 65% and 78% accuracy. When classifying grade group value, the best results were obtained using Gemma-2-9B with 83% accuracy. This study demonstrate the cost-effective scalable approach to engineering and manual work of processing medical diagnosis.

title: Research on Optimization Methods of Financial Decision Making System Combining Big Data and ETL Architecture
authors: Qiaochu Lu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: With the rapid advancement of big data technologies, financial institutions are encountering escalating requirements for real-time responsiveness, intelligent analytics, and enhanced system security. To address these challenges, this study presents a comprehensive optimization strategy for financial decision-making systems, focusing on real-time ETL frameworks and scalable big data processing architectures. A distributed computing framework is developed, integrating real-time ETL pipelines with a high-performance storage structure to enhance data throughput and access efficiency. To strengthen predictive capabilities, the system incorporates machine learning algorithm optimization, multi-dimensional feature engineering, and a hybrid risk evaluation model. Moreover, multi-level parallel computing techniques and privacy-preserving mechanisms are applied to ensure stability and data security under high-concurrency workloads. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system significantly outperforms traditional platforms in terms of latency, throughput, resource utilization, and risk control, offering a practical reference for intelligent financial system design and digital transformation.

title: Reconstruction of the marketing curriculum system based on digital technology stack and algorithm engineering
authors: Xiwen Hao, Xuanyi Zhang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: With the global digital economy exceeding 50 trillion US dollars and accounting for more than 40% of the global GDP, the marketing industry has fully entered the era of “algorithms are productivity”. Computer-related courses account for less than 15% of the traditional marketing education system, and the teaching content is seriously out of touch with industry needs. This study has constructed a full-process teaching system with Django+TensorFlow+Spark as the technology stack, and cultivated students' technical capabilities through the three-dimensional fusion model of “technical tools-business scenarios-engineering practice”. Evaluation data show that after the reform, the rate of students' Python full-stack development ability has increased from 52.3% to 89.7%, the distributed computing practice ability has increased by 104.1%, and the model engineering ability has increased by 286.9%. The performance of the teaching system has been significantly optimized: the algorithm training time has been shortened by 65%, the system stability index has been optimized by an average of 84%, the resource utilization rate has increased by 62%, and the GPU utilization rate has increased by 168%. This teaching system effectively bridges the gap between marketing education and the demand for digital economy talents.

title: Design of a Stand-Up Walker Based on CiteSpace Visual Analytics
authors: Zhi-Yun Wu, Min-Hong Li, Le-Qi Chen, Jing-Xiu Lin, Ting Han
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: As global aging intensifies, existing mobility aids are homogeneous and limited in their functional design, making it difficult to meet the increasingly diverse needs of the elderly population. This study uses CiteSpace visual analysis tool to systematically analyze the database literature, map the improvement hotspots, identify the key functional requirements, and carry out demand-oriented optimization of existing mobility aids, so as to provide theoretical data support for the innovation iteration of mobility aids. By summarizing and analyzing the main pain points and desired needs in the use of walking aids, we propose an innovative design concept for the “get-up-assisted” walking aid, which promotes the development of the product in the direction of high safety, intelligent personalization, and multifunctionality, and improves the user's experience and quality of life.

title: The Current State and Trends of Research in the Field of Physical Activity and Health Equity: A Data Visualization Analysis Based on Cite Space Software
authors: Jingling Shi, Si-min Huang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: None

title: Effects of Community Park Environment on Meaning in Life in Older Adults with Multiple Stepwise Regression and Structural Equation Modeling
authors: Xinjian Cai, Shunshun Bai, Yuting Zhong, Yuhao Che, Xinyue Wang, Rouzhu Zhang, Qiuling Chen
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 International Conference on Health Informatization and Data Analytics
abstract: None

title: AgTrust: Framework for Securing Critical Agriculture Technology and Emerging Solutions
authors: Mir Ali Rezazadeh Baee, Leonie Simpson, Luke Kane, Warren Armstrong, Praveen Gauravaram
publish: IEEE Transactions on AgriFood Electronics
abstract: Agriculture technology (AgTech) applies emerging technologies, such as the Internet of Things (IoT), sensors, and artificial intelligence to collect, transmit, and process information related to agricultural enterprises. AgTech solutions involve many interconnected systems, each with a range of security vulnerabilities that may impact data trustworthiness. To engage AgTech effectively, a framework is necessary for providing assurances that data used for decision making can be trusted. This article introduces a novel framework “AgTrust” that provides a cohesive solution for enabling trust in farming ecosystems. This includes assurances of data integrity, data quality, and data provenance supported by anomaly detection, quantum-safe encryption, authentication, and the underlying key-management mechanisms. The AgTrust framework is a modular design, intended for flexibility to enable implementation in a range of context and to meet the challenges of a rapidly evolving threat landscape using appropriate security mechanisms to ensure data trustworthiness. The modules providing various security functions can be adapted to future-proof the AgTech development and can be applied to other IoT or smart-device-based networks. The AgTrust framework specifies the functionality required across various layers and services and coordinates interactions between functions. Four case study examples related to the implementation of the AgTrust framework in real-world scenarios are presented and discussed.
