title: How AI-generated Summaries of Reviews Are Reshaping E-commerce with Competing Retailers?
authors: Zheng Li, Yina Li, Jiayu Zhou, Fei Ye, Yuanzhu Zhan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Engineering Management
abstract: With the rapid advancement of generative AI (Gen AI), e-commerce platforms like Amazon and Newegg are adopting AI-generated summaries (AIGS) to synthesize online reviews. We analytically study the transformative impact of AIGS one commerce with competing retailers by examining its two key effects: the convenience effect, which reduces consumers' reading costs to access review information, and the filtering effect, which aids consumers in making more informed purchase decisions. Retailers differ in their market reputation (MR), and not all consumers in the market trust AIGS. Our findings suggest that the convenience effect and the filtering effect influence competition in opposite ways. When consumer trust in AIGS is high, its adoption may intensify price competition. We further show that moderately high consumer trust in AIGS enables its adoption to create an all-win outcome for both the platform and competing retailers. Surprisingly, we find that while high trust in AIGS can reinforce high-MR retailers' advantages (a Matthew effect), the adoption of AIGS under low trust may instead reshape market competition by narrowing these advantages. Interestingly, when AIGS is fully trusted and adoption costs are moderate, it improves social welfare but may lower consumer surplus due to elevated prices.

title: Stability strategy restrictions do not elicit compensatory mechanisms during mediolaterally perturbed slow walking_supp1-3630549.pdf
authors: Aaron Best
publish: N/A
abstract: Objective: Healthy individuals have the ability to overcome perturbations when walking without falling. They have multiple stability strategies at their disposal, but it remains unclear how these different strategies compensate for one another when one may be limited due to external factors. The objective of the current study was to determine how the different stability strategies compensate for one another when mediolateral perturbations were applied. Methods: We performed both human experiments and computational modelling. The human experiments involved imposed restrictions on the different stability strategies while perturbations were applied and measuring the response of the other strategies. The stepping strategy was limited using visual feedback of step width projected onto the ground, the ankle strategy was restricted using narrow strips of rubber under the foot, and the trunk strategy was restricted using a brace. Similarly, in the computational model, we observed changes in the remaining strategies once one of the balance strategies was removed. Results: In our gait study, we found that the limitation of one strategy did not result in compensatory behaviour in the remaining strategies. However, our computational model did exhibit compensatory behaviour when strategies were removed. Conclusion: These conflicting results suggest that compensatory behaviour has the potential to be beneficial for overcoming perturbations but is not utilized by healthy individuals. Significance: The mismatch of experimental and modelling results suggests that human responses are not purely motivated by the continuation of forward motion but instead by a combination of objectives.

title: Survey of Supercapacitor Energy Storage Technology, Modeling and Ancillary Service Applications in Low-Carbon Power Systems
authors: Karlo Kobeščak, Tomislav Baškarad, Igor Kuzle
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The increasing share of renewable energy sources in electricity generation has reduced the presence of conventional rotating machines while increasing the share of converter-connected units. As a result, the overall system strength and inertia are reduced, making power systems more vulnerable to instability. To ensure reliable and secure operation, new technologies and novel, fast-acting ancillary services are being considered to replicate the inherent behavior of synchronous generators. Among the potential solutions, supercapacitor-based energy storage systems stand out due to their unique characteristics, particularly their ability to deliver rapid power support. This paper provides a comprehensive review of supercapacitor technology with a focus on applications in power systems. It examines their advantages and limitations, evaluates the shortcomings of existing studies, and summarizes the main performance metrics and integration possibilities. In addition, this paper also highlights research contributions that explore the use of supercapacitors for frequency-related as well as non-frequency ancillary services. Key challenges are identified, and directions for future research are proposed, with the aim of advancing the role of supercapacitors in enhancing power system stability.

title: TS-SatMVSNet: Slope Aware Height Estimation for Large-Scale Earth Terrain Multi-view Stereo
authors: Zhiwei Wei, Song Zhang, Wenjia Xu, Lili Zhang, Yang Wang, Jinming Zhang, Junyi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: 3D terrain reconstruction with satellite imagery achieves cost-effective and large-scale earth observation and is crucial for safeguarding natural disasters, monitoring ecological changes, and preserving the environment. Recently, learning-based multi-view stereo (MVS) methods have shown promise in this task. However, these methods simply modify the general learning-based MVS framework for height estimation, which overlooks the terrain characteristics and results in insufficient accuracy. Considering that the Earth’s surface generally undulates without drastic changes and can be measured by slope, integrating slope considerations into MVS frameworks could enhance the accuracy of terrain reconstruction. To this end, we propose an end-to-end slope-aware height estimation network named TS-SatMVSNet for large-scale remote sensing terrain reconstruction. To effectively obtain the slope representation, drawing from mathematical gradient concepts, we innovatively proposed a height-based slope calculation strategy to first calculate a slope map from a height map to measure the terrain undulation. To fully integrate slope information into the MVS pipeline, we separately design two slope-guided modules to enhance reconstruction outcomes. Specifically, we designed a slope-guided interval partition module for refined height estimation using slope values. And, a height correction module is proposed, using a learnable Gaussian smoothing operator to amend the inaccurate height values. Additionally, to enhance the efficacy of height estimation, we proposed a slope direction loss for implicitly optimizing height estimation results. Extensive experiments on the WHU-TLC dataset and MVS3D dataset show that our proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance and demonstrates competitive generalization ability compared to all listed methods. Our code will be available at https://github.com/StriveZs/TS-SatMVSNet.

title: A Robustness Optimization Method for UAV Swarm Communication Network Topology Based on Flocking Behavior
authors: Zhen Yang, Xincong Li, Xingyu Wang, Yicong Li, Bao Zhang, Kaibo Yu, Deyun Zhou
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: In complex battlefield environments where adversarial attacks are frequent and UAV swarms are vulnerable to interference, the communication topology is prone to damage. To ensure the mission success rate of UAV swarms, optimizing network robustness is particularly important. In this context, this paper presents a study on enhancing the coordination capability of UAV swarms under enemy attacks and interference by implementing a zone-based isolation management method, a preventive optimization method based on a hierarchical simulated annealing algorithm (HSA) with small-world network characteristics, and a recovery optimization method based on a temporary leader mechanism. A communication topology model for UAV swarms is also established.The partitioned isolation management method divides the overall topology into multiple connected sub-topologies, thereby limiting the impact of faults or attacks within a specific area. The hierarchical simulated annealing method based on small-world networks optimizes the network topology within interference regions, reducing internal links while maintaining overall connectivity. In addition, when the topology is damaged, temporary leaders are selected to maintain the integrity of the remaining topology.Simulation results indicate that the proposed preventive robustness optimization method can effectively enhance the robustness of the communication network. The recovery optimization method maintains the connectivity of the remaining swarm topology and enables the reestablishment of the flocking state, demonstrating the practical effectiveness of the proposed robustness optimization approaches.

title: TA-CSA: A spatio-temporal framework with temporal aggregation and clustered spatial attention for traffic forecasting
authors: Peng Wang, Wenhao Zhang, Longxi Feng, Kanghua Hui
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Accurate traffic flow forecasting is crucial in intelligent transportation systems for mitigating congestion and enhancing intelligent traffic management. Although recent methods have shown excellent performance, they still encounter two major limitations: (i) Existing models face challenges in balancing prediction accuracy and computational efficiency. (ii) Existing spatial modeling methods use unified mechanisms to model all nodes, neglecting the inherent heterogeneity among them. To address these limitations, we propose a spatio-temporal architecture, TA-CSA for traffic prediction, which consists of Temporal Aggregation Pooling (TAP) and Clustered Spatial Attention (CSA). Specifically, in the temporal dimension, we design the temporal aggregation pooling module. This module extracts temporal features from multiple time windows through parallel pooling operations, thereby strengthening the model’s capacity to capture global temporal trends and dynamic fluctuations. In the spatial dimension, we introduce clustered spatial attention. The method employs hierarchical clustering to divide nodes with similar functional characteristics into the same cluster and performs local attention calculations to achieve regional-level spatial perception. Extensive experiments on six real-world traffic datasets demonstrate that TA-CSA consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in both routine and long-horizon forecasting tasks.

title: IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications
authors: N/A
publish: IEEE Security & Privacy

title: An Evolutionary Approach for the Computation of ∈-Locally Optimal Solutions for Multi-Objective Multimodal Optimization
authors: Carlos Hernández, Angel E. Rodriguez-Fernandez, Lennart Schäpermeier, Oliver Cuate, Heike Trautmann, Oliver Schütze
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of efficiently computing finite-size approximations of the set of -locally optimal solutions of a given multi-objective optimization problem (MOP). Such sets are in particular interesting in the context of multi-objective multimodal optimization (MMO). To this end, we first propose a bounded archiver, ArchiveUpdateLQ,∈B, that is, a modification of a previously proposed unbounded archiver. These archivers can be used as external archivers to in principle any multi-objective evolutionary algorithm (MOEA). In order to reduce the computational cost compared to such archive equipped MOEAs, we propose, in a next step LQ,∈MOEA. This evolutionary algorithm directly uses ArchiveUpdateLQ,∈B for the selection process and hence does not need an external archive for the computation of ∈-locally optimal solutions. We further propose a hybrid of LQ,∈MOEA with a multi-objective continuation method, which significantly improves the accuracy of the obtained solutions in case the gradient information is at hand. Finally, we show some numerical results that demonstrate the benefit of both the bounded archiver and the new MOEAs.

title: Minimal-Size 2-D Sources for Mask-Constrained Synthesis of Shaped Patterns
authors: Giada M. Battaglia, Andrea F. Morabito, Roberta Palmeri, Tommaso Isernia
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: We provide an effective deterministic solution to the canonical and, until now, unsolved problem of the optimal synthesis of 2-D mask-constrained shaped beams. In particular, for 2-D arrays on planar grids and continuous aperture sources with circular support, we identify the minimum source size required to achieve a given mask-constrained performance and, subsequently, synthesize such a source. Conversely, the proposed method can also determine and achieve the optimal performance attainable by a source of fixed size. The approach, based solely on convex programming and polynomial factorization, can accommodate completely arbitrary upper and lower bounds on the radiated power pattern. As such, it constitutes the first method capable of solving this problem without any restriction on the beam shape and footprint while completely avoiding the use of global optimization algorithms. The results from representative test cases demonstrate the ability of the method to find sources with provably minimal size, leading to significant reductions in the number of array elements compared with alternative designs. The effectiveness of the approach is further confirmed by the successful incorporation of full-wave simulated radiating elements, including mutual coupling effects.

title: DeVIL: A Dual Verification Framework for Integrity and Ownership of Light Field Images With Customizable Watermarking
authors: Wenying Wen, Yu Ye, Xiangli Xiao, Shuren Qi, Yuming Fang, Yushu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Light field (LF) images capture both spatial and angular data, providing enhanced detail in multi-view and 3D scenes, which makes them highly applicable across various domains. Thus, compared to traditional images, LF images not only contain more complex data and are more susceptible to unauthorized tampering or malicious uses during transmission due to their unique structure, thereby increasing the need for verification. Existing dual watermarking techniques are designed for single-view images and lack adaptability to the multi-view structure and geometric consistency of LF images, making it difficult to simultaneously address integrity verification and ownership verification for LF images. Given the multi-view characteristics and geometric consistency of LF images, there is an urgent need for a highly robust and adaptable dual watermarking method. Therefore, we propose a dual verification framework with customizable watermarking, called DeVIL, which specifically designed for LF images and enables both ownership and integrity verification. By embedding reversible ownership watermarks into the sub-aperture images (SAIs), affiliation can be verified after transmission. Among them, the embedding technique can flexibly choose either a reversible robust watermarking technique or a robust zero-watermarking technique based on different application scenarios. Subsequently, we perform Arnold transformation on key SAIs and embed them into non-key SAIs to create stego images, effectively reducing the risk of information leakage. Furthermore, integrity watermarks are embedded in the stego images, forming stego images with integrity watermarks to detect subtle tampering during transmission. Experimental results show that DeVIL can successfully recover SAIs and demonstrates strong robustness and adaptability against various attacks. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, DeVIL reduces the average bit error rate by 9.32% under different attacks, with average normalized cross-correlation improvement of 0.17, significantly enhancing the robustness of ownership protection in different datasets.

title: Experimental Investigation of the Charging Characteristics of Metal Particles in Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Liang Chen, Xiaolong Huang, Xiaoxi Le, Huikai Xu, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Metal particles generated under high-current conditions can significantly degrade the insulation performance of vacuum interrupters. Therefore, studying the dynamical behavior of these particles during the post-arc phase is of great importance. Driven by electric field forces, metal particles move between electrodes and undergo charge exchange upon colliding with them. This study employs experimental methods to investigate the charging characteristics of metal particles after electrode collisions, as well as the variation in their charge during movement across the electrode gap. The experimental results show that the amount of charge acquired by a particle after colliding with an electrode is positively correlated with the instantaneous macroscopic AC uniform electric field strength at the moment of impact. Once the particle detaches from the electrode and travels through the gap before the next collision, the charge it carries remains approximately constant. Furthermore, a particle that carries a charge of opposite polarity to the electrode will experience a reversal in charge polarity upon collision with the electrode. These findings provide a theoretical basis for the numerical simulation of metal particle dynamics during the post-arc phase in vacuum interrupters and contribute to a deeper understanding of the physical mechanisms underlying delayed breakdowns induced by such particles.

title: A Study of the Effect of Gap Differences on the Development of Vacuum Arcs
authors: Yunlong Jia, Chongyang Huang, Si Fu, Feiran Zhang, Zhengbo Li
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Taking double-break DC vacuum circuit breaker as the research object, the arc simulation calculation model is established to simulate and analyze the plasma distribution and arc development process in the arc starting stage of the interbreak arc under the contact gap difference caused by the nonsimultaneous movement of the mechanism dispersion, and the gap difference and non-difference conditions in the breaking process are obtained, as well as the magnetic field, temperature, and speed of the vacuum arc in the arc starting stage, Pressure distribution law and difference. Comparison of the two sets of simulation data, the results show that: compared with the gap no difference working conditions, the gap between the fracture gap difference, small gap between the fracture of the vacuum arc metal vapor concentration is high and the magnetic field is weak, the arc is not easy to diffuse state transition, which leads to local ablation; large gap fracture, the magnetic field effect is higher than the no-gap conditions, the speed of the plasma movement is accelerated.

title: Optimizing Vacuum Interrupters by a Suitable Selection of Contact Materials and Superimposed Axial Magnetic Fields
authors: Markus Fischer, Michael Beltle, Stefan Tenbohlen, Dietmar Gentsch
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: For most applications in medium voltage switchgears, vacuum interrupters are used. The switching arc during interruption processes in vacuum appearing at the mechanical contact separation is evaporated from the contact electrodes. Near the current zero crossing the arc gets instable due to decreasing energy input and can chop abruptly [1], [2]. This can be critical especially at low currents in inductive load circuits: The high current gradient induces transient overvoltages at the load, which can exceed the insulation strength and cause damages [3]. Also, secondary effects like disturbance emissions might affect safety-relevant components like protection relays in terms of electromagnetic compatibility (EMC). The arc chopping is characterized by the chopping current Ich, which represents the instantaneous value of the power frequency current before its interruption. To reduce this current two measures are considered in more detail. By a proper choice of the switching contact materials the arc should be maintained until current zero crossing. For the material properties this means a lowered evaporation temperature of the contact material. Optimized copper-based contact materials with additives of carbide and carbon show chopping values between $I_{\mathrm{ch}}=0.5 \mathrm{~A}$ and $I_{\mathrm{ch}}=3 \mathrm{~A}$. In line with [4]–[7], this work also examines the influence of superimposed (externally generated) axial magnetic fields on the arc chopping behavior. Measurements for the investigated copper-based materials indicate no optimization (reduction of $\left.I_{\mathrm{ch}}\right)$ due to the additional magnetic field. For a better classification of the chopping behavior a statistical evaluation is performed. This is necessary since $I_{c h}$ shows significant scattering even at constant test conditions. For the statistical analysis each series of measurements under constant flux density is performed with a predefined number of measurements (interruption operations). The median chopping currents and outliers of a vacuum chamber with superimposed magnetic field are evaluated. Additionally, for switching operations without applied magnetic field, a probability distribution of all $I_{\mathrm{ch}}$ values is considered.

title: Preliminary Experiment on Vacuum Breakdown Strength of Metal Electrode Materials
authors: Pan Dong, Jie Li, Longjian Ye
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Vacuum breakdown is one of the main causes of the failure of vacuum devices, and it is also the key factor restricting the miniaturization of devices such as accelerators. Vacuum breakdown mechanism is complex, including prebreakdown and breakdown. An experimental device for vacuum breakdown of differential metal electrodes has been set up, and five kinds of metal materials, Fe, Mo, Al, TC<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> and Cu, have been tested. The surface roughness is 0.2, which minimizes the influence of micro-tips. The tested surface morphologies have been observed by microscope, and the results show that 304 and Cu electrodes are anode-induced breakdown, whose vacuum breakdown field strength are lower, while AI, TC4 and Mo are cathode-induced breakdown, whose vacuum breakdown field strength are higher. The amount of gas adsorbed by different materials are different, which cause their vacuum breakdown model are different.

title: X-ray Radiation in 126 kV Vacuum Interrupters During Sequential Power-Frequency Conditioning and Comparative Analysis of Conditioning Methods
authors: Wei Sun, Huantong Shi, Peizhou Zhang, Jian Wu, Xingwen Li
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In this paper, the evolution of X-ray radiation characteristics during sequential power-frequency voltage conditioning processes of a single 126 kV vacuum interrupter (VI) is investigated, and the effectiveness of three conditioning methods from a radiation perspective are compared. Experiments were conducted using a self-designed spectrometer to measure X-ray dose and spectrum during sequential conditioning processes. It was found a progressive reduction in total X-ray dose and significant spectral hardening across five conditioning experiments. Comparative analysis of three methods revealed that high-current preconditioning reduced subsequent power-frequency conditioning dose rate by $35 \%$ and softened the spectrum, compared with conventional powerfrequency voltage conditioning.

title: A Computer-Aided Intelligent Evaluation Model for Accounting Data Quality Improvement in Data Governance: Algorithms and Case Studies
authors: Xiaochen Huang, Lin Zhang, Yuchen Luo, Jiayang He, Nan Zhang, Siyuan Chen
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: With the digital transformation, accounting data quality issues (e.g., duplication, inconsistency) pose significant challenges to enterprise decision-making. This paper presents a computer-aided intelligent evaluation model for accounting data quality, integrating machine learning algorithms (e.g., decision trees, SEM) and blockchain-based traceability technologies within the data governance framework. Through empirical analysis of 130 enterprises and case studies in manufacturing/finance sectors, the research demonstrates that the model enhances data accuracy by 25%-40% and reduces error rates via automated cleaning and real-time monitoring. Key innovations include: (1) a hybrid governance model integrating structural equation modeling and clustering algorithms; (2) blockchain-based data integrity verification system; (3) NLP-driven real-time quality monitoring mechanism.

title: Virtual Roads, Smarter Safety: A Digital Twin Framework for Mixed Autonomous Traffic Safety Analysis
authors: Hao Zhang, Ximin Yue, Kexin Tian, Sixu Li, Keshu Wu, Zihao Li, Dominique Lord, Yang Zhou
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: This paper presents a digital-twin platform for active safety analysis in mixed traffic environments. The platform is built using a multi-modal data-enabled traffic environment constructed from drone-based aerial LiDAR, OpenStreetMap, and vehicle sensor data (e.g., Global Positioning System (GPS) and inclinometer readings). High-resolution 3D road geometries are generated through AI-powered semantic segmentation and georeferencing of aerial LiDAR data. To simulate real-world driving scenarios, the platform integrates the CAR Learning to Act (CARLA) simulator, Simulation of Urban MObility (SUMO) traffic model, and NVIDIA PhysX vehicle dynamics engine. CARLA provides detailed micro-level sensor and perception data, while SUMO manages macro-level traffic flow. NVIDIA PhysX enables accurate modeling of vehicle behaviors under diverse conditions, accounting for mass distribution, tire friction, and center of mass. This integrated system supports high-fidelity simulations that capture the complex interactions between autonomous and conventional vehicles. Experimental results demonstrate the platform’s ability to reproduce realistic vehicle dynamics and traffic scenarios, enhancing the analysis of active safety measures. Overall, the proposed framework advances traffic safety research by enabling in-depth, physics-informed evaluation of vehicle behavior in dynamic and heterogeneous traffic environments.

title: A Novel Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons Unit With Dual-Band Negative Group Delay
authors: Guodong Lu, Yiqin Liu, Weiwen Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Plasma Science
abstract: Spoof surface plasmon polariton (SSPP) structures with negative group delay (NGD) have generally been restricted to single-band operation. To overcome this limitation, this work presents a novel SSPP unit that achieves dual-band NGD by simultaneously exhibiting single-negative permittivity and single-negative permeability. The proposed unit provides group delays of −5.5 and −2.4 ns at 1.86 and 2.78 GHz, respectively, representing significantly enhanced compensation capability compared with prior reports. By embedding this NGD unit into a conventional SSPP waveguide, both Gaussian pulses and double-sideband (DSB)-modulated signals are effectively compensated, leading to envelope advancement and reduced propagation delay. The results confirm that the proposed dual-band NGD mechanism broadens the functionalities of SSPP systems and offers strong potential for applications in high-speed communication, synchronous transmission, and real-time sensing.

title: HLSWI: A Simple yet Effective Water Index Using Harmonized Landsat-Sentinel-2 Data for Complex Scenarios
authors: Sihan Meng, Xin Hu, Manlin Wang, Yao Li, Jie Wang, Zhixiang Yin, Penghai Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: As a vital resource for the Earth’s ecological environment, effective extraction of surface water has a profound impact on human livelihoods and socio-economic development. Currently, water indices based on satellite imagery are widely used for surface water extraction. However, their accuracy remains significantly limited in complex scenarios—such as urban areas with high- and low-reflectivity buildings and shadow interference, sediment-laden or eutrophic water bodies, and intricate water–land transition zones. These limitations typically manifest in the failure to detect smaller water bodies, unclear water edges, and the presence of surrounding noise. To address these challenges, this study introduces a novel and practical water-body index—the Harmonized Landsat-Sentinel Water Index (HLSWI)—based on the Harmonized Landsat and Sentinel-2 dataset. HLSWI integrates the complementary spectral characteristics of the Landsat OLI and Sentinel-2 MSI sensors and optimizes classification thresholds via the ISO-Data clustering algorithm. HLSWI’s effectiveness is assessed through comparisons with seven commonly adopted water indices across 14 study areas worldwide and three representative complex scenarios, covering various surface types, including wetlands, arid zones, and urban aquatic environments. Experimental findings indicate that HLSWI outperforms the other seven water indices, reducing total water extraction errors by an average of 1.18% to 5.55% and improving overall accuracy and the Kappa coefficient by 1.42%–3.63% and 0.02–0.05, respectively. Therefore, HLSWI serves as a simple yet effective tool for surface water detection using optical remote sensing imagery and provides essential technical support for water extraction in complex environments.

title: A Color Correction Method for Multiple Non-uniformly Illuminated Whisk-broom Optical Satellite Images
authors: Tao Peng, Mi Wang, Qianyu Wu, Ru Chen, Jun Pan, Qiongqiong Lan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Achieving color consistency is essential for stitching large-area optical satellite imagery. The narrow swath width of individual images, combined with varying acquisition conditions, inherently introduces color differences. These manifest as marked disparities in brightness, color tone, and local contrast, degrading overall regional consistency. Existing methods primarily focus on correcting color inconsistencies between adjacent images, while often overlooking intra-image illumination non-uniformity, thereby propagating radiometric errors into optimization frameworks. Whisk-broom sensors, which can acquire imagery over a much wider swath width along the parallels, frequently exhibit substantial intra-image brightness variations, particularly in high-latitude regions. Compounded by frequent cloud cover and rapid temporal changes of features, extracting reliable color correspondences for optimization becomes intractable. To address these challenges, we propose a novel color correction framework that simultaneously considers intra-image illumination non-uniformity and radiometric variations caused by cloud prevalence and dynamic surface changes. First, a solar elevation angle map is extracted for down-sampled source image based on their geographic metadata and sensor geometry. An inverse compensation based on the normalized sine value of the solar elevation angle is then applied to mitigate brightness disparities caused by varying incident radiance. Second, to address atmospheric effects that vary with wavelength, such as differential absorption and scattering that cause color casts especially in low-illumination regions, a reference spectral channel is selected to guide the correction. Finally, we introduce a hybrid strategy for selecting reliable color correspondences in overlapping regions, using both grayscale and texture similarity under complex coverage conditions. Residual radiometric information is incorporated into a cost function, which jointly considers original color control and overall color balance to enhance the global consistency of the corrected mosaic. Extensive experiments conducted on imagery from the Wide Swath Imager (WSI) of DaQi-1 (DQ-1) and the Chinese Ocean Color and Temperature Scanner (COCTS) of HaiYang-1E (HY-1E) demonstrate that the proposed method effectively removes uneven illumination and color discrepancies. Compared to three state-of-the-art methods, our approach achieves superior performance in both visual quality and quantitative metrics.

title: Domain Knowledge-Informed Few-Shot Fault Diagnosis of Multiple Low-Severity Faults in PMSGs Under Imbalanced Loads
authors: Du Nguyen, Van Khang Huynh, Kjell G. Robbersmyr
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Electrical experts can readily diagnose high-severity faults in permanent magnet synchronous generators (PMSGs) using a few samples of harmonic order data in the time-frequency domain, leveraging their prior knowledge of interturn short circuits, local demagnetization, and mixed faults. However, traditional harmonic analysis methods are often hindered by low signal amplitude, noise, and overlap with various operating conditions, which present significant challenges for intelligent fault detection and identification models. Moreover, the high similarity between healthy and faulty signatures, combined with the scarcity of faulty samples across diverse operating scenarios, leads to high misclassification rates in conventional FDI models. To address these challenges, this article proposes an explainable few-shot learning architecture that integrates symmetrical components and harmonic analysis to classify incipient faults using only a small number of samples under multiple operating conditions. A convolutional neural network–based attention mechanism is employed to extract physical features of PMSGs in both normal and abnormal states. The proposed model achieves 89% accuracy with 20 shots, outperforming the pretrained ResNet50 (43%) on a 4320 sample PMSG dataset. The precision, recall, and F1-score metrics are used for validating the predictions. Additionally, by incorporating physical domain knowledge, the model can generate interpretable predictions with visual explanations of its inference process, aligning with the transparency and accountability principles mandated by the EU AI Act for high-risk systems in the energy sector.

title: HashTAG With CALM: Low-Overhead Hardware Support for Inter-Task Eviction Monitoring
authors: Pablo Andreu, Pedro Lopez, Carles Hernandez
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Multicore processors have emerged as the preferred architecture for safetycritical systems due to their significant performance advantages. However, concurrent access by multiple cores to a shared cache induces intercore evictions that generate nondeterministic interference and compromise timing predictability. Static partitioning of the cache among cores is a wellestablished countermeasure that effectively eliminates such evictions but reduces flexibility and system throughput. To accurately estimate inter-core cache contention, Auxiliary Tag Directories (ATDs) are widely adopted. However, ATDs incur substantial hardware area costs, which often motivates the use of heuristic-based reductions. These reduced ATD designs, while more compact, compromise accuracy and therefore are not suitable for safety-critical domains. This paper extends the proposal of HashTAG, a novel approach to accurately upper-bound inter-core eviction interference. HashTAG introduces a safe and lightweight Auxiliary Tag Directory mechanism that tracks which cores are responsible for evicting cache lines used by others, thus measuring contention. We further refine the proposed HashTAG approach by creating CALM, a custom-made memory allocator that significantly improves HashTAG performance in multicore systems. Our results show that no inter-task interference underprediction is possible with HashTAG, making it suitable for the safety domain. HashTAG provides a 47% reduction in the Auxiliary Tag Directory area, presenting perfect measurements on 80% of cases and only a 1% error on maximum inter-core eviction measurements for a HashTAG tag size of ten bits.

title: A Broadband Single-Ended-to-Differential Converter in 28-nm CMOS
authors: Yunchen Li, Zhen Chen, Lingjun Zhou, Junbo Zhu, Chen Zhang, Daoqun Liu, Xiaomin Nie, Mengqi Wu, Xiaoqi Peng, Zhenyi Yang, Lei Wang, Fan Zhang, Ke Li
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a broadband single-ended-to-differential (S2D) converter implemented in a standard 28-nm CMOS process. The design leverages cascode current-mode logic (CML) amplifiers with embedded asymmetric transformers (ATRs) and achieves reliable operation over a wide frequency range from 10 MHz to 65 GHz, maintaining phase error (PE) and gain error (GE) within ±6° and ±0.4 dB, respectively. Eye diagram measurements confirm the ability to support <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</small> keying (OOK) signals from 1 to 128 GBaud and four-level pulse amplitude modulation (PAM-4) signals from 1 to 112 GBaud. The total power consumption is 139 mW, including 17 mW for the S2D core and 122 mW for the buffer modules. The S2D core occupies only 0.027 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, making it attractive for high-speed wireline transceivers.

title: DMformer: Difficulty-adapted Masked Transformer for Semi-Supervised Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Zelin Peng, Guanchun Wang, Zhengqin Xu, Xiaokang Yang, Wei Shen
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: The shared anatomy among different human bodies can serve as a strong prior for effectively leveraging unlabeled data in semi-supervised medical image segmentation. Inspired by the success of masked image modeling, we notice that this prior can be explicitly realized by incorporating an auxiliary unsupervised gross anatomy reconstruction task into a teacher-student semi-supervised segmentation framework. In this auxiliary task, consistency is maintained between the student's predictions on masked images and the teacher's predictions on the original images. Despite its potential, we observe that the reconstruction difficulties of different organs/tissues can vary significantly and therefore reconstructing them requires tailored learning strategies. To address this issue, we introduce a difficulty-adapted mask mechanism based on the teacher-student framework, wherein the reconstruction difficulty is adapted to facilitate training. Specifically, we control the reconstruction difficulty by modulating two important factors: masked region ratio and masked class ratio. Accordingly, we design two corresponding mask strategies. 1) Region-based masking: randomly masks a fraction of each class according to an automatically computed mask ratio. 2) Class-based masking: masks the entire regions of the specific classes according to the class confidence predicted by the teacher model. During training, a conflict-aware gradient computation strategy is introduced to mitigate potential optimization conflicts arising from modulating the two reconstruction factors simultaneously. By building on vision transformers, we develop an Difficulty-adapted Masked Transformer (DMformer) for semi-supervised medical image segmentation. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of DMformer, which outperforms the previous SOTA by 9.53% and 4.63% in terms of DSC on ACDC dataset with 5% labeled images and Synapse dataset with 30% labeled images, respectively. Code is available at: https://github.com/SJTU-DeepVisionLab/DMformer.

title: Multiobjective Task Allocation for Electric Harvesting Robots: A Hierarchical Route Reconstruction Approach
authors: Peng Chen, Jing Liang, Hui Song, Kang-Jia Qiao, Cai-Tong Yue, Kun-Jie Yu, Ponnuthurai Nagaratnam Suganthan, Witold Pedrycz
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: The increasing labor costs in agriculture have accelerated the adoption of multirobot systems for orchard harvesting. However, efficiently coordinating these systems is challenging due to the complex interplay between makespan and energy consumption, particularly under practical constraints like load-dependent speed variations and battery limitations. This article defines the multiobjective agricultural multielectrical-robot task allocation (AMERTA) problem, which systematically incorporates these often-overlooked real-world constraints. To address this problem, we propose a hybrid hierarchical route reconstruction algorithm (HRRA) that integrates several innovative mechanisms, including a hierarchical encoding structure, a dual-phase initialization method, task-sequence optimizers, and specialized route reconstruction operators. Extensive experiments on 45 test instances demonstrate HRRA’s superior performance against seven state-of-the-art algorithms. Statistical analysis, including the Wilcoxon signed-rank and Friedman tests, empirically validates HRRA’s competitiveness and its unique ability to explore previously inaccessible regions of the solution space. In general, this research contributes to the theoretical understanding of multirobot coordination by offering a novel problem formulation and an effective algorithm, thereby also providing practical insights for agricultural automation.

title: Cost-Stability Evaluation Framework for Reliable Deployment of Object Detectors in Industrial Applications
authors: Kuhyun Lee, Jihoon Hong, Beom-Seok Kim, Yuna Song, Dong-Hee Lee
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The practical deployment of object detectors is often hindered by a gap between standard academic metrics and real-world requirements—namely, performance at a specific operating threshold, cost-asymmetric errors, and performance stability under distribution shifts. To bridge this gap, we introduce the Cost-Stability Evaluation Framework (CSEF), a systematic workflow that transforms the selection of a model and its operating threshold from a heuristic practice to a rational, data-driven decision process. CSEF operationalizes user-defined requirements—an IoU threshold (τ) for localization accuracy; a cost asymmetry parameter (β) that serves as the recall-to-precision weight in the F-beta score; and a maximum tolerable performance degradation (σ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">req</sub>)—to algorithmically recommend the most operationally reliable model–threshold pair. CSEF first selects the threshold that maximizes the F-beta score on the validation set, and then quantifies robustness as the relative change in the F-beta score, σ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">deg</sub>, from the validation set to an unseen held-out test set. Candidates that pass a conservative stability gate—where the bootstrap upper bound of |σ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">deg</sub>| does not exceed σ<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">req</sub>—are then ranked by their operational F-beta score at the fixed threshold. CSEF’s utility is demonstrated across four industrial scenarios, from medical imaging to semiconductor manufacturing, highlighting its adaptability to domain-specific requirements. Ultimately, CSEF provides a practical and auditable methodology for deploying object detectors with predictable performance and reliability, thereby helping close the long-standing gap between academic evaluation and industrial deployment.

title: A Review of Assets'2024 from a Newbie Academic
authors: Martin Lettry
publish: ACM SIGACCESS Accessibility and Computing
abstract: My name is Martin Lettry, I'm a master's student in Computer Science at EPFL in Switzerland and an alumnus of the University of Lugano (USI), also in Switzerland. My academic journey has been significantly impacted by my collaboration with LighthouseTech – a startup developing smart glasses for blind and visually impaired (BVI) people. As part of my bachelor thesis, I focused on defining default settings for these glasses through user testing with BVI individuals in Milan and Bern.

title: Retraction Notice: An Automated Cost Prediction in Uber/Call Taxi Using Machine Learning Algorithm
authors: Elizabeth Rani. G, Sakthimohan. M, Revanth Raj. R, Sri Ganesh. M, Shyam Sunder. R, Karthigadevi. K
publish: 2022 2nd International Conference on Advance Computing and Innovative Technologies in Engineering (ICACITE)
abstract: Uber, Ola, Meru Cabs, and other cab businesses have sprung up in recent years. And these taxi firms serve tens of thousands of people every day. It is now critical for them to correctly manage their data in order to come up with fresh business ideas and get the greatest outcomes. As a result, it becomes critical to precisely predict the fares. The motive of this paper is to compare all the fare details of specified cabs and predict the lowest fare cab using linear regression method. In this paper we implemented prediction model for the three models like Uber Go, Go Sedan and Uber Auto. Here deviation of the cab fares also compared and using these data, build an application that can assist the users to select the cab with the determined benefits and lowest fare. In this model we use machine learning technique of linear Regression model, and it may contain labelled data. Here the methodology and outcomes of this work can contribute to a more real-world demand. This application can improve the transport accessibility, reduce waiting time and reduce the transportation fare etc.

authors: Abdullah, Kanta Prasad Sharma Gupta

abstract: The software engineering stages assisted by means of deep learning to know due to the variety of SE responsibilities, it is vital to perceive the present SE duties assisted through deep learning, given that it supports practitioners locate the plausible to leverage deep learning knowledge of in their personal glitches. The framework bridges the gap amongst item orientated blueprint traits, maintainability and Stability. Framework measures and improves the maintainability of software program blueprint on the blueprint degree of software program improvement lifestyles cycle, maximum massive to a dependable cease product. Stability and maintainability estimation fashions were proposed through the use of the evolved framework. Stability estimation version has been formulated which takes item orientated blueprint traits into attention and proposed Stability estimation fashions take maintainability in attention for enumerating stability of object oriented blueprint.

title: Experimental Study on the Dynamic Behavior of Cathode Molten Pool Particles During High-Current Vacuum Interruption
authors: Xiaoxi Le, Huikai Xu, Liang Chen, Saikang Shen, Xiaolong Huang, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Delayed breakdown in high-voltage vacuum circuit breakers has emerged as a critical challenge to reliable current interruption and is increasingly attributed to the influence of metal particles. The intense energy injection during high-current vacuum arcs can induce vigorous boiling on the cathode surface, leading to the emission of large, slow-moving, high-temperature metal particles. These particles may act as potential triggers for post-arc restrikes. In this study, a laser shadow technique was employed to experimentally observe the continuous motion of cathode molten pool particles under realistic interruption conditions. Both the overall motion characteristics and representative particle trajectories were extracted and analyzed. The results show that particle dynamics are strongly influenced by arc plasma forces, and that prolonged cathode molten pool particle residence in the post-arc gap may interfere with dielectric recovery. This work provides experimental evidence for the role of metal particles in delayed breakdown mechanisms and offers valuable insights for improving the interruption performance of high-voltage vacuum breakers.

title: ADNAC: Audio Denoiser using Neural Audio Codec
authors: Daniel Jimon, Mircea Vaida, Adriana Stan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Speech Technology and Human-Computer Dialogue (SpeD)
abstract: Audio denoising is critical in signal processing, enhancing intelligibility and fidelity for applications like restoring musical recordings. This paper presents a proof-of-concept for adapting a state-of-the-art neural audio codec, the Descript Audio Codec (DAC), for music denoising. This work overcomes the limitations of traditional architectures like UNets by training the model on a large-scale, custom-synthesized dataset built from diverse sources. Training is guided by a multi-objective loss function that combines time-domain, spectral, and signal-level fidelity metrics. Ultimately, this paper aims to present a PoC for high-fidelity, generative audio restoration.

title: Study on Vacuum Surface Insulation Properties of Sulfur/Fluorine-Containing Specialty Polyimide Films Targeting Space High-Voltage Solar Array Applications
authors: Changchun Qi, Xiong Yang, Haoyan Liu, Wenrui Li, Baipeng Song, Guan-Jun Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Polyimide (PI), as a critical insulating material for spacecraft solar arrays, has its surface insulation stability directly impacting the reliability of space power systems. With future spacecraft power systems advancing towards higher voltage and higher power levels, the vacuum flashover issue of polyimide is anticipated to become more severe. To address these challenges, this study fabricated specialty polyimide films incorporating sulfur (SO-PI) and fluorine (CF-PI). Utilizing a custom three-parameter evaluation methodology based on the first breakdown voltage ($U_{\mathrm{fb}}$), conditioned voltage ($U_{\mathrm{co}}$), and hold-off voltage ($U_{\mathrm{ho}}$), the surface insulation performance of these materials under vacuum was systematically characterized. Experimental results demonstrate that the specialty films exhibit significantly reduced surface charge accumulation and a higher withstand voltage threshold compared to commercial polyimide. Notably, the $\boldsymbol{U}_{\mathrm{fb}}$ value of CF-PI showed a $24.74 \%$ improvement over that of commercial PI. This research provides valuable insights for the design of insulating materials in high-voltage space power systems.

title: Influence of Oxygen on Contact Erosion in Vacuum Circuit Breakers
authors: Bingjie Shi, Jing Li, Wei Duan, Chongyang Huang, Si Fu, Yue Fu
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: During interruption, vacuum circuit breakers generate intense arc energy that erodes the contact surfaces, severely impairing their interruption success rate and electrical lifespan. Aging tests cannot fully remove residual air from the contact surfaces, and this trapped oxygen markedly alters the erosion mechanisms.This study compares erosion characteristics under two conditions-residual air in the arc chamber (as in aging tests) versus an ideal vacuum-with a focus on how oxygen content influences contact erosion. We developed an oxidation-kinetics model for contact erosion by modifying the momentum-conservation equation and treating the dissolved oxygen concentration in the molten metal as a function of temperature. The model accounts for changes in surface-tension coefficients caused by dissolved oxygen, which drive Marangoni flows and reshape the molten crater, as well as the resulting variations in droplet size and ejection angle.By contrasting the two environments, we examined differences in crater morphology, mass - loss rate, and splashed - droplet characteristics. Our results show that as vacuum level increases, both erosion morphology and erosion rate change significantly. In lower - vacuum (higher - pressure) conditions, oxygen participation leads to relatively shallower erosion depths. Conversely, in higher - vacuum environments - where gas molecules are scarce-the erosion depth increases, while droplet sizes decrease and ejection angles narrow.

title: Toward Practical and Scalable Adoption of Nonce-Based Content Security Policy on the Web
authors: Anhao Xiang, Mengxia Ren, Chuan Yue, James Crea, Jack Kingham, Zachary Samuels
publish: IEEE Security & Privacy
abstract: Content Security Policy is a widely supported browser mechanism designed to mitigate content injection attacks. However, its real-world adoption remains limited, and many existing deployments are insecure due to the complexity of writing and maintaining secure policies.

title: A Transformer-Based Model for Predicting the Continuous Purchasing Behavior of Bank Customers
authors: Xiaoguo Wang, Jianfei Xiao, Hongming Zhu, Chao Chen, Huanzhang Li
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: In response to the practical business need for banks to predict customer behavior in continuously purchasing wealth management products, we propose a Transformer-based model for predicting the Continuous Purchasing Behavior of Bank Customers (CPBBCformer). We employ a multi-scale feature fusion approach, which simultaneously extracts and integrates features from different time scales. This not only captures short-term fluctuations in customer behavior but also reveals periodic behaviors and long-term trends, thus providing a more comprehensive understanding of customer behavior characteristics. Additionally, we propose a position encoding method that combines time series length and embedding dimensions to enhance the model's ability to perceive the distance between different time points. Experimental results show that, compared to other baseline models, the CPBBCformer model outperforms the competing models on relevant public datasets, validating its effectiveness.

title: Research on the Sensitive Data Supervision Based on Blockchain
authors: Yu Meng, Jiarun Huang, Xingchuan Liu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Blockchain technology of technical characteristics and the height of the judicial practice of the digital age, determines the blockchain is suitable for the judicial certificate, the rule of law supervision and the possibility of collaborative scenarios, blockchain technology applied to the judicial field, effectively make up for the deficiency of the traditional data supervision system of the rule of law, solve the data in the supervision of the rule of law data island, data security, lack of trust and lax supervision. In this paper around the blockchain technology can explore the rule of law construction, analysis of blockchain technology in the practice of the application of sensitive data supervision, lack of unified standard and algorithm mechanism challenges, and combined with the judicial supervision mode put forward the corresponding solutions and Suggestions, power blockchain technology and the rule of law supervision construction mutual traction, iterative development.

title: Research on the Equilibrium Model of a Four-Layer Dual-Channel Supply Chain Supernetwork under Random Demand
authors: Ping Li, Huanming Zhao
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Against the backdrop of the deepening process of global economic integration, the economic systems of various countries have formed a closely interconnected situation. This interdependence has greatly promoted the evolution and innovation of the supply chain system. In the face of increasingly fierce market competition, enterprises at all links of the supply chain are actively exploring more efficient development paths to enhance overall competitiveness. This study focuses on the equilibrium problem of a dual-channel supply chain hypernetwork under random demand conditions, aiming to provide scientific decision support for supply chain participants. The supply chain hypernetwork model constructed in this study includes four key levels: suppliers, manufacturers, retailers, and end consumers. Based on the traditional supply chain architecture, this study particularly introduces the direct sales channel of manufacturers, enabling them to sell products directly to consumers through e-commerce platforms; at the same time, retailers adopt a hybrid sales model combining online and offline. To address the uncertainty of consumer demand, a random demand model is adopted to enhance the practical applicability of the research. Through a systematic analysis of the decision-making elements of participants at each level, this study establishes the corresponding optimal decision objective function and transforms it into an equilibrium model through the variational inequality method. This research not only expands the research scope of traditional supply chain theory but also provides a new analytical framework for strategic decision-making of enterprises in complex market environments.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Discount Strategies on Customer Behavior Using Random Forest Regression on JD.com
authors: Qianhao Zhu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 2nd International Conference on Digital Economy, Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence
abstract: With the rapid development of e-commerce, JD.com has expanded its market share through a series of promotional strategies. However, different promotional methods have varying impacts on consumer purchasing behavior. This article studies the use of K-means clustering to divide sub samples based on customer characteristics and apply a multi model comparison method to predict the response of JD users with different characteristics to sales promotion. Specifically, customers were segmented into three clusters, labeling high-value customers, potential consumers, and regular customers. Linear Regression, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting models were trained for each group. Results show that the Random Forest Regression achieves the best performance overall in predicting click-to-order conversion rates, with MSE of 0.020066, 0.020228 and 0.020878 in the test set of the three clusters. The analysis of feature importance finds that the ‘direct_discount_ratio’ is a key factor affecting purchasing decisions. In addition, Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) analysis further reveals an inverted U-shaped relationship between direct discounts and ‘click_order_ratio’. This discovery emphasizes the widespread effectiveness of direct discounts in stimulating purchasing desires among various types of users. The study provides data-driven decision support for e-commerce platforms, which has important practical significance and helps optimize promotional strategies and enhance investment returns.

title: Enabling Synchronous Hybrid Participation at Assets 2024
authors: Oliver Alonzo, Emma J. McDonnell, Jesse J. Martinez, Jay Henderson
publish: ACM SIGACCESS Accessibility and Computing
abstract: The ACM ASSETS conference is the premier venue for accessible computing research, and it is dedicated to providing access to all attendees. At ASSETS 2024 we were determined to establish a hybrid conference to provide synchronous access to remote attendees, which served as an accessible option for community members who were not attending in-person. This newsletter article details our hybrid setup, which consisted of Zoom, Discord, and YouTube. Combining these tools enabled both synchronous and asynchronous participation across different tracks. Our model was well received by the community. We hope that sharing our setup can be a valuable contribution towards more robust synchronous, accessible, and integrated hybrid conference experiences.

title: Patch Type Antenna with Rectangular Slots for Future WiFi Communication Networks
authors: Valentinas Breivė, Diana Belova-Plonienė, Raimondas Pomarnacki, Audrius Krukonis, Andrius Katkevičius, Darius Plonis
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and full-wave analysis of a 24 GHz rectangular microstrip patch antenna whose copper patch contains a centered rectangular cut-out. Baseline dimensions for patch length, width and effective permittivity are derived from classical cavity model equations, followed by antenna refinement in CST Studio Suite via the finite integration technique transient solver. The cut-out is first left unfilled and then successively loaded with n-type germanium inserts at four doping concentrations to assess material-filled slot tuning. Simulation results show that a lightly doped Ge fill shifts the fundamental resonance upward by approximately 1.3 GHz and expands the bandwidth from 4 % to 7 % while the far-field pattern remains essentially unchanged. Heavier doping offers little additional benefit but preserves beam pointing and side-lobe levels. Although the Ge insert reduces realized gain by ~3 dB, it provides a fabrication friendly route to bandwidth enhancement without multilayer stacking or footprint growth. The findings supply practical guidance for compact millimeter-wave Wi-Fi and short-range radar front ends that require wider bandwidth yet can accommodate a moderate gain trade-off.

title: Architectural Requirements for Digital Twin Development Platform: A Review of Scientific Literature and Practical Considerations
authors: Gusts Linkevičs, Guntis Mosāns, Jānis Kampars, Rasa Gulbe
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This paper presents an edge-cloud Digital Twin (DT) development platform designed to support modular, scalable, and data-driven applications in smart cities and other complex domains. The architecture supports full DT lifecycle management, emphasizing flexible composition, real-time monitoring, and analytics-driven decision-making.A conceptual model defines the core components and their orchestration across development, monitoring, simulation, and data integration layers. A complementary usage model formalizes the iterative process from DT configuration to operational control. The platform’s design prioritizes modular reuse, resolution-aware abstraction, and system-wide orchestration over visualization-centric implementations, offering a strong foundation for advanced DT ecosystems.

title: Autoformer Neural Network Framework for Solid Particles Prognosis in Diesel Generator
authors: Tomas Sirutavičius, Patryk Osuch, Bartlomiej Byczuk, Mirosław Rucki, Artūras Kilikevičius, Tadas Žvirblis
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: Economic growth led to an increase in global energy consumption, with electricity and fossil fuels seeing significant growth from 2010 to 2017 by 19.4% and fossil fuels by 9.1%, respectively.. The development of smart, eco-friendly diesel generators and the application of advanced artificial intelligence algorithms for optimizing control and reducing emissions are becoming increasingly important in industrial automation. In this study, the autoformer neural network framework was developed and adopted to diesel generator for solid particles prognosis. Vibration, sound, and thermal images of exhaust gases were used as input parameters for the autoformer’s predictions. Generator was loaded with 0.0 kW, 0.3 kW, 0.6 kW, 1.0 kW, 1.3 kW, 1.6 kW, and 2.0 kW power and particle sizes of 0.3 µm, 0.5 µm, 1.0 µm, 2.5 µm, 5.0 µm, and 10.0 µm were measured in exhausted gases. The developed autoformer model showed the best results when the generator was working with loaded 0.6 kW power, the MAPE were 2.7%, 4.6%, 2.4%, 0.9%, 2.2%, and 0.9% for 0.3 µm, 0.5 µm, 1.0 µm, 2.5 µm, 5.0 µm, and 10.0 µm sized particles, respectively. Despite the fact that the accuracy of the autoformer should be better under other generator load conditions. Overall, the results show that the model is advantageous and suitable for predicting exhaust particles.

title: The Example of Using MHD Theory and CFD Software for Simulating the Behavior of an Electric Arc
authors: Veljko Djurkovic, Vladan Radulovic
publish: 2025 IEEE 12th Workshop on Advances in Information, Electronic and Electrical Engineering (AIEEE)
abstract: This paper presents the possibilities of using MHD (Magnetohydrodynamics) theory for analyzing the behavior of an electric arc, with the use of CFD (Computational Fluid Dynamics) software tools. These software packages are based on the finite element theory, with the assumption of local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE). This approach treats the electric arc as a conductive fluid, including all its electromagnetic properties. The simulation was conducted using Ansys Fluent software, through the built-in MHD module, as well as user-defined functions (UDFs). As an example, an initialized plasma channel of an electric arc was considered based on a model found in the literature, which was simplified to save computational resources and simulation time. The model includes the anode, cathode, and the so-called "splitter," which serves to separate the arc, cool it down, and increase its resistance. The movement of the arc is demonstrated through natural dynamics caused by temperature increases, as well as forced movement due to the Lorentz force from an external magnetic field. Due to these factors, the electric arc moves upward through the geometry design, increasing its length, after which separation and cooling occur, significantly reducing the conductivity of the plasma channel as its length increases. The surrounding medium is air. The paper covers all necessary aspects of modeling the electric arc, as well as the selection of appropriate physical models that describe the properties of air during the arc’s duration. This simulation demonstrates the potential use of the aforementioned theory for analyzing various geometries of switching equipment in alternating and direct current systems, which could serve as a significant complement to practical experiments.

title: Bellows mechanical endurance research of vacuum interrupter in embedded pole
authors: Min Li, Zhanwei Tu, Zhongjun Liu, Guangli He, Baochun Song
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: The bellows mechanical endurance of vacuum interrupter has been investigated in embedded pole with atmosphere air in cubicle. The mechanical stress of bellows can be reduced $8.4 \%$ percent by adding one more convolution. The mechanical endurance of vacuum interrupter can reach over 50000 operations in embedded pole by adding one more convolution or by changing material from $\mathbf{3 1 6 L}$ to $\mathbf{3 1 6 T i}$. The vacuum interrupter can pass 48 kV power frequency test after mechanical endurance test.

title: Optimization of Vacuum Interrupter Contact Structure Based on GWO-SVR
authors: Jingjie Yang, Xiaoming Liu, Hai Chen, Xingwang Wang, Shang Qian, Qiyang Shuai
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: Contact structure is an important factor affecting the breaking performance of vacuum interrupter (VI). In order to improve the breaking performance of VI, this paper takes $27.5 \mathrm{kV} / 2500 \mathrm{~A} / 31.5 \mathrm{kA}$ vacuum circuit breaker as the research object, optimizes the contact structure by combining support vector regression and grey wolf optimizer (GWO-SVR). Firstly, the central composite design method is used to construct different contact structure parameters (slot length of contact piece, slot width of contact piece, slot deflection angle of contact piece, inclined slot depth, and cup seat thickness). The magnetic field strength of the center surface of the different contact structure parameters at the peak current is calculated by the finite element method. Then, the GWO-SVR model is constructed with the contact structure parameters as the input, and the maximum magnetic field strength and the radial kurtosis value of the central surface between the poles as the output. Finally, the GWO-SVR model is optimized by NSGA-II to obtain the optimal contact structure parameters and improve the control ability of the axial magnetic field to the vacuum arc.

title: Arc Transfer Characteristics in Targeted Current Conditioning for Vacuum Interrupters
authors: Chaozheng Peng, Xiaoshe Zhai, Zhichao Chen, Haojie Jia, Shaoming Shi, Xiangzhe Li, Jin Yu, Jianhua Wang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: This study experimentally validates targeted current conditioning (TCC) for vacuum interrupters through synchronized optical-electrical diagnostics. Experiments employed a demountable vacuum chamber with axial magnetic contacts under high-vacuum conditions. During multiple TCC discharges at controlled parameters, arc dynamics were captured using high-speed imaging with precise synchronization. Key findings demonstrate: Strong spatial correlation between initial breakdown sites and sustained arcing positions after current-holding phases, confirming consistent weak-spot targeting; Progressive redistribution of breakdown locations across the contact surface with successive discharges; Evolution from localized to homogeneous energy deposition, achieving comprehensive surface coverage after sufficient discharge cycles. The TCC methodology demonstrates three critical advantages: precise spatial targeting of insulation weaknesses, controlled energy deposition at identified defect sites, and progressive homogenization of surface processing. These mechanisms collectively enable complete conditioning coverage.

title: Enhanced Vacuum Gap Insulation Between NonArc Metal Components in Vacuum Interrupters by Ion Implantation
authors: Yongjia Luo, Yuwen Zeng, Xin Liao, Saikang Shen, Zhiqiang Tian, Shenli Jia
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: High-voltage vacuum interrupters widely adopt a multi-stage floating shield structure, wherein the non-arcing metal gaps are subject to the risk of unintended breakdown, threatening the reliability of the switchgear. To enhance the withstand voltage performance of such gaps, this paper investigates the feasibility of ion implantation as a surface modification technique for the shields. In this study, 304 stainless steel was used as the substrate, into which Mo and Ta ions were respectively implanted. DC breakdown experiments were subsequently conducted across vacuum gaps of $0.5 \mathrm{~mm}, 3$ mm, and 5 mm. The results indicate that ion implantation can effectively increase the initial breakdown voltage of the gaps. Surface analysis reveals the underlying mechanisms: ion implantation modifies the crystal phase composition of the electrode surface, improves the uniformity of surface hardness, and elevates the surface work function. This paper confirms the potential of ion implantation for enhancing vacuum insulation performance and points out the challenges for its application in vacuum interrupters.

title: Simulations of micro-scale dynamics of discharges in conditioning experiments at the High Voltage Padova Test Facility
authors: Federico Caruggi, Agostino Celora, Antonio De Lorenzi, Giovanni Grosso, Federico Guiotto, Luca Lotto, Tommaso Patton, Nicola Pilan, Oscar Putignano, Marco Tardocchi, Gabriele Croci, Andrea Muraro
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: As part of the development project for the Neutral Beam Injector for the ITER tokamak, and to support operations of the Megavolt ITER Injector and Concept Advancement (MITICA), the High Voltage Padova Test Facility (HVPTF) is operational in Padova, Italy. The experiments at HVPTF focus on investigating and understanding the phenomena associated with in-vacuum discharge events occurring between high-voltage electrodes, with the goal of mitigating or preventing breakdown occurrences. The facility features a cylindrical vacuum chamber equipped with moveable supports for two electrodes. Two independent power supplies provide voltage differentials up to 800 kV DC, with current and voltage signals being monitored during experiments, as well as the pressure within the chamber and the composition of gases exiting it. Additionally, multiple lines of sight enable the installation of various diagnostics around the chamber, allowing for comprehensive observation of the dynamics of emissions during discharge events across visible, IR, UV, and X-ray spectra. Past works have presented analyses of the X-ray radiation coming out of the chamber, mainly caused by the Bremsstrahlung effect of the electrons travelling in the volume. Different aspects of the experiments were considered, and tentative explanations were brought forward. Some recent advancements in the development of the diagnostic and control systems of the experiment have given the chance to obtain more accurate and reproducible results. At the same time, the realization of a simulation environment, based on the combined use of multiple software has been proposed, for the modeling of the various processes involved in micro-discharges. This paper presents the basis for the development of the simulation model, focusing on the interchange of charged particles and photons between the electrodes. The coefficients required for the balance equation of the model are presented and calculated, with a display of the results.

title: Three-dimensional model of cathode spot crater formation in vacuum arc with the variation of effective radius
authors: Cong Wang, Lijun Wang, Xinyi Liu, Runming Zhang
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In order to understand the formation and development process of the tungsten cathode spot, a three-dimensional cathode spot model is established. The Joule heating effect, surface tension, and the dynamic changes of the effective radius for the cathode-plasma interaction are considered in the model. And the minimum current density threshold required to maintain stable operation is introduced to judge whether the spot is extinguished. The simulation results show that under the premise of constant current, when the effective radius for the cathode-plasma interaction exceeds its initial value, the continuous increase of the effective radius will cause the current density peak to gradually decrease. The reduction in the current density peak directly leads to a reduction in pressure acting on the cathode surface. It slows down the expansion rate of the cathode spot in the later stage of development. When the current density peak drops below the minimum current density threshold, the temperature at the center of the cathode spot may not reach the melting point. And the simulation results are consistent with the experimental results, which verifies the effectiveness and accuracy of the model.

title: Numerical Simulation on Temperature Rise Characteristics of 40.5kV Switchgear Based on the Coupling Technology between Electromagnetic and Temperature Fields
authors: Guangxing Liu, Weidong Xu, Cong Yuan
publish: 2025 31st International Symposium on Discharges and Electrical Insulation in Vacuum (ISDEIV)
abstract: In this paper, the 40.5 kV medium-voltage switchgear is selected as the research object, by using an electromagnetic and temperature field coupling model, temperature rise simulations are conducted to study the temperature rise characteristics of the switchgear when contact faults occur between the plum blossom contact and the static contact, and between the dynamic and static contacts in the arc vacuum interrupters. The research results show that the temperature rise meets the national standard requirements, verifying the rationality of not requiring built-in fans. The simulation results also show that the temperature rise in vacuum interrupters is the highest, and the temperature rise in the cable room and bus-bar room is the lowest. The paper also studied the influence of the diameter of the connection structure between the circuit breaker handcart and the cabinet on temperature rise under natural convection conditions. The research results show that increasing the outer diameter of the conductive rod does not change the distribution pattern of temperature rise, and can effectively reduce temperature rise.
